The moral priorities are determined from the first episode onwards: the Sharpe-character is personified by Uhtred of Babbanberg (Alexander Dreymon) who must negotiate several obstacles before he can assume his rightful place in the formation of a new kingdom. Good guys and bad guys are easily distinguished, chiefly by their hirsuteness; the bad guys have bushier beards and longer hair than their rivals.Each episode has its fair share of incident, romance, and a touch of pathos; the visual style owes a lot to Ridley Scott's KINGDOM OF HEAVEN (2005), with its lengthy pans of lonely isolated, almost primeval landscapes contrasted with dimly-lit interiors illuminated by candlelight. Considerable emphasis has been placed on the elements - sunrises, sunsets, storms, wind and rain - making us aware of how difficult life can be for those trying to establish social and political order. Hence their acts of heroism become all the more noteworthy.THE LAST KINGDOM might be hokum, but it is nonetheless highly entertaining: we care for the characters and their futures, even if we are well aware of what will happen in the end. As with most adventure novels, there is little doubt that it will have a morally definite ending.

First published in 1952, and here translated into racily colloquial British English by Cengiz Lugal, CEMİLE tells a straightforward tale of its eponymous heroine, a teenager working in a factory spending most of her evenings looking after her family; her aging father Musa and brother Sadri.  She falls in love with thirty-lira-a-month clerk Necati, but the two of them cannot get married due to Necati's poverty.  Hence she is viewed a potential marriage prospect by the much older Pockmark Halil, an oleaginous man with plenty of money who would be prepared to carry her off and wed her by force if necessary.This love-story is set against the background of an emerging industrial society whose factory workers are badly paid and resent the introduction into their midst of an Italian manager, whom they believe is out to swindle them out of their hard-earned money.  Life at the factory is dominated by corruption, with illiterate co-owner Kadir scheming against his more educated partner Numan, and the intermediate managers below them all out for their own ends.Life in Musa's house and its environs is equally complicated, with families living pell-mell on top of one another in a world where everyone knows one another's business and privacy is a quality seldom enjoyed.  Community life has its benefits - especially when someone falls ill - but it has its disadvantages as well, especially for those such as Cemile who are perceived as being less powerful than their elders.Orhan Kemal's novel offers a vivid portrait of a society in flux during the mid-twentieth century at a time when the Republic of Turkey underwent profound socio-economic change.  Rapid industrial growth led to mass migration from the country to the city, with people living in gecekondus (slums) and working for pittances.  The elders dreamt of the past, or of an idealistic future when they could take their earnings and return to an idyllic life in the country.  Yet that prospect was never a serious one; once people had shifted to the city, they mostly stayed there for life.In this newly-emergent world of capitalism, everyone is out for themselves.  Even in a community-based society where family values retain significant importance (insofar as girls are expected to look after their male elders), individuals such as Pockmark Halil believe that anything and everything exists for their pleasure and can be picked up and put down at will.  The fact that he the kind of person prone to spend most of his leisure hours drinking and eating döner kebap, renders him all the more morally worthless.The plot comes to a head when Numan lays off many of his factory workers, rendering them permanently unemployed, once he discovers Kadir's schemes.  Instead he threatens to employ new workers brought from İstanbul and İzmir at much higher wages, even though this will cause further societal chaos in an already uncertain society.  Yet Kemal portrays this development as an inevitable product of capitalism, where money-making is life's be-all and end-all.  Cemile and Necati achieve their desired aim of marriage, but we have no idea whether their relationship will last or not.CEMİLE is written in stark, uncompromising prose, accompanied by a genuine sympathy for the characters who deserve it.

Neil LaBute's work has always been raw in tone, frequently offensive, yet never lacking in punch.SOME VELVET MORNING proves no exception to this rule. Set in a split-level apartment in a big city, is concerns an apparently unstable relationship between middle-aged lawyer Fred (Stanley Tucci), and his twentysomething former mistress Velvet (Alice Eve). Fred claims to have left his wife and returned to Velvet after a four-year absence, while Velvet apparently resents his unexpected appearance in her apartment.Most of the film's eighty-two minute running-time is devoted to a roller-coaster depiction of the characters' relationship as it veers from protestations of love, false demonstrations of passion, and the more obvious depicting of male power based on strength. In the final reel there is an unexpected denouement that calls into question the entire basis on which the plot has been constructed. Some might consider it artificial; others a too-obvious elaboration of the film's basic theme.In terms of style, SOME VELVET MORNING has much of the rawness of David Mamet's OLEANNA (1994), another two-hander based on the clash between a man and woman of varying ages, combined with the destructive potential of Mike Nichols's WHO'S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF (1966), wherein the main characters tear emotional lumps out of each other in pursuit of emotional as well as physical mastery.As director, LaBute refuses to let his characters out of sight of his penetrating camera. We feel uncomfortably close to them, especially Fred as he tries to ingratiate himself once again into Velvet's emotions. Yet there is a sense in which the film glorifies as well as condemns male power; Tucci portrays Fred as the initiator of most of the conversations he conducts with Velvet. Until he achieves his desired aim, he will never give up.In truth the plot begins to pall as it unfolds, as we wonder why Fred is so insistent on achieving his desired aim. Is it part of his own feeling of insecurity; that he is an emotional wreck with a pathological inability to articulate his emotions? As Velvet, Eve tends to be too much of a foil to him; in Beckettian fashion she tells us she is going out but never actually takes any positive action.It might be said that SOME VELVET MORNING gives an uncompromising portrait of modern relationships. In truth it actually reveals the bile at the heart of the writer/ director's consciousness, which manifests itself in a consciously sexist piece of work.

Comedies such as 'ALLO 'ALLO have a lot to answer for. While watching some of the scenes where Violette Szabo (Virginia McKenna) is interrogated by the Nazis, I couldn't help recalling parallel scenes where Herr Flick (Richard Gibson) did exactly the same thing, aided (or is it abetted) by the leggy Helga (Kim Hartman) in the Lloyd/Croft British sitcom. This offers a good example of how time can modify our perceptions of a text.On its own terms, however, Lewis Gilbert's film is a quietly understated biopic of a naive girl with a French mother (Denise Grey) who marries a Frenchman (Alain Saury) in a whirlwind romance. He loses his life at El Alamein, and Violette responds by becoming an agent parachuted into occupied France. Together with her partner Tony Fraser (Paul Scofield in one of his rare screen appearances) they accomplish one mission successfully, but things go horribly wrong when Violette embarks on her second, more dangerous assignment.The film has some good action sequences, shot in and around Pinewood Studios, but Gilbert's principal focus centers on the characters' interrelationships - between Violette and her father (Jack Warner), who knows what she is doing, but agrees voluntarily to keep it a secret. Violette's relationship with Tony could bloom into love, but both know that they could lose their lives at any moment, so they agree to keep it platonic. McKenna portrays the central character as an ordinary woman with an extraordinary inner strength giving her the courage to undertake the missions while remaining determined to resist any attempts to force vital information out of her.Her transition from ordinary homemaker to toughened agent is lucidly handled, as she is at first intimidated by and then learns to cope with her uncompromising NCO instructor (Bill Owen). It is a tribute to her strength that she learns to cope with various ordeals, of being ducked in the river, of walking home on a filthy wet night, and handling a shotgun. The training proves invaluable for her later on, when she has to take on a platoon of pursuing Nazis virtually single-handed.Despite her hopes, Violette Szabo never made it back from the War, leaving her daughter Tanya (Pauline Challoner) to collect a George Medal from King George VI. As Tanya returns to her quiet suburban home with her grandmother and grandfather, we can but reflect that it was chiefly due to Violette's selfless efforts that Britain and the Allies managed to emerge triumphant from six years of conflict.

What to make of this book?  It is important to separate the subject from the biographer in any evaluation.  Michael D'Antonio creates a portrait of a monster - someone so narcissistic that he is pathologically incapable of self-analysis.  Even when Trump does refer to his past in interviews, it is only through a series of carefully rehearsed anecdotes that tell us more about what he is not saying rather than what he actually says.Donald Trump grew up in prosperity; his father was a successful property developer with a gift fot publicity.  He never achieved the publicity heights set by his son, but the father knew how to attract attention.  He was also a strict parent, firmly preventing his children from swearing or indulging themselves in unseemly behavior.  Donald was something of a wild child; hence he was packed off to military school where he evidently learned self-discipline.  After a two-year term at a midranked institution, he finished off his education at the University of Pennsylvania.  From then on the younger Trump never looked back; his skill as a negotiator and his obsessive concern with self-presentation led to considerable success.In assessing Trump's career, it is often difficult to separate truth from myth.  He has always been an obsessive self-promoter, someone regularly prone to exaggeration and misrepresentation so as to present himself in the best possible light.  Mistakes are seldom acknowledged; everything is geared to creating an even better future.  D'Antonio recognizes Trump's abilities as a negotiator, or a wheeler-dealer; but emphasizes the number of enemies he has made in the process.Sometimes it seems that Trump has been so self-obsessed that he rides rough-shod over any objections.  This was especially true in a recent incident where he wanted to build a golf-course and hotel complex in Aberdeen in the north of Scotland.  Although many of the locals objected strongly to the plan, Trump simply brushed aside their objections, mobilizing every force at his disposal - including the Scottish government and the First Minister - so that his plans could be implemented.  Eventually he could only accomplish part of what he wanted, but he made many enemies in the process.As a politician, Trump has often sacrificed sense to sound.  He has seldom been taken seriously, and has often sought to provoke just for the sake of it.  Earlier in 2015 he announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination; whether he accomplishes his goal or not, one wonders just why people continue to take him seriously.D'Antonio's biography is a glaring indictment of someone totally ignorant of the notion of community as an indicator of business success.  Trump never listens to anyone except himself, and appears to break every promise he makes if it is expedient to do so.  He might have fulfilled the so-called "American Dream" of success, but by doing so he has alienated most of his business colleagues.  On the other hand, as the book coherently argues, Trump remains a prime example of the ways in which style assumes more importance than substance, especially in terms of media presentation.  He rehearses at a grand level what many of us indulge in as we write our thoughts on Facebook, Twitter and other social media.

MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED invokes many of the beliefs that really work towards transforming education - creativity, collaboration, ability-based tasks, connection as well as negotiation.  The authors back their arguments up with a wealth of evidence about what is wrong with the US education system and how it might be reformed.  The overall thrust, which is a good one, is for individual educators, boards and groups to initiate change from the ground upwards, rather than expecting any centralized reform.  The more educators embrace change and resist the standardized, test-based formula that dominates education today, the more encouragement will be stimulated for the future.And yet the book is marred by certain assumptions which seem to undermine the very fabric of a good education.  One of the authors is an entrepreneur who has 'made it big' through individual initiative, and desires to put something back into the communities that nurtured him.  A laudable intention indeed; but that does not mean that education as a whole should be geared towards business and/or commercial success.  Learners should be encouraged to develop in whatever way they choose; it might not be fruitful for some people to pursue business related projects, but rather to concentrate on a liberal education, or on the arts, appealing to the imagination rather than the practical side of our brains.  Educators should be encouraged to help learners develop in any way they please, without having any real goals or 'successes' in mind: sometimes people turn out to be late developers in whatever they believe is their particular field of interest.Part of the book's problem, it seems to me, is the authors' assumption that American education has to be 'competitive' with other systems worldwide - Singapore and Finland are regularly quoted.  The implicit assumption behind this is that America has to reassert its position as a superpower in the educational as well as the political fields.  But education is not like that: it is precisely that desire for competition that has led to the introduction of standardized tests, and provoked Presidents to introduce unworkable schemes for everyone.  Education is messy; it should be individualized and allowed to progress in whatever way it should, giving full freedom of thought and preparation to learners and educators alike.  "Competitiveness" is a false goal, and one with no real lasting guarantee of success.Perhaps the problem is that the book has an inherent belief in American superiority behind it.  According to the authors, the so-called "efficient" systems in Korea and Singapore are based on testing, a form of examination that is not suitable for American learners, as it limits creativity.  It follows therefore that Koreans must lack creativity, especially as the authors claim that parents spend all their waking hours forcing their children to work at test practices.  There are also some comments that might be considered racist, such as the likening of a malfunctioning Harlem school to Baghdad.Sometimes it would be useful for writers to think outside the box and look at the individual in a global rather than a country-specific context.  In that way education can be used to create citizens who can contribute anywhere, anytime and in any way they wish to the improvement of their lives.

With a format shamelessly borrowed from Bill Bryson's ONE SUMMER: 1927 (2013), Robert Winder tells the story of the remarkable sporting summer of 1934, a golden period in English sport when Fred Perry, Henry Cotton, Hedley Verity and Dorothy Round all achieved prominence in their respective sports.  Their achievements offered hope for the huge audiences attending sporting events, at a time when Britain was trying to emerge from the ravages wrought by the Great Depression, as well as coping with the impending threat of war with Nazi Germany.The book interweaves biography and history in a deft combination.  Fred Perry was the son of a socialist Member of Parliament, who achieved prominence in table-tennis, and then switched to the outdoor version.  An obsessive from his youth, he never fitted into the tennis Establishment which - as now - upheld conservative values that inhibited rather than encouraged development.  Perry traveled extensively round the United States, but resisted all offers to turn professional.  After numerous failed efforts to win Wimbledon in the early Thirties, he triumphed in 1934, the first of three straight titles before he finally succumbed to the lure of playing for money.  Winder portrays Perry as someone preoccupied with his own self-image, so much so that Perry deliberately rewrote his life in his autobiography, including certain incidents that turned out to be totally fictitious.  Although ostracized by the Establishment after turning professional, and subsequently taking US citizenship, he was accepted back into the fold in later life.Henry Cotton was an equally obsessive personality, preoccupied with the acquisition of money and the need to show off.  In a sport dominated by Americans in the early Thirties, he showed an almost maniacal desire for perfection: practice meant everything to him.  Eventually he triumphed by winning the British Open in 1934 at Sandwich in Kent, southeast England, on a course full of traps for the unsuspecting player.  Cotton never had to worry about the amateur/ professional divide, and pursued a lengthy career until his retirement in the early Fifties.Verity and Round were more acceptable figures - especially to mid-Thirties administrators - as they tended to remain within the existing organizational fold.  Verity was a great spin bowler in cricket, but remained a gentleman both on and off the field.  He achieved some remarkable bowling figures, and had the distinction of being one of the few bowlers that could flummox the great Australian batsman Don Bradman, as shown in the Lord's Test of 1934 when he dismissed "The Master" cheaply in both innings.  Round tended to spend most of her career in Britain, combining playing with coaching, but her sheer dedication to tennis helped her win the Wimbledon Ladies' Title in the same year as Perry; the first and only time that two British players have won the singles titles in the same year.  Verity was to die at the age of only thirty-eight while fighting in Italy in 1943, while Round retired from tennis after her marriage later in the Thirties and spend her subsequent career as a coach.Winder tells a fascinating story, marred only by a tendency to believe that these great figures of the mid-Thirties would not be able to compete with today's legends - especially in tennis.  This is a fallacious judgment, based on the false belief that improvements in equipment and training methods automatically make 'better' players.  Perry and Round were the greatest exponents of tennis at that time, and there is no reason to suppose that they would not be equally successful today.  The book also contains some irritating proof-reading errors - at one point we are told that Cotton won a tournament in 1939 before he won the British Open in 1934.Winder has been handicapped by a reliance mostly on secondary sources (it would have been nice to see him make use of the oral histories and herstories of the period available in many British libraries), but HALF-TIME is nonetheless an entertaining read, a throwback to a more innocent age of sport, perhaps, but one that was still bedeviled by political matters.

Don't go looking for originality in Paul Andrew Williams's film.  The plot recycles a familiar thematic chestnut: a curmudgeonly pensioner Arthur (Terence Stamp) resents his wife Marion's (Vanessa Redgrave's) participation in a pensioners' choir, especially as she is dying from cancer.  When she passes away, Arthur shuts himself away from everyone, but with the encouragement of choir-master Elizabeth (Gemma Arterton), he rediscovers his ability to sing.  The choir make it through to the finals of a competition, but they are about to be excluded on the grounds of being a laughing-stock compared to the other, more sophisticated entrants.  Arthur makes a last-minute entrance, strides on to the stage, sings a song accompanied by the choir, and they end up finishing third.More recent variations on this story have included ONE CHANCE, the story of BRITAIN'S GOT TALENT winner Paul Potts with James Corden (2014).  In Williams's film the two protagonists don't have to do much other than provide contrasting characterizations: the perpetually scowling Stamp set against the more optimistically inclined Marion.  There is one memorable sequence where she refuses to talk to him unless he accedes to her wishes.What makes the film touching is the way in which Williams handles his subject-matter.  He does not shy away from the idea that cancer is a killer; however much we like to pretend otherwise, Marion's death is imminent.  Having one's partner cruelly taken away after years of happy marriage is traumatic, as it proves for Arthur - especially as he cannot seem to get on with his son James (Christopher Eccleston).  A group of OAPs in a choir singing Motorhead might seem incongruous, but the experience gives them a renewed belief in life.The film makes some telling visual contrasts between the prison-like suburban life Arthur follows, and the beauties of the sky above.  As he watches the sun rise and set, he understands how there are far more important things in life than sitting in the house.  Marion looks down upon him from the heavens; and it's his duty to honor her.It's a cliché to say that films like this are life-enhancing, but A SONG FOR MARION proves the truth of this statement.

FAMILY LIFE concerns the life of an Indian family moving to the United States of America in the late Seventies and trying to cope with a society that really didn't know how to deal with people from the sub-continent.  Hence the novel is about something far more profound than just a "clash of cultures" as other reviewers would have us believe; it is about a country that really only thinks along certain pre-ordained tramlines and finds itself unable (or unwilling) to think out of the box.  This applies as much to America as it does to India.The story is a straightforward one: Ajay Mishra comes with his family to the United States to follow his father, who has settled down into a reasonable clerical job.  However things take a turn for the worse when Ajay's elder brother Birju is reduced to a catatonic vegetable as a result of a diving accident.  Thereafter the family have to spend most of their time looking after him, while trying to cope with their inward guilt as if they they believe they were somehow responsible for the catastrophe.  The father turns into a hopeless alcoholic; the mother stays at home endlessly washing and ironing; while Ajay moves through school while realizing gradually that there are far more important elements to life than simply finishing top of the class.At one level FAMILY LIFE contrasts the relatively unsophisticated life in India - where the children play cricket in the street and collect milk from the seller - with the far more urbanized (might one say regimented) life in the United States.  Author Sharma refrains from moral judgments; on the contrary he is at pains to show how growing up in India leads to a certain intransigence when moving to another country, an intransigence that parallels anything that the white American can reveal while trying to cope with Indian immigrants.  One would like to say that the novel follows an optimistic progress, as the two races come to understand one another; but that simply doesn't happen.In the end Ajay passes his exams with flying colors, goes off to college and ends up a as a hotshot lawyer.  However, when he finds a girlfriend for the first time, and begins to experience life himself, free from his family's coat-tails, he finds that it's not quite as easy as he had anticipated.  The novel ends in suspended animation, as we reflect that Ajay will rehearse many of the conflicts experienced by his father when he first came to the United States.  Nothing, it seems, has changed in the direction of cross-cultural understanding.Entertainingly written, with an acute sense of what it's like to be an immigrant, irrespective of one's ethnicity, FAMILY LIFE is the kind of novel that can be easily read in one sitting.

Published nearly thirty years ago now, TWENTY STORIES BY TURKISH WOMEN WRITERS is still important today as it shows how women of different classes and ages still lead difficult lives in a country that since the creation of the Republic in 1923 has always advocated equality of opportunity and treatment under the law.  Most of the stories show that this objective, although laudable in itself, seldom prevails in a predominantly patriarchal world.The writers represented include major figures in Turkish literature such as Leyla Erbil, Füruzan, İnci Aral, Adalet Ağaoğlu, Pınar Kür, Erendiz Atasü and Latife Tekin.  All of them have been translated by Nilüfer Mizanoğlu Reddy into clear, fluent prose that nonetheless communicates the strem-of-consciousness style of many of the writers.The tone of the anthology is set in Sevim Burak's "The Window," the story of someone who may or may not be about to commit suicide.  The narrator's imagination runs away with the thought of it, to such an extent that she observes that the woman must "HAVE NO HOPE WHATSOEVER."  Yet the story has a surprise ending, especially for the narrator - perhaps s/he is simply projecting her own feelings on to the person observed.  Fürüzan's "In the Park by the Pier" depicts a world of down-at-heel gentility where one of the characters observes that her suit is "getting frayed here and there," unlike the (imaginary) past when "silk noiré was the rage."  That past might not ever have existed, but it is something to look back on nostalgically.Pınar Kür's "The Commuter" vividly captures the hellish ritual of traveling from İstanbul's suburbs to the center, a journey which took as long in the late Eighties as now.  The narrator observes that their life feels "made up of different fragments" that cannot be told apart.  Perhaps this is inevitable: the strain of commuting blunts the judgment, leaving the narrator to face the exigencies of "the sweaty, dusky heat of a summer evening that makes all the bright colors fade."  No one, it seems, can enjoy the pleasures of the imagination in a world dedicated to money-making.Işıl Özgentürk's "The Dagger" focuses more directly on a female protagonist who resorts to prostitution in order to support her family.  This might be considered a dishonorable profession, but often necessary to ensure survival.  Yet what does this suggest about contemporary Turkey, where women have to resort to such a decision?  Ayşe Kilimci's "The Snail Girl" considers the issue from a slightly different perspective, as she writes about characters having to make a living by preparing snails in a factory for the delectation of İstanbul's bourgeoisie.  The workers have been deprived of the power of self-determination and have to make do with what they have - in other words, being subject to the authority of an eccentric (male) manager who determines when and if they will finish at the end of every day.Latife Tekin's "How Dirmit Started Writing" poems, an extract from her semi-autobiographical novel DEAR SHAMELESS DEATH, describes how a young woman tries to write poetry as a way of making sense of the world around her.  This is not easy: words and phrases do not always come to mine despite strenuous imaginative effort.  When they do, however, they provide a means of liberation from the humdrum world around her.  Yet still she remains a vulnerable figure, especially when members of her own family deride her efforts to write.The collection rounds off with Nazlı Eray's semi-comic tale of "The Underdeveloped Pharmacy," which parodies the way in which the Republic of Turkey is often represented as "an underdeveloped country," by comparison with first world nations such as the United States.  If that is so, then it follows that the standard of medical service should be equally underdeveloped, leading to more and more suffering.  Maybe that's not always the case: Eray suggests that perhaps we as readers should be a little more accommodating in our views of women in Turkey and treat them on their own terms, not as stereotypical representatives of a certain "type" of nation.As with any anthology, there are bound to be some stories that appeal more to readers than others.  Cumulatively speaking, however, the collection offers a penetrating insight into the harsh economic realities of living in a capitalist society, whether in the Republic of Turkey or elsewhere.

Jailed for twenty-five years for arms dealing in 2011, Viktor Bout became a media celebrity as the so-called "Merchant of Death," dealing in arms across the globe and thereby contributing to the continuation of bloody civil wars in the Congo, Angola and Rwanda, amongst others. When finally arrested as a result of a deliberately staged "hit" operation, Bout was agreeing to a deal that could have resulted in American civilians being slaughtered.Tony Gerber and Maxim Pozdorovkin's documentary profiles Bout, an entrepreneur of quite extraordinary aptitude, who built up his business empire in the wake of the liberalization policies introduced by Boris Yeltsin in Russia during the 1990s. Bout's primary interest, it seems, was in cargo; bringing in hitherto unobtainable commodities into Russia while transporting other goods from place to place. He set up his sphere of operations in Sharjah, where be built up a huge empire. It did not matter what was transported; Bout built his reputation on flying goods expeditiously using his own fleet of airplanes.As the Nineties progressed, so Bout expanded his operations into some of the trouble-spots of Africa. He had a small airport in the Congo in the midst of civil war operations; and enjoyed good relationships with military leaders all over the continent. The documentary works hard to portray him as a business person interested solely in making money, but it seems that he was largely indifferent to the morality of arms-dealing.What makes THE NOTORIOUS MR. BOUT most interesting is the amount of home movie footage Bout shot during his business career. Everything, it seemed, was worth filming, from rebuilding his aircraft to the most ordinary domestic scenes such as the birth of his daughter. We get the sense that his real desire was for some form of celebrity; to be remembered for what he did, regardless of why he did it.In the end Bout achieved his aim as he was deported from Thailand to New York to face a high-profile trial. Through interviews with Bout's wife Alla, as well as some of his closest business associates, the documentary works hard to suggest that Bout was more sinned against than sinning; there are legions of arms-dealers from all countries who are still at large and making huge profits out of other people's suffering. Nonetheless we feel that the prison sentence he received was somehow justified, if only as a means to show what would happen to any arms-dealer, whether great or small, should they be brought to justice.Slickly filmed with the use of voice artists speaking some of Bout's words, THE NOTORIOUS MR. BOUT is an entertaining piece.

Based on a novel by Nahid Sırrı Örik, KISKANMAK (ENVY) is a powerful depiction of the ways in which people's lives are hemmed in by class, gender and emotional preoccupations.I cannot comment on the adaptation's relationship to the source- text, but as it stands Zeki Demirkubuz's film, although set in the early Thirties, offers a powerful comment on inequalities within contemporary Turkey.The action opens at a celebration in the Black Sea town of Zonguldak. Couples dance idly round the floor until the band-leader calls them to order and invites everyone to sing the National Anthem in praise of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk. The action takes place only seven years after the Republic was established in 1923; and we are reminded once more of the principles upon which it was founded - equality, fairness, and opportunity.Unfortunately what follows completely subverts that impression. Mine-owner's wife Mükerrem (Berrak Tüzünata) leads an aimless existence dominated by tea-parties and social occasions. Sharing her house with her husband Halit (Serhat Tutumluer), and her sister- in-law Seniha (Nergis Öztürk), she orders her servants to wait upon her hand and foot. Eventually Mükerrem falls in love with Nüshet (Bora Cengiz), the youthful son of a local society family; together they spend clandestine evenings together, while Halit apparently remains oblivious.Mükerrem's actions enrage Seniha, who hitherto has enjoyed a close relationship with Halit's wife. Seniha ends up taking a decision that ultimately leads to the destruction of all three protagonists.Shot in washed-out colors, with the lighting focused deliberately on the characters' faces, Demirkubuz's film creates a self-enclosed world in which outward show matters: preserving one's honor counts above everything else. Within this world women are kept as virtual prisoners: the film is full of repeated shots of them either looking out of the window from inside, or photographed inside their houses from the outside. The sense of imprisonment is enhanced by repeated close-ups of lattices, grilles and covered lights.The idea of female confinement is nothing new; it is characteristic of any patriarchal society in which men like Halit come home from work expecting their dinner, and prepare for business trips by having their suitcases packed for them. As portrayed by Tutumluer, Halit is a very passive person, despite his apparent power: everyone, it seems, is prepared to do all his work for him.What gives Demirkubuz's film added bite is the way he shows the characters experiencing emotional as well as physical imprisonment. Neither Mükerrem nor Seniha can see beyond their limited field of self-interest; and hence destroy themselves as well as those closest to them. In a highly socially stratified society, they have been brought up to observe certain mores; and when these mores have been traduced, they have no means of coping. Their reactions are almost childlike, but entirely coherent in a society whose inhabitants are almost entirely prevented from thinking for themselves.KISKANMAK is a domestic tale but carries substantial political undertones. In any world that curtails self-determination, few people can survive for very long. The film ends with Seniha photographed alone on a cruise-ship, biting into a sandwich and admitting her faults in voice-over. While understanding that she has acquired self-knowledge, we hardly feel sympathetic towards her, in light of what has previously taken place.The mood of melancholy is cleverly underlined by the use of a musical leitmotif from Albinioni. KISKANMAK is a mournful yet memorable piece of work.

Translated by Richard McKane and originally published by Seyrek Yayinlari in Istanbul, TEK SEKERLI CINARALTI (TEA WITH ONE SUGAR UNDER THE PLANE TREE) is a sequence of poems, some of which have been translated, others not.  They reflect on the poet's status as as important recorder of life, as well as writing the kind of material that comments on social and political inequalities prevalent at the time of publication and which still exist today."Byzantine Coffin Nails" comments on the plight of the poor trying to survive in pouring rain in an indifferent world; but perhaps that world can be redeemed by love - the love between humans irrespective of race, class, and gender.  "The Satin Flower of Passion" develops the theme by inviting readers to listen to their inner natures rather than behave according to predetermined conventions.  This is the kind of recommendation that good poets can make; through their ability to create metaphors appealing to the imagination rather than reason, they can affect readers at an intuitive level.  Their work can not only become responsive to nature but can make sense of catastrophe.  Above all poets are fearless: writing very much in the tradition of Nazim Hikmet, Huseyin Avni Dede sees the poet as a political figure commenting directly on society's ills."Under the Ladder" develops the themes of the poet's relationship to nature and the worlds they inhabit.  Normally walking under a ladder might be considered superstitious - the kind of thing anyone might avoid if their luck was out.  Dede argues that such traditions are nothing more than old wives' tales.  One should trust in the world and "smell a carnation without reason," or enjoy "the budding smiles on my lips."Carnations are a favorite with Dede.  In "Lament of the Unguillotined Carnations," he talks about how the industrial city not only breaks people but destroys its fauna and flora, creating a world in which money counts for everything.  People become so obsessed with survival that they become impervious to the beauties of nature.  In "Rhapsody on a Dead Square" he explores the consequences of this dystopian world.  Poets lose their significance; their raison d'etre, you might say.  If such is the case, then they might as well be incarcerated underground for life.  The only way to ensure their survival is to be mindful of the world around us.Richard McKane's blank verse translations represent Dede's verse as akin to stream of consciousness, or a spontaneous outflow of powerful feelings in which sound matters as much as sense.  Definitely worth reading.

Halide Edip Adivar was a pivotal figure in the foundation of the Turkish Republic as an activist, educator, and supporter of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.  Born into a privileged family and married young to a much older man, she led a sheltered existence until circumstances forced her into the public gaze.  Thereafter she contributed significantly to the spread of education over the former Ottoman Empire, as well as giving speeches in support of a democratic way of life that would supplant the tyranny of the previous regimes.  She ended her career as a teacher in the University of Istanbul as well as a translator of major works of English Literature into Turkish.HOUSE WITH WISTERIA is the first of two autobiographical volumes chronicling Adivar's extraordinary life.  Written in 1925, only two years after the creation of the Republic, it vividly recreates the author's origins.  She spent most of her early life working out of a small room - at the time (the late nineteenth century) it was assumed that women should be seen and not heard.  She became a writer, but no one would really listen to her.  Her marriage proved dissatisfying - as was customary then, her husband believed in polygamy.  It was only when she secured a divorce and began to pursue her public career that she managed to achieve her ambitions - even though she ran considerable risks by doing so.The book is told as two separate sections.  In the first, chronicling her early life, she writes in the third person, almost as if the infant Halide Edib were a different person from the writer.  This strategy makes it clear that the book is about different selves, which might be described as the public and private.  In public Adivar had to put on the guise of being a reformer; but this was often achieved at great personal cost, especially to her children, whom she had to leave behind as she pursued a peripatetic existence.  Often the two selves conflict with one another - so much so that they are often irreconcilable.  Adivar has to make the best of what she can.In her struggles she often counts on the support of the deity.  The book contains several instances where she recognizes the power of God not only as the Creator, but the only real person who can be trusted.  Sometimes the only way to cope with life's exigencies is to think beyond the minutiae of daily life and consider the importance of completeness - the idea that human beings are at one with the universe, if they listen to their inner selves.HOUSE WITH WISTERIA contains some fascinating vignettes of what life was like in the last days of the Ottoman Empire, especially for women.  Adivar's mother died young, and she was mostly brought up by her grandmother in what might be described as a traditional mode of life.  She was expected to get married, have children, and remain in the home; whenever she appeared in public, she should wear sober clothes and look down at the ground, thereby acknowledging her subordinate status.  It is to Adivar's credit that she challenged such stereotypes by insisting that women should be entitled to a good education and to live their lives according to their own rules,. even if that meant challenging the patriarchal order.The book is often a disturbing read, as Adivar tries to survive in a society which believes in violence first and asking questions later.  Attempts to introduce a more democratic way life are often brutally crushed by the Ottoman despots.  Poverty is rife, and no one in government really wants to alleviate it.  Hence the importance of Adivar's contribution to the Republic; she believed that everyone should be entitled to equal opportunities, regardless of their social origins.Sibel Erol's introduction to this reissued edition gives a good account of Adivar's technique and her place in Turkish history.  HOUSE WITH WISTERIA is definitely worth a read for anyone interested in notions of liberation and free thinking.

The title of Miranda July's novel THE FIRST BAD MAN is a fascinatingly ambiguous one.  Most obviously it refers to one of the bad men represented in one of the old-fashioned self-defense videos that the protagonist Cheryl Glickman disinters from a warehouse at her place of work.  In these videos women are shown how to cope with all forms of male sexual assault, with the "bad men" portrayed by actors.  The "bad man" could also be Phillip, a sixtysomething colleague whom Cheryl believes is in love with her.  It is a humiliating moment for her when she discovers that he is pursuing a sixteen-year-old instead.  The "bad man" could also be baby Jack, whose first moments on earth prove harrowing for everyone involved.  Arguably Cheryl's housemate Clee, a twentysomething woman with odorous feet, could also be classed as a "bad man" in light of her physique and penchant for martial arts.July's deliberately ambiguous title adumbrates the main thrust of this novel, as Cheryl searches for some form of identity.  Living mostly on her own, exchanging dialogue with her inner self, she cannot really assert herself either personally or professionally.  Exploited at work by her uncaring bosses, who treat her as a convenience; uncertain about her sexuality; and unable (or unwilling) to resist Clee's dominant nature - even within Cheryl's own house - Cheryl is buffeted through a series of emotional peaks and troughs.  She retreats into a fantasy-world dominated by explicit sex involving Phillip and Clee; some of the descriptions are graphic, to say the least.  Yet they prove of little help to her in resolving her mental conflicts, in which actual living has been substituted by vicariousness.Cheryl only achieved satisfaction once she has the chance to look after Clee's baby Jack.  Ostensibly we are led to believe that this is a lesbian relationship; but July refuses to allow us the satisfaction of a definite decision.  Cheryl assumes ultimate responsibility for looking after Jack, and conducts a series of conversations with him - all within her own imagination.  What such conversations do suggest, however, is that sexual orientation is no longer of any real importance to her; the fact that she has a living being to nurture, without anyone to tell her what to do, assumes far more significance.The novel ends with a short epilogue set in China in which Cheryl has found what she has been looking for after a considerable struggle.  No longer influenced by "bad men," she can look forward to at least partial emotional satisfaction.Miranda July is especially good at depicting the inner life of the central character, and how it manifests itself in curious ways - not just through sexual fantasy, but through some decidedly idiosyncratic domestic arrangements.  The fragility of her world is emphasized when Clee moves in and proceeds to impose an alternative lifestyle on Cheryl.  THE FIRST BAD MAN emphasizes the randomness of the contemporary world, in which the best-laid plans for organizing one's life often go sadly awry, yet sometimes circumstances conspire to work in an individual's favor.  This is what happens to Cheryl, and she takes full advantage of her good fortune.Sharply observed, with a distinct sympathy for all of the characters trying to make their way in an indifferent world, THE FIRST BAD MAN is an absorbing read, even if it can prove uncomfortable on occasions.

LIVING THE SECULAR LIFE provides an eloquent defense of what author Zuckerman describes as "the secular life" - in other words, life lived without belief either in religion or the presence of the deity.  Through a series of chapters, liberally laced with quotations from various sources, allied to first-hand interviews, he argues that the secularist, as opposed to those who embrace religion, have the benefit of choice whether to pursue their way of thinking, without being influenced by received beliefs.  There is no "supreme being" that dictates their actions; hence the secularists can learn how to acquire their own beliefs in morality and righteous living.  Blessed with the power of choice and self-determination, the secularist acquires what Zuckerman describes as "aweism" - the capacity to perceive life's mysteries unfettered by other people's beliefs.Zuckerman's arguments reinforce the prevailing belief expressed by many Americans in the power of individual self-determination, as well as freedom of choice.  The book is actually rather paradoxical; while opposing the religious beliefs embraced by Republican Presidents such as George W. Bush, Zuckerman actively favors freedom from control by higher powers, whether Gods or governments, a belief that is characteristic of many Republicans.  Maybe this is not actually what the author intended, but it seems to be that his arguments become somewhat confused at this point.This sense of confusion underpins the entire book.  One wonders why the binary opposition of secularism vs. religion has to be set up in the first place - as Zuckerman himself observes, many people might not be actively religious, but they do acknowledge the presence of a God.  Their behavior might be self-determined, but they can also believe in an after-life.  Every person's religious belief differs; and in some communities, this right to embrace one's own construction should be respected.  I understand Zuckerman's frustrations, as he recounts the experiences of some secularists living in overly religious communities within the United States; but perhaps there has to be more give-and-take, a willingness on the part of everyone, religious and secular alike, to listen to one another and acknowledge different points of view.Zuckerman's arguments are also somewhat limiting, in the sense that he does not acknowledge that the concept of religiosity might differ from culture to culture, from religion to religion.  What constitutes the "religious" life in a Christian community might be very different from its equivalent within an Islamic community.  Nor does he admit the fact that the issue of religion vs. secularism can be viewed very differently in some Islamic cultures.  He assumes, quite wrongly, that his day-to-day experiences within the United States can serve as a microcosm for those inhabiting other parts of the world.  Perhaps the book could be more accurately re-titled LIVING THE SECULAR LIFE IN SOME PARTS OF THE UNITED STATES.The only way that people of different persuasions can understand one another is to set aside binary oppositions and acknowledge the presence of pluralism.  To do this, we need to set aside the rather hectoring tone that lies at the heart of this book and learn how to listen rather than pronounce.  While LIVING THE SECULAR LIFE makes some good points about the importance of adaptation, both personal as well as communal, its basically strident tone becomes tiresome.

It would be easy to dismiss 41: A PORTRAIT OF MY FATHER as just another attempt by a former US President to cash in on his reputation.  In George Bush's case, that reputation is twice as strong, given that his father occupied the highest office of state before him.  And in truth there are several instances where readers become painfully aware that Bush is not a natural writer; he tends towards the obvious in many of his conclusions, while his language can sometimes be clunkily banal ("a nice soup" is one of the phrases that lingers in the mind).In truth, however, such shortcomings are redeemed by the heart-felt nature of this volume, an affectionate tribute by a son to his father's life and reputation.  Born to a prosperous family in the mid-Twenties, George H. W. Bush had a privileged education which was abruptly interrupted when he decided to join the US Air Force.  After some rigorous training, he was sent out into the Pacific to fight the Japanese.  The younger Bush is particularly good at recreating the live-or-die atmosphere of the time, when aircrew never knew whether they would survive or not.  The older Bush had to bail out of an aircraft on one occasion, and was rescued by a submarine after drifting alone in a dinghy.  Such harrowing experiences proved character-forming, as Bush learned the importance of maintaining strength of character even in the toughest situations.When he was demobbed in 1945, Bush entered the oil industry and became a successful entrepreneur specializing in offshore operations.  He built up an impressive fortune while remaining loyal to his family.  His son remembers how Bush used to create "quality time," even after the busiest working days, which helped develop strong filial bonds.  The older Bush also inculcated a strong moral sense into all his six children based on respect for God and loyalty to the family.  As a father Bush seldom told his children what to do, but rather encouraged them to pursue whatever careers they wished.As a politician, Bush's career up to his presidential election in 1988 was slow but sure.  He served as Ambassador to the United Nations and head of the CIA under President Ford; and as Vice-President under Ronald Reagan.  He built up a reputation for loyalty and an ability to see another person's point of view; some critics considered this quality a sign of weakness, but it helped Bush establish a network of friends worldwide that stood him in good stead throughout his political career.His presidential career was dominated by one major incident - the Gulf War.  The younger Bush is quick to defend his father as someone who gave Saddam Hussein every opportunity for peaceful resolutions, but eventually lost patience with the Iraqi leader and declared war.  The President, it seemed, was only interested in restoring Kuwait's status as an independent monarchy, not in driving Saddam out.  In retrospect perhaps this policy was a mistake, but it seemed justifiable at the time.  It is one of the ironies of history that what started out as a short, sharp strike has degenerated into an apparently insoluble conflict; but blame for that does not necessarily lie with the elder Bush.Despite his obvious successes, the older Bush was unceremoniously ejected from power in 1992.  His son believes that a series of reversals - most of which had little or nothing to do with the President - had a lot to do with this defeat, as well as the machinations of independent-minded politicians such as Ross Perot.  This might be true, but the elder Bush was part of an aging generation whose world-view did not necessarily mesh in with the prevailing zeitgeist, shaped as it was by the boomers who grew up in the postwar era.In retirement the elder Bush has continued to pursue various activities.  Even at the age of over ninety, and in a wheelchair, he continues to fulfill as much as he can.  He completed a parachute jump on his ninetieth birthday, just to prove that there was life in the old man yet.Readers might disagree with some of the younger Bush's judgments about his father's place in history; but we cannot help but admire the strength, loyalty and person-skills of a man who throughout his long life has placed his family first above everything.  At the end of the book we come to know more about the 'real' George H. W. Bush behind the mediatic portrayals of his life and career.

ORDINARY LIGHT begins as an autobiography of Tracy Smith, the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet.  Born in 1972 to a father in the military services, and a mother who spends her life as a homemaker, apart from a brief period when she works as a teacher, the young Tracy grew up in a loving family placing considerable emphasis on basic virtues such as love, loyalty and a respect for God.  Her life, at least until she entered Harvard University, was sheltered; Tracy did not have a boyfriend, and spent much of her time trying to make sense of her own identity as an African American and a practicing Christian.  Although well advised by her mother, and following her elder brother Conrad"s example (Conrad has left home and training to work in the medical profession), Tracy experiences a series of identity crises, especially concerning her relationship to the outside world and the (re-)construction of her identity.  She encounters the regular prejudices against African Americans at school, as well as the criticisms of those who believe that practicing Christians spend too much time talking about God and not enough on day-to-day realities.  While such comments do not wound her too deeply, they still prompt her to reflect on herself as someone growing up in California who feels rather alienated when she visits her grandmother in the family home in Alabama.When Tracy enters Harvard, she experiences further crises of identity.  She falls in love with a white boy, and believes that she has truly discovered herself until she finds out that he has fallen for someone else.  She picks up familiar university identities as someone fighting for "blackness" and discovering pluralities through exposure to critical theory and cultural studies material.  She changes her style and finds herself - perhaps for the first time - alienated from her mother.  Normally such rebelliousness might be dismissed as "part of growing up," but for Tracy it causes further anxieties.Her quest for that something - whatever it might be - is only brought to fruition when her mother is dying from colon cancer.  The passages where she describes the way in which her mother first conceals the extent to the disease, and subsequently comes to admit it and make peace with her God, are exceptionally moving.  Much of Smith"s prose consists of interior reflection; for the first time, she discovers the power of poetry to suggest emotions and promote empathy not through tangible meaning, but through suggestive combinations of words.In the end Smith"s book proves that the "ordinary light" of her life is actually something extra-ordinary.  She discovers the power of the mind to range beyond the day-to-day realities of the tangible and conjure up new worlds.  Although her mother passes away at the early age of fifty-nine, Smith realizes that she can continue communicating with her - not by following Christian doctrine to the letter, but by allowing her mind to wander across the continuum connecting life and death.  Smith becomes a mindful person; someone who, while living a happy life with her husband and three children, can allow her imagination to run its course, to discover hidden meanings and new connections for herself.  Words for her are not just means of communication, but a way of exploring her psyche.  Sounds become as significant as sense.As readers, we are drawn into this extraordinary piece of writing, where subordinate clause follows subordinate clause in a form analogous to stream of consciousness.  I am not calling Smith a specifically 'modernist' writer; rather she is using words to explore her imagination, and her imagination to explore the power of words.  ORDINARY LIGHT is an extraordinary book, one that explores issues of race and religion and ends up transcending them.  God exists for ourselves, in any form we choose.

Therese Anne Fowler's Z is a fictionalized recreation of the life of Zelda Fitzgerald from her origins in Montgomery, Alabama to the death of her husband in 1940.The novel is told mostly in the first person, from the point of view of an idealistic if naive woman who leaves her traditional family in the South to marry Scott Fitzgerald, and embarks on a dizzying life of parties, social gatherings, chance encounters and drunken revelries in all parts of the world.  The narrator comes across as a sensation-seeking personality, someone who wants to experience life viscerally as an alternative to the roles expected of her as a daughter, wife and mother.  A talented person in her own right, she spends her life trying to express herself while being married to a spouse who, despite his talent, remains at heart a child, unable to move beyond patriarchal notions of gender.Scott Fitzgerald comes off quite badly in this novel - a hugely talented person with major personality flaws.  He drinks to excess; spends a lot of time associating with people such as Ernest Hemingway (whom Zelda does not rate at all); chases women and socializes; in other words, doing anything to avoid the onerous business of writing.  After the failure of THE GREAT GATSBY (1925), it seems as if he lost the will to write; the next novel he published, TENDER IS THE NIGHT (1934), was almost entirely based on Zelda's experiences in various psychiatric wards.  Unable to resolve the psychological demons within himself, he transfers his resentments on to Zelda by accusing her of various faults including disloyalty and irresponsibility.Yet despite the marriage gradually souring, Zelda stays with her husband.  She still loves him in a strange way; perhaps because of his child-like irresponsibility.  There are perhaps two occasions when she contemplates a divorce, but neither of them are really serious.  Perhaps she is looking for something else - not independence, perhaps, but rather to be recognized on her own terms as an artist, not simply Scott Fitzgerald's spouse.The characterization is convincing; the style less so.  We don't get much sense of Zelda's gradually degenerating psychological state, as she suffers from bipolar disorder.  The forces ranged against her are portrayed as indifferent and uncaring: the doctors aren't there to cure her, but rather to keep her away from her husband.  Yet we don't get any sense of her frustrations, or the strategies she might adopt to cope with her ordeal.  We understand how she loses her self-esteem, but we don't see precisely how her conception of the division between "madness" and "sanity" is gradually eroded.  On the contrary Fowler's language veers toward the banal, as if reluctant to engage at a deeper level with Zelda's complexities.The book ends rather abruptly with a fast forward in time until Scott Fitzgerald's death.  We don't hear much about her time in hospital, which is a shame, in view of the fact that this focus might have rendered the book more interesting.  Instead Fowler chooses to rehearse familiar stereotypes about the Jazz Age and the Smart Set running wild in France during the Twenties.  The writing is colorful, but covers over-used ground.Z is a reasonable read, but is a little short on insight.

Published by Boğazii University Press in 2007 from a manuscript given to the university by Alice Berkeley, FLOYD HENSON BLACK: A REMEMBRANCE celebrates the achievements of one of those unsung heroes who helped to lay the foundations of the Turkish educational system.Born in Illinois to a farming family, Black began his career teaching at Robert College.  At that time - the early twentieth century - the college was a cosmopolitan community of Ottomans and other European races, where several languages were spoken.  Black learned one of the educational principles that stayed with him throughout his life; that humanity was the same, irrespective of culture, race or ethnicity.  Although he became mutlilingual himself, he was more concerned with learning both from his learners as well as his colleagues.Black subsequently moved on to the American College in Sofia, where he met his future wife, the daughter of a Bulgarian farming community.  Together with a small group of expatriates he helped to establish a happy educational community committed to equality; even though the curriculum and the ambience was American in orientation (the learners sang American songs on a regular basis), the education was transcultural.  However Black's employment was abruptly curtailed during the Second World War when Bulgaria signed a memorandum of understanding with the Nazis and declared war on the United States.  Black was rather hurt by this, in light of his previous experiences with the Bulgarian people.He completed his career in İstanbul, first as an officer in the American Consulate, and latterly as the President of Robert College - both the boys' and the girls' sections.  By now the curriculum had become more Turkified, but Black reached an understanding with the Ministry of Education (Milli Eğitim Bakanlığı), so that the institution could continue as a quasi-independent concern.  He retired back to the United States, where he continued to receive guests from the Republic of Turkey as well as the United States.  He died aged 95 in 1983.Cyril Black's biography is a little short on interpretation and long on facts.  Nonetheless it provides a valuable record of an educational pioneer in the Near Eastern region.

Gerard Woodward's novel opens with a military court-martial in which Kenneth Brill, artist and camouflage expert, has been accused of various misdemeanors, none of which he believes are actually his fault.  This situation provides the springboard for a Chinese box-like narrative veering back and forth in time, in which nothing is quite what it seems.  Told largely in the first person from Brill's perspective, VANISHING looks back at his childhood days, his turbulent life in various schools, his abortive time as a student at the Slade School of Art in London, and his subsequent itinerant life as an artist until he joined up in the army.The most important aspect of the novel is to understand the implications suggested by its title.  Woodward recreates a now-vanished world in and around the hamlet of Heathrow where Brill grew up.  Before there was an airport there, it was mostly farm-land, fertilized by heaps of dung.  Families lived there for generations - sometimes feuding with one another, but learning in the end how to co-exist peacefully.  Yet this apparently timeless world is abruptly curtailed by a government edict during the Second World War in which all the land was commandeered to make way for an airport.  This draconian decision makes us aware of the mutability of all things: nothing lasts for ever.The same also applies to Brill's artistic productions.  Artists' canvasses record things - impressions, environments, people - for all time, as their work is exhibited in art galleries for future generations to enjoy.  In Brill's case, however, many of his canvasses are either concealed, destroyed, or misunderstood.  No one, it seems, can recognize his talents - least of all Brill himself.  His work, as well as his abilities, simply vanish into thin air.Gerard Woodward vividly recreates a world riddled with hypocrisies, where morality was apparently strict (in its denunciation of homosexuality as something evil) yet people tolerated most nefarious activities, so long as they were kept out of the public eye.  Men like Brill not only remain uncertain about their sexuality, but can never distinguish between their friends and their enemies.  Those whom they trust the most turn out to be working against the national interest.  Living in such a random universe, we wonder whether or not that Brill himself is a victim of a vanished morality; a society that claims to adhere to Victorian values yet understands not a shred of what such values truly are.Reading the novel is a disconcerting experience, as our expectations as to what will happen next are continually frustrated.  It is up to us to piece its various temporal strands together and understand what they tell us about Brill's past, present, and future.  We are in sense victims of another vanished convention; that of the reliable narrator.  VANISHING demands close attention but proves rewarding all the same.

Released in 2009, İKİ DİL BİR BAVUL is a low-key documentary that nonetheless makes some important points about the shortcomings of the Turkish education system.  Ever since Mustafa Kemal Atatürk's time, public school policy has been dictated by the Ministry of Education (Milli Eğitim Bakanlığı), which had consciously reinforced the one-nation ideology by insisting that all classes should be delivered in Turkish.  This might work in the majority of schools, but falls flat in the mainly Kurdish-speaking east of the country.Orhan Eskiköy and Özgür Doğan's film explains why.  An idealistic young educator Emre comes from Denizli in the west of Turkey to the village of Demirci in the east.  This is a predominantly rural community whose inhabitants eke out an existence in an inhospitable landscape by tending sheep or growing wheat.  They live a very self-contained life under primitive conditions; most of the mud-brick houses lack running water, and the women mostly use local produce to create their meals.  Few of them can either read or write; hitherto they have had very little need to.Entering this community and trying to teach the learners represents a difficult, if not impossible task.  The children seldom actually come to school; and when Emre encourages them to do so, he finds it almost impossible to communicate with them.  They know very little Turkish, having only heard a few words on television; in turn, Emre speaks no Kurdish.  Hence they are all imprisoned by their respective languages.  The children might repeat the familiar phrase "Ne Mutlum Türküm Diyene" (Happy is he who is a Turk), but they have no understanding of what it means.  On the celebrations for Children's Day (23 April), a holiday instituted by Atatürk both to reward children and remind them of the importance of Republican values, the children play games and mouth the phrases they are supposed to do, but the significance of the occasion eludes them.  Try as he might, Emre finds that progress in class is slow, often impossible.Having said that, he is not without his faults.  There is little indication of his being prepared to meet the children halfway and learn some Kurdish during his time at the school; and some of his pedagogical methods leave a lot to be desired.  Merely shouting at the children and/or intimidating them by making them repeat phrases over and over again is hardly conductive to creating a good learning environment.  On the other hand he is a new teacher with little grasp of effective classroom technique, so perhaps we can exonerate him.The documentary takes place over a year, from September to June.  The directors make much of the changing landscapes from the hot sun of late summer to autumn colors, a harsh winter with snow whipping across the barren landscape, and the onset of spring with a duck leading her ducklings across the farm.  They emphasize the unchanging nature of life in Demirci, whose citizens pursue a life that remains immune from any of the major urban and social developments taking place in the west of the country.  In this kind of situation, it's hardly likely that anyone would respect the Ministry's desire for a Turkish-only school.Since the film was made, the government apparently made some moves towards a more multicultural education policy by permitting some lessons to be given in Kurdish.  In light of current events, however, where renewed conflicts have broken out in the east of the country between the security forces and the local people, we might wonder whether such initiatives have any real chance of taking root, or whether the east will remain the cultural and educational backwater as represented in this film.

This is a very strange book.  Comprising a collection of essays from academics predominantly from the United Kingdom and Australia, it uses the zombie metaphor to describe what is wrong with higher education in a post-capitalist era where learners are transformed into consumers, research is always measured, staff are transformed into administrators as well as educators whose performance has to be continually measured, and the humanities are perpetually under threat from shrinking government funds and the need to find alternative sources of funding through devising research initiatives.Needless to say, much of the zombie material comes from familiar films such as WHITE ZOMBIE (1932), the Jacques Tourneur cycle of films for RKO from the Forties, and the George A, Romero cycle beginning with NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD (1968).  While appreciating the sentiment behind much of the essayists' points - that learners are being reduced into zombies through tests and academic work that depends purely on memorization rather than imaginative empathy; class-sizes have become so large that it's difficult for academic staff to tutor them successfully; while academic workloads have become so large that it's difficult to organize successful research programs - they are made with such wearying repetitiveness that eventually the reader becomes rather tired of them.  We look for solutions rather than complaints: if this is what academic cultures represent at present, how will academics and learners negotiate them?Many of the answers are couched in familiar binarist terms; it is the responsibility of academics and learners to "challenge" the existing socio-poitical order; to "undermine" the capitalist hegmony; and "liberate" the academy from the dead hand of materialism.  Such arguments were popular nearly three decades ago with the advent of cultural materialism, but they hold little sway now in a post-Marxist world.  Alternatively some contributors fall back on the old chestnut of "crtitical thinking," which apparently has a political as well as an intellectual orientation, enabling learners to perceive what's wrong with capitalist-driven education and look for suitable alternatives instead.To be honest, there is only one essay that really departs from this wearying - and clichéd - critical orthodoxy.  Jessie Stommel's "Toward a Zombie Pedagogy: Embodied Teaching and the Student 2.0" at least recognizes the fact that in today's connected universe, it's necessary to devise new approaches to learning based on collaborate ventures, i.e. involving learners in the process of co-creation so as to negotiate tasks and reflect on their outcomes.  Even so, I'm not sure that "teaching" per se is actually a satisfactory term to use: in any learning situation, all of us should consider ourselves part of a shared task.  So, if universities are becoming peopled with zombies, as many of the contributors suggest, it's the responsibility of everyone within that community - learners and educators alike - to devise innovative approaches to learning that can help transform everyone into active learners.  In other words, rather than blaming others for the state of the contemporary academy, it's time to find new ways of learning that not only meet the standards expected of researchers and administrators, but give learners a sense of why they are doing things, and how such strategies might help them in their futures.Make no mistake - the academy is a political structure, which can influence as well as promote innovation among its staff as well as learners.  But that politics should originate from the ground up, from a willingness to wrestle with zombification (if such a state exists) and find ways of reconstructing it for everyone's benefit.  That means avoiding complaints and adopting innovative strategies that treat everyone equally.  If readers are looking for ideas as to how such strategies might be devised, ZOMBIES IN THE ACADEMY is not for you.

Based on a stage musical, THAT DAY WE SANG is a piece that celebrates the city of Manchester through a parallel structure contrasting the life of young Tubby (Harvey Chaisty) growing up in 1929 with that of the older Tubby (Michael Ball), living a humdrum life four decades later. In 1929 Manchester is full of terraced houses, cozy back- streets and cramped living-rooms; when Jimmy goes for an audition to join the city choir, he does so in an oak- paneled, poorly lit school-room. Forty years later the cityscape might have changed somewhat, with functional maisonettes replacing the old terraces; but the major landmarks remain such as Piccadilly Square, a testament to the city's Victorian confidence.In terms of plot, THAT DAY WE SANG focuses on the humdrum lives of Tubby and Enid (Imelda Staunton), both of whom have reached middle age without actively doing anything. They both work in anonymous offices, bound by routines and finding visceral pleasures where appropriate (Enid has a squalid little affair with her boss Mr. Kirkby (Daniel Rigby). The two protagonists meet, and together reminisce about the time when they were members of the choir and sang "Nymphs and Shepherds" for a gramophone recording. The memories help to stimulate their imaginations, and they look forward to a brighter future together.The musical has plenty of what might be termed Victoria Wood touches - the lyrics often involve complicated rhymes; whenever we can hear them, we understand just what a talented artiste she is. The dialogue contains plenty of references to domestic products (hand- creams, bathroom cleaners, etc.) reminding us of just how comic brand names can be. There are also intertextual references to some of Wood's earlier hits, such as the appearance of dinner (or should it be tea) ladies wheeling their trolleys around the office building.The songs are mostly upbeat, giving plenty of opportunity for Ball and Staunton to show off their vocal prowess. In truth, however, the most memorable number is a specialty piece set in a Berni Inn - a long-forgotten chain of steakhouses, all red plush and prawn cocktails. Enid and Tubby are taken to dinner there by their social climbing neighbors Frank (Confeth Hill) and Dorothy (Sophie Thompson), who take the opportunity to show off their social advantages, accompanied by a bevy of dancing servers. The number is extremely funny with an unexpected dénouement.THAT DAY WE SANG may be slight, but its sheer joyousness and the zest of the performances render it a piece of memorable entertainment.

This is the first in the rebooted series of HABABAM SINIFI movies, based on the books by Rıfat Ilgaz.  It is basically plotless, providing the excuse for a series of comic sketches involving the gulling of a succession of educators including Bülent Kayabaş, a gender-bending love-interest plot involving Arzu (Nehir Erdoğan) and her beloved Kete (Mete Ekener), and the return to the school of one of the original HABABAM SINIFI learners in the guise of an educator (Halit Akçatepe).Basically there's not much more to say about the film, apart from the fact that the cast includes luminaries such as Hülya Koçyiğit (as an harassed educator), Zeki Alasya (as a janitor), and Mehmet Alı Erbil giving a characteristically overstated performance as Behri the headteacher.  The messages are clear - despite the continual trickery, the school upholds the core values of nationalism, family and tradition.  The best moments occur when Necmi (Akçatepe) returns to the school, and the soundtrack plays extracts from the original HABABAM SINIFI movies of the Seventies.  The camera then cuts to a shot of the original cast, including Kemal Sunal, and a large photo of Rıfat Ilgaz, the author of the source novel.  Traditions certainly matter as a means of promoting unity.

This is a curious book.  It is excellently written, with a fine understanding of the philosophical problems arising from transformative decision-making - in other words, those decisions we come to that will eventually change our lives.  Through a series of case-studies, partly friviolous, partly serious, Paul makes us aware of how difficult such decisions are, both philosophically as well as emotionally.  The case-studies include deciding to become a vampire (or embracing the vampiric spirit), deciding to have a child, and (for deaf people especially) deciding to have an implant so as to restore the power of hearing (or to make profoundly deaf people hear for the first time).Paul writes in the second person, addressing all arguments to an imaginary reader.  This gives the book a personal, intimate tone that perhaps works against the complexity of the ideas advanced.  Sometimes the ideas are a little difficult to follow, especially for readers unacquainted with decision theory.  Maybe the book can really only be appreciated by philosophers, rather than those seeking to understand what kind of decisions or ideas help to inspire transformative thinking.What really undermines the book is the emphasis on rational thinking.  Personal experience has revealed that many transformative decisions represent a leap in the dark: we decide to change our lives without really knowing what the consequences might be.  Such decisions can be bold in the extreme, but they help us develop strategies of coming to terms with new experiences and developing new ways of thinking that are not always based on previous knowledge, as Paul claims.  Sometimes that previous knowledge proves unhelpful, especially when we compare the new experience with our previous experiences.  These normally turn out to be value-laden comparisons that perpetually change over time.Sometimes the human mind is "unreasonable," prompting us to make decisions which we cannot explain, either to ourselves or to others.  We either answer "I don't know," or "it just seemed right at the time."  Such responses undercut the basic thrust of Paul's argument that we can find a rational justification for transformative thinking.  We tend to let our emotions rule our brains, especially when these kind of decisions need to be made: sometimes we regret them, but on other occasions we are grateful that we set aside our reason and jumped off the emotional cliff instead.

One of the modern reboots of a classic series, based on the novel by R'fat Ilgaz, that first appeared in the late Seventies.
