The material will seem extremely familiar to non-Turkish viewers, with strong echoes of chaotic classroom comedies such as the ST. TRINIANS saga, and British black-and-white National Service satires such as ORDERS ARE ORDERS (1954) and most notably CARRY ON SERGEANT (1958).The comedy opens with Bedri the Lunatic (Mehmet Ali Erbil) being outwitted once again by his anarchic group of mature learners. He has acid placed on his head teacher's chair that burns through his pants and leaves his bottom bare. He walks out of school to a chorus of laughter. In revenge he decides to send the whole class on National Service, even though technically they should have left school before they are eligible for this.There follows a series of gags based on the familiar theme of the incompetent squaddies bossed about by their sergeant (Erbil again). The chief comic conceit is that the learners think the sergeant is actually Bedri the Lunatic in disguise, and cannot take him seriously. They only learn to do so when Bedri unexpectedly turns up at the barracks, claiming that he has missed his class too much.The comedy is quite old-fashioned, with several gags based around the squaddies ogling their female counterparts in a fashion reminiscent of Benny Hill. There is also a battle-of-the-sexes theme, as the sergeant resents the presence of female squaddies in the barracks under the command of Major Zehra (Hülya Av'ar). His antediluvian prejudices are soon put to shame, however, as the girls outwit the boys in a night exercise.HABABAM SINIFI: ASKERDE is nonetheless interesting, if only for its underlying nationalist preoccupations. We see several shots of the Turkish flag in the background, as well as the portrait of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk. Right at the end a soldier is seen in medium close- up giving the kind of cheer-leading speech that would encourage soldiers to fight in their country's cause, and thereby fulfill Atatürk's vision of a great nation.The film ends with a surprise twist, but this does not undermine its underlying emphasis on the importance of everyone forming a community so as to ensure their future irrespective of gender differences.

TO RISE AGAIN AT A DECENT HOUR is set in contemporary New York.  Narrated by a dentist Paul O'Rourke, it dramatizes his impressions of a world with which he is fundamentally at odds.  Addicted to his smartphone (which he describes as "a me-machine"), watching the Boston Red Sox on television and videoing every game, and looking out over the balcony of his apartment at the Brooklyn townscape, he finds it almost impossible to relate to those around him.  He retells his previous love-affairs in exhaustive detail, notably with Connie Plotz, who now works as his practice manager.  But nothing actually emerges from these recollections; it seems as if he is unable, or unwilling, to reflect on the consequences of his actions.Paul's life becomes irrecoverably disrupted, however, when he discovers that someone has apparently stolen his personality and compiled a practice website, a Facebook account and a Twitter feed in his name.  He starts by writing a series of abusive letters to the practice website provider, but at length becomes involved in a complex plot involving his past, a mysterious and elusive figure now based in Israel, and a religious group calling themselves the Ulms.The novel begins as a light-hearted satire of contemporary life in New York, whose people are so addicted to virtual communication that they find themselves almost pathologically incapable of relating to one another.  Things have got so bad that Paul's hygienist has turned to God for salvation and berates Paul for his inability to understand the power of religion.  Paul attributes much of his myopia to a disturbed family life when he watched his father watching Red Sox games, but had to come to terms with his father's suicide at an impressionable age.As the narrative unfolds, however, the tone turns distinctly somber.  We learn how Paul has embraced both Catholicism and Judaism in a futile attempt to ingratiate himself with his girlfriends' families.  In essence, this is no bad thing - anyone should be happy to cultivate inter-faith awareness.  What Paul does, however, is to ape the rituals of each religion without actually believing in God: an atheist playing at being religious.  At the end of the novel he hears the story of someone else who did this, and turn to the Ulm religion instead.  Yet we get the sense that Paul is at heart an empty vessel; someone who tries to belong to a variety of groups - social, religious, or whatever - but lacking the conviction to do so.As a first person narrative, TO RISE AGAIN AT A DECENT HOUR is relentlessly narcissistic, but eventually the reader tires of it.  Maybe Paul cannot cultivate self-awareness, but at least he might have learned something about the people closest to him, especially his employees.  But no -- when Connie chooses to leave the practice, he almost adopts the chlidlike pose of saying: "What did I say?"  "What did I do?"  The answer is a straightforward one - nothing.Joshua Ferris writes well, with penetrating insight into the mind of his fundamentally unlikeable central character.  But I do wish that the structure could have been less relentlessly concentrated on internal reactions; it would have been good to have worked the other way from the outside in rather than inside out.

From the novel by Muzaffer İzgü, ÖĞRETMEN (Teacher) is a sentimental tale of a dedicated pedagogue (Kemal Sunal) who travels from a village school to İstanbul to take up a new post with fifth-graders.  The move is not an easy one - although accompanied by his family, he suffers from grinding poverty.  He has a lengthy commute from the suburbs to his school, involving one dolmuş journey plus three bus journeys; on several occasions he turns up late, including his first day.  When he returns home, he is usually so tired that he cannot look after his family.  Inevitably he suffers; he wears out his shoes and hurts his leg.The only way he can survive is to take up street-selling.  This is a risky occupation, as he has to watch out for the police, who will invariably arrest him for illegal hawking.  He ducks and dives; for the most part he is successful, but there are occasions when he suffers as a result.  On one occasion while selling simit (Turkish bread sticks), he falls down a hole in the ground and injures his leg.  Inevitably he finds it difficult to reconcile the two sides to his life - the street-seller and the teacher - which affects his future life.The story of ÖĞRETMEN may seem familiar, but Kartal Tibet's film offers a fascinating series of snapshots about the Turkish educational system; its insistence on order and discipline, with learners having to repeat what they have learned in class, while conforming to a rigid set of rules that limit creativity.  Sunal's Hüsnü (the teacher) challenges those rules and earns the learners' respect as a result.  When they learn of his grinding poverty, they arrange for a surprise to be given to him on Öğretmenler Günü (Teacher's Day).  Hüsnü is touched as a result.Inevitably Hüsnü comes into conflict with the bureaucracy at his school - one of the flash-points involves a stray dog.  For the most part he can deal with such conflicts, but in the end the need to conform to a rigid set of rules affects him.Normally associated with comedy films, Kemal Sunal gives an affecting performance as Hüsnü, alternately serious yet charming in front of the learners.  He never seems to lose his temper with them, which is something to be admired.The world of İstanbul might have significantly changed since this film appeared in 1988, but the educational atmosphere has hardly altered.  Life in today's high schools is as difficult for today's educators as it was for Hüsnü.  All we can do is to admire him for his determination to adhere to his humanist ideals.

I love a good mystery, and this is an excellent mystery.  The book is intriguing from the beginning to the end, and as the story unfolds, it becomes even more mysterious.  The more I read, the less I knew, and by the end, I was left with more questions than an unsolved episode of Dateline.  Two teenagers at the same school suddenly hit with amnesia; it's a secret that they aren't sharing with anyone.  Charlie and Silas have no idea what happened to cause this, but they discover that although they are strangers today, they were very much connected yesterday.  As they try to figure out what happened to them, they also find out that the person that they are today is not the same person they were, and they are as much a stranger to themselves as the rest of the world.  As parts of their past are revealed, both good and bad, the race is on to uncover what has happened to them before the rest of the world unearths their secret.  Looking forward to the next installment.**************************************************************************************************Not a biggie, but I'm a reader who pays attention to details.  At the beginning of the book, "Miss" is spelled as "miss" twice, and I wasn't sure why.  Also, Charlie mentions that she doesn't have a smartphone, just a regular phone, but later in the book she mentions that she can tell that her texts are being read by read notifications.  I don't think that's possible unless it's on a smartphone.

***Spoiler Alert- I don't know how to discuss this without spoilers, but I tried.********************************************************************************************Ahhh, so I'm enjoying this story that focuses on two best friends who have been dancing around "what-if" they were to become more than just friends. There is a pact made that if they reach the age of 30 and still single, they will get married. So we follow Stephanie and Linden for the next five years falling in and out of relationships, wondering if anything will come from the pact. Suddenly towards the end of the story, Linden does something so spineless, so douchey, that I want to rip off what's remaining of his genitalia , and have him go sit in the corner with Bruce Jenner, so they can share lipstick and nail polish and talk about when they used to be men. I'm serious, I'm so pissed that this Scot-turned-wuss, that I can't forgive him, and I've forgiven a lot of antics in the book world. What's the matter Linden, are you still having mommy issues, didn't get hugged enough, wasn't breast-fed? Linden is a spineless coward, and if I could get this book in Word format, I would rewrite Linden's fate. I'd have Mateo from Love, in Spanish to pay him a visit and explain to Linden all that he gave up to be with Vera. Then Mateo laugh in his face and tell Linden that he purchased him a subscription to Harlequin Romance and Nicholas Sparks' books, because Linden's man card  has been shredded into a 1000 pieces.  I want to bring in Javier from The Artists Trilogy , and Javier seduce Steph on the bar, not giving a crap who watches or gets mad, because good sex is worth butt-hurt friends. I want to send Linden and James to Bad Book Boyfriend prison and have Nadine as their prison guard. Yeah, I might be slightly angry at Linden.The rest of the book is well-written, and the Halle does a wonderful job of writing eclectic characters, but Linden...screw him and Jack.

I began reading Beautiful Oblivion last week, and normally it should have taken me a couple of days to finish this book, but it took several days.  I would read so many pages, and then for the sake of my sanity, I would place it aside and do the things that I normally try to avoid doing.  Usually I procrastinate housework, but this time, I found myself procrastinating finishing the book, but on the bright side,  grease spatters under my stove are gone, the rim under the toilets cleaned, hell I cleaned out the vegetable storage drawer in the fridge and I think I tossed out fruit that I purchased in 2002.  I did everything that I could possible do to avoid reading more of Beautiful Oblivion, and why?  Because the story was going nowhere quick.  Why didn't I stop reading the book?  Because there was a secret that kept being flaunted, and I just HAD to find out what that secret was.  The way that the secret was touted, it had to be a good and juicy MISTAKE, alas, the only good and juicy mistake was me taking the time to finish this story.  The secret is discussed more below the spoiler line.The relationship between Trenton and Camille was lackluster, she is seeing him daily although she says that they are "just friends", and her long-distance boyfriend accepts this.  Then there is the relationship with Camille and her family.  Her brothers are constantly yelling and bullying her, particularly about not showing up for a weekly dinner with their bullying and abusive father.  Although they are in their 20s, they argue and fight as if they are twelve, and they hold themselves accountable to their parents.  Of course Camille is the martyr and the one responsible for all the family angst, and she is also the one responsible for fixing her brothers.  There wasn't one scene when they were together that I didn't want to scream because of their adolescent behavior.The bit with the names, what the he!!  is up with that?  This wasn't a case of the worst name in history; this was a case of all the characters in the two families given names that begin with the same letter.  It sounds stupid with the Kardashians and it sounds twice as stupid in this book.  There is Camille, and her brothers and cousin: Coby, Clark, Chase, and Colin; then there are the Maddox Brothers: Trenton, Travis, Tyler, Taylor, and Thomas.This story left such a bad taste, that I can't even move on to read a new book.******SPOILER***************SPOILER**********************POSSIBLE SPOILER BELOW*********************SPOILER***************SPOILER**********************POSSIBLE SPOILER BELOW*********************SPOILER***************SPOILER**********************POSSIBLE SPOILER BELOW***************The bottom line is that the author achieved major success with the Abby and Travis story, and she attempted the same formula to make the story of Camille and Trenton as successful, but it doesn't work, it reads like a watered down duplication.  It's also a repeat of males who sleep around are just being boys, but females who sleep around are whores.  There isn't a real plot to the story, I couldn't figure out why they weren't together as a couple, yet they work, eat, and sleep together.The secret was actually an insult to the intelligence of readers, were we suppose to buy that they live in a small town, they all belong to the same fraternity, and Trenton doesn't know.  And why didn't Camille tell the secret in the beginning when Trenton first introduces himself?  I see the phrase "When a Maddox Brother loves, he loves for life".......uh....no.....I don't think so in this book.

***Possible Spoiler Alert*** I try to only discuss the basics of the story without giving away any spoilers.Anders Ellis is not only a Hollywood’s box office star; Anders is also the epitome of a Hollywood playboy and one of the biggest a$$holes that you’ll ever meet. Seriously, look up “a**hole” in the Oxford dictionary, there’s a photo of Anders. Everything that Anders does, it’s for him and/or his career. His ego is as massive as the line of women who have bedded him or dying to bed him. So why does this story appeal to me, because I love watching a badboy getting his just deserts.Anders has slept with so many different women, and that’s easy to do considering his “no repeats” policy (yeah, total jerk), that there comes a time when he can no longer match a familiar face with the vagina he has banged. Now imagine being one of his sexcapades, and running into the guy that gave you the best sex that you’ve ever had, and he smiles and says “Have we met?” Yeah, not only do you deal with feeling promiscuous, but now you have to face that the night of your greatest orgasm was so vanilla to him that he doesn’t even remember. You would be mortified or humiliated, right? Not Josie, see Josie starts off being a honey badger, Josie doesn’t give a sh*t. Well maybe she does just a little in the beginning, but she gets over it rather quickly the more time that she’s around Mr. Badboy. Josie’s indifference is like waving a red flag to a bull, thus Anders’ interest and pursuit begins. I was expecting Anders to turn over a new leaf at this point, but this is where the story pulls me in, because Anders is still very much an conceited jerk. He tries to cover it up in front of Josie, but the reader gets a glimpse into his thoughts, and what Anders says and thinks are two different things. At times he is repulsed by the way he is attracted to Josie, especially when she isn’t in his presence, but then his plans not to give a sh*t about her are thwarted when he sees her on the movie set. There are times when they are together and the story shows how his douchiness is freaking out internally, I love how he struggles to conceal what a pr*ick he is, but it often comes back to bite him.To further complicate matters, Anders and Josie spin a web of deceit, but the lies they created in order to be together, are the very lies that are pulling them apart.This story appealed to me because it was like climbing inside the mind of an a$$hole and watching his wheels spin. I liked that the author kept Anders true to form, instead of an immediate change in character.**Disclaimer--I received an ARC of this story, but I wasn’t asked to give a review in return; in fact, it was only after I had finished that I discovered that the story was going to be released as a book. I’m not part of a blog tour nor acquainted with the author.

I have to be vague in discussing the story so that I don't reveal any spoilers, other than to say that the story follows a family trying to recover from a fatal car accident, and a sister trying to save her brother who is suffering from mental illness.  The book is good, but there were a couple of items that kept me from loving the story.  The first one being that this book lacks a connection, a connection between the characters, and a connection with the reader.  Even though the family is isolated and doesn't have much interaction with the outside world, I don't feel a relationship or bond between the family members.  Calla says her most important concern is to take care of her twin brother Finn, yet when they interact, I didn't sense that bond that she mentions so often throughout the book.  There isn't much communication between the rest of the family members; most of the book is based on Calla's thoughts.  Dare is the mysterious stranger who Calla encounters, and Calla is immediately drawn to him.  But even as they spend more time together, I didn't get a sense of any intimacy growing between the two.  Calla and Dare talk, but I felt that Dare was as much a stranger to Calla towards the end as he was in the beginning.  In fact, one of the problems that I had with this story is that I knew as little about the characters by the end of the book as I did when I began reading it.  I realize that this book is a mystery/thriller, therefore ambiguity and secrecy is part of the scheme, but I needed to have a connection or understanding of Calla.  I have to say that Calla saying that her ovaries might explode whenever she turned on by Dare is weird.  Instead of the story pulling me in and making me feel  as I'm experiencing the scenes unfold with the characters,  I'm left with a lackluster sensation that I'm reading this story as if it were a magazine or newspaper article.Possible Spoiler Alert*****  Please do not read past this point if you don't want to know anything about the ending.******Besides the distance or lack of closeness, another problem for me is the cliffhanger.  I am not opposed to a cliffhanger in a story, but usually a cliffhanger is in addition to the main storyline/plot or an epic moment in the book.  Nocte  reads on an even keel, it doesn't have moments of angst or drama, so I am expecting when I get to the end that the plot will be revealed, unfortunately , the plot is the cliffhanger.  I would have been satisfied with the plot being revealed, and then the story ending with a cliffhanger, but I'm left feeling that I wasted my time reading up to this moment, and discovering that I still don't know the purpose for the story.  I think there were a few scenes that could have been epic moments, but there was as much emphasis placed on those scenes as the ones where they are standing in line for coffee.

*Possible Spoiler Alert**Yawn*  Was there a purpose to this book?  Unless the purpose behind this book was an attempt at driving this series into the ground, then congratulations, it was a success.  This book is similar to ordering a box of candies from a company that you've trusted in the past, and they send you  a huge box, and you think that it's going to be filled with all sorts of goodness, but then you open the box, and it's filled with nothing but packing peanuts, and you keep searching thinking that you're going to find something, and finally after going through all the packaging, you find a caramel.  The packing peanuts in this book are the sex scenes, and try as you may to search through all of them, but you aren't going to find a caramel, maybe a piece of butterscotch candy.  Because I enjoy erotica, it pains me to say "Enough with the sex", please, we get it, we also get that they need each other to survive, Gideon is the yin to Eva's yang, he can't breathe without her, his body hurts not being inside her,  they feel each other's presence before they see each other, their skin aches when they part, WE GET THIS, IT WAS ESTABLISHED OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER IN ALL THREE PREVIOUS BOOKS.  Seriously, they have sex before work, while on the way to work, while at work, and then after work, at this point I would be happy just to see either one standing at the water cooler talking to a co-worker about the last episode of The Walking Dead, effing anything but the two of them effing.  It would be nice to read one of having an independent scene without the other waiting in the shadows.  It would be interesting to see Eva going to California without Gideon trailing, as it would to read about Eva going to lunch without Gideon waiting a table close-by, it would have been interesting to read any scene without them together, because as we all find out, they can't be together without engaging in sex.  That's is all there is to this book is the sex, and although I like sex scenes, it would be nice to have a little storyline to go along with it.  I skipped through dozens of pages because the sex is a yawn fest.This series began with beautiful, wealthy, interesting yet flawed and damaged people, but has turned into a series about beautiful co-dependents that I seriously doubt can take a p*ss without the other one holding his/her hand.  I now loathe Cary, instead of him being a supporter and friend to Eva, all he thinks about is how her every move is going to impact him.  This book is essentially the three of them discussing sex, making each other miserable, whining and complaining, but can't be away from each other for longer than an hour.  C'mon, how ridiculous is it that Gideon wants Cary to move in the penthouse that he and Eva are having remodeled so that Cary doesn't feel deserted.  Gideon has turned into a pansy, frantic schoolgirl, but instead of passing notes of "Do you like me, yes or no?", he sends texts.  Corrine having sex with Angus would be more interesting than to reading this,  watching paint dry on the walls would be more interesting than this story.As with book three (Entwined with You) in this series, nothing was resolved, nothing new occurred, it was basically a repeat of book three.  The name of this book should have been: Entwined with You Version 2.0, or Gideon Has Sex With Eva Again and Again and Again and Again and Again and Again and Again and Again.Save your money folks, nothing new going on here.  I included a "Possible Spoiler Alert" because I wasn't sure if saying nothing new occurred would be a spoiler.

This story is simply beautiful, and by beautiful, I mean it shows the stark-naked-ugly- hairy-a$$- truth about two people who fall in when they weren't supposed to fall in love.  If you are looking for a sweet love-conquers-all fairytale, please allow me to show you the exit door, because $hit just got real in this book.Before I plunge into my review, let me just say that I want to take a hard copy of LiS, grind it into powder, pour it into a spice jar, and slap a "Mateo" label on it.  Eggs tasting a little bland, sprinkle a little Mateo on them, having a bad hair day, sprinkle a little Mateo on your head; not feeling so fresh down there, sprinkle some of that Mateo powder on the cooch.  MATEO MAKES EVERYTHING BETTER!  I think that the author should contact me so that we can get a plan in action.  If you see a 3 a.m. As-Seen-On-TV infomercial for Mateo powder, you can thank me for improving your life.  Okay, okay, let's talk about the story.***Warning:  Possible Spoilers Below***Love, in Spanish (LiS) picks up where Love, in English (LiE) ended, but this time the story is told from Mateo's POV.  The story is NOT a rehash of the first book; it's a continuation of Mateo's and Vera's life after their scandalous affair.  This book is as important IF not more important than LiE, because it tells the story of  the aftermath left once news of Mateo and Vera's affair goes public, and Mateo leaves his wife and home to be with Vera .  This story is so remarkable and powerful because it shows that  love, sometimes it's downright ugly, and just because two people love with all their heart and soul, even that isn't always enough to sustain the relationship.  Love, in Spanish gives a big dose of reality; it brings to light what often occurs when a person leaves one commitment/marriage to be with the one who brings him to life, who breathes air into his soul.  Before Vera, Mateo was the man who had everything and nothing at the same time; and now Mateo is the man who has nearly nothing and everything at the same time.  Vera made Mateo realize that he was living the wrong life.  However, just because Mateo makes the huge decision to choose Vera over his lifeless marriage in LiE, that doesn't mean that the worst is over and that they get to live happily ever after.Mateo choosing to be Vera is like an earthquake, and just like a real earthquake, sometimes the most damage is not brought on the quake itself, but by the aftershocks or a tsunami.  Have you ever wondered about a real-life affair that was so powerful that it caused the demise of another committed relationship, yet the couple fell apart afterwards?  LiS shows us that the hardest part of a forbidden affair isn't the decision to leave significant others so that the two people can be together; it's living that life afterwards that's the toughest.Mateo soon learns that his affair wronged not only his wife, but every wife in in their social circle, school, and city, and none of them are going to allow neither him nor Vera to forget that pain and humiliation. Mateo also discovers that when he divorced his wife, he ended up divorcing his friends and supporters.  He planned on losing his house and wife, but  he didn't plan on losing a majority of parental rights and decisions, friendships,  loyalty, respect from others, his image, admiration from his countrymen, and social status;  his wife got custody of all that and more from the divorce.  This is why so many affairs end; people don't foresee all the other losses.  Mateo does gain a few things, but nothing like he anticipated; he inherits ruthless media, negative publicity that plays out his private life in the tabloids, scorn from the other parents, disrespect from former friends, a big pile of guilt, insecurities and doubts.  In addition to all the losses, Mateo recognizes not only the age gap, but the language barrier and cultural difference between him and Vera.  Mateo prefers swilling scotch in his apartment, whereas Vera enjoys getting drunk and dancing all night.  Mateo is a man of traditions, Vera is very much a free spirit; Mateo is rooted, while Vera is the star in the sky.  But like Mateo said, "You don't keep your eyes on the ground once you've seen the beauty of the stars." At times I found myself irritated with Vera, some of her behavior brought embarrassment to Mateo, as well as hardship.  Then I remember that Vera is only 23 y.o., and also a free-thinking, inked-up,  non-conformist, who is living in a foreign country where she is vilified, and not only does she not have any family connections, but she doesn't even speak the language and could be deported any day from the man that she loves.  How the hell do I expect her to behave?My heart ached for this couple, how long should they have to carry around that big bag of guilt and shame, and how long should two people be punished for falling in love?  They deserve family and friends who love them, instead of choosing to judge them.  Never has that old adage, "Nothing worth having comes easy", been truer than with Mateo and Vera.

**Spoiler Alert****Spoiler Alert**What the f**k did I just read?! Seriously, what the f**k did I read? My mind is reeling from this mess of f***ed up characters. I don't even know if I liked, loved, or hated the story? The only thing I do know is that everyone is talking about this book; I have 6 different PMs and a book blog discussing this story, and I've never seen so much rabid conversation going on. I don't even know how to rate this, but if a book has this much discussion and conspiracy talks going on, I have to rate it high. Here's the thing, I want to give the book a 5 because of all the buzz it has generated. However, I can't get past the fact that she was only 15, and that Grizz and Grunt had been wanting her since she was 13 years old. That is really messed up, and the story would have still worked had Kit been written older. Then at the end, when we see that Kit caught Grizz's eye when she was only six, even though it wasn't sexual, if was too over the top.I can't tell you one good thing that I liked about this book, I can tell you that I despised that Kit was underage when she was taken, I bloody hated the brutality, there wasn't one person that I felt some sort of empathy or connection, and yet I can't stop thinking about what I read. My kids came up to me after I read this telling me that they are hungry, I slid a box of Captain Crunch and told them that this was dinner, and that mommy has a headache. Don't worry or call CPS, my husband came in a few minutes later and prepared dinner. Stupid stupid book.This book did not make me a better person or bring some freaking happiness to my life, it messed with me. I almost loathe myself for finishing this book. The dang author dropped clues left and right, and feeling like the superior reader, I had it all figured out; yeah, I had it all figured out, until the author, Beth Flynn, gave it to me up the ess at the very end. Let me just say that I don't enjoy being taking it up the ess without any lube. For the record I am neither Team Grizz nor Team Grunt; I am Team No One, no, I am Team Get-your-butt-out-before-they-kill-you. I disliked Grizz because he is totally messed up and brutally violent, but I can't stand Grunt, that sneaky rat-ess ba$tard. It's like choosing Ted Bundy or Charlie Manson. Oh my god, I hate myself for feeling anything for these characters.To Beth Flynn, you may have gotten me at the end, but I'm onto you. Here's what I think will happen in book two.1. Grizz is alive.2. Kit's parents were in on the kidnapping and possibly still alive. What, Kit didn't see a body.3. Grunt was involved in Moe's death and possibly Kit's rape.Ms. Flynn, do me a favor and kill each and every character in book 2 so I don't have to feel my soul tortured or comprised with book 3. Just get out of my freaking head and leave me alone, my kids need to be feed.

Two and a half stars***May contain spoilers***I chose to read Sweet Addictions because it was nominated in the GR Choice Awards and several readers in various groups raved about it.  The book's description is  "Sweet Addiction is the story of one woman's struggle to keep things casual, and one man's desire to never let her go", a better description would be "Sweet Addiction is the story of one woman who says she wants to keep things casual, but does just the opposite over and over".The story takes place at the wedding of Dylan's ex-boyfriend, no they didn't remain on good terms, Dylan is a baker and has been hired to bake her ex's wedding cake.  Within minutes of arriving, Dylan falls into the lap of the gorgeous Reese, CPA extraordinaire.  Immediately she is filled with the thoughts "Oh God, I want those lips on me".  Following the ceremony, Dylan and her gay friend Joey, have no problem meeting up with Reese and his gay friend, each couple engaging in mind-blowing sex, and Dylan experiences her first orgasm ever with Reese in the bathroom stall.  Afterwards things become awkward, and Dylan's best friend, Juls, informs Dylan after she reappears from the bathroom romp that Reese is married.  Dylan flees the wedding, but not before her ex grabs her and propositions her.  There is more sex going on at the wedding reception than honeymoon suites at the Poconos and Sandals Resort combined.The next day Dylan's friends try to convince her that it doesn't matter if Reese is married, he is hot and so romantic.  Really?  Although Dylan denies that she has any feelings for Reese, and it's tough considering that they spent all of 30-40 minutes talking and having sex in a bathroom, but 30-40 minutes in this book equates to 2 weeks in the real world.  Dylan decides to confront Reese about him being married and having sex with her, although she hadn't planned on seeing him again.  So Dylan does what every mature adult female *cough-selfish-crazy-psycho-cough*  does, no she doesn't call him on the phone or ask to meet him anywhere, she goes straight to his workplace , because that's what mature adults *cough-unstable-people-cough*  do.  When she sees Reese, this gorgeous CPA sitting behind his desk with his oh-so-big calculator, that she loses her train of thought, but once she has regained her composure she does what every mature female *cough-crazy-psycho-cough* does and slaps him.Okay, I have to address the multiple slappings that goes on in the story, I am zero domestic violence, but if a female doesn't want to be slapped, then she shouldn't hit.  Slapping became Dylan's way of dealing with Reese, and at one point I wanted him to retaliate and give her a dose of her own medicine.  Instead of being shocked or abhorred by Dylan's behavior, it was considered "HOT!".  Everything that this group does is hot and convenient, so much that the book could have been "Little Caesars".  How convenient that everyone is able to pair up with someone in the other group, how hot that these partners at a CPA firm are able to engage in sex with the doors unlocked when the women show up,  I repeat they are CPAs!!!Dylan and Joey waffle so much, that I was craving a serving of Scattered, Smothered, and Covered hash browns to make this story complete.  In one sentence she won't allow herself to become serious about Reese, and the following sentence she is ruined for any other man, and this is while they're on their first date.  Dylan says she wants a casual hookup, but then she suggests that they be "monogamously casual".  Speaking of first dates, it is time that the scenario of a couple getting ready to engage in sex, and the female says that she is on the pill, has been tested and cleared of any STDs, and would like the guy to go bareback because she trusts him, and the guy replies, and I repeat ALWAYS replies, "I've never done it without a condom before, EVER, but I will with you".  That scene has been done in so many stories that it needs to be retired to the Smithsonian Institute.  I've seen that same scenario in at least 10 books this year alone; that scene has earned its retirement, now let it collect Social Security and rest in a rocking chair.Getting back to the story, there is plenty of angst, but it's angst brought on by Dylan's thinking.  I'm sure if Dylan was to receive some anger management therapy, Ativan, or Prozac, she would be a lovely gal.  Also, I have to point out that it took Reese eight years to achieve his Master's degree in Business Administration, that's about the same length of time that it takes for someone to finish medical school, so something tells me that Reese may not be as stellar as Dylan thinks or maybe the company's CEO isn't that selective who makes partner.  Also, it takes two years working under a CPA before a person is qualified to be a CPA, just throwing that out there.This book was all over the place, it felt like a Disney princess film meets the 90210 crowd; the characters' behaviors were more of middle or high school students than adults.  It was a make out session whenever they all got together, and everyone sitting on each other's laps,  true love as soon as they meet,  making out at the office in front of co-workers, always angst, but no real plot to generate all the angst.  Bryce Roberts' character, what was that about?  It felt like he was going to become a fixture for some angst, but he just fizzled away to oblivion.  Big thumbs up to the wedding scene when Dylan's feet wouldn't move, that was pretty original and sweet.

If Sempre was that unknown horse that no one has heard about, yet wins the Kentucky Derby, "Made" is the Triple Crown in this trilogy.  J.M. Darhower just gets better and better with each book in the Sempre series.  Sempre introduced us to the story of Haven and Carmine, Sempre Redemption showed  us  a side of Corrado and Vincent that we didn't get to see in Sempre, and Made brings everything  full circle."Made" tells us how The Kevlar Killer is made, not just how Corrado Moretti became a "made man" in organized crime, but how he came to exist.  Organized crime has always been a part of Corrado's life, even when he didn't know it, it was there.  Corrado grew up knowing enough of the rules, and how a person could became dead when the rules were broken.  Author Darhower  writes beautifully how the Mafia is much like Hotel California, as you can check in, but you can never leave.  "After they invited you in, after they embraced you, there was no walking away.  It's a beautiful web of glorious silk, intricately woven together with deception, which draws you in like moths to a flame.  But as soon as you're close, as soon as you approach, the web snatches a hold of you and refuses to let go.  And once you're stuck, the black widow comes and f**ks you good before eating you alive." If you think that Corrado is cold, compared to his mother, he is a ray of sunshine.  When a stranger asks Corrado "what made you this way?"  Corrado's explanation is " The world treats me like I wronged them, when really, the world wronged me.  The world made me this way.  And maybe they all hate me, but still, they need me.  Because without villains, there would be no superheroes".  At one point in his childhood, Corrado had to consider the fact that his own mother might try to kill him one day.  If Joan Crawford was able to read Made, even she would cringe and say "That is one cold-a** mother".  Corrado learns early in life the rule of not to get too attached to anyone, because eventually he/she will disappear, and one thing that Corrado is good at, it's following rules.  People have a way of disappearing in Corrado's world, and he grew up knowing that "it's cruel, but it's unavoidable.  If the shark didn't eat the man, the man would eat the shark.  That's just how it goes".  That rule works out perfectly for Corrado, until he meets Celia DeMarco.  Celia is a total enigma for Corrado, growing up in a house of ruthless women; he doesn't know how to handle this strong, passionate, yet caring female.  Corrado has lived in a world colored only in black and white, just obey the rules, follow orders, and don't never ever ask "why".  Celia brings color, fire, and passion to an ugly ruthless world, and although Corrado fights to keep her away, Celia isn't used to obeying every rule like Corrado.  These two are meant for one another, Celia keeps Corrado on his toes, and brings a small trace of gentleness to Corrado, even as Corrado fights these conflicting emotions, he is no match for Celia determinedness.  Celia really is an enigma, because even though Celia brings some change to Corrado, she also aware of the world in which they live, and she knows when to be supportive and just let Corrado do what he has to do.  Celia compliments, yet contrasts Corrado, but one thing is for sure, they belong together.Made comes full circle for the Sempre series, we learn not only of Corrado's and Celia's past, but we get to read about Vincent's past and how he found the woman who would eventually shake up  his world, but also the world of  La Cosa Nostra.  Darhower stays true to form in not making a flashy story romanticizing the criminal underworld, instead she shows the reader once again beauty found in an ugly world.  Corrado, you are wrong, you and Vincent showed sacrifice and loyalty to the ones you love, you'll always be my superhero.

Three and a half stars, spoiler-free review.Torture to Her Soul is the follow up to Monster In His Eyes.  This was one of my most anticipated releases because I loved Naz in the first book.  In MIHE, Naz was mysterious and dark, he admitted that he wasn't a good man, and his actions led me to believe him.  I loved him in spite of this, because he didn't make any apologies nor did he try to change to please Karissa.  In Torture to Her Soul, Naz fell off the pedestal that I created for him.  For me, Naz turned from this dark, take-charge, always in-control tiger into a brooding puppy.  In the first 1/3 of the book, Naz is basically following Karissa throughout the house trying to figure out what she's thinking, how beautiful she is, or how much he loves her.  For me the author made a common error that most female authors make when writing a male's POV once he has fallen in love, she wrote the words that females want to believe that the male is thinking, not what an actual man would make, especially a man such as Ignazio Vitale.  His world outside of Karissa basically comes to a halt while he focuses every minute on Karissa.  Naz drops everything he is doing, stays at home with Karissa, even though she refuses to talk to him and ignores him for days, and waits patiently for her to love him once again or just smile once again.  TMI was the downfall to this part of the book; Naz's POV is giving me too much information.  I don't need or maybe just don't want to know that he's eagerly waiting for her minute after minute to toss him a bone, like a puppy.  I don't want Naz to be a puppy; I want Naz to be the Naz that he was in the first book.Fortunately the couple begins venturing outside the house around the 2/3 of the book, and the story starts to escalate.  The last 1/3 of the book gave me the adrenaline and excitement that I loved in Monster In His Eyes.  The ending was climatic; both thrilling and chilling.One part of the relationship that the author absolutely nailed, or at least it worked for me is that Naz and Karissa did not completely trust one another.  I loved this concept, because this isn't a couple that met through a mutual friend, fell in love while sharing unlimited bread sticks at an Olive Garden.  Karissa knows that Naz is a bad man, and Naz knows he committed acts that have turned Karissa's life upside down.  In a scenario like this, you don't roll out of bed, kiss each other on the cheek, and make coffee; no, you wonder if he'll kill you if you try to leave, or did she put poison in my coffee.I loved the ending to story, however the first 1/3 of the book had me wondering if Naz had grown a vagina, and I almost didn't finish it.  I look forward to reading more stories from J.M. Darhower

I am so excited to be writing a five star review for a Kristen Ashley book, to be honest I didn't connect with her last four releases, and it left me feeling odd, as if I were book impotent, or that I had to watch out for a Cantu sister cutting my brake lines.  In her latest release, Deacon, Ms. Ashley brings her A-game,  and I love the end result.  I suspected that Ashley was writing outside her comfort box when I read the disclaimer warning readers that the book was dealing with a dark romance, erotic scenes, anal sex, bondage, and ..........wait did I just read "anal sex" ....... in a K.A. book......SHUT THE FRONT DOOR!Also another indicator that this book was going to be different is that the heroine, Cassie, is 5'5", that's petite in a K.A. book where nearly every female role is 5'7"-5'11".  It isn't just Cassie's stature that causes her to stand out from the other K.A. female characters; Cassie is in charge and attempting to live her dream.  Cassie doesn't need to be saved or rescued from a situation or a man, she is independent, capable, down-to-Earth, and I connect with her character.  She doesn't lose herself in a man, and she doesn't lose her feminine qualities while being independent, she's as tough as nails when she needs to be, and she isn't scared of being alone.  God, I can't tell you how much I love her character.Deacon rolls in, and he isn't the typical alpha-male that I'm used to seeing in a K.A. book, he's dark, mysterious, and foreboding.  He doesn't step in and immediately take over Cassie's life; in fact, it takes years before they are comfortable with each other.  Deacon is enigmatic, he rolls into town every few months, and the reader knows that he has shadowy secrets, but just how dark is the question.  Cassie knows that on some level that this isn't going to work out, yet she enters a relationship cautiously, and I have to give her credit that she prepares from the beginning that he is going to leave.  I love Deacon, he's able to recognize Cassie's strengths and independence, and he compromises....COMPROMISES....he doesn't go all alpha-male and control every situation.  Let me just say when his secret is exposed, I felt his pain to my bones.  His past is brutal, K.A. doesn't spare any details in giving the reader an insight to Deacon's pain and what causes him to die inside and become this tortured soul.The sex, Holy Mother of Fornication, was so explicit, and hotter than any other Ashley's book.  I don't know what brought this out in K.A., maybe she got a subscription to HBO After Dark or Cinemax, but holy hell.  There was bondage, anal sex, butt plugs, but it wasn't just used on the female; yeah, you read that right, Cassie had her some fun too.  It isn't that I can't find these scenes in other erotic books, but I was unprepared to read it in Deacon, and K.A. wrote it passionately and tastefully.  I loved it!I adore Cassie's best friend, Milagros.  Milagros was always looking out for Cassie, and she wasn't swayed by Deacon's good looks, and she aired her suspicions with Cassie.  This is the kind of best friend that every gal wants in her corner.Deacon is at the top of my favorite 2014 reads.  I embraced everything about this book, and I loved that Ashley allowed one of my favorite Rock Chicks' couple make an appearance.  I read this on a Kindle, and if the scene at 93% doesn't move you, then you are a serial killer who likes to kick around puppies as a pastime.

I reviewed this book when it was originally called "Break Me", and my review received a lot of support because fans of the UnDeniable series could see that Kate Stone had used character names, dialogue, and storylines from the UnDeniable series.  Now the book has been re-released with a slightly changed title and author name, not only has Kate/Katie re-released this book, but she has released a new book titled "Hell's Horsemen".  Doesn't that sound familiar?! Don't worry, I reviewed the new book, and I can honestly say that it was one of the worst written stories that I've ever read.  Below is my review of the first release titled "Break Me".************************************************************************************************************************************************************Let's pretend that Chef Gordon Ramsay prepared the most succulent dinner, a meal so delicious that you'll be telling your grandchildren stories about it. Hours later after the food has entered the stomach, the gastric juices break down that most decadent meal, and eventually it is turned into excrement. Folks, meet Kate Stone, the gastric juice in the literary world. Kate has taken a 5 star book, UnDeniable, broke it down and attempted to copy it, and Break Me is what was pooped out.Did Kate think that no one would notice the similarities between her story and UnDeniable? I'm willing to bet that she will deny ever reading UnDeniable, the book that is highly favored by fans of the MC genre. If you think my review is harsh, let me point out some facts.1. The Break Me story centers around a character that has been in and out of juvie since his teens and called "Crazy Evan", and introduces members of the MC called Mick, Ripper, Danny, and ZZ, a red-head that cleans the clubhouse, and a young girl that wears tattered jeans and t-shirts. UnDeniable's list of characters include "Crazy Frankie", a young man that's been in and out of jail since his teens; other characters include Mick, Ripper, Danny, ZZ, Dorothy (a red head that cleans the clubhouse), and Eva (a young girl that wears torn jeans and t-shirts).2. Break Me's club prez is an older man with one syllable first and last name that throws around the word "darlin'"; UnDeniable's club prez, Cole "Deuce" West put the word "darlin'" in Urban Dictionary, I would say Webster's, but we all know Webster's is too uptight and button down collared shirt for that stuff. Seriously though, Deuce is legendary for using "darlin'".3. Crazy Evan is very, very similiar to UnDeniable's Crazy Frankie, from his fixation to kill the club president, the coerced sex, to his obsessed with the heroine, stating "Need you more than life baby...More than f*****g life...Can't f*****g sleep, can't f*****g eat. Don't you know that?" In UnDeniable, Crazy Frankie made the statement to Eva "I can't sleep without you, and I can't breathe, baby. I can't f****n' breathe. ".4. Break to Callie: "Tell me," he whispered, "do you want it hard, or do you want it slow?" In UnDeniable, Deuce to Eva: "You want it hard, baby?" he whispered, "Or you want it slow?"5. In one instance, Break says "She's not for the club, she's mine". Deuce made the statement "She doesn't belong to one of my boys. She's f****n' mine".6. In a rape scene, Break is forced to watch, and Callie finds salvation during the act by staring into Break's blue eyes. In UnDeniable.....ditto.....same thing.There are other similarities, but I've made my point. My review is harsh, but I hate when someone steals another person's ideas and hard work and tries to profit from it.I can't even bring myself to call Kate an author, Kate is a copy-cat and an opportunist; she is not a writer. I want to call her a plagiarist, but she changed just enough words that the statements aren't verbatim. Sadly, this isn't the first MC book that has attempted to copy "UnDeniable", but it's probably the worst-written semi-plagiarized version. What parts that Kate didn't "borrow" from UnDeniable, were poorly written.Here's an idea, Kate and to others that want to create a succulent dinner by stealing Chef Gordon Ramsay's recipe (aka Madeline Sheehan's book) and calling it their own: go watch Paula Deen on The Food Network (aka take a writing course), then practice with your own ingredients (aka your own words and story), and then when you've worked hard enough and come up with an original recipe, host a dinner party (aka publish your own book). In the meantime, if you want a book that is equivalent of ordering a pink-slime burger through a speaker and being asked "Would you like fries with that?", this might be your book.

Loved it!  By the time I finished reading UnBeloved, I felt as if I had just hopped off a roller coaster. This book had me crying, nervous, laughing, and filled with excitement.UnBeloved is the 4th book in the saga of Hell's Horsemen Motorcycle Club. I think it's safe to say that this series has moved from just being an MC romance genre to an MC story. This installment deals primarily with the aftermath and dealing with the wounds, both physically and emotionally, from the relationship between Jase/Dorothy/Hawk from years earlier, betrayal from one of the brothers, the spiraling downfall of a former brother, the Russian Mafia, and finding redemption and hope in places that one doesn't expect to find it. If this story feels different than previous stories, that's because it is different. This story doesn't deal with a new love, rather it is dealing with the aftermath of two love affairs that span nearly 20 years.Before I launch into a full review of UnBeloved, I want to talk about the UnDeniable series as a whole. Only a few books have connected with me in such a way that I want to experience them over and over. The in-depth writing of Madeline Sheehan provokes my imagination and connects me to characters that I never thought I could relate. This series is pioneering because the author has taken a band of outlaws, old ladies, and club bunnies; characters so varied, and gives them each a unique voice. At times their tale is sad and tragic, yet we see humor, loyalty, and undying love. Sheehan portrays their beauty and flaws honestly, never apologizing or pleading with the reader to embrace them. Also trailblazing is that the characters are allowed to age, and it's never been so evident than in this fourth book. Whether or not it was the author's intent, she is breaking new ground because the reader watches as the young, flighty women from the earlier books progress from their 20s and 30s , into their 40s and 50s. *gasp* Book characters having a life and sex after 40; I thought at that age, they were supposed to be lead out into a pasture to wait for the Grim Reaper; never to be seen again in the story.UnBeloved is the story of Dorothy, Jase, and Hawk, and how the actions of each affected not only them, but the lives of their families. If I could only use a few words to describe UnBeloved, they would be "redemption", "forgiveness" AND "homecoming". In UnBeautifully, we saw how their love turned into an F5 tornado, creating a path of destruction for not only them but everyone around them. Chrissy, Jase's wife, was convicted of first degree attempted murder for shooting a very pregnant Dorothy, Dorothy shunning both men and the club, Jase losing his mistress and family, and Hawk leaving his brothers and going nomad. Seven years later, the trio still haven't addressed the carnage left by their love vortex, until an emergency has everyone coming home, and the trio is finally forced to walk through the broken mess, and assess the damage and rebuild. The story begins with Dorothy being called back to Miles City, Montana due to an emergency. Once she is inside the clubhouse, she is informed that one of the Horsemen isn't who he has claimed to be and has been covering up his past. So the entire club is reeling from this betrayal, and also from one of their own being held hostage. In dealing with the dire situation, Dorothy is forced to a day of reckoning, seven years after surviving the gunshot, she has to deal with the issues from her past. Jase is also forced to come to terms with the poor choices made years ago. Instead of hiding from the issues like Dorothy did by moving away, Jase has hid from them inside a liquor bottle. Jase's road to redemption comes from the most unlikely source. When he finally comes face-to-face, he knows that he has to make amends and stop the vicious cycle. Hawk has literally ran from all the problems from the past, going nomad and seeking refuge in the road. Now all the running and hiding comes to an abrupt halt. As in any family, when there is an emergency and the chips are down, everyone comes together, and this MC family is no different.Once again I get to see my favorite character, "DEEEEEEEEUUUUUUCCCCEEEE!". What can I say, I've loved him since UnDeniable; even when he was an a-- hole at times. My love for Deuce has not wavered, if anything, it has grown. Deuce is still a force to be reckoned with, and it is never more evident than the scene on the highway between he and Preacher, and when he and Ripper pay a visit to Hawk. Cox and Kami are still fighting as usual, and Cox's humor has grown even more vulgar and dirty, as impossible as that seems. OMG, that one scene had me laughing and gagging at the same time. Eva's influence on the club is evident in how everyone, including the women, views it not as a club, but rather another home. The women have formed tight bonds, and just like the Horsemen being brothers, the gals also have a sisterhood.*******CAUTION BELOW MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS, READ AT YOUR OWN RISK ****I have to talk about my two favorite scenes: 1. the highway scene and 2. the Vegas arena scene. The highway scene, oh that highway scene, that one is my favorite. Sheehan's writing is pure perfection, from her description of the surroundings to the bantering between the characters, if I felt anymore immersed in that scene, I would have needed to throw on my coat and gloves. The spoken dialogue and unspoken thoughts from each character is profound, beautiful, and insightful. That scene showcases how the men have progressed since the beginning of the series; it's powerful and serene at the same time. The Vegas scene, let's just say that I had goosebumps when Sheehan first walks us through the arena, that scene is dark and scary. I didn't know what to expect. Okay, no more, because I don't want to give away a spoiler......As the characters find reckoning, redemption, forgiveness, and peace during their homecoming; some say a sad goodbye. Like a regular family, sometimes we lose members, and this story is no different: one deciding to take the road that leads to home, one's path taking him to jail where he doesn't pass GO and collect $200, and ZZ's route, let's just call Z's road "psycho path", and a couple of bikers that take the journey on that eternal highway through the Harley Davidson's pearly gates. In the words of Dorothy Kelley Matthews "This is the story of us all...all our fates intertwined, and for that reason alone, pain and death be damned, I wouldn't change a thing." As for me, I wouldn't miss the ride on a rocky road with this band of outlaws, old ladies, and club hookahs for anything. Vroom, vroom!!

Moments In Time is similar to purchasing or receiving a box of assorted Lindt or Ghirardelli chocolates; you get to sample several different varieties, and there isn't a bad one in the bunch.  The chocolatiers in this anthology are Madeline Sheehan, Karina Halle, Nicole Jacquelyn, Ashley Suzanne, Daryl Banner, and several other talented writers, and the genre ranges from Fantasy to Steampunk to Contemporary Romance.  You cannot go wrong with this book of short stories, PLUS all the proceeds go to the Western New York Independent Living, a nonprofit organization that works with people, young and old, living with a disability, and teaching them life skills that will enable them to take control of their lives.  It's a win-win situation for everyone involved.The first story that I couldn't wait to read is Because You Are Mine by Madeline Sheehan, and it didn't disappoint.  This story involves a  shape-shifter, half human and half wolf, and 100%  hot alpha male wolf.  This story is that one piece of chocolate in the box that everyone fights to claim it first, and I couldn't help, but think of that  piece of delectable chocolate in the image of Joe Manganiello.  I only wish that the story could be developed from a short story into a full novel; I would love to see more Shayanne and Grey.  The Benson by Karina Halle is that piece of chocolate with the center being filled with delicious buttery caramel goodness.  Each story in Moments In Time is delicious, and the wonderful thing is if you get a flavor that you don't like, skip it and move to a different variety:  if you're not a connoisseur of Erotica, move on to Paranormal, Fantasy, Steampunk, or Contemporary Romance.  This book is a treat for readers of all genres, not only should you buy it for yourself, it would also make the perfect gift.

After suffering from book impotency for a few weeks, I have found my literary Viagra. It pains me to say that I nearly missed reading this book, I didn't think that I could suffer through another college-age-coming-of-age Cinderella story. Thankfully this isn't another Cinderella fairy tale.....it's more like Red Riding Hood meets the Big Bad Wolf. What prompted me to read this were the following lines:"I love you, too. Promise me you'll remember that."I promise.""Good," he says. "Because I"m about to f*** you like I don't."Karissa may be a college-age girl, but her love interest is no boy, Ignazio "Naz" Vitale is all man. But this is not the typical student being taught by the master; Karissa is teaching Vitale a thing or two. Karissa is embracing college life, she has no other option, because home is basically being tethered to her paranoid mother. Naz is a .....well, I don't know what exactly Naz is in the beginning, but whatever he does, he does it well. The two bump into each other the college campus, and then later at a club. It isn't love or sex at first sight, but Karissa probably should have paid closer the old adage about curiosity killing the cat. The two end up in a relationship, but the story isn't just about the romance, the reader gets a feeling that there is something more going on, and there is....but I don't want to give away any spoilers.Naz may be leading Karissa down a dark troubled road, but let's just say that she fueled up, bought new tires, and packed snacks for the ride. This story held my attention from the beginning until the last page, it got better with each page turned. The suspense kept building, and it didn't disappoint at the end. The author, J.M. Darhower, keeps Naz cool and dark, unlike many stories where the bad guy turns into a softie once he meets the female, this isn't that story. Naz doesn't lose his dark side when he meets Karissa, because Naz doesn't act cool and dark, Naz IS cool and dark.Bottom line....this is at the top of my list for my favorite reads in 2014. If you are expecting a sweet HEA, this may not be the book for you.....but if you like a story with a trip on a bumpy and curvy road, doing 95 mph while blindfolded, this might be your book.

I was excited to see that this romance involved mature adults, and a ready-made family.  However, I was not prepared for Josie to speaketh dowdier than a PBS Downton Abbey marathon.  Why?  Josie was born and raised in the U.S., am I to believe that Josie picked up this speech pattern from her surroundings?  The word "untoward"Josie is an assistant to renowned fashion photographer, ..... you know what, I just can't.  I want to write an accurate review, but the bottom line is that the Josie character is ridiculous.  Josie speaks as if she found a time machine in 19th England and transported herself to the present time.  Josie is written to appear clueless and stodgy at times, such as her irritability if she eats dinner at an different time, being frugal and saving her earnings, and being in love with her employer for 20 years;  lives in his guest house, travels all over the world, but doesn't convey her feelings.  Then there are times that Josie is written to appear worldly and trendy; close friends with designers, rockers, and such a sexual prowess that a one-night stand with a famous hip-hop artist, that left him  in love with her.  Josie doesn't have any children or experience with children, but that doesn't stop her from resolving all the teenagers issues:  from romantic interests to mending the children's relationships with their parents.  All the men in Josie's life are in love with her, I don't know of one male mentioned in the book that wasn't smitten by the sex kitten Mary Poppins.The is the 3rd consecutive release from Kristen Ashley that has left me disappointed.  After reading so many rave reviews, I thought for sure this was the book that would help me forget about the other two books, Kaleidoscope and Broken Dove.  Alas, I wished that I had skipped the reviews. and saved myself from this untoward book.

I was elated when I discovered that the follow-up to Crow's Row, Scare Crow was released, and couldn’t wait to download the book. It has been over a year since I read Crow’s Row and awaited the follow-up, which is a decade to a reader. I’m a patient reader, I never want to rush or place stress on an author to finish a book; it’s his /her story to write.My best description for this book is to imagine that you are hungry, absolutely starving, and a driver shows up to take you to a restaurant. She takes you on the most beautiful and scenic route, and then you discover that the road is actually a dead-end street, so then the driver takes a different road, and again, the scenery is as beautiful, but then you discover that it’s another dead-end street. The same scenario keeps playing over, another decorative route that doesn’t lead to the restaurant, and finally you decide that you’ll settle for any restaurant, it doesn’t have to be the one that you were anticipating. You no longer care about the scenic route; you just want to get to a destination. That’s how this story felt to me.Julie Hockley’s writing is beautiful; I don’t know any other way to describe her meticulous flow of words. Ms. Hockley’s exceptional skill of depicting character and their surroundings pulls in the reader; I was immediately drawn into the story. However, around 80 pages, I began feeling that the scenes that I had read didn’t lead anywhere. I didn’t understand the importance of Emmy working in the admissions office, and initiating a plan that would allow her to see information about Cameron. In the end, all she ended up was the address of his mother; the same address that she visited in Crow’s Row. I also couldn’t understand Emmy’s financial situation; in one scene she is scared because she is unemployed, yet she isn’t making any effort to attend school to keep her scholarship from being revoked. Emmy is worried if she can’t pay rent that she will be homeless, yet she has the cabin that Cameron owned. In one scene, Emmy shows up at a bank with information of an over-seas account written on a wrapper, and when the bank personnel can’t help her, unlocking the codes to obtain the account is shelved for a later time. If I thought I was close to being homeless and unemployed, decoding the information to gain access to a potential boatload of money could be important. However, I’ll give Emmy a pass since the love of her life is deceased. Emmy’s desire to remain in that broken-down shack is another aspect that I don’t understand. In one scene, she discusses how she isn’t close to any of the other tenants, that she doesn’t really know them; yet, when Griff show up with money, she can’t bear the thought of leaving her roommates or her closet of a room. Then there are all the details that went into describing the cartels, their families, and connections; so much of it was unnecessary information. The Canadian woman who Cameron supports wasn’t relevant to this story, and it was just one of many details that didn’t really pan out or contribute to the story. Also, I would love to know how many times the name “Meatball” is written; I’m a animal lover, but towards the middle of the story, I was wanting more Cameron and a little less Meatball.I will say that the scene in Canada was absolute killer, Hockley’s account of the brutal and vicious events was fantastic; Hockley didn’t romanticize Cameron’s role. Hockley kept to the raw savagery of an underground crime boss, and didn’t sugarcoat Cameron’s activities. Let’s talk about some Cameron; his character has changed, and to me it wasn’t for the better. I understand how he missed Emmy, I loved that he missed Emmy, but I felt that he grew a vagina when he lost Emmy. Cameron reminiscing about Emmy’s 16th birthday party and all the details, it was too wimpy for me. A huge thumbs up for the depiction off Spider and Carly. The couple has changed since they were living at the Farm in Crow’s Row. Carly is now showing the effects of living in the criminal world, her presence is bleaker; the couple’s relationship with Cameron is strained. Cracks are beginning to form not only with the couple, but inside the crime family as well. Trust is beginning to waver, and they are at each other’s throats.Towards the end of the book, the story began moving at a rapid pace, and then BAM, the book has ended. The events towards the end of the book would have been better suited in the middle of the book and more time dedicated to those scenes. I thought that the book was packed with unnecessary fillers; scenes that didn’t impact the story. I felt that the author didn’t know where to take the characters.Julie Hockley ‘s writing skill is so creative and profound, one of the best that I’ve seen in any author, but the storyline/plot wasn’t there until the very end.

Mud Vein is the story of a woman who wakes up one morning to find that she has been kidnapped and left in a house with a man from her past.  Senna/Brenna and Isaac are forced to cohabitate in a cabin in a rural area surrounded with an electric fence.  They have no idea who has kidnapped them, but Senna knows that all the clues point to her past, and so she revisits her past to find the kidnapper before time runs out.I like the basis of the plot, two people who share a past, kidnapped and brought together, where they must work together to figure out a way out of the cabin or the person behind the kidnapping. Someone has stocked enough food and fuel for the generator to keep these two stranded in the cabin for months, so the reader knows that the kidnapper has been plotting this revenge for awhile, but figuring out who and why isn’t so easy.  However, about mid-point in the book, I realized that I didn’t like Senna enough to even care if she made it out alive; I kept reading because I was curious as to who the kidnapper is, and I was also holding out hope that that I would feel a connection to Senna before the story ended.  I felt Isaac’s pain and grief from being separated from his expectant wife, and his character was likeable and the reader could feel a connection.  Senna/Brenna’s communication is very short and choppy, she often answers a question with a question; she is a recluse without any friends or family, and doesn’t seek contact with anyone.  I see Senna struck with some terrible incidents when she relives her past, but she was a one-woman island before these events occur.The abduction turns into many months, with both characters giving up hope at different times, and taking turns saving the other.  Throughout the months, Senna is still revisiting her past, trying to piece together all the clues in the cabin.  There are many clues, however, sometimes the clue is so hidden or vague that it makes no sense why the kidnapper even used the clue because it is unrealistic that the Senna would grasp or recognize it.  After examining Senna’s past, it is a guessing game of which character is responsible for their abduction:  mother, father, wife, or ex-boyfriend, etc..  Both characters come very close to death, which led me to think that this was done by a love-interest-gone-wrong from either Senna’s or Isaac’s past.  But when the kidnapper is revealed, the plot loses me; the kidnapper had access to indoor cameras, and could see all the suffering and near death, yet didn’t intervene.  It would have been different had this been a revenge kidnapping, and also at the end, Isaac reveals a decision that he made that could have resulted in him being released, yet he didn’t seize the opportunity.The bottom line is that I liked the beginning plot, it had me on the edge of my seat; I liked Isaac, and there were times that I liked Senna, although I couldn’t connect with her.  But as the story progressed, the clues were so inexplicit that it was unrealistic to imagine that Senna would figure them out.  When the kidnapper is revealed, and also that the kidnapper had access to watch them, I had to ask what is the purpose in allowing them to suffer and/or die?  (It’s hard to not give any spoilers, but I’m trying.)This book is a testament to the progression of the author’s writing, I think she is evolving and striking out into a different genre, and that’s a big plus.

I only had to wait 2 weeks for Sempre Redemption because I was late to the Sempre party and only discovered it two weeks ago.  I enjoyed Redemption even more than Sempre.  The story grew beyond the love between two teenagers and morphed into a bigger story;  the love that a father has for his son, deciding loyalty between the  bloodline family and La Famiglia, sacrifice, forgiveness, and redemption.  If you need your characters to be black and white (good/bad), stop here, don't proceed, don't download this book because the characters are drenched in grey. If you need a story where the h is saved by the H and the two of them can overcome all obstacles on love alone, go fetch a different book from the Romance section because this isn't going to be that book.  If you want a story filled with erotica and hot angst sex, don't even look at this book.  If you want a book that has twists and turns, bad guys doing good deeds, good guys doing bad deeds, love testing the bonds of loyalty, then you want to read Redemption.Sempre ended with Carmine giving his loyalty to the Mafia in order to find Haven.  Redemption picks up with the Godfather calling for Carmine to come to Chicago and fulfill his lifelong commitment to serve the organization.  Carmine knows that he can't renege on his vow, but he knows that he can't bring Haven into a life filled with crime.  Carmine has to choose.  Vincent has fought all his life to keep his sons out of the hands of "The Family", but even he can't protect Carmine from that life now that Carmine has given his promise in order to save Haven.  Corrado...Corrado...dang...let's talk some Corrado.  Corrado is a hitman for the organization, but he isn't just any ole hitman, Corrado may be a murderer amongst other bad things, but he is a stickler for rules.  Doesn't matter if it's a Mafia brother or blood family, the rules of the organization must be followed or Corrado will dish out the punishment like a lunch lady serving two-day old baked ziti:  hard and cold.  No excuses.  As much as Corrado hates the organization at times, he knows that he has given his oath to serve, and he makes sure that the rules are followed so that his crime group succeeds and isn't engaged in war with other Mafia factions.  In other words, even if you're family, you serve with loyalty or face Corrado.  No one....and I mean NO ONE wants to be on the receiving end of Corrado.  Then there is Haven.  Haven's world has been sheltered from the rest of the world, but now she is thrust into the world, and she has to decide whether to sink or swim...her choice.  But it isn't easy considering that she was former slave and never had the privilege of choosing.Redemption is about choices and freedom.  Both don't always go hand-in-hand.  Carmine took a vow to the serve the Mafia, but was he really free to do it because of Haven being kidnapped.  Later when Carmine makes choices to give Haven her freedom, he doesn't realize it, but he actually limiting her freedom and taking away her options.  Carmine once a free man is now enslaved by the Mafia.  Haven, now has a new life, but is it one that she chose or one that someone chose for her?In Sempre, the author gave us the story of two teens finding each other and trying to find a place in this world together against odds and bad people; in Redemption, the author gives us not only the two teens, but the people trying to help them find their place.  Redemption shows us betrayal, hopelessness, and hate, but we also get to see undying love, ultimate sacrifices, loyalty, and most of all...redemption.Bottom line:  Sempre Redemption....You were worth it.

I read Surviving Raine, and I'm probably in the minority, but I rated it a 3.5 stars.  For me this story could have be dubbed Travis Maddox  in Castaway,  with the role of Wilson being replaced by Raine.  I went into this story with high expectations, but it fell short for me.  The story is told from the male's POV; Bastian has similar characteristics as Travis Maddox and Remy.  Bastian is aggressive and possessive towards Raine, he can't seem to control his temper and he is very much an a**hole.  He has a very shady past, a retired underground deathmatch fighter, but now Bastian is the alcoholic owner/captain of a ship.  Did I mention Bastian is an a**hole.After his ship sinks, Bastian and Raine are survivors in a small lifeboat out in the middle of the ocean.  Bastian starts out as the leader in charge, but his alcoholism leaves him weak and vulnerable, as much as he doesn't want to accept Raine's help, he has to lean on her in order for them to survive being lost at sea.The book has some good plots and twists, but I couldn't get into Bastian's character.  Another underground fighter that enjoys the company of wh**es and prostitutes, he can''t control his temper, has the power to snuff out four men threatening Raine, is possessive and jealous of anyone that comes in contact with Raine, is that sounding familiar at all?  Did I mention that he's an a**hole.  I understood his a**holiness when they first became passengers in the life boat, it was a stressful time, but all through the book, the same scenes were repeated, he knew she didn't deserve his rudeness, yet he would still say rude and vicious words to her.  Just because you admit that you're being an a**hole in  your head, doesn't make it okay to keep being an a**hole.  I also tired of hearing how his male body part (Amazon won't let me use d***) jumped whenever he thought about her, and how he didn't deserve her, several repetitive scenes.If you love Travis and Remy, then  Surviving Raine may be the book for you.  I liked it, but I didn't love it.

I just added this book to my 2013 favorite books list, I finished Sempre this morning and this story took me by surprise. Sempre is like that unknown horse that no one has heard about, yet wins the Kentucky Derby. I can't believe that it wasn't recommended to me prior to it being on sale last week, and if I had to choose one book to recommend out of the dozens that I've read over the past few weeks; Sempre is my Secretariat. Sempre isn't a flashy story, it isn't about a billionaire, it isn't erotic, it isn't about perfection, it isn't black and white; it's a lot of grey that includes good people doing bad things, it's about risking it all for the one that you love, it's about hope, and it's about surviving. There was so much suspense and intrigue, that I simply couldn't put the book down until I finished it.
