This is such a great idea!  My little one loves making the cars go down the ramp, and she also likes collapsing the ramp and opening it back up.  I love that it folds to save space and it works great to take to Grandma's house or to appointments, on vacation, etc.It was easy to use, it took me a couple minutes to get the knack of opening it up and folding it up again, but I've got it now.Because it is made to collapse it can seem a bit shaky at times, and once in a while the cars go so fast they fly off the middle of the track.  But otherwise I can't think of anything bad to say about this.  I would recommend this for age 4 and under, I think even 3 year olds who love cars will enjoy this toy.

These toy hammocks are great for storage, and this one gives you a pack of two of them - for two corners of your kids room or for two rooms.  Since space limited at our house, I love having these around.  They aren't just for stuffed animals, but can be used for toys, bath toys, blankets, towels, pillows, quilts, etc.However, they only come with suction hooks to attach them to the walls, so the suction won't work if the wall is not tile or glossy.  And even then, the suction won't hold a large weight.  However, I was able to use them in our bathroom above the tub for my daughter's tub toys.If you want to hang them in the corner of a drywalled bedroom, you could probably use those drywall picture hanger hooks for the 3 sides but you have to purchase those hooks separately.I received a sample of this product for review purposes, and I'm pleased with the product - I just wish it came with another option for hanging on the wall.

I agree with other reviewers that this shoe organizer is not very sturdy, and also would not hold shoes that are very large.  However, they have been working perfectly for my young daughter's shoes.She needed a good way to organize her shoes, so I'm glad to have this.  Because her shoes are small they do not put a lot of pressure on this organizer so it is less likely to rip or tear.  She doesn't have this many shoes so I can put some toys in the other pockets too.The only other complaint I have is that the hooks that hang over the door fall out easily when you are trying to move this organizer.  It would be nice if the hooks were attached somehow so they didn't keep falling off.I received a sample of this product for review purposes, and I would recommend it for children's shoes and toys.

I received this ring in a women's size 7 and it seems to fit very well, true to size.  When it first arrived I was surprised at how lightweight it is, it almost feels like it is made of plastic at first.  But it is very comfortable to wear for a long time and slides on and off my finger very easily.The inscription "you are my only love" is VERY tiny.  It is almost impossible for me to find it at first.  But I kind of like it that way, it's like the ring has a secret message on it.I also appreciate that it does not tarnish and is very non-allergenic.The inside has engraving too, but it's not a secret message, it is simply stating that the ring is stainless steel.The ring seems very unisex, would look fine on a man or woman.  I think this ring is perfect for a promise ring when money is tight, or if you are in a situation where you can't wear expensive jewelry.  This ring would be the perfect every day ring to wear.  I received a sample of this ring for review purposes and I'm pleased with it.

I love this protein powder, it doesn't have any unnecessary ingredients - it's just organic protein powder.  It also doesn't have a strong taste.  I've been using it in my green smoothies so that they keep me fuller longer.I received a sample of this product for review purposes, and I am very pleased with it.  I would recommend it to anyone looking for organic protein powder without dairy or gluten and without artificial sweeteners.  I will be buying this in the future.

These bottles are a very pretty light purple/lavender color.  They work well and seem to cause less gas bubbles than other bottles due to the vent holes on the bottom.I also like that the bottom and the top come completely off for cleaning purposes.  You can even sterilize them in the microwave by filling the bottom with water.  The lid also doubles as a measuring cup.  I was impressed at all the possible uses.But most importantly they do seem to cut down on gas, and my baby seems to really like them.

This is a very high quality jacket for the price.  My husband could not believe it was only priced at $100, it could easily compete with jackets double the price or more.  We received the Brown Leather jacket size XL for my husband who normally wears size Large, and it fit him perfectly.  This jacket seems to run a bit small, but it could be because it is styled to be very fitted to the body.  If in doubt you should probably order a size bigger.(For reference, I measured the size XL jacket while laying flat.  Underarm to underarm: 25 inches.  Shoulder to bottom: 27 inches  Shoulder seam to cuff: 27 inches  Shoulder to shoulder seam across the top: 22 inches)Other than it running a bit small I have nothing but good things to say about this jacket.  It is heavy and feels like it would provide good protection, there is extra protection built in to the jacket at the elbows, on the shoulders, and on the back.  The lining is great for warmth but easily zips and velcros in and out as needed.There are pockets everywhere!  Some are simply ventilation pockets, others hold small things like wallet and cell phone or mp3 players, etc.  All the pockets are easily accessible from the front, with one hand while driving if necessary.The leather is not overly stiff, it seems soft enough, although I think this jacket will feel even better once it's broken in a bit.  We also like the color - it is dark brown but from a distance almost looks black.  It's a very attractive jacket.I received a sample of this product for review purposes, and we are very pleased with it.

My husband was pleased to be able to test this shaver.  He commented on how lightweight it is, and it is easy to grip/hold in your hand without slipping.  The blades flex a LOT and seem to do a good job conforming to your face, chin and neck.He does not like shaving in the shower, but he likes the water resistance because the shaver sits right next to the sink and occasionally gets splashed.  So there's no need to worry when that happens.After shaving his face felt a bit smoother than with his old shaver.The only negatives he felt were the noise - it is a bit louder than his old shaver, and it did leave about the same amount of stray hairs as his old shaver.  Overall he likes it and says it does a decent job.

I really like this Otterbox Ipad Mini case so far.  First of all, it looks great, very classy looking, and suitable for men or women.  Second, I like how easy it is to pop your ipad in and out.  I've used an Otterbox case that I could not remove without using a butter knife.  This is much easier to work with.  I like that you can prop up your ipad mini in a lot of different positions.  It took me a while to figure out how to rotate it 360 degrees but I learned and it's quite easy now that I know how.  I like that is is magnetized to stay closed, and I like that the screen turns on when I open the case.  Of course I love the Otterbox drop/shock protection, it gives me peace of mind when my daughter uses the ipad.  Otterbox has been the best brand of cases I've tried as far as drop protection.The only thing I do not like is there is no screen protector included.  So when the case is open, if my daughter drops the ipad, the screen could get scratched.  I can easily buy a screen protector, I just thought it would be nice if one was included with this case as well.Otherwise I have no complaints, I really love this case and will definitely use it.

My daughter was delighted with these when they arrived, but I was slightly disappointed.  They are the perfect size for little ones, and if Mom and Dad use binoculars, all the better - kids will have fun using their binoculars along with Mom and Dad.They are lightweight and easy to carry, and the neck strap comes apart if pulled on sharply, for safety.  There are soft rubber rings around the eye openings to be gentle on little eyes.The only reason I was disappointed was because I did not think the magnification was very good.  It only magnifies a small amount.  I think the key is to remember that these are only a "toy" not real binoculars.  If you keep that in mind you won't be disappointed.

I was a little nervous that I wouldn't like these bars, but they are really good!  They taste very chocolately, and would be great for a sweet snack, or even breakfast on the go.  I'd say they taste mostly like oatmeal and chocolate.  There is no aftertaste from the brown rice syrup, sometimes brown rice syrup does that, but not with this bar.I love the simple ingredients, I love that they are gluten free, I love the 10 grams of protein (keeps me full longer) and of course they taste great.  I would definitely recommend these. :)

This is a beautiful pair of earrings, about 2 inches from top to bottom, very easy to notice on my ears.  They feel well made and good quality when I hold them in my hand, however they are easy to bend out of shape.They come in a pretty blue box and would make a lovely gift for a reasonable price.They would look nice with blue jeans and also with an evening gown, in my opinion.I only have one problem with them - I expected them to look like they do in the main picture above.  However, when they are on my ears they do not 'lay' that way.  They turn to the side, so that the most attractive view of the earrings is actually slightly from the side.  When you look straight in a mirror they do not look the way they do in the above photo, you see more of a 'side view' from the front.Overall I think they are beautiful earrings at a reasonable price and would be a nice gift as well.

I love these expanding folders!  I find it helpful to have a different folder for a different category or type of paperwork, for instance, all of my young daughter's records/important papers go in one of them, all bank/loan info goes in another one, etc.  I do office work for a living and love these files for office categories.  They look so much better than a huge "to-do" box!This particular one is very useful and also very pretty - love the colors!I would recommend these to anyone needing to organize paperwork.

We have read all of the books in the Captain No Beard series so far.  My daughter loves the colorful pictures in all of them, however this book is perhaps the cutest story of them all, in my opinion.There's another new crew member - baby Zack, and he really wants to "help".  But his helping causes problems among the crew.  Captain No Beard needs to find a job for Zack.  Everyone needs to have an important job and uniting the crew is more important than personal preference.  It's a very good life lesson for all of us.I received a copy of this book for review purposes, and I would recommend this entire series for parents and children to read together.

My daughter and I have enjoyed all the books in this series so far.  The pictures are bright and colorful, and the language is simple and yet educational.This newest book about China was particularly interesting to me because there is a lot that I don't know about China, so it taught me something too.  I appreciated the sections about history and about opening the way for people from other countries to visit China.There are pronunciation guidelines for harder words and a glossary in the back.I did find one or two typos in the first few pages, for instance an "a" was missing and the word "in" was missing, but I did receive a sample of this product for review, so there is a chance that the typos were fixed after my copy was made.Overall I would recommend this book and this series for parents and children to read together, I think it would be a great series for home schooling families as well.

This is a brightly illustrated book that is sure to grab little ones' attention right away.  My daughter was interested immediately.  The book aims to help children understand what being multi-racial means.  The little girl Sofia explains that her dad is chocolate and her mom is vanilla and she and her brother are 'chocolate mixers'.  She realizes this while she is mixing chocolate syrup with vanilla soy milk.  The book ends with a very positive message about how we all are a mixer of some kind or another and we are all special just the way we are.I would recommend this book to any young child, regardless of race.  It will help them understand the world a little bit better.(I received a sample of this book for review purposes.)

This stick on light is a great idea, I love that you can reposition it if you accidentally put it in the wrong spot, and you can move it to another place entirely.I am using it to light up a dark corner of my desk, but I would also put this inside a dark closet or cabinet.  It would make a good nightlight too.  I can think of many possible uses for this.  The black and white design goes with most decor.This uses AAA batteries, and was fairly easy to put together - except I did have some trouble figuring out how to access the battery compartment.  Otherwise it was quick and simple.Now that it is installed, I just tap it to turn it on and tap it to turn it off.  It is very bright.I would recommend this light for anyone looking for a quick and easy way to light up dark areas of the home without using screws or nails or brackets.

I have been wanting an invisible fence for quite some time so I was delighted to test out this product.  First of all, it would have been very hard for us to install an underground wire on our property due to the placement of the paved driveway - we would have had to dig up the driveway or put the wire over the driveway, neither of which is a nice option.  So I LOVE that this works without digging a trench.  It's also nice for people who rent an apartment and are allowed to have a dog, or for those who travel a lot, because you can take this with you much more easily than a wired fence.Setup was fairly easy following the instructions provided.  We have a large yard but it is a little narrow from side to side so the dog's range does go onto our one neighbor's property a bit.  But we have been working on training our dog to stay off their property anyway, and he listens pretty well - if he is going to roam away he's going to roam to the other side of our property.We do have some sloping on our property and some trees, so we have one or two areas without much signal, but for the most part when our dog reaches the boundary he stops running and turns around, or at least he stops running and doesn't go any further.I think this is a great tool to use in addition to personally training your dog - it reinforces the boundaries that you have already been trying to teach him/her.I also like the warning inside the house that the dog has crossed the property line.  I used to go outside all the time with the dog but now that I have a child I can't always go out with him, so the warning system gives me peace of mind.

This is a very pretty bracelet for a reasonable price, and would make a great gift or stocking stuffer.It measures about 8 inches around and would work for teenage girls and most adult women as well.  It can be difficult to put it on and take it off with one hand and requires some practice.It might bend after a few times of wearing it.But even in spite of that...it is very lovely and it is hard to find such a lovely bracelet for the price.(I received a sample of this product for review purposes and was pleasantly surprised at how nice it is.)

This is very cute and perfect for my daughter, who has just started to want to wear necklaces and bracelets.  She loves Hello Kitty and she likes opening and closing the locket.  She can't tell time yet but this will be useful as she gradually learns to read a clock.The chain is quite long, about 26 inches, so would work well for an adult too or a teenage girl, as long as they like Hello Kitty.It feels heavy and well made, I don't know how long the watch will keep working but for right now it's working great.I received a sample of this product for review purposes and my daughter and I are pleased with this so far.

When I first saw these animals I couldn't quite figure out what they were supposed to be, but my daughter loves them and immediately grabbed them to play with.  I've come to the conclusion that these are multi-purpose toys.  They look like dusting mitts and would be great for children to help parents clean around the house.  They would also work well in the bathtub with body wash as a scrubber.  They could simply be used as a cuddly toy.  And I think they could even be dog toys if your dog likes plush toys like mine does.I received a sample of this product for review purposes and I like that they have multiple possible uses.  They are cute and colorful too.

Pros: This cooker was easy to use as a slow cooker. The directions were clear and the knobs are easy to adjust and set up for cooking. Clean-up was a breeze. The ceramic coated slow cooker pot is virtually non-stick and lifts easily out of the heated portion of the cooker to be washed and replaced for further use.Cons: It is almost too big for a family of two. It is set up to roast meat and to be used for baking as you would use an oven. I'm not sure if those features will ever be used, so they may be extraneous features and will have only added cost.In the end, I think this "cooker" is a nice addition to my kitchen equipment and I will enjoy using it for large batches of slowly simmered soups and stews or a tender piece of pork shoulder. Last night's Slow Cooker Ropa Vieja (cookinginstilettos) certainly was a good choice. I recommend the dish if you are looking for a spicy and interesting entree to try out your new slow cooker from Black and Decker.

It is not a mattress pad - it's a mattress cover that goes under a mattress pad.  So for that simple fact seems a bit labor intensive.  It is soft but since you aren't sleeping on it, that probably doesn't matter. Seems a little small, so concern would be that after multiple washings, it's going to be tight on the mattress, however since it has to fit under a mattress pad - maybe that's not a bad thing.  Not sure anyone has any major allergies here, so it seems like another step to making the bed more than anything since it's not a mattress pad. However, since it is soft, I could use it has a sheet over the mattress pad so I'm thinking that's what we will use it for.

This is one of those things that "just works," at least once you figure out how to get it going.  I'm very happy with it once I was able to get it set up.Because my Wi-Fi access point is located in one end of my house, there was low signal strength at the other end and on the lower level.  This made it hard to roam around the house and get reliable Wi-Fi access everywhere - perhaps a bit like traveling around with your cell phone and encountering those maddening areas with low signal strength just when you needed it.  Because most of my house is finished, it is very difficult to run ethernet cables to other parts of the house, thus ruling out using wires to put in another access point.  I had considered getting a "range extender" of some type, but frankly I have been totally worn out by dealing with all of the problems of managing a home network of growing size and problems, and thus was leery of adding something like this that would likely only add to the complexity.But I decided to give this Linksys a shot.  It seemed simple enough (like so many things these days that turn out to be anything but).  Right out of the box I just couldn't get it to work at all.  The device was recognized by my network, but just wouldn't allow other devices to connect.  The included instructions were scanty to say the least, and the manufacturer's web site offered no help.  Very frustrating!Then I read through all of the other reviews here on Amazon, and found one that mentioned several configuration details that were needed to make it work.  Bingo!  It suddenly started working just as it should, providing a strong Wi-Fi signal at the other end of my house.  That was several weeks ago, and now I've just forgotten that this device is there doing its job.  That is what quality is all about.Since it has been several weeks since I set it up, I don't remember the exact review or instructions, but from memory I think it had to do with setting either this device or my normal wireless access point to use WPA2 (not WPA) with AES (not TKIP) encryption.Once I got it working ... it just works.Update 8/15/2015I had to unplug this device and stop using it.  Why?  Although it did provide increased signal strength in parts of my home and property that are far away from my access point, it also caused big problems.  Although it seems to work fine under most circumstances, every so often all of the wireless devices connected to it would just lose connectivity to the rest of my home network, for no obvious reason.What seems to be happening is every so often this device will start doing strange things in my wireless network.  One symptom of this is that some devices will start reporting IP address conflicts for no apparent reason.  I have used inSSIDer on a laptop to monitor wireless activity, and every so often it shows odd things that come from the MAC address(es) associated with this device (there are several).  This includes MAC addresses such as 00:00:00:00:00:00 and other weird things.I have tried various fixes to this problem, including assigning a fixed IP address to the device, but to no avail.  After a number of my wireless devices just went mute again today, I finally unplugged this device - and the problems went away.This device seems like a good solution to providing broader wi-fi coverage, but it's problematic, and thus I am not using it anymore.

The longer I have this feeder the more I am impressed by it. It is easy to clean and refill and my hummingbirds seem to go through more syrup than with any other hummingbird feeder, thus it is a success from their point of view and mine.With other feeders the bugs, mostly bees, infiltrate the openings and float in the syrup rendering it unusable within days. I have never had a feeder emptied until this one. I just went to clean it and refill it and it was empty, nothing more than a drop of sugar water came out. This has never happened with my clear glass hummingbird feeder nor my beloved Droll Yankee hummingbird feeder. Normally, I have to dump most of the syrup and start over in just a few days due to the aforementioned bug infiltration and also mold issues. This syrup had been in the feeder for almost a week and there was only one tiny spot of black mold in the edge of the basin and not one bug.I conclude that there is something about the red color that filters the sunlight and deters mold and the openings are big enough for hummingbird beaks but not for bugs.I will be getting more of these to surround myself with the beauty of hummingbirds wherever I go.

Having read - and enjoyed - the author's earlier book "Russia Against Napoleon", I looked forward to reading his account of events in Russia a century later.Unfortunately, either things in Russia became much more dull in that century, or the author's writing style did since his last book, because I found this book to be a difficult read - the opposite of a "page turner", so to speak.Perhaps that is because the focus of this book is on the various Russian diplomats and all the details of their arcane political intrigues during the crucial period just before the Great War.  This certainly does provide good additional insights into how things came about during that tumultuous period - mostly from the Russian viewpoint - but for me, it was it was just too much static detail to be enjoyable, and I had to force myself to keep reading.What's good is that the author clearly has done a prodigious amount of new research into Russian archives to expose more of the thinking and details of the Russian diplomats of the period.  I would give that aspect of the book a 5 star rating, but for its appeal and readability for the general reader, I'll go with 3 stars.

So far this shirt has been tough enough to stand up to anything a four-year-old boy can throw at it, yet is lightweight and feels nice on the skin. The latter aspect is very important to my little guy, who is *very* sensitive to any tags or things that itch -  and this shirt earned his stamp of approval for being good in that regard.It washes and dries easily with no wrinkling. White is a tricky color for a four-year-old boy who goes through every knee in his jeans but so far it has cleaned perfectly.  Sizing seemed accurate.UPDATE 8/15/2015This shirt seem indestructible.  Despite everything that a little boy could do to a WHITE shirt, it has survived - perfectly!  It remains a favorite of a little boy, and also his mother.  What more could one ask for???

I am very fond of this La Cuisine 5 quart pan. It may very well become my go-to pan. It has been thoughtfully constructed and is easy to clean. After using the pan I simply let it cool, fill it with hot water and let it sit, perhaps overnight. In the morning it cleans easily (like Teflon but better because it isn't).It is large enough to boil pasta, make soup or stew and roast meat but also will do small tasks like poaching two fillets of salmon.It is a heavy pan, so if lifting is an issue you would want to be aware of its weight but it is no heavier than my French copper chef pans and its weight presents no issue for me.Anyway, I've been using it quite a bit since I got it, so that's a good thing.  Maybe I've already "gone" to my new go-to pan?

Having listened to nothing more than the built-in speakers of my flat-panel Samsung TV, I was eager for an improved sonic experience.  The Polk Audio Soundbar did indeed provide *much* better sound than the TV's speakers (unsurprisingly).  Overall it's a nice product that is easy to set up and use, with a few tiny quirks that are typical of add-on products of this type.  The real question for any prospective purchaser is whether the improved sound is worth the steep price tag.The Good:- Very easy to set up and begin using.  The instructions are minimal - they tell you to connect the audio cord, but just assume that you will also know to hook up the power cords - but what you need to do is simple and logical:  Plug both the sound bar and the subwoofer into power, connect your TV's audio to the soundbar (using either optical or traditional - both types of cord are included), and you're good to start listening although you'll want to perform a few more adjustments after that.- The subwoofer connects to the soundbar wirelessly, which is very nice because it eliminates a cord and allows much greater freedom of location for the subwoofer.- The soundbar was perfectly sized to go with my Samsung TV, and looks good with it.- The soundbar comes with its own tiny remote control, but you can easily train it to respond to your existing remote (at least for volume control).- And the sound is much improved over that of the TV's built-in speakers.The quirks:- By default, the bass volume was very high, so that needed immediate tuning because I don't like house-rattling bass.  But the subwoofer really can pump out the bass if that is to your taste.- The soundbar turns itself off and on automatically when it senses a signal from the TV's audio.  When you turn the TV on, this can take several seconds, leaving an uncomfortable period when you wonder if something is wrong with the audio.- You'll want to turn off the audio on your TV's built-in speakers so you can enjoy what this unit can do.  But at least on my Samsung TV, doing this causes an annoying on-screen message saying "Function not available" every time I press the volume control buttons with the TV's internal speakers disabled.  This not Polk's fault, but an example of some of the quirkiness that happens when you mix products from different manufacturers together.Overall I'm quite pleased with the Polk Audio soundbar, but I'm not sure that the amount of improvement in audio quality is worth the price of the unit.  But if you do value good sound, you might have a different opinion.

I've relied upon my wonderfully lightweight and durable Oreck vacuum to keep my carpets clean for 15+ years, but have only used outside services to shampoo them.  Being very overdue for another shampoo, this new Oreck Revitalize seemed like it might be the perfect solution.When it arrived, I spent 2 minutes unpacking and assembling it, and a few hours later had carpets that were visibly much cleaner than they had been in several years.  I was amazed by the amount of very dirty water that accumulated in the dirty liquid tank, and was very happy to pour it out, knowing that all that muck was no longer in my carpets.So the Revitalize accomplished my objective, but I did have a few difficulties with it along the way that you should be aware of:* You need to follow the directions very carefully, especially with regard to technique you use when moving the unit back and forth over the carpet.  In particular, it is very important to make a "back and forth" pass while applying the liquid detergent (or water rinse), then immediately make another back and forth pass over the same area to most effectively let the unit suck up the applied liquid.  This is because the liquid is applied as a mist that will quickly (in seconds) evaporate or soak into the carpet, thus preventing you from sucking it (and the dirt) back up.  Don't be tempted to apply liquid over a larger area and then come back even 20 seconds later to pick it up - because you won't get much.* The tank that contains the dirty liquid that is picked up from the carpet has a filter screen in it.  You *must* keep that screen clean at all times, or the vacuum pick-up action will be greatly reduced.  It is very easy to pop the tank off and remove any carpet fibers that accumulate.* If any of your carpet is shedding fibers to any degree, this unit won't work very well if at all, mostly for the preceding reason.  The carpet in one of my 3 carpeted rooms is like this, and was a near disaster.  This unit has some pretty effective scrubbers that pulled up significant amount of loose fibers that plugged the filter over and over, plus permeated the the whole scrubbing and pick-up system.  Obviously that piece of carpet now needs to be replaced, but the Revitalize was almost defeated by it.* Dealing with the preceding item caused me to learn that this unit is (mostly) very easy to clean out and wash up after use. All of the parts except one short hose come off to allow them to be washed out so you can put the unit away in clean condition.  The only difficulty is that the main plastic pick-up unit is held in by 2 small Phillips-head screws that need to be unscrewed and refastened every time time you need to wash out that particular part.  Besides needing to find a screwdriver to do this (the only time you need any kind of tool), those screws are easy to lose when washing the part (I almost lost one down the drain); it is very likely that those screw heads will be stripped before too long; and having to unscrew and refasten the screws all the time was the most annoying aspect of using this unit.  If Oreck had used fasteners that were larger and could be worked with just your fingers (something like wing-nuts), it would have been much better.* Although it carries the Oreck name, this product subjectively does not seem to be of the same quality and durability as my trusty 15 year old Oreck vacuum.  Maybe that is OK, since I don't expect to shampoo my carpets nearly as often as I vacuum them.  I haven't checked, but it is also possible that new Oreck vacuums have changed over the years as well.  And unlike this Revitalize unit, nowhere on my vacuum does it say "Hecho in China."* Don't expect the Revitalize to produce the miraculous "clean paths" through dirty carpet that you see in commercials for carpet cleaners - and even on Oreck's web site for this unit!  That is not what happens, and is overly-dramatic to the point of being false advertising.  This product *does* pick up a lot of dirt and *does* make your carpets cleaner, albeit in a less dramatic fashion, so Oreck should skip the drama.Despite the foregoing items, I am generally happy with the Revitalize, and my carpets are too.  Recommended.By the way, the Revitalize was *so* easy to use that even a man could use it!  And did, at my house.  :-)

The premise of this book fascinated me, so I had to read it.As a child, I was raised in one of the major churches that preached revealed religion via "faith" (i.e. just believe what you are told), but as I matured I became an agnostic because I simply could not accept what I had been taught as a child.  I have remained uncertain about how things came about in the Universe, and how it could have just "happened," and could there be a god.  This book seemed to offer a possible answer, so it intrigued me.This book provoked a variety of thoughts and emotions for me, thus I judge the book a very worthwhile read.I fully admit that I did not (and still do not) grasp all of what the author is trying to say, so I need to read it again.  I can't say that about very many books.Some of the author's ideas are fascinating, while others I reject.  I will leave other readers to decide for themselves on these, and won't attempt to review all of them here.One of the ideas I liked the best was her description of "god" as an "emergent" phenomenon.  Perhaps I don't get out enough, but I was not familiar with the whole concept of "emergence."  But now that I have been introduced to the concept by this book, many (non-religious) things are much more clear.  Simply put, an emergent phenomenon is one that is literally greater than the sum of its parts, e.g. a living organism is composed of unthinking atoms that individually just obey the laws of physics, but when aggregated into a human body, a totally new and wonderful thing emerges - somehow.  The author's premise is that god is also emergent, which is quite interesting.  I am still trying to decide if I buy this or not, but I *am* still thinking about it.Overall, the author firmly believes that the laws of physics do apply everywhere, and that "god" must also obey them.  So if you don't agree with that, some or most of the book will be a tough sell.  But she makes a convincing case that this might be true.Perhaps my only disappointment was that if "god" truly is an emergent phenomenon, that still does not explain "the beginning."  But perhaps god did not create the universe.  Perhaps there never was a beginning, and just an endless circle. More to think about.None of this can be proven or disproven, but at least here we have a coherent body of thought that doesn't rely upon blind faith in a revealed religion of some type.Recommended.

I admit that I got this just for the novelty of being able to take infra-red pictures.  Years ago I experimented with infra-red B&W film in my camera, so I wanted to play around with the modern - and MUCH better - equivalent.Taking pictures of my dog, spouse, and kids was fun, with the resulting false-color pictures interesting to everyone.Then I starting looking at what else it could do.  I found two very useful things:1. It showed weak spots in my house's insulation.  Almost like having X-ray vision, it showed where many of the rafters and studs were, which was merely entertaining.  But then I found some unexpected cold spots in the wall that I had not been aware of.  These turned out to be places where insulation had settled or been disturbed, several of which I was able to make better as a result of knowing where and how bad they were.2. I have built some "quiet" PCs in very small cases, and have been concerned about adequate cooling of the components.  With this device, I was able to immediately see which components were hot and roughly how hot, and how that changed with various configurations of internal components and cooling fans.  That helped me come up with arrangements that ensured better cooling, promoting longer component life.So - the device that started out for me as a toy turned into a useful tool.  That I still enjoy using as a toy as well.

This wooden figurine set is attractive to my grandsons who are ages 3.5 and 2, each for their own reasons. The almost 4 year-old loved setting up the village and felt an attraction to the wooden figures thanks to an animated show on television whose main characters actually resembled the village pieces including the knight and the dragon. He was beyond delighted when he realized he could also set up his wooden railroad around the village and run the train around the perimeter.The two-year-old was much too young for the set, or so it seemed to me. His delight was in knocking it down as fast as the 4 year-old could build it including the railroad track that surrounded the village. All of the sturdy pieces survived the rough treatment and I know in time the two-year-old will enjoy playing with it as much as he did tearing it down.

For me, this book was a mixed bag. Perhaps that is because it is presented as series of essays, each of which addresses some topic related to the Civil War, but that don't all support the book's subtitle of "Why the Civil War Still Matters."  Much (too much?) of the book keeps coming back to slavery; the better parts give us some insight into what Lincoln had to deal with; while some other chapters are anecdotal looks at a few very specific characters such as McClellan and Farragut.While reading the book, I kept expecting to finally come upon the answer to why the Civil War still matters, but I didn't find it.What I did find:* Some quite interesting glimpses of how very different things were in the 1860s.  At one point, Lincoln, Seward and Hay *walked* over to Gen. McClellan's house, waited 90 mins to see him only to find out that he had gone to bed without seeing them, and then the 3 of them walked back to the White House.  Can you imagine any of that happening today???  What a different world.  I enjoyed reading some of those tales of how different things were in the past.* A constant emphasis on slavery by the author, to the point where it becomes the over-arching topic of the book.  Of course, the existence of slavery was a significant political issue in the 1850s and 60s, but my amateur understanding of the era was that states' rights was the primary issue.  Slavery was not illegal at that time, and only became so during the war, and not totally because of just the moral issue.  The author spends some time discussing without totally dismissing, the incredible thesis put forth by some others that the slaves themselves did (or could have done) most of the heavy lifting that led to the abolition of slavery, which totally devalues the efforts of the 750,000 Americans who died fighting over this issue.* Most of one essay goes on and on with author's disagreement with Mark Neeley's "The Fate of Liberty: Abraham Lincoln and Civil Liberties", who he repeatedly takes to task on a variety of points.  I get it - the author doesn't agree with Neeley.  Next chapter, please.* Some other insight into a general political observation that when whomever those in power veer too far away from the center, it often provokes an opposite reaction from others, as though Newtonian physics also applies in politics.  (It's too bad that our current and previous president don't understand this - if they had read this book and got this message, our country would be much better off that it is today.)* Related to the last item, one realizes after reading this book just how much profound political disagreement and polarization there was in the USA in the middle of the 19th century.  As we reflect on how polarized things are becoming today, perhaps we should realize that extreme polarization led to war in the past.  The author doesn't mention this, although it might have been useful in helping to support the book's subtitle.My verdict:  This book passed my key test of being worthwhile because I learned at least one useful thing from it.  But I only give it 3 stars because it seems like a random set of disconnected essays that fixate on slavery, but that left me wondering exactly why the Civil War still matters, in the author's opinion.

Like so many others here, I was about to purchase TurboTax Deluxe again this year as I have for many years, when I made the same unpleasant and terribly disappointing discovery that many others have reported here.To the VP from TurboTax who said:"One of the challenges of selling on Amazon (and other sites) is that we don't know who purchases our product so we can't differentiate between new and returning customers like you. We know that some of our customers won't be able to use the same TurboTax product as last year. So purchase the product you normally get and then call one of my team members ... so they can get you the upgrade necessary to meet your needs.By the way, if we did this for revenue purposes we would have targeted a segment of our customer base much larger than the 2-4% who are affected by this change."I say:"One of the challenges of buying things from your company is that we don't know how and when you will make arbitrary and inexplicable changes to your product for returning customers like us.  We now know that you don't care that some of your customers won't be able to use the same TurboTax product as last year.  We *did* want to purchase the product we normally got - and then actually GET the product that we have normally gotten - without now having to call and beg for it.By the way, why did you target *any* segment of your customer base for this treatment?  If not for revenue, then was it just to confuse them, or to annoy them, or to intentionally drive them away?"It seems that Mr. Scrooge is now in charge at TurboTax.  Bah, Humbug!We consumers can only vote with our dollars.  I have just used mine to vote for Block Financial H&R Block Tax Software 14 Deluxe + State.

I've used several different types of pedometers and heart rate monitors, so was attracted by this new unit from Epson because it can be used for both purposes.After several weeks of use, I have concluded that it has some very nice characteristics, a few things that could be better, and one serious drawback.The device itself is a black plastic wrist band that measures your pulse through the use a of green light on the underside.  The face of the device has a string of colored LEDs that light up in various patterns that tell you various things, and can also convey some of the same info via a vibration mode.  The device is rechargeable, using a propriety recharger that is included.  The recharger needs to plug into a USB port, and does not come with a brick to plug into line voltage.The real user interface is intended to be an iOS app that you run on your iPhone and that you pair with the device via Bluetooth.  It's a nicely-designed app that can show your current heart rate, along with steps taken, equivalent distance traveled, and hours slept.  Not only does it show numerical values, but it can also show graphs so you can see your activity rate over time.What I liked:* The graphing mode in the iOS app.* The device itself is fairly nice looking.* The heart rate monitor seems to be quite accurate, yet does not require straps around your chest or other cumbersome things like I have used in the past.Things I was not so fond of:* The wrist band is hard to adjust, and to make it stay adjusted.  It has 12 holes (like on a belt) that you can use to adjust for wrist size, but every time I put it back on (you need to take if off for showering and for recharging), I struggle to get it adjusted back to the correct size.* The device itself is fairly thick, as is the buckle area, thus it (especially the buckle part on the bottom) frequently catches on shirt sleeves in an annoying way.* It has a feature that can alert you whenever you change from one activity "zone" or level to another.  It does this by a series of 5 vibrations and/or turning on the LEDs in a certain pattern or number.  I found that it would frequently vibrate and light up, both of which were very annoying when they happened while I was not exercising.  Fortunately you can turn both of those things off using the iOS app.* The iOS app includes a battery strength indicator, but it's not on the main screen and thus you have to take several steps to view it.  Given that you need to recharge the battery every few days, you need to keep an eye on battery strength, thus this indicator needs to in constant view instead of tucked away.* Setting up the iOS app and pairing it with the device required me to create an online account and supply an e-mail address, the process for which was cumbersome.  Having to divulge my e-mail address to yet another place also raises privacy concerns, what with all these companies getting hacked these days.* It's not the fault of this device, but you are encouraged to wear it on the wrist of your "non-dominant" hand.  Unfortunately, that's where I usually wear a wristwatch.  Maybe I need one device that is both a watch AND a pulse meter.  Apple?* In the past I have most often used a heart rate monitor to watch my heart rate while exercising.  The devices I have used in the past have been cumbersome, but have also allowed me to watch my rate in real time.  This device does make provision for that through a specific screen in the iOS app (or also by setting up the vibration trigger to go off when entering/exiting a certain level), but using the iOS app to do that requires you to have your iPhone in front of you, and leads to the next item -The deal-breaker:* Once I started using this device paired with my iPhone 4S, battery usage on my iPhone went up alarmingly - to the point where I had to charge it at least daily.  Before using it, my iPhone battery would last many days.  I had to start turning off Bluetooth to get around that problem, but of course then the device doesn't talk to the app on my iPhone.  Unless I can find some solution for this problem, I'll probably stop using this device.

If you are into Apple devices, you can never have power cords for them.This is a nice little set, with a USB Lightning cord and a car charger plug that you can use together or separately.Why this product is good:* Very reasonable price, especially for the combo.* It works.  That should be a "given," but my experience with non-Apple cords has not been all that great.  Quite a few of them don't work, or stop working soon, or break.* The little LED on the car charger lets you know when the outlet is "hot."  My vehicles have a variety of outlets, some of which remain hot when I turn the car off and some of which don't - and I can never remember which is which.  I suppose having the little green LED remaining on while you walk away from the car might seem odd, but it would probably take several years to drain a car battery from such little current draw.* AND - This actually *does* work with my iPad.  Some chargers do, and some don't - because of the additional power required by the iPad, which is quite a bit more than your iPhone or other smaller devices require.I only found one drawback, which is that the car charger only has a single USB outlet.  One of my cars only has a single power outlet, thus plugging in this car charger does not allow me to plug in anything else (unlike some chargers which have 2 outlets).I like this set, and am considering getting more.

I liked this book, and enjoyed reading it.I have never been in the military, and cannot imagine being in harm's way as the author and thousands of others have been, thus this book provides a real-life glimpse into that world for those like myself who haven't been there.Of course, what makes this story special is the fact that the author was not just an average soldier going through a typical deployment.  If he had been a cook or logistics person for example, I'm sure he could still have written about some of the aspects of being in Afghanistan, but what makes this soldier's story special is the extraordinary set of circumstances he experienced, his particular role as a sniper, and especially what he did.I admit that reading about someone whose job is killing other humans does raise some uncomfortable questions, but this is a story about war, which is a sad reality of human existence.  The author clearly views his mission with the professional detachment that is clearly necessary for the job, and the reader must accept that approach.This is a "soldier's story," the autobiography of an enlisted man who carries out missions assigned from above, and thus is told purely from his point of view as is usual for an autobiography.  You will learn what he is seeing, hearing, thinking ... and sometimes even smelling.  Being in a fire-fight can't be fun, but the author tells about each of the major incidents he participated in with calmness and matter-of-fact clarity, without unnecessary embellishment.Because we are experiencing the events as described by the author, there are lot of things that one is left wondering about.  It's not a fault of the book, but you won't get any background for the larger picture in which the author operated or what others were thinking or doing.  There are a number of mysteries that remain mysterious (what WAS that enormous hole his friend fell into, anyway?), and not much explanation of the weapons, tactics, equipment, or units.But perhaps the biggest unexplained mystery of the book was why was the author able to rack up such a large number of confirmed kills, when (as I understand) the majority of other soldiers deployed there (including other snipers) had few, if any, opportunities to do so?  Is it because of his skill in marksmanship, or his being in the right place and the right time many times, or both ... or something else?These things did not detract from the story, but I did find myself hoping for an appendix or afterword in which a few of these things had been explained for the benefit of the curious such as myself.One other thing that became clear was that Afghanistan is a place that I would not have cared to visit.  Besides Taliban trying to kill you, there is the blast-furnace heat, raw sewage in ditches, and - something that the author delicately mentions - some unspeakable local Afghan sex habits.Near the end, as he talks about returning from his last deployment, it is interesting to read about how he has to make the transition from being in a combat zone where one has to be constantly ready to fight, to being back in civilian life in the US, where the combat reflexes are no longer appropriate.  I would think that would be a very difficult transition for soldiers to make.A very interesting read.

This is a nice-looking scale, but one that I wouldn't recommend and would not purchase again because the manufacturer doesn't stand behind their own product.  Read on.My scale came in a box that presumably was sealed at the factory in China, but after I opened it and installed the 2 AAA batteries in the compartment on the underside of the scale, I noticed that the cover for the battery compartment was missing.  The cover is likely a small piece of plastic that is not attached to the scale but that should snap in place to hold the batteries in place under the scale after they have been installed.  I triple-checked the box and packing material, but clearly the battery cover had not been included.I then used the customer service section on the manufacturer's web site to report the problem, and ask for a replacement battery cover.  They responded the next day, asking me to send them photos of the front and back of the scale (which I did), and told me that they would "send a replacement" in a few weeks (it was not clear if this would have been a replacement battery cover or an entire scale).After receiving the pictures (which clearly showed the missing cover), I received the following response:"We do not have battery covers as replacement parts. Lost parts are not covered under the warranty and since you received it from Amazon they would have to contact us to get the replacement sir. Sorry for your inconvenience.Thank you for contacting Taylor Precision Products."Maybe my scale was the only one for which the factory forgot to include the battery cover.  Or maybe many of them have this problem.  But in any case, you won't get any help from the manufacturer.Regarding the product itself, I got it to replace a 20 year old Accutech digital scale that still works fine but looks a bit outdated.  Both scales give exactly the same readings, so that is reassuring.  From a visual standpoint, this scale is sleek and modern, which goes better with my bathroom decor.This scale can be set to read out in pounds, kilograms, or (for the UK market) stone & pounds (a stone is 14 lbs).  This is the only user control.One quirk that I had trouble getting used to is that it is almost impossible to read the digits when you are standing on the scale - they are barely visible from that angle.  But when you step off of the scale, they suddenly become much more readable at that viewing angle.  My old Accutech with red LEDs gave an immediate reading that I could see while standing on the scale, while with this scale you have to hop on to it and wait a few seconds for the display to start blinking, then hop off and look at the reading.Other usage notes:You need to step on the scale briefly to have it self-calibrate the first time you use it.  No big deal, except that you need to do this every time you move the scale.You must place the scale on a hard surface.  It won't work right on carpet, because it has 4 small feet on the bottom.  On my scale, the 4 feet do not stand level on the floor, thus the scale tends to rock ever so slightly while sitting on the floor.  This is not a significant problem either, but was noticeable to me.Bottom line:  I would not recommend this product due to the indifferent attitude of the company towards a customer who reported a problem with their product.Additional note:  In fairness to the manufacturer, I followed up with them *3* times to further explain the problem and tell them what I needed help with, but to no avail.  While it is commendable that they have a customer service department that actually does respond to customer inquires, that doesn't do much good if they are unwilling to help correct a problem with their product.

I'm not an architect, but have had a long-standing amateur interest in the design of things, especially houses.  I know that Mr Ching has written lots of books on architecture, so I was hoping and expecting this book to provide me with some new insights and ideas on the design of buildings.Unfortunately, it didn't.What you get here is a thick book that seems to be a catalogue of architectural concepts, accompanied by *lots* of architectural drawings by Mr Ching, mostly of famous buildings, that are offered as illustrations of the listed concepts.  This approach really left me cold and uninformed.Perhaps if I were an architect, I would somehow understand the value of this and thus appreciate it more.  But I would also assume that someone trained in architecture would already know and understand these concepts.  So I can't actually figure out what this book is for, or who the audience is.Despite the large volume of drawings, this is not an "idea book" from which one could find inspiration for designing your own house (as I am doing).And in the end, this book failed my ultimate test of value:  Did I learn one enduring or useful thing from it?  No.  Well, maybe that Mr Ching is good at making architectural drawings of famous buildings.I would contrast this to any of the books by Christopher Alexander, from whose books I feel that I learned what design is all about, and *why* various design elements make so much sense.If I had browsed this book in a physical bookstore, I would never have bought it.NOTE TO READERS 12/17/14When I published my 2-star review of this book, 5 people quickly rated my review as "unhelpful" while no people rated it as helpful.While I don't expect everyone to agree with my opinion, it really seems odd that there were SO many negative votes so quickly, especially given that no other review has gotten more than 2 votes of any kind so far, and nobody left any comments to explain why my comments were not helpful.Since I have absolutely no connection with the author, the publisher, or any of their possible competitors, I was not motivated by any purpose other than to write a frank review to help others who might consider spending money on this book.I will let others decide for themselves whether it seems there has been any ballot-box stuffing here to discredit a review that did not promote the sale of the book being reviewed.

This mirror really seems like a product from the past - back when things were solid, heavy, and substantial - as opposed to the cheap and flimsy articles we find in the stores today.  What a refreshing change, although one that is reflected in its price, which is also substantial.  You get what you pay for.The side of the mirror with 3X magnification is very nice, with no noticeable distortion.  This side is slightly concave, and provides just the right amount of magnification to see things on your face that you probably couldn't easily see in detail without magnification (this might be good or bad, depending upon what you are looking at!).The size of the mirror is just right - big enough to see as much of your face as you need to, without being so big that it takes up too much space.The design is simple and pleasantly attractive.Because it's constructed of lots of metal instead of plastic, it's just heavy enough to stay put and not be tippy, unlike cheaper and flimsier products.It doesn't have any built-in lighting, but that is consistent with its solid and simple design, and thus no cords or batteries are needed.I really like this mirror.

Having used an Epson B11B178011 Perfection V700 Photo Scanner since 2006 to scan over 10,000 photos and slides, I decided to try this unit as a potential "more modern" replacement.  Verdict:  I'm going to keep using the V700 for reasons that I will get to in a minute.The V700 is top-notch photo, film and slide scanner that I reviewed on January 21, 2007.  Despite giving it only 3 stars at the time due to some quirks, it has been a very reliable and flexible workhorse for the past 6 years, and I continue to use it for all of my photographic scanning.  Being that old, it uses fluorescent tubes for illumination, making it quite bulky by modern standards and also requires it to warm up for a period before use.  In contrast, the V370 uses LED technology for illumination and thus is only half the height of the V700 and has virtually no "warm up" delay.As a photo scanner, the V370 works fairly well and with one exception, produces scans of a quality that will be just fine for most people.  It also uses the same software and scanning concepts as the V700, so if you are used to the Epson way you can just carry on.It does have some things I didn't like:* The cover opens "sideways".  Every other flatbed scanner that I have or have owned has a cover that is hinged on the short axis and thus opens away from you if the scanner is positioned with the short axis facing you (which minimizes the amount of space it takes up on my desk).  But the V370 has the cover hinge on the long axis, on the right side.  This might be great for some people, but I find it unhandy, as will most right-handed people.* The V370 comes with only 1 insert or frame for holding slides and film (a combo unit that can hold 4 slides or 1 strip of 35mm film), while the V700 came with a set of 5 different types (of which I have used every one). Like the previous point, this will probably not be a problem for most people who typically don't have a lot of 6x6 negatives and other oddball formats to scan anymore.* Continuing a negative Epson tradition that I pointed out in my review of the V700, you can't buy replacement or additional film holders directly from Epson.  Their web site gives you a list of distributors to contact - Is that the best Epson can do in this age of buying online?* I should also mention that I could not get the drivers to install from the CD included with the product.  I am running Windows 7 64-bit and have never had trouble if this nature, but this CD would not autoplay, and when I tried to browse the CD and manually execute the setup.exe program, it would just hang.  Only after a considerable amount of fiddling around did I finally manage to get through the install process.  I was unable to determine if the problem was the Epson CD, some quirk with my computer, or the fact that I already had the Epson V700 software installed.But here's the real problem:  It doesn't always keep the edges of photos flat while scanning, thus you will likely see places on one or more edges of scanned photos where the photo is not totally pressed flat into contact with the glass of the scanner.  This causes some scans to have a slightly wavy edge and a tiny but wavering shadow in places.  Inspection of the scanner design shows the cause:  Because the V370 can scan both reflective materials (e.g. photos) and transparent materials (e.g. slides and film), it has illumination in both the base and the cover as would be expected.  For scanning photos, you slide an insert into the cover that provides a white background ... AND that should also press the scanned photo flat against the scanner glass.  Unfortunately, the white background is only backed by a plastic rectangle that does not support either the center of the background or its edges, thus fails to keep scanned material pressed flat against the glass.  I see no easy way for the user to fix this, but Epson could easily just re-design and replace this inexpensive item, which is not attached to the scanner unit itself.I also have a Canon LiDE 110 scanner on my desktop for doing quick document scans, so I had hoped that perhaps the V370 could have replaced *both* the V700 and the Canon, but that wasn't feasible either.  Without going into the details, the V370's drivers didn't work well with either of the document scanning applications I use.  I don't consider this a negative since the V370 is marketed as a photo scanner - I was just hoping to reduce the amount of stuff on my desktop.So I'm going to stay with my current scanning set-up of the V700 for photographic scan and the Canon LiDE for documents, and find a new home for the V370.

In the latest reports, Magnesium Threonate has been found to cross the blood brain barrier and is the only form of magnesium known to do this. Why is this important? Magnesium is necessary for a well-functioning brain, and if this form crosses the blood brain barrier it will feed your brain and keep your brain fighting fit.I am a great believer in taking magnesium and have taken magnesium threonate (trying MagMind and a couple of other brands of magnesium threonate, one by Doctor's Best and one by Life Extension) for about one year. I find three MagMind capsules per day to be the correct dosage and the least costly. Doctor's Best magnesium threonate has fewer fillers and additives but I found that I needed almost twice as much to equal the effects of MagMind and cannot justify the increased cost just to avoid fillers.I have not conducted a controlled study, so my results are purely anecdotal. My subjective feeling is my recall for names is  better than it was. I more easily do crossword puzzles; my recall for passwords seems better and I also sleep better with a mind that isn't so busy and find myself more relaxed during the day. I find it easier to lay claim to success when my legs and feet no longer cramp nor twitch but MagMind is really for the brain, magnesium chloride seems to work better for leg cramps, etc. so I take it was well.

I take 1000 mg of Krill oil every day to reduce inflammation and the resultant negative issues inflammation creates in a human body (such as high cholesterol, inflammatory arthritis). I decided to try Jarrow Krill oil to see if it compared favorably to my usual Mercola krill oil and, in the end, it did not.Upon opening the bottle of krill oil an acrid rotten fish smell hit me first. Then I noticed the size of the capsules which were not unlike tiny footballs. They weren't hard to take but they are much larger than the "Licaps" that Mercola's krill oil comes in and the dark color of the gelcap masques whatever stinky substance is inside the gelatin, maltitol and natural flavored capsule. There were no fishy after-burps but I have never experienced that with krill oil and would have been a cause to give this product one less star.In summation, I will keep buying my Mercola krill oil even though it is slightly more expensive (but only just) because the "Licaps" are small and easy to take and there is absolutely no fishy smell to be detected.

The human brain is one of the great wonders and mysteries of the Universe, perhaps surpassed only by the Universe itself. Memory is just one aspect of the brain, and thus we have a great subject here to study and read about.I judge books by whether they leave me with some thought or idea that I am likely to remember and use for years to come, and in that respect, I am certain this book will have succeeded, because it definitely provided me with several interesting new ideas.  (Although in the spirit of the book, I'll actually have to come back a few years from now and see what my memory has actually retained.)When my daughter was young, I used to jokingly accuse her of "remembering things that never happened," but after reading this book I now realize that that can actually happen due to the way memories work.One of the key insights I gained was that memories are not like pictures or videos that are stored away intact; instead, memories are reassembled by the brain as reconstructions, using lots of bits and pieces that have been stored away somehow. When a memory is "recalled," the veracity of that memory depends upon the reconstruction process and the quality of the selected bits and pieces, which can vary with each reconstruction and are subject to distortion and manipulation over time.Some of the other things you will learn about including why humans unable to remember things before a certain age, and how the past and the future (i.e. imagination) are related, among many other things.The author uses a number of long stories or descriptions of the reminiscences of others to illustrate several points, and while he does this on purpose, for me those passages were the weakest and least interesting parts of the book.  And the fact that the author is British becomes abundantly clear when he relies upon things that are unfamiliar to non-British readers to describe things, e.g. "about the size of Cafe Creme cigars", using Blu-Tack, taking a GCSE, or what happens on Bonfire Night - as he does frequently, although this is just a minor annoyance.Anyway, I enjoyed this book quite a bit for the new insights it provided me, although I now realize that even at this very moment I am having to rely upon the ability of my brain to (imperfectly) reassemble and reconstruct what I finished reading just minutes ago!

Having just gotten a new Canon G15 camera that has an HDMI output via a small HDMI jack on the camera, I got this cable thinking that it would be perfect for connecting the camera to my TV for viewing pictures and videos on a large screen.  Alas, it didn't fit on the camera end.It turns out that there are THREE sizes of HDMI connector today:- A large one called type "A" - this is the one found on TV's and monitors- A smaller one called type "C" or "mini HDMI" - this is found on many cameras such my Canon- An even smaller one called type "D" or "micro HDMI" - typically used on smartphonesThis cable is accurately described as a "HDMI to micro HDMI" cable.  I got it before I realized there were TWO types of small HDMI connector, which is my fault.  I am smarter now, and I hope that readers of this review will be, too.But is this situation really necessary?  I am a reasonably savvy person, yet was unfamiliar with the proliferation of HDMI connector types (which is very similar to the situation in the USB world, where we have standard, mini and micro connector types as well).  For the industry to create many variations is a bad thing, because it causes consumer confusion and more electronic waste, so besides blaming myself for ordering the wrong cable, I'll also assign a fair amount of blame on the electronics industry for allowing many variations to exist.And nowhere in the specs or 316-page instruction manual for my camera does it describe the connector as anything other than "HDMI", so I also put some of the blame on Canon for their careless lack of precision on something that makes a difference.So how to assign a rating to a cable that I cannot actually test?  The cable appears to be very nicely made by cable standards; it was accurately described; and it came in Amazon's nice "frustration free" packaging.  So I'll arbitrarily say 4 stars until such time as I can actually test it.

I had never heard of this product until a recent service job on my 2004 Ford F-250 Super Duty with 6.0 liter PowerStroke diesel.  I dropped it off one night at my mechanic for routine service the next day, and it sat outside on a cold night before my mechanic  worked on it. When I picked it up the next day, my mechanic commented on how roughly it started after sitting out in the cold overnight (this has not been unusual for this truck, but has never caused me any problems either); that the Navistar 6.0 liter diesels like the one in my truck have been known for this; and that he had treated several of them with Rev-X and it made them start more smoothly.I was a bit skeptical of how an oil additive could help with this, but thought I'd give it a try anyway.That was a few months ago, and I have to say (unscientifically) that I think my truck now starts more smoothly on cold mornings than before.  So I think the Rev-X is doing some good.  If it saves or prolongs the working life of an expensive engine, that can't be a bad thing.

Having read books about the "heroic" Antarctic explorers such as Scott, Mawson, Amundsen, Shackleton and others, but never paying much attention to what has happened on that continent since then, and never having been to Antarctica myself, this book provided an interesting glimpse of what has been happening there recently and what has changed over the past century.And what changes there have been.The men of 100 years ago who struggled to reach the South Pole by the only means possible at the time - months of arduous and sometimes fatal journeys on foot - would be astonished to find humans living there year-round today, with living comforts similar to home, and in constant contact with home.The author, who has spent considerable time on the Antarctic continent herself, takes us along with her on visits to the Amundsen Scott station at the Pole as well as a number of other of the outposts scattered across the continent, all of which are there for the purpose of doing scientific research (with one odd exception).  She tells us about having a drink with 800,000 year old ice cubes (presumably for the novelty, as one can't imagine too much demand for chilled beverages in Antarctica), how the atmosphere at each station various according to the nation that runs the station (naturally the French have the best food), how she went from hating penguins to loving them, and more - and colors the whole experience with stories from the heroic age of exploration.  You'll pick up a lot of little factoids, including learning that children and domestic animals are prohibited on the continent.Another of the things that has changed since the heroic age is that women are now present on the continent - as the author tells us over and over, as though this is a surprise.And of course a modern story about Antarctica and change wouldn't be complete if it didn't spend a lot of time pointing how "climate change" has affected the place over the past century, with lots of ice melting.I enjoyed the book for the modern glimpse it gives us of the Earth's most remote continent.  It was like reading a very long article in National Geographic - a magazine that I still enjoy reading from time to time.  It's not a bad thing, and I mention this more to describe the journalistic style than anything else.

You'll never find this book on a list of best-sellers because it's highly focused on a very specific and uncommon topic, but I really enjoyed reading it.  Maybe that's because I always like trains as a kid, and I'm an engineer by training.I don't know how many people in the whole world are experts in "the forensics of rail disasters," but there can't be very many, thus the author is a man of rare knowledge.  He's clearly an engineer through and through, because he writes in a terse, non-nonsense, right-to-the-point style.If you hated high school physics, you probably won't like this book.  While quite a number of actual train wrecks are used as case studies, this book is not a set of involved train wreck stories.  The author tells you just enough about each wreck to give you the situation, then jumps into the analysis which often involves Newtonian physics (mass, force, acceleration, etc).  To the author's credit, he does a great job of explaining all this in fairly simple terms that you don't need to be a scientist to understand.After reading this book, you will know a lot more about how railroads physically work - like so many things, it's a lot more complicated than it appears.  There's a LOT more to being a railroad engineer than just sitting the cab while twiddling with the throttle and blowing the horn occasionally.You will also learn a lot of obscure but interesting facts, such as:* How long was the longest train in the world?  (Hint: MUCH longer than a mile)* Why it's bad to have too many engines at the front of a train.* That the front and back ends of a train are rarely traveling at the same speed at the same time.* Why trains (in the past) often had to back up a ways before they could start moving forward.* That cars of different weights and lengths need to be put into a train in a certain order.* How railroads overcome the thermal expansion of steel rails to use long lengths of continuously-welded rail (instead of the bolted-together 39' sections of the past)* That fatal train wrecks can even happen to trains that only traveling a few miles per hour.* and LOT more!My enjoyment of reading Train Wreck was diminished slightly by the author's desire to express all measurements in both English and metric terms.  This is not so bad when he writes things like "a single locomotive moving at 25 mph (40 km/hr)", but it gets tiring after a while, and then there are some pretty horrific cases such as "Given a typical 74-foot (22.5-m)-long, 15-foot (4.5-m)-high, 10 foot (3-m)-wide, 415,000-lb (188,240-kg) locomotive design..."Which then leads to an embarrassing problem that I am sure was not the author's fault.  Whoever translated Fahrenheit temperatures into Celsius failed to realize the difference between absolute and relative temperatures.  For example, when talking about actual air temperature, it's correct to say something like "70F (21C)", but when giving a temperature *difference* this needs to be calculated differently or you end up with silly mistakes such as "One inch (2.54 cm) of steel heated 1F (-17C)..."  This latter mistake is made over and over throughout the book, which is a shame.But overall an interesting and rare book if you like trains and engineering.

I recently upgraded to this version from last year's version (2012).  I reviewed that product a year ago and found that it worked well for me although contained a number of niggling little issues, thus I called it "Quirken", but none of them has caused any real problem in a year of use.Compared to the 2012 version, the 2013 version looks and acts virtually identically except for a new "Mobile & Alerts" tab on the top bar.  Many years ago I bought an applet called "Pocket Quicken" for my Palm Pilot, and found it to be very useful to be able to enter and manage my expenses while away from home, even if that device did not have a wireless capability (you had to "hot sync" the device by connecting it to your PC every so often).  Sadly, Pocket Quicken and Palm Pilots went away, and I have missed the mobile capability ever since.  Will the 2013 version finally bring mobility back to Quicken?I installed this version from CD onto a PC that was had been running Quicken Deluxe 2012 on a 64-bit version of Windows 7. To ensure that I could undo the installation, I *first* set a system restore point by going to Control Panel > System > Advanced System Settings > System Protection > Create.  I highly recommend doing this anytime you are about to make a potentially risky system change, including installation of a critical software product.  If things go wrong, this allows you back out the change and restore your system to the way it was before you made the change.Impressions:* The installation process was quick (5 mins), simple and error-free.  It looks like it only installs a small amount of the product from the CD, because the longest part of the installation process was a download from the internet, supposedly to "get the latest version."* During the installation process, it installs a "Free Credit Report" icon on your desktop.  This is really annoying and unnecessary.* As usual for every one of the past many versions of Quicken, it converted my existing Quicken data to a new format, saving a copy of the existing data in case you need to go back.* And of course you need to "register" this copy with Intuit online.  I wish it could just pick up my previous registration data instead of making me re-enter it.* I ran through a variety of typical operations, all of which worked just fine for me.* I then clicked on the new Mobile & Alerts tab, which prompted me to create a Quicken Cloud account.  That was fine, but then it wanted me to select which of my accounts to enable for the cloud.  This part makes me a bit uneasy, because I have never allowed ANY of my financial data to leave my computer.  I'm just not certain I like that, but to try it out, I selected one of my accounts and proceeded.  Quicken then spent a few minutes uploading a lot of stuff from that account, and hopefully keeping it really safe.* Quicken then advised me to get the relevant app for my mobile device.  Since I have an iPhone, I went to the Apple App Store and got the free Quicken app.  Be sure to get the one from Intuit and not one of the others than come up when you search.  Once installed in my iPhone, I logged in with my new Quicken Cloud ID, and found the data for the one account I had enabled.  Seems OK so far.* ADDED: I found that my Net Worth didn't match what it had been with Quicken 2012.  The reason seems to be that in 2012 there was an option to exclude selected accounts from your Net Worth, which I did for a few accounts that I use to track unvested assets.
