I don't know a word of Spanish... well, I can count to twenty, and know a few phrases, including some that have worked their way into the English language (eg, vaya con Dios, dos cerveza por favor), but basically just your average redneck gringo.  However, I love music, have a very nice audio rig, and a Mexican health professional who comes in twice a week to help me.  She's great, and likes music, so I asked her who she likes and went on Youtube to sample Joan Sebastian.  I liked him, especially Un Idiota - even a redneck idiot like me could figure out that title - and then Secreto De Amor began... I was hooked, went straight for the Amazon download and am listening now to El Toro, another winner.  All the songs are good, so getcha some, gringo.

I like these better than the highly-praised Pioneer 22's by Andrew Jones which I also own and like.  These are even better through the mids to my ear.  They can soak up more power than you'd expect from such a small speaker.  I prefer them with a subwoofer, though they do sound good on their own.  If you live in an apartment and don't wish to annoy neighbors with low bass thump, then these are a very good choice for the price.  You could still add a sub, but turn it off for late hours, still having very enjoyable music or movie sound.  What they will provide is high quality sound from, say, about 80hz and up.  Have a decent amp or receiver, though..

Didn't work for a tooth filling for me.  However, the stuff is pretty amazing, and I have several household projects for which it will be very useful, so am happy to have discovered the product.  It semi-melts into a moldable plastic which quickly hardens as it cools.  Don't expect it to stick like cement, but you can fashion small plastic parts for an endless number of uses.  Obviously, those uses would not include scenarios which put the piece in a greater than 150-degree F temp  application.

Light is very bright.  I leave it plugged to its charger, which has circuitry to prevent over-charging.  Compact, hands off, and bright.  Use a smaller flashlight for very tight spots, but this one fills 99% of our needs around the house.  Oh, and I do have old eyes, so when I say bright, I mean BRIGHT, because I've had enough of dim flashlights or those that have uneven dispersion.  This light casts a wide, tall pattern which is uniformly bright.  Darn thing is a floodlight.  You'll dang sure see what you want to see.  Just switch it own, point it in the general direction - no aiming required - tilt it back if needed (swivels), and have both hands free to work.
This album drew good reviews when it was released.  Still enjoyable today; wears well/

Very pleased with the quality overall.  Really liked the color (beige).  Left off one star because I thought the fabric could have been just slightly thicker (heavier) but I'm just a reg'lar  guy so whatta I know?

Beautiful MusicRock Band:  CamelAlbum:  “The Snow Goose”The HistoryIn 1940, as Germany proceeded with its war for world domination, they entered France.  French armed forces fighting with assistance from Great Britain's BEF (British Expeditionary Force) were no match for the German onslaught.  England had hoped to help keep France free, because the English Channel is pretty narrow – only twenty miles across at the Strait of Dover.  Outgunned and over-matched, the forces retreated all the way to the port city of Dunkirk with the Germans at their heels.  The French and English forces faced imminent slaughter or surrender, a certain defeat.However, two German Generals failed to press the attack at that point, inexplicably deciding instead to pause and regroup for three days to make sure none of their opponents could evade fate.  Those three days gave many of the 300,000 British and French fighting men a chance to evacuate Dunkirk, crossing the Channel to Great Britain by using every type of boat available along the coast.  Civilian boat owners came in droves, making multiple runs across the channel, with quite a few losing their craft – and their lives – to the enemy.  So this, in broad strokes, is a synopsis of the evacuation during the Battle of Dunkirk, fought in late May/early June 1940.  True history.Also true is that an author, Paul Gallico, born in 1897 and thus 43 years old at the time, became inspired to write a short story soon after reading newspaper accounts of the battle and evacuation, and used those events as the backdrop to his work of fiction, which was published in 1940 in the Saturday Evening Post not long after the actual battle (years later he would write “Poseidon Adventure”).  In 1940 “The Snow Goose” was published as a short story but would grow into a novella within a year.The StoryA lonely hunchback artist moves into a lighthouse near Dunkirk to paint birds and to lead his outcast, solitary life.  Walking the beach one day he finds a young lady named Fritha trying to assist a wounded snow goose.  He helps, and together they nurse the bird back to health until it can continue its migratory lifestyle thus building a bond between the disfigured artist and the girl.  However, after the goose flies away the artist sees the young lady no more... for a year.  However, a year later the bird returns to the lighthouse during his annual migration.  Rhayader (the artist's name) immediately sends for Fritha with word of their feathered friend's return.  She quickly arrives to see the goose.  During subsequent migratory years, the goose continues to return, strengthening Rhayader and Fritha's bond until romance seems nigh.  Finally the goose returns to the lighthouse to stay.It is then that word of the soldiers' plight in Dunkirk is broadcast with a plea for boats to respond to the need.  Rhayader takes his boat, and the bird flies along behind him as he makes trip after trip to save as many soldiers as possible.  Finally, his boat is hit by enemy fire and Rhayader and his boat are sunk into the sea.  The goose flies back to Fritha at the lighthouse, who considers it the soul of Rhayader bidding her farewell.In 1975, 35 years after the battle and the published story, the rock group Camel wrote music inpired by the story.  It is a really good album, all instrumental, and probably would not be considered rock by many listeners.  It is well-known and loved by fans of progressive rock (aka prog rock) and is a soothing listen.  Highly recommended.[This is a very brief account written by me, using various sources, and is likely to contain errors of fact.  However, it does indicate the essential history of this example of historical fiction, published so soon after the actual battle, for those who were unaware of what this music is all about.  The story had quite an emotional impact upon many readers, both then and since.  I always think of my late father's service in France during WWII when I listen to the recording.]

First:  Peel off the thin film over the screen.  It's not easy to get a corner started.  If you don't do this, you'll think the device doesn't work.  After that's done, everything else is easy.Wife wanted an MP3 player for Christmas.  I have a big, heavy Zune to which we are accustomed, so the small size and feather weight were a surprise.  It sounds great, works well, and my wife put it on three hours ago while doing chores and hasn't taken it off since.  She loves it but was a little disappointed with its capacity (being used to my 30GB Zune), so I ordered a 32 GB card a few minutes ago.  She's not very tech savvy, but operation is easy;  she depends on me for synching.

I have the world's best cat.  He loves these little mice, they are so much fun to bat around and so easily portable from room to room.  I bet you wish you had the world's best cat, too.  Sorry, but he's not for sale;  you'll just have to settle for second best and learn to live with it.  Anyway, just so you know, his name is Jumper.  You can pay me to let you pet him, but that's just for the opportunity;  he decides who can and who can't, and it's up to you to win him over.  His decision is final, and I don't give refunds.

Very attractive stand, sold as a pair in one box.  Lots of extras make it really nice:  for instance you get two pairs of upper plates, one is rectangular, the other a truncated triangular shape (use whichever works best for your speakers, store the other pair of plates for different future needs, nice), also choice of self-adhesive pads or small press-in cones for the speaker to rest upon, and includes carpet spikes or plastic feet for the base plate.  Very easy to assemble using a Phillips head screwdriver.  Carpet spikes have a nut that can be tightened with just pliers, small channel locks, or appropriate wrench (something in the 1/4" to 3/8" range judging by sight - not sure, I just went with channel-locks).  Also has a pair of grooves into which you slide flexible plastic slats for hiding speaker wires, which worked fine for my 14AWG wire.The stands' piano black finish looks very nice.  My Peachtree Audio D5 speakers look fantastic on this stand, which brings them to the perfect height.  I am very pleased with the quality, the solidity, the function and appearance of these stands.  Highly recommended while they last.

A few years ago I gave my wife a very expensive (to us) long, black lamb's wool coat with fur trim and black leather laced trim which we call her "Audrey Hepburn" coat because it has timeless style and a svelte appearance with my slender wife wearing it.  She also has a nice brown leather jacket for more casual wear.  Her gloves match the jacket, but she had none to really accentuate the style of the nice dressy coat.  Until now.  I put these in her Christmas stocking over the fireplace mantle, but a cold snap hit and then it was time for an event to which she would wear a black silk dress and her "Hepburn" coat.  So I told her to check her stocking for an early gift.  Wow, they looked even better with the coat than just the gloves alone.  They look like they were custom made for her coat.  She loves the warmth and the style.  I love getting to be a hero once or twice a year;  and the look really is amazing.

Very good for the price, so an excellent value imo.  Doesn't get as deep, nor have the output of my Paradigm subwoofer (at almost 6x the money), but adds significant bass output to my tertiary system in a small listening room.  Using with a Cambridge Audio Sonata receiver and RCA/Radio Shack small bookshelf speakers with the Linaeum tweeter.  This speaker has very good mids and highs but suffers from severe anemia in the bass;  the Polk subwoofer, used judiciously, really improves the sound adding dynamics along with the low end.  Not made for high SPLs, but packs a nice punch when used within its capability.

I'm using these in my bedroom for Paradigm 7se MkII speakers which are 25" tall by about 11" x 13".  They weigh about 38 lbs each.  My 12 lb cat jumps upon them sometimes without any mishaps so they seem pretty stable to me.

These are not self-drilling anchors.  We definitely had to drill holes in our dry-wall and tap the anchors into the holes with a light hammer, then torque the screws into the anchors.  Attempts to use these anchors as self-drilling resulted in bowed-out anchors with bowing on the outside of the wall, not the inside as they should be.  As anchors, these are just okay;  as "self-drilling" anchors they fail completely.  I'm not sure the designer even understands how a self-drilling anchor is supposed to work.  Not recommended and would never order a Shells brand product again.

Fantastic and affordable solution for organizing my walk-in man cave closet filled with audio paraphernalia, including several pair of various bookshelf speakers, lots of various wires, a solder station and other small tools, and spare receivers and integrated amps.  Along with two Sterilite shelving systems, the closet was tamed and organized.  Now my penny-pinching wife is considering spending a little to organize her two walk-in closet hoards after seeing mine so useful.  Great result for about a c-note.

Affordable and durable.  I ordered two trays and a stacker set.  Assembling the stacker mounts is a bit tricky, but here's a tip for you:  Once you figure out how the lower end connects to the bottom basket (that's the tricky bit), then you will find it easier to assemble if you get one end done first because then you can tip the other ends far enough apart so that the two final mounts can be rotated into place.  The stacker mounts actually become very strong springs that hold the upper tray tightly in place such that it is very unlikely to accidentally come apart.  Well-designed and well-built actually, though a bit tricky.The stacker set includes four mounts, which is enough to stack two baskets.  Baskets are ordered individually, so order two baskets and one stacker set for two-tiered storage, or three baskets and two stacker sets for three-tiered.  Order as many trays as you need, and as many stacker sets as your own design requires.  Makes a nice custom configuration for your specific needs.  I'm using them to help organize a closet and will probably order more because the trays are deep enough to be very useful for my minimal home office needs.Highly recommended.  Functional and great for a closet or an office where style is not important.

Compact, but roomy.  Plenty of space for my wife's desktop (I use a laptop).  We were using a large, cheap corner desk which wasted a lot of space in our small home office.  This new desk maximized usage of the space, with room to spare for add-on devices in the future.  I used nylon zip-ties to neaten wire management, so our PC is no longer an eyesore.  Using this desk to organize our space enabled us to expand the functionality of the room, which now includes two bookcases and comfortable seating for three in a non-cluttered, attractive area which also includes music listening, and a small TV, too.  Careful planning was required to achieve all this while retaining a clean, non-busy appearance, but the PC desk was invaluable in its contribution to the success of the project.

I really don't understand why so many reviewers claim the stand is sturdy.  They fall over with the Pioneer SP-BS22LR speaker; won't stand at all.  Even with small, light speakers they wobble.  They need either a heavier base or spikes, or both.  I like the clamp-on feature, but the tilt function is difficult to adjust properly.  All-in-all, they are good with the potential to have been great but miss out in the ways described.  They are okay for speakers near the 5-lb range, but not stable enough very much beyond that; not a great model for use around pets or toddlers.Those who can weld  a heavier plate under the base might well find this stand a delight to use with a wider range of speakers.  Larger squares of plywood or MDF could be bolted through the existing feet holes to increase stability also, and painted flat black would look fine.  I happened to have a smaller speaker which I used rather than the Pioneer which I'd have preferred, though I do intend to modify the stand to increase its stability.  Then I'll use what I want.

I am very much pleased with the quality of this product.  It isn't just a wooden board with screwed-on castors and handle.  You will need either a 12mm socket-wrench, nut-driver or basic wrench to tighten the hexhead 12mm screws.  Or at the least an adjustable crescent wrench, which though not ideal, will do this job well because the screws tighten easily with any of these tools.  Split type lock washers are included.  All four screws for each castor screw directly into the cart's metal frame.The cart handles are already fastened into place, in a closed position.  Raising the handle snaps it firmly into place;  the user's foot can be used to depress the strong spring if handle needs to be folded back down for storage or transport.  I really feel like I got my money's worth with this cart.  Very sturdy and can handle some real weight.  Rolls easily.Note that carts like this are made to be pushed, not pulled.  Not due to the cart itself, but back strain is much more likely if carts are pulled;  it's a human body mechanics issue.  This is why swivel castors should be on the 'handle end' of the cart.UPDATE EDIT:  One of the best purchases I've made.  This cart has been so useful around the house several times already and made several chores/projects so much easier that I hate to recall all the extra work required before we bought it.

Cambridge Audio quality at 50% off the regular price makes for a very nice deal.  This receiver is smaller than standard, meaning that it fits places where others won't.  I love the combination of style, sound and function.  Even the remote control device breathes quality, with its attractive metal face and sensible set of features.Even just opening the box reveals the above-average engineering design, which extends even to packing materials, which were made with cutouts for each included unit.  That seems a small, perhaps even inconsequential observation, but the results are a well-protected package which makes a nice presentation when unpacked.Sound quality is very good, with an excellent top end.  Sparkle and shimmer of cymbals, chimes, and other such instruments is exquisite, mids are good and the 2.1 receiver's subwoofer output provides the signal for a powered subwoofer to provide the bottom end, relieving the small on-board amplifier of that duty thus extending it's dynamics.With or without a subwoofer, I highly recommend this receiver.  With smaller receivers currently rare - most choices being either cheap crap or prohibitively expensive - the CA Sonata AR-30 falls right into a reasonable price range at the current close-out.  It seems the number of units available are restricted.  Get yours while the getting is good.

Best for the money I have seen.  I don't mean they're good for the price.  I mean they are good.  Period.  The price is right, and the quality is as good as some which are more expensive.  In fact, you can pay more for lesser quality.There are, of course, better and more expensive plugs than these - not denying that.  But some that are priced higher are not as good as these.  Great value here.

I bought my first pair of these AKGs sometime from 1975 to 1978, and loved them.  Used them for about 15 years until they were damaged in a mishap.  I've had other 'phones since then, most notably the Nakamichi SP-7, but none I liked as much as that old pair from the past.  So when I saw that they were either still - or once again - available (and on sale) I had to get a pair especially since I'm using headphones a lot lately.  I just had to know whether they were as good as I recalled.They are better.  Improved, I guess.  They still look, feel and fit the same - and that's a good thing.  The bass is deep and well-defined, not artificially boosted but can thump with the best when a thump is on the recording(Gov't Mule's "Lay Your Burden Down").  Highs are clean and well-extended - certainly they go higher than my 10khz cutoff hearing - younger folks who've passed through like the highs.  Mids sound good, with virtually none of the congestion you can get with lesser 'phones or speakers.  As the mids become more complex due to multiple instruments, its easy to follow just one (for instance cello in several quartets I sampled).Dynamics are great, as heard in Glenn Miller Orchestra, "In the Digital Mood,"  "Chattanooga Choo Choo" track, and the Tchaikovsky "1812 Overture" in this case on Telarc.  With movies, explosions can be startling.In addition to sound quality, these headphones are also superlative in other ways.  One is the way they fit.  Yes, they are pretty large, but the large cups fit around the ear and press against the skull, which reduces ear soreness to virtually none.  The gimbal construction, which auto adjusts when simply put on the head has always been a strong point of this headphone.  I can wear them for hours with no ear soreness.Also, fit and finish is excellent - AKG have obviously kept QC standards up despite having these made now in China.  Connections are first-rate, and the cable enters at the Left earcup as the good Lord intended.  I love the compactness and fit of the screw-on 1/4" plug (an adaptor that fits over the 1/8" - 3.5mm - plug).The one area in which the headphone does not excel is isolation, but that is to be expected with an open (they call it semi-open) type cup construction.  On the other hand, it is extremely difficult to attain this level of sonic excellence in a closed-back design.  I've heard none, if they exist, but even if there is one I'm sure it would be much more pricey.  Generally, one just expects to give up the "airy" sound of an open design with a closed headphone, so it depends on the importance of isolation to the listener.  I have a pair of closed-backs to use when needed, but most of the time I'll be using these.I'm not saying these are perfect, but they are as close as I'll get, since I certainly won't spend more than a c-note on headphones - it just wouldn't be prudent.  I pushed my own limits to get these at just less than seventy bucks, and I'm darned glad that I did.  My opinion then is obvious - best at the price, and better than many to which I've listened in the past that were much more expensive.
Peach may just be Jelly Belly's best fruit flavor - tastes just like a fresh, ripe, juicy peach.  Mine arrived fresh, well-packaged and promptly.

I have owned some classic budget amplifiers over the years, from a Pioneer SA-5500 to an NAD 3020 to several Adcom GFA-series amps, including the GFA-535 and 535 II, as well as some more powerful amps by NAD and Adcom.  Others too numerous to name.  How Emotiva manages to offer such a quality amplifier as the mini-x a-100 so affordably in the current era is beyond me.  It has power to spare for most speakers, while sounding every bit as good as any I have owned.  In my opinion you'd have to spend several times the asking price to best it, and I'm not sure that the difference would be obvious - since my ears aren't so young anymore the difference would have to be in the mids on down into the bass for me to notice an improvement.  Some young guys who've listened to my system claimed the highs were well extended and clean - my hearing now cuts off at 10khz.It is a compact little brick of an amp, heavier than it looks.  The size and price were equally important factors for me because I needed to replace a large, heavy Adcom GFA-5503 in order to use the space it occupied in my audio cabinet for a different component.  The amp appears well-built, its auto-on/off sensing circuit (switchable) responds quickly,  Banana plugs fit well, I think it's attractive, and its half-component-width size was critical for my purpose - it does require some depth, though.  My cabinet has plenty of that.I did try an SMSL SA50 Class D amp first, and was surprised at its admirable capability.  I wound up using it for rear channel, and put the Emotiva on the front L/R speakers.  It simply sounds better, as the SA50 exhibited a tendency to become slightly strident as volume increases - a characteristic that exacerbates the same tendency in my Klipsch.  The Emotiva makes my speakers sound nice and smooth.  I highly recommend this amp - nothing I've heard anywhere near the price comes close.UPDATE:  I have just ordered a second mini-x for a highish-end system which is all currently in transit or about to be.  The speakers are the Peachtree Audio ERA D5 while the preamp is the NuForce HAP-100 and a pair of Sanus' best speaker stands.  It will be interesting to hear how well this combo fulfills its potential.

I have had this disc for years, and can't recall for sure where I bought it - I think at a large, popular used bookstore in Houston, TX.  Anyway I stored the jewel box in  the attic years ago - with hundreds of others - as I have a couple of 400-disc players which I use for both storage and play.  I don't think the artists were identified.  The sound quality is first rate, and the performance seems just as good to me.  I'm glad I have this, even though it's now redundant to other discs I've purchased.  This one definitely remains in my play rotation (I've begun to have to make choices about which discs hold their spot in a player and which get kicked in favor of another), so it's pretty good, especially the Four Seasons.

Missed the movie (and the soundtrack) in mid-80's when I was busy working and raising kids.  Found this perusing affordable soundtracks, scanned the reviews which prompted me to listen to 30-second excerpts - had to have it.  I think some of the best music for years has been composed for film.  This recording is among the best;  a consensus of positive reviews on Amazon always gets my attention.  Thank you to all who bother to write.  I'll add my recommendation to the mix.

Let's get one thing straight, right up front:  I hate opera.  Can't stand it, fat lady sings, fat man sings, words in a language I can't understand;  hate everything about it.  I hate opera.  Don't know the story;  I have no clue what it's even about.  Those are just some of the reasons I hate opera.Well, thanks for stopping by and letting us know;  we were all wondering... but what's your point?You're welcome.  Point is I love this.But it's opera - you hate opera.Yeah, I know, and it's kinda p$$$g me off.  'Cause I hate opera.So, what happened?  What's different about this one?Well, what happened and what's different are the same thing.  I listened to a few minutes of it... then a few more... then next thing I know it's about two hours later, it's over, and the songs were so good some melodies were just stuck in my head.  So... I had to hear them again, just to get over it, but more tunes stuck.  It's as tragic a story as any opera.Yeah, due to your hatred of opera, because you do hate opera.Right.Whatever will you do?The only thing I can do.  Now I hate loving opera, and will check out other operas to discover whether I can hate loving them, too.  It seems my only way out.  In the meantime, I just want to warn opera haters everywhere not to listen to this recording because you just might like it.  This is my public service message.  (This is all true, my twisted sense of humor led me to review in this way.)

Bugs were eating me up.  Had gnats, mosquitoes, even a few fleas, and some other occasional crawly creatures in the house.  Driving me nuts.  My online research indicated that this is what the pros use.  Mixed up a .5% solution for indoors.  Bugs gone from inside house (and we keep a clean home).  Waiting for garden sprayer I ordered to arrive to use 1% outside.  Sure is more comfortable to have a bug-free home again, and our cat is just fine, thank you.  Sure is more comfortable to have it for about $25 than paying hundreds for a pest control contract.  This one bottle will likely serve us for a few years.  Life is good.

I am certainly no Brucknerian, nor expert in judging various orchestras, or conductors, or combinations of them as regards the finer points of interpretation.  I just know what I like.  I've tried other Bruckner symphony recordings - some more highly regarded than this one - but the Barenboim/Chicago is the one to which I keep returning, and the one which touches me most.  As far as I'm concerned, its detractors under-rate this cycle.  I'm glad to have it all back again;  it makes me feel kindly toward my USPS delivery person, who put it in my mailbox yesterday.

I just ran across these Big Box deals recently, and have purchased most.  I've found sound quality to be very good to excellent, with performances mostly at a high level.  I am no expert, but I have owned a modest library of classical over the years, so I have a lot of listening experience.  I've always wanted my collection to be more complete, but classical is just one genre of music I love so the expenditures get spread around.  It was thrilling to buy these sets, and I've been listening almost non-stop and still have much to discover.This Haydn disc is great, and while one reviewer criticized it mildly for having too many chorale selections, I must say that they aren't my favorite, either.  However, I have found that there are a few that I liked at first listen.  I'd never have heard them at all if it were not for the great price and the preponderance of non-vocal music.  The Haydn strikes me as being right up there with the Bach set(s) in quality and selection.  I love Amazon and the various labels involved who make these glorious and ridiculously affordable offerings available.  Bravo!

I'm a new Tony Bennett fan, and I ordered this CD and the old "...Heart in San Francisco" CD, which I was able to enjoy immediately, thanks to Autorip.  However, this live disc arrived today, and I just opened it, and WOW.  The quality of the sound is top-notch, clean and dynamic and far better than I'd hoped... and I had hoped for a high level of fidelity.  Recorded music just doesn't get appreciably better than this.  Better yet, the performance itself gives up nothing in quality to the recording...meaning, this is indeed one very fine performance.  His voice sounds fantastic.  I already don't even recall what I paid for this, it just doesn't matter - and I do have a cheapskate bone.  I highly recommend you buy it, even if it seems a little pricey;  It will still be one of the best music purchases you'll ever make.
I just bought the $2.19 download.  What a deal!  Great sampler, good sound quality, 106 pieces of music for a couple bucks.  Highly recommended for those interested.

This is my favorite Bach composition from the first time I heard it on record 40 years, or so, ago.  I think the copy I had then - on a vinyl LP, of course - was one of the old Funk & Wagnell's records which were accompanied by a very nice book about the composer's life.  I have long since sold all my LP's and had the piece on cassette tape for many years until it disappeared, too.  It was with harpsichord rather than piano, as is also this recording.  I love this rendition, and the low price is just icing on the cake for me.The pace and timing  are perfect, in my book, and the sound is clean.

Sound is stereo, clean and dynamic.  If you have no clue which conductor/orchestra combos are considered the best "interpreters" of Beethoven, and so long as they sound good think they sound pretty much alike, then you should buy this and save money.  Sounds great over my big Klipsch Forte speakers.  If you are a highly experienced and knowledgeable Ludwig listener then you may want to get it, too, just because of the low, low price.  Then you can tell everyone about its shortcomings... and strong points, too.  I'll read all about it and still enjoy it as much as I would any other Beethoven cycle.  Good deal for regular folks and cheapskates!I only took off one star because it's not a famous, top-tier orchestra and conductor, but they sound great to me.  And I have heard tympani sound a bit better...but, then, also worse, too, and from better orchestras, at that.  Hard to fault much for the price.

Wow, that picture is lovely!  The green tones combined with the lovely flowers in this duvet cover really remind me of pond lilies, or maybe just the season of Spring in general.  It's really nicely priced for such a beautiful print, especially something that's made entirely of cotton, so I decided to take a chance on this unknown product brand and ordered it (along with their Sunny Blue Daisy set, which I also fell in love with).Well, now that I've seen it in person, it's not quite what I was expecting.  There's a lot more white in the print than I would've guessed from the picture – the green parts are mainly at the top and bottom, and they sort of fade into a big white middle section (which still has spots of purple flowers printed on it).  I was expecting a lot more green color (and I'm ever so slightly disappointed), but there's not much to complain about since it's still very pretty.  The two pillowcases I got were pretty random (one of them seems to come from the white section and the other one is green), so, it's a bit of an odd mis-match there.  Oh, I should note that this duvet cover is reversible!  The backside is actually that blue geometric-style pattern you can see on the sheets in the picture.  That's a nice bonus.  The pillowcases, however, aren't made reversible with the blue fabric on the underside (despite the fact that it would've been easy to do), so that's a bit of a baffling oversight...Quality-wise, this seems like a solid item.  I washed it (in hot water and a hot dryer, no less) and the colors didn't fade at all.  It came out a bit wrinkled, but that's to be expected for an all-cotton item, and most of the wrinkles have already fallen out (this is helped by the fact that I folded it immediately after drying).  It has convenient corner ties already added to it, as well as a nice zipper closure, and seems pretty true to size (I ordered the queen).  The fabric itself feels just like you'd expect average cotton to feel – not super soft or satiny, but reasonable for its 300 thread count (if you've ever touched a normal quilt, you'll know exactly what kind of cotton I'm talking about).My ultimate feelings about this item are that while I'm slightly disappointed by the colors in the print and the lack of attention to detail in the pillowcases, I'd have to say that I'm still generally pleased with it.  It's still a lovely item for a good price, and I can't complain about that.  If you saw the manufacturer's picture and thought to yourself, "wow, this would be perfect if the green was toned down a bit with more white," then go ahead and give this item a try.  Personally, I'd have to say that I ended up liking their Sunny Blue Daisy set better, but I'm pleased enough with the overall quality of this set that I'm definitely going to be keeping an eye out for any new products from Swanson Bedding in the future!

I really fell in love with this duvet cover when I first saw it.  The orange, yellow, and white daisies on that light blue background really remind me of the sky on a bright, sunny day!  Plus, it's all cotton, and the price is pretty affordable for such a beautiful print.  Still, I wondered if such a bright, crisp print could really look that good in person, especially for such a good price...Well, now that it has arrived, let me assure you that it looks great!  The print on those daisies is crisp and clear, and the colors are just as bright in person as they are in the picture.  In fact, it looks exactly like the picture.  I washed it (in hot water and a hot dryer, no less) and the colors didn't fade at all (woo!).  It came out a bit wrinkled, but that's to be expected for an all-cotton item, and most of the wrinkles have already fallen out (this is helped by the fact that I folded it immediately after drying).  It seems pretty true to size (I ordered the queen), and has convenient corner ties already added to it, as well as nice zipper closure.  I should also add that the duvet cover technically has a reverse side – the underside has a slightly different print, which is light blue with pale greenish-white daisies on it.  It looks very similar to the top side, so I'm not sure I'd actually call this reversible even though the underside is technically a different print.  As for the feel of the fabric, well, it feels like your average cotton.  It's not super soft or satiny, but it feels like a good sturdy cotton, and that's good enough for me.Well, I'm overall very pleased with this item.  It seems like a great value (I got mine for about sixty bucks, inclusive of shipping) for an all-cotton duvet cover set, especially one that is so pretty.  I hadn't tried Swanson Bedding before, but if the company's other items are this good of a quality at this kind of value, then they have definitely won themselves a loyal customer.  If you're in the mood for something cheerful and whimsical for the bedroom, or if you're just a fan of daisies, then I highly recommend you try out this duvet cover; it'll put a smile on your face!

I decided to try out this new Febreze scent since it seems like a great way to freshen up some musty-smelling areas (like closets, towels in storage, etc.).  So, after it arrived, I decided to get straight to testing!My first test was on some clothes hanging in the closet, as well as the smelly shoes being stored there.  The fragrance is pleasant enough, and somewhat "fresh" as the name suggests, but it's rather hard to describe.  It's not floral or fruity in any way, and it reminds me of maybe a cross between cologne for a man and the smell of fabric softener sheets.  Yeah, I know that's vague, but it's really quite difficult to describe.  I like it okay, but it's not my favorite scent.  Anyway, it smelled strong to me when going on the clothes, but while it's very strong when it first comes out, it seems to lessen over time.  However, while the strength of the odor did diminish, the smell lingered for quite awhile.  After five days I could still faintly smell it.  Seven days is a bit of a stretch (I still noticed it if I stuck my nose in the clothes and sniffed hard, but it was mostly gone by then).  As for the effect of the smell, well, it won't get rid of odors that are already there, but it will help you freshen musty things or cover up some lingering odors once the source is gone.  That's pretty par for the course with Febreze products, though.Lastly, let's talk about the bottle.  It's got a nozzle that can be twisted to "off" or "spray" but there's two spray settings, and they don't seem to be any different in volume.  It would've been nice to have a heavy spray vs. a light spray setting.  Nonetheless, I'm pretty pleased with the spray performance because it comes out as more of a mist, whereas in the past I've had Febreze fabric bottles that came out in huge heavy sprays, and this one is much easier to control.  That being said, the neck of this bottle baffles me.  There's a clear separation that looks as though the top could come off, and there's a symbol for locked and unlocked.  I took this to mean that the head will twist off (perhaps so one could clear any clogs that might happen, or refill the bottle or something), but it won't budge.  It doesn't seem to open at all, and all that did happen when I tried is that liquid squeezed out onto my hand.  Oh well, I have no idea what that's about.Anyway, if you are a fan of Febreze products and want a fragrance that doesn't smell floral/fruity, then this might be the product for you.  If you are not already a fan of Febreze, then this certainly isn't going to change your mind.  As for me personally, I like the better misting effect the spray bottle provides, but I think the smell is just okay.  If I do get this product again in the future, I think I'll choose a different fragrance.

I'm a bit new to the world of duvet covers, and naturally, I wanted to start off with a cheaper one to test the concept before I start investing in expensive stuff.  I also wanted one that was 100% cotton, and that was bright and pretty.  That seems like a pretty tall order for a lower-priced duvet cover, but then I stumbled onto this item.First off, once you see it in person, you'll notice that the colors are a bit more muted and pastel in tone, while the picture looks a bit brighter.  This is something that didn't bother me (it's still pink and blue and pretty!), but it should be noted.  Also, it's hard to tell from the picture, but the part that folded over (where you can see a bit of a darker blue with pink roses) actually represents a reverse side.  The duvet cover is reversible!  I actually prefer the reverse side a little more (it's a solid baby blue with pink roses here and there), as opposed to the more multi-colored side that's pictured.  Nevertheless, I think the reversibility adds extra value to what was already an inexpensive duvet cover (it was about thirty-six bucks when I bought it).As for quality...well, the first thing I did was wash it, and it didn't fall apart at all.  It did seem to shrink a bit in the dryer (and wrinkled, but those seem to have largely fallen out over the past couple days of use), but this was actually helpful due to its odd size.  I ordered the queen size, and the shams measured 20x30".  It shrank to about 20x29" and seemed to fit my pillow a bit more snugly.  The duvet cover itself is the odd size of 88x96", which is very weird for a queen duvet cover, which normally are around the 88x88" size, or 90x90".  Nonetheless, it's a pretty easy fix with a sewing machine to reduce the length.  There's a zipper closure at the bottom, and it works well, but there are no corner ties, so you'll have to add them yourself if you care about such things.  I should also mention that the listing says it comes with a flat sheet, but I got no such thing.  I don't really care, though, as I never use flat sheets anyway.  As for the way the fabric feels...well, this is 200 thread count cotton, and it feels like it.  It's not particularly soft or smooth, but you can't really expect that for this price point and for this thread count.  To me it feels like your average cotton – not high-end, but sturdy enough, and I like it just fine, personally.Well, I'd have to say I'm pretty pleased with this item.  It's certainly great for the price, since it's very hard to find all-cotton duvet covers that are so brightly colored for such a low price.  I think it's weird size is a drawback, but for the price, it's worth fixing with your own sewing machine (or getting somebody else to do it for you).  It's a quick, easy fix, so I can't really complain too much, and I didn't hold it against the item in the rating because it's clearly stated in the listing.  I must retract a star, however, for the missing flat sheet.  I don't particularly care about it, but it's still technically false advertising.  For the overall package, though, you're still getting a great bargain on a lovely duvet cover (and two shams).  I'd definitely recommend this item if you're on a budget, and I'll probably be checking out more of their stuff in the future!

I'm new to the world of duvet covers, and was looking for an inexpensive way to try one out.  That's when I happened upon this item.  It looked bright and cheerful, and the price just couldn't be beat (about thirty bucks when I bought it), so I gave it a try.It is indeed as bright as cheerful in person as it looks in the picture, and the colors are pretty spot on!  However, the picture is a bit misleading in another way.  Because of the way it is folded, you can't see the top half of the duvet cover.  The bottom is indeed that nice blue color, but about halfway up the cover, the blue sort of fades out into a big white strip, which fades into the tan/cream color you can see in the picture in the folded over part of the cover.  When I first saw the picture, I assumed the tan color was a reversible print side, but both sides are the same.  I'd honestly say the design hurts it a bit, and it would look better if the whole thing were blue.  I still think it's reasonably pretty, but you should be aware of this incongruity.Quality-wise, the duvet cover seems well made.  There were no loose threads or tearing seams on mine.  There's a zipper closure at the bottom that worked fine, and it does seem to be reasonably accurate to the listed size of 91x91 inches (I had bought the queen size).  Oh, and if you are used to your duvet covers having corner ties, well, this one doesn't, so you'll have to add them yourself if you care about that sort of thing.Now, let's talk about the fabric.  This duvet cover is a 50/50 polyester cotton blend.  I thought this would be reasonable for me to take a chance on because I've had a comforter in the past that was a 80% cotton, 20% polyester blend, and it felt just fine.  With this one, however, I guess the polyester content is just too high...  I can REALLY feel the polyester - in fact, it feels way more like polyester than cotton to me.  It also feels like it doesn't breath particularly well, which is a typical trait of polyester.  I'm rather sensitive in my dislike of polyester bedding and I just didn't like the feel of this duvet cover, so I ended up returning the item.  You might be wondering why my rating is so high for something I returned.  Well, it's because this item is rather nicely made for its price, and its texture is pretty typical of a polyester-containing item.  In other words, it didn't seem fair to knock off its score just because I have a personal dislike of polyester.  I did, however, retract a star for the misleading nature of the print (as mentioned earlier).Overall, I'd have to say that this item is pretty good, despite my personal dislike of its fabric content.  If you are the sort of person who has no qualms with polyester bedding, and you happen to want a cheap and cheerful-looking duvet cover, then I'd definitely recommend you try this one out.

I use tampons frequently, and I've gone through quite a few different brands/models over the years to find out which kind I like best.  I'm not really brand loyal at this point, but the one thing I require is plastic applicators.  Yes, I have suffered the cardboard ones in the past, and all they tended to do was slide in roughly, be uncomfortable, and collapse annoyingly when trying to use the tampon plunger part during insertion.  Plus, if they get wet from being set down in the bathroom, then forget it - those cardboard applicators just squash in and become useless.  So, I now stick exclusively to the plastic ones.  However, that brings us to these o.b. tampons, which claim to work without applicators.  I'm both intrigued and skeptical.  On the one hand, I'm worried that they will be very uncomfortable to insert, but on the other hand, I'm quite attracted to their small size (just imagine how easy these would be to fit in a purse!).  So, I'm willing to give these a chance!First off, I'm pleased with the overall spread of sizes offered in this package; it's a good mix of regular, super, and super plus.  Of course, if you find that your needs are different, you're probably going to want to buy the sizes separately anyways.  Now, onto the nitty gritty - the actual use!  After trying them out...  Well, this is where my enthusiasm has started to damper.  These things are quite rough and unpleasant to insert, even on a relatively heavy flow day for me - so forget about using them during a lighter flow day (a problem I did not have with regular size tampons with plastic applicators because those went in smooth, and by the time they were ready to be removed, were sufficiently filled as to come out easily).  Maybe my flow isn't as heavy as other people's (even on my heaviest days)?  I don't know, but these things feel like sandpaper going in.  Also, you'll likely get your finger messy when you're inserting these.  This isn't such a problem at home where one can run to the nearby sink to wash up, but imagine trying to use these tampons in a public bathroom.  Not fun at all.  As for absorption, well, it was fine enough, and about average, I'd say, for each size range.  I didn't have any problems with leakage or anything, so that's good.While absorption was good and the small size is nice (the regulars are 1 " long, while the super sizes are 2" long), I'd have to say that I'm overall dissatisfied with these.  What's the point of using them if insertion is so unpleasant?  Of course, each person is different, and you may have better luck with these than I did, so if the concept of applicator-less tampons intrigues you, then you might as well go ahead and give them a try (maybe try to buy a smaller size for testing purposes).  As for me, though, I'm going back to my normal plastic applicators.

I don't normally use overnight pads (but I've tried some in the past.  I'm very paranoid of leaks (I've had some bad experiences) so now I almost exclusively use a tampon at night combined with a normal pad or a pantiliner (depending on heaviness of flow) in order to add a double-layer of protection against leaks.  Nonetheless, these Stayfree Ultra Thin Pads seemed like a decent option for the tail end of my period (when it's not practical to use a tampon anymore).First off, physically, these are very long (measuring a full 11.5" when laid flat) - even longer than most normal overnight pads I've tried in the past.  They are also rather wide (3.5") and feature two sets of wings (yes, two!).  These are extra big (although still thin - somewhere between a pantiliner and a regular pad) supposedly in order to guard against leaks in the night.  Well...as for actual performance, if you sleep on your back, I can definitely see these being good.  I, however, sleep on my side almost all the time.  I used these towards the end of my period when the flow is lighter, and I can say that I didn't have any leaks while using these, but I don't usually have leaks at that point even while using normal regular size pads (you know, the ones that are of a normal length and thickness).  As for trying to use these during my heavier flow days, well, I'd be frightened to.  They just don't feel thick enough for a heavy flow, and when one sleeps on their side, gravity pulls all things down in that direction, so leaks would probably escape at some point.  If you sleep on your back, though, it'd probably do an admirable job - it's certainly long enough for that.  Oh, and for anyone who's wondering, these do seem to have a very, very light scent, almost not enough to even say it's there.  I don't know if this will bother anyone or not, but be warned.Anyway, I think these worked admirably for light flow days, but I won't chance it for heavy flow days - for that, I'm going to stick to my tampon/pad combo at night.  As for these, I like them just well enough to use up, but I'm not going to get them again.  They just don't offer me, personally, enough benefit over normal-sized pads to keep them on hand.  Oh well, if these sound like something that would work well for you, give them a try!

I've long been a fan of "gothy" comics, or just darkly humorous comics involving the supernatural, and I just so happened to stumble upon this one while browsing amazon.  So, I decided to give it a try.  "Outlook: Grim – The Dead Nasties" is actually a collected volume of the first six issues of the series.  I much prefer collected volumes over individual issues since I can get one big chunk of a story in one place, so this pleases me.  Of course, I've not actually read any of the individual issues previously, so this is my first experience with their series.  Now, onto the meat of the review...First off, the artwork is quite stylized (which I enjoy) and it's also quite detailed; each page is absolutely stuffed with things to look at.  I appreciate the details, but at the same time, there is almost no shading in this black and white comic, so it can be quite difficult to actually look at sometimes – like it's too chaotic and hard on the eyes.  Nonetheless, once I got accustomed to the art style, it became easier to follow the action.  Also, I'd be remiss if I didn't point out the monster designs – they are both incredibly cute and horrible, and I love them!As for the story, well...the story is fairly interesting, involving main characters Wren and Chloe unleashing ghosts in Wren's apartment, and then trying to find a way to get rid of them.  The interesting bits don't really pick up until the latter half of the book, though, and the overall story feels unfinished – as though it's only an opener to a bigger story.  I presume this volume is only the beginning of a longer story, and seems like it'd be a good introduction to a future Volume 2.  As it is, though, I'm not sure Volume 2 is coming.  I certainly hope so, because I'd like to see a continuation of this series, if only because it feels like there's some character development that needs to happen in our main characters.  Wren, in particular, is riding the line of being unlikable, and she desperately needs some fleshing out as a three-dimensional character.Overall, I'm very conflicted about what rating to give this book.  On the one hand, it kept my attention while reading, and was never boring.  On the other hand, it feels like it's only the beginning of a longer story, and as such, doesn't feel complete.  Plus, the story and characters feel like they need further expansion.  If it is truly just the first volume of many to come, then it's a good introduction, but as it is, I must judge it on its own merits.  If I could, I'd give it 3.5 stars as a stand-alone book, but since that isn't an option with the rating system, I'll give the author the benefit of the doubt and round up to four stars.  I truly hope Volume 2 is coming!

I was randomly browsing through comics of an "alternative" bent when I stumbled upon this one.  I'll state right now that I know nothing about the character of Emily the Strange, nor have I read any Emily the Strange comics previously.  So, I decided to pick this particular book up since it is Vol. 1, just to give franchise a try.First off, the book is nicely made in the physical sense.  The pages are nice and thick, and the inking looks really vivid.  I applaud the manufacturer for not cheaping out on the pages.  Unfortunately, the cover binding on my copy popped off.  I fixed it successfully with some rubber cement glue, but that's a bit of knock against build quality there.  Nonetheless, I'd say the book overall feels solid discounting that exception.As for the actual content, the art is quite lovely.  The book is technically in color, but the art tends to stick to a black, white, and red color-scheme.  I found the art style overall enjoyable, and I really dug the red and black aesthetic that was used on a lot of the pages.  While the art is nice, however, the story really lacks substance.  The book is composed of a series of short skits, with none of the stories really being part of an overarching narrative structure.  That's fine enough, but with a skit-style comic, the skits have to be really good to carry the book and maintain the interest of the reader.  Sadly, these skits were neither funny, witty, clever, or engaging.  It was as though the writers were desperately trying to have jokes, but none of them successfully achieved humor.  Out of all the mini-stories in the book, I only thought the "Lostco" one was amusing.  That's not a good track record at all...  Another issue I take with this book is its treatment of goth subculture.  I quite enjoy goth-y comics (or at least comics that are darkly humorous in tone - Jhonen Vasquez has a grumpy hissy-fit if you refer to his works as "goth"), and in fact I tend to stick to them primarily.  This book feels more like a parody of goth than an actual entry in the genre.  Everything is "black" and "dark" and not in an ironic way...  The whole thing comes off as superficial and immature, as though it's desperately trying too hard.  Of course, I could've forgiven all this if the book had been entertaining, but sadly, that wasn't the case.I know humor is subjective and all, and you might get more out of this book than I did, but I just didn't care for it.  Overall, even though the artwork is quite nice, I just can't strongly recommend this book, especially since there are better options out there.  Check out "Serenity Rose: 10 Awkward Years" for some gorgeous artwork and a funny, yet mature storyline, or "Squee's Wonderful Big Giant Book of Unspeakable Horrors" for a hilarious romp of dark humor.  Either way, find something better than this book...

I doubt that anyone who isn't a fan of Cradle of Filth would be looking at this, but just in case you know nothing about this item, let me describe it.  “The Curse of Venus Aversa” is a small comic story that was inspired by the band, Cradle of Filth.  However, this story does not directly feature the band at all (not exactly, anyway).  In fact, the story involves a brand new fictional protagonist, although there are many references and themes that are drawn directly from CoF's previous works.  So, people who were expecting a story featuring the band will be disappointed.  I, however, liked it well enough.Story-wise, the book feels very Victorian-Gothic in style, but with the band's trademark cheesiness filtered over it.  Without spoiling anything, I'll say that I found it entertaining enough, but it also felt a little lacking in closure.  I don't know if a second issue is planned, but I doubt it.  Oh well, in that case, I guess you could say it has an open ending.  As for the artwork, this is a black and white comic, and I'd say it's very nicely drawn.  The style is more realistic than cartoony or stylized, and the inking and shadow work are quite heavy.  I can't say it's my favorite comic artwork ever, but it certainly looks like a good deal of effort was put into it, and I appreciate that.However...all that heavy inking has a downside.  I don't know if I just got a dud copy or what, but when I first received my copy, it has a terrible chemical ink stench to it, and just opening the book set off my allergies.  I had to wrap it in a paper towel and stick it in a box full of baking soda for a week before the smell dissipated to a tolerable level.  Once again, I don't know if I just got unlucky or if this is an issue with all the copies, but do be careful picking this up if you're sensitive to smells.Nevertheless, if you're a fan of CoF, I'd suggest giving this comic a chance.  It's nice enough, and if you don't have allergies to ink then you'll probably enjoy it!

“I Feel Sick” #2 is the conclusion to the small spin-off story involving the character Devi, who was originally featured in Johnny the Homicidal Maniac.  While it could be considered an independent story, I believe you really need to read JTHM to fully get what's happening in this story, so I suggest you start there first.Strangely, out of all of Jhonen's comics, I'd consider the “I Feel Sick” story arc to be my favorite.  Maybe that's because it's the only one to have beautiful, fully-colored art, but honestly I think it's the story itself.  This comic is only two issues long, but it feels like the most coherent and complete of Johnen's stories in terms of plot development, and for me, the humor was absolutely spot-on.  So, I'd describe it as short, but sweet.  On another note, I've heard that this comic sort of metaphorically represents Jhonen's frustration with Nickelodeon while working on Invader Zim, and that he felt his creativity was constrained by corporate mandate.  If that's true, then it's sad.  I understand his frustration, but I also believe that Invader Zim may well be Jhonen's greatest work (although it wasn't entirely his, as many people contributed to the final product) and that it's too bad that he found the experience so unpleasant.  To be honest, though, some of his ideas (such as killing off Dib only to replace him with an identical character) were terrible ideas from a narrative perspective and I'm glad Nickelodeon didn't let him do it.  On the other hand, “I Feel Sick” is a great way to covertly see Jhonen's perspective in the whole thing, and I respect that (I daresay that small cameo Jhonen makes in this story says it all).  On a surface level, though, “I Feel Sick” is a great story in it's own right, and is quite funny, too.Obviously, if you pick this up (and it's quite rare and somewhat expensive now, but I still suggest getting it), then you need the other issue, too, to complete the story.  I really hope Jhonen re-releases both issues as some sort of nice compilation thing (as he did with JTHM and Squee), but I'm not sure when or if that'll ever happen.  Nonetheless, if you are a fan of Jhonen's works, try to get your hands on this one, too.

While it could be considered an independent story, I believe you really need to read JTHM to fully get what's happening in this story, so I suggest you start there first.Strangely, out of all of Jhonen's comics, I'd consider this one to be my favorite. Nonetheless, if you are a fan of Jhonen's works, try to get your hands on this one, too.

Squee is essentially a follow-up to the Johhny the Homicidal Maniac comics, but not in a traditional sequel-type way.  Squee was a character that appeared in JTHM, but was not the main focus.  This volume focuses directly on Squee, though, so it can't really be seen as a sequel to that book – it's more of a spin-off really.  That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed “Squee.”“Squee” still has Jhonen Vasquez's usual dark humor, but it feels like a slightly lighter, more fun collection compared to JTHM, and I'd have to say I found “Squee” to be funnier than JTHM overall.  Not to say I didn't enjoy JTHM, it's just that “Squee” is my favorite out of the two.  I really love the humor of Squee, and, additionally, for fans of Invader Zim it's super fun to see strange little precursors to characters and alien designs that appear in Invader Zim.  Aside from the main Squee-related stories, this collected work also includes the “Meanwhiles” and “Wobbly Headed Bob” side-stories, so if you get this and the Director's cut of Johnny the Homicidal Maniac, you'll have the whole collection of side stories.So, if you like JTHM, then you need to pick this up.  If you haven't read JTHM yet, then you should start there since that's the origin of Squee as a character.  The best option of all, though, is to get both!

Well, here we go...  Sigh, I hate to even have to say this, because this story must be pretty cliché by now, but I was introduced to this (and Jhonen Vasquez's other comics) through my love of Invader Zim.  I didn't start with JTHM, though, but with Filler Bunny.  Yeah, nevermind why that happened...but anyway, if you are looking to get into JTHM, this is the collection to get since it has all the JTHM volumes (this sentence will be awkward and incorrect later if he ever releases new JTHM comics).The book itself is softcover, and the pages are not the thickest or highest quality I've ever encountered, but they seem sturdy enough.  The comic is in black and white, and Jhonen's spidery art style and text will either appeal to you...or it won't (I personally like it).  As for the story...well, let's just say that you may think this book will just be a weird revenge fantasy thing wherein the reader is meant to identify with the main character's violent acts, but it's not.  By the end of the comic, it becomes apparent that there's a bit more going on here, and that this is less about mindless violence and more about following one special person's descent into further madness, all wrapped up in dark humor.  If you pick this up, just give it a chance and go in with an open mind.So, if you want to collect all the JTHM comics in one convenient format, then this “Director's Cut” version is definitely the one to get.  If you end up liking it, then I'd suggest you try out “The Collected Works of Filler Bunny,” “Squee,” and “I Feel Sick” (and after you work your way through those, “Serenity Rose” is an excellent comic).  If you are new to Jhonen's works, then you should definitely start here since all his other comics pretty much get their origin stories here.  Oh, as an extra note, this book also includes the “Happy Noodle Boy” and “Anne Gwish” segments (these are sort of little extra stories, unrelated to the main storyline).  The other half of the side stories included in the original versions of the comic (the “Meanwhiles” and “Wobbly Headed Bob”) are included in “Squee,” which I strongly suggest you also pick up.

Like most people, I have already read (and own) the other Filler Bunny comics, but I figured I'd go ahead and just review all of them here in this lovely collection.  Also like most people, I was first introduced to Jhonen Vasquez's works through Invader Zim (of whom I am a huge fan), and eventually decided to try out his comics.  That's where I differ a bit from the typical fan, who would probably have started with Johnny the Homicidal Maniac.  Nope, I somehow decided it'd be easier to ease myself into the comic world of Mr. Vasquez by starting with Filler Bunny.  No, I don't know why I thought that'd be a good idea (and I don't recommend it for others).  Anyway, that brings us to this item, “The Collected Works of Fillerbunny.”If you are looking at this review, I presume you are already a fan of Filler Bunny, or at the very least, Jhonen Vasquez, or else, why would you even be here?  Well, if you are looking to collect the Filler Bunny comics, this is the best item to get.  The physical book is bound in softcover, but is of high quality.  The pages feel decently thick, but are in the original black and white (except for the few pages of the third Filler Bunny comic that were originally in color anyways).  Also, if you are concerned that this version misses anything from the originals, the only difference I can see is that the covers for the original books are reproduced in black and white when they were originally in color.  Other than that, everything appears to be here from the originals.  Plus, in addition to this, there's a brand new Filler Bunny comic included!  As for the content of the new comic, if you liked the old stuff, you'll probably like this...If you DO happen to be someone who's never experienced Filler Bunny before...Well, the plot of this thing is a bit difficult to review.  Filler Bunny was originally meant literally to be filler in the spare pages of Johnny the Homicidal Maniac, because apparently when Jhonen needed to fill some extra space he instantly thought the best way to do so was to draw a cartoon rabbit being tortured over and over again (yeah, it sounds bad, and it might be, but it's pretty funny as far as dark humor goes......don't judge me!).  Anyway, Filler Bunny is not a coherent narrative experience since it was only ever meant to be filler.  Over time it's sort of grown into its own unique thing, though, and has evolved beyond just being filler for another comic.So, if you want to easily collect all the Filler Bunny comics in one place (plus the extra comic), then this is the definitive version to get.  As for whether or not you'll like it if you've never read anything by Jhonen before, I think you'll just have to try it yourself.  I strongly suggest, though, if you are new to Jhonen's works, that you start with Johnny the Homicidal Maniac first.  Nonetheless, for people who are already fans of Jhonen's works, “The Collected Works of Filler Bunny” is a real treat.

This is a standard USB to micro USB cable, good for charging cell phones, and for other cable-related tasks.  Functionally, I have tested it, and I see no problems with its performance.  As for it's physical characteristics, it's a little over 3 feet long, accurate to its listing.  I'm quite pleased to say the ends are reasonably slim, which is great since some cables have those fat ends that won't fit easily in certain electronics.  The last thing to mention is the bright orange color, which is indeed as bright as it appears in the pictures.  Having the cable be bright orange is great for people who have a lot of cables because you can easily pick out which cable is which.  It might be cool to find other cable types in different colors so everything is color-coded.  Anyway, this is a fine enough cable for the job, so give it a try if you need an unusual color!

I've been looking for a decent photo prop for displaying my sales earrings for quite some time.  It's surprisingly hard to find a mannequin with a normal sized pierced ear (many of the ones that do have ears feature ears that are too thick and not good for post earrings).  When I came across this lovely-looking bust, it seemed perfect!I really love the aesthetic of this item.  The half-face bust looks so sleek, modern, and sculptural, and the whole thing looks like a pretty piece of art.  The long torso would certainly be good for displaying long necklaces.  As for construction, mine arrived undamaged, and the pole fit into the base and bust with ease, and the whole thing felt stable.Unfortunately, that's where the good points end.  First off, it's not realistically sized.  It is far smaller than a real human's face (as compared with my face – I'm pretty average).  The description claims that it is “8 1/4" wide x 5 1/2” deep x 19 1/2" tall” and that's pretty true for the height and depth.  However, the width is actually smaller than stated, being only 7” wide at the base, and slightly narrower at the face.  What it all amounts to is that the face is not realistically proportioned compared to a real person (unless you intended this bust to match a small child).Well, even though the size is off, I figured it'd still be good for earrings (the primary reason I got it).  I'd read other reviews that claimed that it was hard to get fishhooks through the ear, and they were right.  In fact, I tried all the major types of earrings, and none of them work.  First, I tried a standard fishhook, and it wouldn't work because the ear is too close to the head.  I'd have to bend the fishhook out of whack to make it fit, and I'm not keen on having to damage my fishhooks.  Not that that matters much since my for-sale earrings are actually post earrings.  Post earrings don't fit any better because you can't possibly get your finger behind the ear to get the backs on, and the posts just fall out otherwise.  Lastly, I tried a hoop earring just for the sake of fairness, and it wouldn't fit either.  So, the three most common earring types and none of them would fit. I'd say that's a resounding failure all around.I ended up returning my bust for a refund since it just doesn't reasonably work for any earrings.  If you were just going to get this to display necklaces, I'd say it's okay for that purpose.  However, if you want something nice to display earrings, I'd keep looking.

I love this new Angelspit album, but I can fully understand why the long-time fans will find this release divisive.  It's certainly much different from anything they've previously done, and some people won't be on board with that.  I actually think this release might be just what they needed to get themselves out of whatever rut they were stuck in before.  Yes, I'm implying that I didn't really care for Hello My Name Is, or Hideous and Perfect before it.  I just found them terribly dull (sorry to anyone who loved those albums; it's just my opinion).  If nothing else, this radical change in style has injected some much-needed life into Angelspit's music.It's really hard to pin down exactly what makes this release so different from their older stuff, but it's very easy to feel the change while listening to it.  There seems to be a heavier emphasis on electro stuff in the music.  Of course, how much that bugs people really depends on how much you like/dislike electronic stuff.  I personally enjoy the music on this album – it feels multi-layered and interesting to listen to.One major change here is the conspicuous absence of DestroyX to lend female vocals.  I don't quite know why she's gone, but despite assurances to the contrary in interviews and such, I can't help but fear that she's planning to leave the band or something - I hope that isn't true.  The real reason her absence is particularly noticeable is because although Zoog does an admirable job of singing, and despite the use of guest vocals by people such as Miss Ballistic, there feels like a serious lack of female vocals.  It just feels like something's missing, and that the “something” is female vocals.  The guest vocalists only seem to contribute tiny parts, and the strong female presence is sorely missed on this album.  As for Zoog's vocals, he clean sings here more than any past release, and he does a good job.  I can't complain there.If I was going to complain about something else, it'd be that while the first half of the album feels strong and energetic, the second half of the album (right after Baal Arise) seems to trail off in energy levels.  I just didn't like the songs after Baal Arise as much as the rest of the album (with Ambassador being my favorite).  Still, I can't honestly say that the songs after Baal Arise are terrible or anything, I just didn't quite like them as much.  I still frequently listen to the whole album and enjoy it, so that's not a huge criticism here.  Oh, and on another note, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that Creeper is a fantastic instrumental piece, perhaps one of the best instrumental songs I've heard off of any album in a long time.  Heck, if Angelspit chose to release a purely instrumental album one day and it was up to the quality level of Creeper, I'd be thrilled!Anyway, the last bit of change one might notice is in the lyrics.  The lyrics seem a bit less abstract than the ones you'd find on Krankhaus (and with more varied subject matter than that album had, too).  Still, I found them to be excellent - just as vivid, colorful, socially aware, and angry as you'd expect from an Angelspit release.  There's certainly enough artistry here to keep your mind as occupied as your ears...Overall, this is a good album, but I feel like it does have a few small flaws here and there that are holding it back.  However, it's a solid release, and a great return to form from the disappointment that was Hello My Name Is (once again, sorry if you liked that one).  While this album isn't perfect, it's great enough that it makes me excited again for future Angelspit releases.  I just hope that DestroyX comes back next time.  If you're an Angelspit fan, then you should definitely check out The Product (if only by listening to the song samples on their website first).  Even if you don't end up liking it, it's still worth listening to and deciding for yourself if you like this new direction.

I love this new Angelspit album, but I can fully understand why the long-time fans will find this release divisive.  It's certainly much different from anything they've previously done, and some people won't be on board with that.  I actually think this release might be just what they needed to get themselves out of whatever rut they were stuck in before.  Yes, I'm implying that I didn't really care for Hello My Name Is, or Hideous and Perfect before it.  I just found them terribly dull (sorry to anyone who loved those albums; it's just my opinion).  If nothing else, this radical change in style has injected some much-needed life into Angelspit's music.It's really hard to pin down exactly what makes this release so different from their older stuff, but it's very easy to feel the change while listening to it.  There seems to be a heavier emphasis on electro stuff in the music.  Of course, how much that bugs people really depends on how much you like/dislike electronic stuff.  I personally enjoy the music on this album – it feels multi-layered and interesting to listen to.One major change here is the conspicuous absence of DestroyX to lend female vocals.  I don't quite know why she's gone, but despite assurances to the contrary in interviews and such, I can't help but fear that she's planning to leave the band or something - I hope that isn't true.  The real reason her absence is particularly noticeable is because although Zoog does an admirable job of singing, and despite the use of guest vocals by people such as Miss Ballistic, there feels like a serious lack of female vocals.  It just feels like something's missing, and that the “something” is female vocals.  The guest vocalists only seem to contribute tiny parts, and the strong female presence is sorely missed on this album.  As for Zoog's vocals, he clean sings here more than any past release, and he does a good job.  I can't complain there.If I was going to complain about something else, it'd be that while the first half of the album feels strong and energetic, the second half of the album (right after Baal Arise) seems to trail off in energy levels.  I just didn't like the songs after Baal Arise as much as the rest of the album (with Ambassador being my favorite).  Still, I can't honestly say that the songs after Baal Arise are terrible or anything, I just didn't quite like them as much.  I still frequently listen to the whole album and enjoy it, so that's not a huge criticism here.  Oh, and on another note, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that Creeper is a fantastic instrumental piece, perhaps one of the best instrumental songs I've heard off of any album in a long time.  Heck, if Angelspit chose to release a purely instrumental album one day and it was up to the quality level of Creeper, I'd be thrilled!Anyway, the last bit of change one might notice is in the lyrics.  The lyrics seem a bit less abstract than the ones you'd find on Krankhaus (and with more varied subject matter than that album had, too).  Still, I found them to be excellent - just as vivid, colorful, socially aware, and angry as you'd expect from an Angelspit release.  There's certainly enough artistry here to keep your mind as occupied as your ears...Overall, this is a good album, but I feel like it does have a few small flaws here and there that are holding it back.  However, it's a solid release, and a great return to form from the disappointment that was Hello My Name Is (once again, sorry if you liked that one).  While this album isn't perfect, it's great enough that it makes me excited again for future Angelspit releases.  I just hope that DestroyX comes back next time.  If you're an Angelspit fan, then you should definitely check out The Product (if only by listening to the song samples on their website first).  Even if you don't end up liking it, it's still worth listening to and deciding for yourself if you like this new direction.

I first became acquainted with Angelspit through their first full-length album, Krankhaus, and this EP feels very much like a companion piece to that album.  Nurse Grenade, however, does predate Krankhaus.  Nonetheless, it's safe to say, if you like Krankhaus, you'll probably enjoy Nurse Grenade.Much like Krankhaus, the music on Nurse Grenade is a cacophony of industrial beats, distortion, and yelling, chant-like vocals, all deftly woven together to create a pleasing whole.  As with Krankhaus, the lyrics here are a superb blend of disconcerting word associations and stream-of-consciousness lyric styles, which help to evoke powerful imagery in the listener.  The standout tracks here (at least in my opinion) are Infect, Meat, and Nurse Grenade, but the whole album is great.  The only song that sort of got on my nerves was the I Feel Disease remix, which goes on a bit too long and tends to wear out its welcome.Overall, though, this EP is fantastic and should not be overlooked by Angelspit fans.  It's also not a bad place for new fans to start out with the band, and if you already like Krankhaus but for some reason don't own Nurse Grenade, then you should definitely pick this up.

Where do I begin?  I guess I'll begin at the beginning!  Well, I'm sure everyone's already heard this story a million times and is sick to death of it, but it's the truth.  I originally saw Invader Zim back in the day (and still am a huge fan), got into Jhonen Vasquez's comics after that, then, like most of his fans, went looking for new material to fill the gaping hole in his release schedule (and in our hearts!), and eventually stumbled my way over to this comic.
