I promise not to make any comparisons to Jhonen's works, though, because that's probably going to feel insufferable by now since it seems that anyone who's related in any way to the cast of Invader Zim (Aaron Alexovich contributed character designs to the show) gets their comics, books, underwear, used tissues, etc. compared to Jhonen's stuff.  Nope, I'll be judging this item on its own merits.So, let's talk about this book in particular: the “Serenity Rose: 10 Awkward Years” collection.  I didn't even know this thing was a Kickstarter funded item (and only learned this recently from reading other reviews), this is the very first time I've ever read any Serenity Rose comics, and I had no idea what to expect whatsoever.First off, let's talk about the physical aspects of this collection.  I knew it was a collection of all the comics released over the years when I bought it, but I was truly surprised by how big it was when I finally saw it.  It's massive!  It's about a full 1  inches wide, like a friggin text book!  Not just that, but the quality is really fantastic, much better than I was expecting.  It's in full hardcover binding, and the pages are thick, glossy, fully inked wonders of beauty (similar in quality to the Hyperbole and a Half book, if you've seen that before).  The artwork itself is mostly black and white, but not quite like what you may have seen in other comics.  The shading work is incredible, and there are splashes of color here and there so as to be not truly grayscale.  You seriously won't even notice that it's not in full color after awhile because it looks so good!  Not to mention, the bits that are in color do not look awkward or forced against the backdrop - everything looks really natural and nice; it's hard to explain but suffice it to say, it looks great.  On top of all that, the book has a blue ribbon attached to the top to serve as a bookmark, just like some crazy old leather-bound tome!  You really couldn't ask for more in terms of physical presentation.As for the story and characters, well, remember that this is my very first time ever reading anything Serenity Rose related, so I'm going in with a completely fresh perspective.  The story starts off a bit confusing in the first and second “issue” sections.  I think it's because this portion is meant to really just be an introduction to the characters/town/world/etc.  That's fine, but what makes it confusing is the author's style of interjecting a mostly linear storytelling method with random pages of information (such as town history background, newspaper articles, ect.).  At first, it threw me off, but after I got used to it, I really became apparent that this background info. is useful to the story.  Not to mention, after the second issue, the plot really starts to get going.  It just gets better and better from there, and overall weaves an interesting story.  Unlike some other comic series, this one feels like it actually has an ending, albeit an open-ended one.  My only complaint is that I never got to see the end of Humbly's story.  Sigh.  Oh well, after the main story, there are several special items at the end, mostly old concept art and stuff garnered off his website. This was all very interesting, and I'm glad it was included.Overall, this was an excellent comic and an excellent product.  My only issue is that now I wonder if this comic is going to unfairly raise my expectations for all other comics I read in the future.  Seriously, though, it's rare to see this level of high quality put into a comic release (or any book release of any kind, to be honest).  So, if you are in any way interested in comics, I suggest you check this one out.

I'm a fan of blooming tea, and the first brand I ever had was Teaposy.  That one was gorgeous and delightful!  After that, I ended up getting a Primula teapot gift set, and eventually I replaced the Primula teapot with one from Grosche.  The actual Primula blooming tea balls were not very impressive, as they seemed to be very unreliable with some of the balls floating and refusing to sink, or some not opening properly (the ones that did open properly, though, were nice).  I had a few of the Grosche tea balls that came with the teapot, and they displayed many of the same problems (although, to be fair, they may have been old or something).  After that, I was intrigued to try out the Numi branded ones.Numi has a great reputation for tea, and indeed I like many of their normal boxed teas, such as the white rose flavor.  However, I noticed many bad reviews for their blooming tea.  Still, the price per tea ball was good compared to Teaposy, and I was really intrigued by their unusual flavors.  Most blooming tea I've encountered is either white or green jasmine tea (which is nice), but the Numi tea seems to have more unusual flavors.  The flavors in this box are: Dragon Lily (white tea with lily petals), Sunset Oolong (oolong tea with lily flower), Lavender Dream (lavender flower, hibiscus, and possibly white tea), and Golden Jasmine (black tea and jasmine).  Lavender is a flavor you never really see in blooming tea, so I was excited to try it out.  Not to mention I love the fact that their tea doesn't have any artificial flavors in it.  Besides, even if the tea balls were terrible, I'd only be out about six bucks.The very first thing to discuss is the packaging itself.  It came in a tiny box (which is fine) but inside none of the tea balls were labeled, leaving me to guess which was which based on matching appearances with the pictures on the box (I think I got it right).  More perturbing than that, though, is that the individual ingredients for each type of tea ball are not listed – the ingredient list is all jumbled together for all four.  In addition, the plastic encasing the tea balls is only loosely sealed – it's not vacuum sealed for freshness at all!  The box claims these don't go bad until March 2016, but not being vacuum seals still worries me a bit.  Oh well, there's only four, so surely they'll be used up before long regardless.  I'll go through each individual flavor and describe my experiences.I started off with the Golden Jasmine first, because that's the one my husband was most excited about.  Unfortunately, this experience seems to reinforce all the negative reviews.  The tea ball failed to sink, and it opened sideways on the top of the water line.  Not very impressive or nice-looking at all.  The flavor isn't particularly impressive either.  It tasted of a rather weak black tea, and although the box describes it as being “scented with delicate jasmine,” there is almost no jasmine in evidence.  The scenting must be very “delicate” indeed.  Lest you think it was my steep time or my teapot size, well, I let it steep a full 15 minutes by the end (10 minutes is my normal steep time), and the teapot is the same one I've used for other brands (that gave good flavor).  After my husband and I  each drank one cup, there was enough for one more cup left.  This liquid had, of course, steeped longer due to being left in the pot, and when I drank it, it was indeed a bit stronger tasting.  Unfortunately, it just tasted like slightly stronger black tea; still no real hint of jasmine.  Oh well, one dud out of the four.  We'll see what the others are like...The next one I tried was the Lavender Dream.  I had high hopes for this one since I do like lavender.  While this one sank and opened correctly, it was not particularly attractive.  The “bloom” in the middle wasn't much to look at – just a few ruddy brown petals that looked more like leaves than anything (that was the hibiscus, presumably).  The taste was not good, either.  The hibiscus taste was mildly there, but the lavender wasn't really apparent and the whole thing had an unpleasant bitter undertone.  Overall, I wasn't impressed.Next I tried out the Sunset Oolong.  This one has to be better, right?  Well, the flower in this one was at least more colorful, but this one once again the tea ball refused to sink, and ended up not fully opening either.  The taste was...bland.  It is rather hard to describe, but it's just bland.  Maybe it didn't steep fully or properly since it failed to open?  I don't know.Lastly, I tried out the Dragon Lily.  By this point, I didn't have much hope for this product.  This one, unfortunately, didn't do anything to change my mind.  This one, once AGAIN, didn't sink and opened on its side.  The bloom was dull-colored and rather unattractive regardless.  The taste was pleasant enough, though.  It just tasted of a mild white tea (which it pretty much is).  I can't say I detected any of the purported “velvety apricot flavor” that the box describes, but it was at least drinkable.  However, it wasn't particularly special-tasting, and I can't say I'd want to drink it again (if only because this is an expensive option for something that tastes of plain white tea – I might as well just buy a cheaper box of white tea).Well, overall, I'm deeply disappointed in Numi.  Normally they make such nice tea, but this was a huge let down.  There wasn't a single bloom in here that made me want to buy this again, and frankly, I won't be.  Unfortunately, the other negative reviews are correct.  If you want some blooming tea, I'd recommend you buy Primula (for a cheaper option) or Teaposy (for a really awesome, but more expensive, experience).  There may be other good brands out there, too.  Either way, avoid these.

I have owned a glass teapot previously (I believe it was the Primula brand) that was of a similar size (about 40 oz. - so slightly smaller than this one).  It was nice enough, but my main purpose for having a glass teapot is exclusively to use for blooming teas (a treat I indulge in only occasionally since they are rather expensive).  The problem with the Primula teapot is that it was short and wide, and while it technically held 40 oz., it was too short to properly display a blooming tea, such that I really couldn't enjoy them as much since the “blooms” would often be squashed and unable to be viewed completely.  Eventually I decided that if I was going to use expensive blooming teas, I might as well purchase a better teapot so that I could fully enjoy them.Enter the Grosche Vienna teapot.  This one is tall and rather large, measuring 5 ½ inches from the bottom to the top lip of the teapot.  The bottom is about 5 inches in diameter.  This makes it quite ideal for viewing blooming teas, even the taller designs.  Physically, the Grosche Vienna teapot feels rather delicate (being made of glass), and I have no doubt that it would break if handled roughly.  The lid does need to be held onto while pouring (or removed), or it will slide off, possibly breaking!  However, it is a glass teapot, and this is an inherent property of them.  It is still quite beautiful regardless, and I really like the nontraditional angular design of the sides.  Plus it is really hard to find glass teapots in this large size range, especially ones that are so nice!  I haven't been brave enough to heat it directly on the stove, so I pour hot water into it instead (a good decision judging by the other reviews, regardless of what the packaging claims).  This method has been working well for me, especially since I only bust it out for the occasional indulgence in a blooming tea (my normal tea gets made in a boring old sauce-pot).I really only use it for blooming tea most of the time, but I have tested the infuser too.  This experience was, sadly, a little less than perfect.  The infuser insert has TINY slits rather than holes, and I'm sure this was meant to prevent small loose leaf teas from slipping through (such as rooibos), but it's more of an irritant than anything.  It doesn't allow water to pass through very quickly at all, which means that tea cannot steep very well, but aside from that, it make filling the teapot irritating.  You have to fill the teapot a bit over half-way so that water doesn't spill out when you stick the insert in, and then, the insert fills with water so slowly that you have to pour the rest of your water in small increments so that the whole thing doesn't overflow.  Bigger holes would have prevented all this nonsense, but of course, a few bits of tea might have fallen out.  I'd say that would be a worthy trade-off, though.  Better yet, adding in some more holes in the sides of the infuser would've helped a lot too.  Oh well, I'd recommend using a teaball (with it's little hook chain hooked to the rim of the teapot) instead of the glass infuser.  I know that defeats the purpose of the pretty glass one, but it honestly works better.My package also came with three bonus blooming teas of the Grosche brand, and unfortunately, they were pretty mediocre.  I don't know if this is a flaw inherent to all Grosche branded blooming teas, or if these were just out of date or something (who knows how long they have been sitting in this package).  The problem with them was that none of them bloomed properly (most didn't open up all the way, or just plain looked hideous, and many of them floated and refused to sink).  The taste seemed okay, though, so maybe it is just a flaw with the Grosche brand.  For reference, I've also tried Primula flowering tea (better, but not perfectly reliable) and Teaposy ones.  The Teaposy ones are the best by far (and most reliable in terms of always opening up properly and such), but also the priciest, so I guess this is one of those situations where you get what you pay for.As for any major flaws in the teapot...well, I can only think of the issue with the infuser.  I do wish sometimes that the glass were a tad thicker, but I haven't yet discovered a glass teapot with thicker glass, so I can't really say it's below the standard or anything.  Also, the narrow opening does make it slightly tricky to clean, but I've discovered that a simple rinse is fine usually, and once it starts to look a bit stained, I use oxyclean.  Just soak the teapot in a bit of hot water and oxyclean and the stains melt right off, no scrubbing involved!  Then just give it a good rinse and it's all ready to go!  Overall, if you're in the market for a glass teapot specifically for blooming tea, I can't think of a better one to recommend than the Grosche Vienna.  Just maybe buy another brand for the actual blooming tea-balls themselves.

Hmm...so i'm not exactly the target audience for this device, but I've decided to review it anyway, because writing reviews is fun!  Besides, I might be able to offer some information to help other buyers in the future (and my husband really doesn't like writing reviews, so he said I should do it on my account).  I bought this as a gift for my husband ('cause I have lots of toys so I thought he'd like one, too!) and have gathered his feedback on the device, as well as my own thoughts on the product.  It helps that I got a really good half-price deal on this, so my perception is already skewed slightly toward the positive.First off, I don't entirely get the whole "fleshlight" gimmick.  I thought the point was to conceal its true nature and have it look more discrete.  That's all well and good, but this item won't fool anyone into thinking it's a real flashlight.  It's huge (bigger than any real flashlight would be), looks really plastic and fake, and as if to rub salt in the wound, it's got the word "fleshlight" plastered on the side in big letters.  Oh, well, I suppose that doesn't matter so long as it functions well...My husband says it works quite nicely and feels quite good (use some nice water-based lube with it, of course - I got him some "Gun Oil H2O," which I recommend).  He recommends warming it up with some warm water first, though.  I stuck my finger down the entrance hole (which is actually strangely fun to do), and I can say it feels squishy, but also kinda firm (like most good things in life!), but didn't remind me strongly of the real thing.  However, my husband seems to like it, so that's good enough!So, functionally, all seems well, but the issue comes afterwards.  Cleanup of this item is not easy at all.  One has to run water through it to remove 'fun-time fluids,' and then the item takes ages to dry out.  Even if you remove the squishy silicone part from the plastic casing, it still doesn't dry out any faster.  Even putting it back into the plastic casing and standing it upright to help the water drip out doesn't make it dry any faster.  It took a couple days for it to dry out completely!  This is certainly an issue if you're worried about kids/roommates/your parents/your pets/that one friend who won't ever go home/etc. seeing this out in the open.  I'm thinking the best way to handle this is to get a blow dryer and use the low heat setting.  That's not exactly discrete either, but it might speed up the process a bit.  If I had my way, I think the design could be improved by cutting the entire item lengthwise, then permanently gluing the silicone to the plastic housing, and have the two halves connected by a hinge that could be open and shut.  That way, it could just be hinged open when cleaning, and it'd be able to be dried much faster.  Of course, I have no idea if this plan is even possible in reality, or if the silicone would lack sufficient rigidity to hold its shape during use in this design.  Oh well.  I still give this item five stars since there doesn't appear to be any better alternatives in the current market, and this is really the best one can get for this type of item.Overall, this seems like a great item for its purpose.  I do sorely wish the design made it easier to clean, but this is probably the best male toy of its type that one can find.  You'll just have to decide for yourself if the functionality is worth the trade-off of the inconvenient cleaning.  If you're on the fence about getting one, try to wait for a good sale before taking the plunge!

I already own several fake gauge earrings because I've really fallen in love with the look of them!  To finish up my collection, I was interested in getting some really cool dragon themed earrings.  I didn't find any that appealed to me for awhile, and then these came up!I love how they are based on a more “medieval” style dragon rather than the oriental kind (which are pretty common in fake gauge earrings – I love the unusualness of this one).  I also like their small size (mine measure at a petite 1.25” diameter) and the silver tips that give it some edge.  Oh, and lest you think this is something that won't look as nice in person as the picture does, the carving work on mine was superb.  All the little details pictured are present and look great!  Indeed, I've not been let down by this seller yet!As for insertion, I found it pretty easy, but I've got so many fake gauges that I'm pretty good at this by now.  If you are new to fake gauges, you might need to practice a bit.  Just make sure you treat them gently so you don't bend the ear wire.  I find them to be very light weight when worn, and they look great on me.So, overall I'm very pleased with these.  If you are looking for some cool dragon earrings, or just some cool earrings in general, give these a try!

At first, I was intrigued by this item but kind of too embarrassed to review it, then I thought, "what the heck, I'll do it!" and picked it up.  TP+ Cleansing Foam with Aloe is exactly what you imagine it to be - a foam you put on your tissue paper to help pamper your behind.  Well, no one pampers his behind more than my husband (who spends an inordinate amount of time in the bathroom), so I decided to let him do the bulk of product testing for me.  Of course, I have tested it as well - it's always useful to get a second opinion.The product itself comes in a small bottle, which measures about 5 inches tall and 1 ¼ inches in diameter.  This is a great compact size if you intend to bring it with you while traveling.  The bottle has a very easy to press nozzle, which secretes a foam substance.  This foam feels exactly like those foaming hand sanitizers.  It's a nice texture because it doesn't run nor soak through the toilet paper excessively and make it soggy (assuming you are using good quality toilet paper and not the horrible industrial stuff).  As for actual use...well, I didn't experience any burning sensations or other allergic reactions, but your mileage may vary here.  I also felt like it did a good job producing a feeling of cleanliness, at least better than plain toilet paper.  I would compare it to moist wipes, but I've never actually used those before, so I wouldn't know...As for my husband's assessment, he says that it's a very nice item to have to get that feeling of extra clean, but that it's not essential.  So, nice as an extra, but not an item he couldn't live without.  That's pretty much the same feeling I had, too.  Once again, though, your mileage may vary here since everyone's different.  I, personally, say you give it a try if the idea intrigues you.  If you end up not liking it, well, then, you're not really out much.

Well, just to give any readers a full disclosure, let me state outright that I'm not too fond of green tea.  In fact, I have tons of different kinds of tea and herbal “teas” (yes, I know brewed herbs are technically tisanes and not “tea”), but the one thing I don't keep on hand is green tea, because I don't care for its flavor.  However, when I saw this item that combines green tea and peppermint, I thought, “why not?”  The great thing about peppermint is that its strongly flavored, and might make the green tea more palatable...The first thing I did when I got my tea in the mail was to open it up and sniff a tea bag.  It smells strongly of peppermint, with no real hint of green tea.  I chose to brew mine for 10 minutes, and after tasting it hot, I can say that the green tea is definitely subtle.  In fact, I almost wouldn't know that it wasn't plain peppermint tea.  It tastes almost exactly like normal peppermint, with only a tiny hint of “something else” in there.  Once I let it cool in the fridge and tried it iced, it tasted about the same.So, I can safely recommend this tea to someone who doesn't really care for green tea, but might be interesting in drinking it for health benefits or some such since you really can't taste it.  However, if you were really hoping that the green tea flavor was prominent with only a hint of peppermint, well, unfortunately, you'll be out of luck with this product.  In fact, if that's your situation, I'd suggest buying some loose leaf green tea and peppermint (easy enough to find) and making your own little mix.  As it is, this tea is decent enough for my needs, so I'm pretty pleased with it!

Over the past year, real life had crept up on me, and I hadn't even noticed that my favorite author had released a new book until now!  I've been a fan of Amelia's since middle school, and although I'm no longer within the target age range for her books (far from), I find that I still enjoy them.  After her last book, Promises to Keep, I was feeling rather anxious about how any future sequels would fare (some rather intense changes take place in that book, but I won't spoil it here).  However, this book does not take place chronologically after that book, but instead is set in the distant past (in the 1800s).  Oh well, so it's not a sequel.  Nonetheless, I did enjoy it.The book follows protagonist Vance Ehecatl, a shapeshifter who was raised in luxury and gently cared for, but who is essentially being manipulated by his vampire overlords.  Eventually, he must choose where his loyalties lie.  I'm not going to give away any more of the plot than that, but suffice it to say, it's a great and interesting new perspective from Ms. Atwater-Rhodes.  I've read every single book of hers (plus extra stuff on her website), so I can definitely say that this book offers a new and fresh perspective.  Diehard fans of her books will be quite pleased with it.However, this book isn't really for “newcomers” to the series.  In fact, in the past I was able to describe certain books of hers as okay starting points for people unfamiliar with her works, but with each passing book, it's become apparent to me that anyone who doesn't already have a background in her world will be awfully confused.  This book is no different.  I know some might claim that you could jump in right here and be fine, but that's not really the case (and judging by the other reviews where people were obviously confused, I'm quite right about that).  That being said, I personally loved this new book, but I'm already very familiar with her world, and many of the characters featured here were introduced previously in other books (and indeed, for the dedicated fan, seeing all those cameos were great!).  Many of the characters, though, were fleshed out much better in previous books, and I can imagine that a new reader wouldn't really understand these people without that prior knowledge (in fact, it's helpful to have even read all the supplementary information in the wiki page on her website). A new reader would probably not understand much of anything that happened in this book, and I don't blame them for being confused at all.  Still, I did enjoy it.So...do I recommend “Bloodwitch?”  Well, if you're already a fan of Ms. Atwater-Rhodes' writing and have read her other books, then yes, it's quite the treat!  However, if you are new to her writings, I'd suggest starting with her very first book, “In the Forest of the Night” and just reading them in order of release.  I know that reading that many books is a pretty big investment, but you'll know after the first two or three if her writing style is for you or not.  I'm already a huge fan and love her work, but not everyone does, so I guess that's up to you.  You'll just have to read and find out!

I have a canopy bed with a big metal frame, and I was looking for some new curtains to put on it.  My first thought was to buy some 216" long window scarves, and I did, but they ended up being awful quality - full of snags and runs.  So, I dumped those and went with Plan B: these ruffled curtains.  I was somewhat reluctant to buy them, though, since there were some negative reviews.  Still, I forged ahead and bought four of the 60x84" ones in the cream color (to match my bedroom).I'm very pleased to say that the quality was great!  I didn't get any with horribly crooked ruffles (of course, I'm sure a few ruffles are a bit crooked, but not to a distracting degree).  They have a great weight to them and are not as sheer as other reviews would have you believe.  In fact, I'd say the material is voile-style and not like a sheer at all.  They are reasonably heavy without being too heavy, I'd say.  The cream color is a light cream (almost an off-white) and is pretty true to the picture.  One negative point, though, is that when I got them they had tons of tiny loose strings hanging off everywhere.  I trimmed them off, and now it's not an issue.  Of course, they were also terribly wrinkled, and I tried the "wet them and let them drip dry" trick to get out the wrinkles, but no luck, so I had to iron them.  That took about two hours, but hey, it's done now, so no big deal.  Oh, as a side note, I think that a rod bigger than 1" diameter probably wouldn't fit through the rod pocket.  Hmm...maybe a 1.5" rod could fit at the most.  Keep that in mind if you're thinking of buying this.The ruffles look great on my canopy bed, and I've already found four different ways of arranging them (via wrapping around the bed posts, draping across the cross-beams, pulling them back and using ribbon ties, etc.) to get different effects.  It's too bad amazon doesn't allow picture uploads anymore, or I'd show some pics.  Oh well, I'm really pleased with the versatility of these curtains for a canopy bed.  They probably wouldn't be nearly as versatile when used on windows, but I'm sure they'd still be pretty enough.Anyway, I heartily recommend these curtains, especially if you have a canopy bed of the sort with a big rectangular frame.  They are a great value for their price (which was about twenty dollars a panel at the time of my purchase).  They would look great with a shabby chic décor, or just for anyone who wants to add a touch of romance or whimsy to their room!

I had recently gotten tired of my old bedding (a perfectly good cream colored Raymond Waites set that is nice enough but I was in the mood for something brighter).  I was interested in something very bright and cheery instead of subdued for my room.  Unfortunately, the manufacturing world has decided to switch most bedding to microfiber (read: polyester) because it's cheaper, but I can't stand polyester.  I need cotton because it breathes!  So, naturally, that limited my options.  I looked at tons of queen sized bedding online, but I wasn't really feeling a lot of them.  I was thrilled when I found this set, because it's made of cotton and is so bright and pretty, but there are some downsides...First off, though, let's talk about the good parts.  The set is indeed brightly colored - just like the picture.  I like the fact that the squares are just printed on instead of being an actual patchwork quilt-type thing, mainly because that's fewer seams that could potentially rip loose in the wash.  The underside of the comforter is light minty green with white dots (a decent backing, but you couldn't really call this comforter "reversible"). The pillowcases seem to fit fine.  The fitted sheet that comes with it has elastic all the way around, which I like.  Unfortunately, it's made for a much bigger mattress than I have (I have an 8 inch memory foam one), so I couldn't use it (FYI: the only sheets I've found that fit thin mattresses like that well come from Target!).  I would've bought the smaller 8-Piece set without the sheets, but it seems chronically out of stock.  Anyway, it's a generally nice-looking comforter for the price, even if I ended up not using the sheets.  That's about it for the good points, unfortunately.Now, the bad stuff...  When I first got the set in the mail and opened it up, I spread it out and noticed that several of the tacking stitches were already torn loose.  I fixed them by hand.  Then I noticed the awful texture of this comforter.  This is some really low grade cotton, and was immensely stiff and actually made a crinkling sound when moved.  It was so bad that I decided a washing was in order to hopefully soften it up (of course, you should always wash new bedding anyways).  The washing did help soften it a bit (not as much as I'd like, though), but the rest of the tacking stitches came loose in the wash - all of them.  I had to fix all of them by hand (I also added extras to be safe).  Well, that should take care of that.  Unfortunately, that's when I noticed that the batting was rather thin.  The comforter fabric feels loose and saggy because there just isn't a decent amount of batting in there (enough to keep me warm, though).  So, I guess my point here is that quality is rather poor overall.  The weird thing is that my other comforter cost about the same price, but is of immensely better quality.  Go figure.Despite all those rather negative points, I'm still overall pleased with it.  It's certainly very pretty, and does it's job of brightening up the room with color.  Just be prepared to do a lot of work to fix it up if you choose to buy it.  It's a shame they didn't do a better job on this comforter - then it would've been outstanding and worthy of five stars.  As it is, though, it's only getting 3 stars from me.  I imagine it won't last forever, but I'll just try to enjoy it until it breaks, then get a new one - hopefully something of better quality.Update:  Okay, here's an update to my original review. I'm lowering my score to 2 stars now.  I really wish I hadn't been so in love with the color of this comforter when I first bought it - I would have sent it back for a refund.  I've had it an additional four months now, and the cotton fabric is still "crinkly" and unpleasant (in a way that cotton really should not be), and doesn't seem to be softening any more with repeated washings at all.  It hasn't fallen apart yet (due to my many tacking stitches), but it's still loose and floppy feeling - like sleeping with an old sack for a comforter.  This is the one time I truly wish the cotton had shrunk in the dryer because then it wouldn't be so floppy and sad!  Also, and this might be just my imagination, but this comforter feels like it doesn't breathe quite as well as my other one, despite having such thin batting.  Either way, there's no doubt about it, the cotton fabric is of poor quality.  On the bright side, the colors have not faded and still look quite bright.  Too bad the thin filling and bagginess of it hurt the overall appearance.  My final verdict on this set now is to just avoid it.  I know it looks really pretty and brightly colored, but it's just not worth the poor quality and the hassle of fixing the stitches.  I'll personally be avoiding the Pointehaven brand in the future.

I own several Sauder furniture products already (the Harbor View Computer Armoire, Harbor View Dresser and the Vinegate Storage Tower) and I love them!  So, when my husband wanted a new desk that better fit his needs, I looked to Sauder once more since I trust their quality (well, for particle board, of course).We ended up choosing this desk and buying it from a certain store that starts with “W” and ends in “-mart” (seriously, it's cheaper there – I paid about $250).  Once it arrived, we laid out all the pieces, and sorted/counted all the hardware.  I only discovered one bit of damage, a large scratch on one of the big pieces.  It wasn't a big deal though, because it was a part that would be under the desk and not so visible.  I touched it up with a furniture marker and moved on to assembly.Assembly for this item is the hardest I've had for any Sauder piece of furniture.  It definitely requires two people, and as with any assembly, you need to proceed methodically and carefully (preferably reading through the instructions first before starting).  Assembly took about 4 hours, as I figured it would.  Oh, and it's in the instructions, but as a heads up, you can adjust the individual heights of each dresser drawer so that they are all evenly spaced and perfect-looking.The desk is quite heavy once fully assembled, but I count that a good thing since that means it's sturdy.  The finish, though, is not the strongest, so if you eat at your desk a lot, I'd recommend using a placemat so you don't damage the finish over time.  In terms of overall appearance, I'd say the desk looks nice enough for being particle board, but it does have little imperfections here and there (such as slightly crooked spots) that keep it from looking like a true “executive” desk.  Let's be honest here, though, no real “executive” would buy an unassembled particle board desk to stick in their office – they'd get one made of real wood.  For its price compared to real wood, I'd have to say it's pretty good, and would be fine for home usage.  My husband certainly seems pleased with it, so that's good enough for me!  Oh, and by the way, this one does not have the blank 'cardboard' back, so it can look good from any angle!Something that you should be aware of, and something that I was disappointed with, is the two top drawers.  They look like two small  drawers each, but they are actually just faux drawers, and it's one big drawer.  That means there's only 4 drawers total (plus the middle one, more on that later), not six.  The two big lower drawers actually are built to hold file folders, which is cool.  They even feature adjustable sizes for different sized file folder types (pretty much all the standard sizes).  The middle drawer is actually a hidden pullout keyboard tray!  It opens up and the front flips down (and features a hole in the back to let cords out).  That's pretty cool, but my husband preferred his keyboard on top of the desk, so he just used the middle drawer for office supplies.  The desk also features a hole in the top (with a cover cap) to hold cords from a monitor.  Overall, it's a pretty cool, functional desk that looks nice enough for home use, so if you have a tolerance for assembling furniture (I'm a freak and actually enjoy it), then I'd recommend it!Oh, and for anyone who needs them, here's a load of measurements for your pleasure...  First off, the whole desk measures 29 ” deep by 65 1/8” long by 30” high.  The space for the desk chair to go under measures 24 ½” high by 29 3/4” wide.  The height of the feet on the bottom of the desk is 4 3/4” (don't know why you'd need this info., but here it is!).  As for the drawers, the interior of the middle drawer keyboard tray measures 27 3/8” wide by 14” deep (front to back) by 3 3/4” high.  When the front is flipped down for keyboard use, the depth is a full 18 1/2”.  The interior of the top two drawers measure 12 1/8” wide by 14 ¼” deep (front to back) and 6 ½ high.  The interior of the bottom two file drawers measure 12” wide by 14 ¼” deep (front to back) and 9 ½ high.  Well, that's everything that I could imagine you needing a measurement for.  Hope it helps!

This seems like a perfectly nice stapler.  It's a rather average desktop stapler and takes average size staples (I used some generic branded ones I already had instead of the recommended brand specific ones).  Size-wise, the stapler is very average for a desktop stapler, measuring 7 1/4” long.  The weight is decent considering it's all-metal construction, but it's not overly heavy or anything.Performance-wise, it seems to be pretty good.  I tested it on just two sheets of paper, and also on a thick bunch of paper (pushing it's 20 page limit) and it performed fine on both.  As I've been using it, I haven't had any jams or staples fail to go through things, so I have no complaints there.  I don't feel like it takes a particularly strong amount of force to staple things, but it's not as easy at those “easy touch” staplers or anything – pretty average, I'd say.  Oh, and as an added bonus, if you use a switch on the bottom, it can be opened up flat and used to staple things to bulletin boards.  I suppose that's useful if you have a bulletin board that requires stapling.Overall, I'd have to say this is an average, but sturdy and reliable stapler.  It might not be spectacular or standout in any way, but I have no complaints against it.  If you need a good, reliable desktop stapler, then go ahead and give this one a try!

I use a lot of binders for college, and having a big 2 inch one on hand is useful sometimes.  I've had other binders from the Wilson Jones brand before, and this one seems decent enough.  I'm a bit disappointed that it doesn't have the awesome double pockets on the inner covers that some of the other Wilson Jones binders have.  Yes, it only has the two standard pockets, and on top of that, they seem just a bit too shallow, such that my papers fall out sometimes.On the bright side, it has the same nice reinforcement down the spine seams to stop tearing.  The rings sit flat on the back cover instead of the spine, if that matters to you.  The rings, unfortunately, are some of the stiffest rings I've ever encountered – this thing is quite hard to open and close!  Well, at least this hopefully means that they will hold up well over time.  Also, this binder has the front and back cover outside pockets so you can label them with a slip of paper, which is nice.This particular binder doesn't seem quite as nice as some other Wilson Jones binders I have (with it missing the double pockets and being really hard to get the rings open), but it still seems like a perfectly serviceable binder.  Good enough, I say!

This seems like a pretty average binder.  I've had binders from the Wilson Jones brand before, and I can't say this one is my favorite or anything.  It's decent enough, of course, but I'm rather disappointed that it doesn't have the awesome four inner cover pockets (two on each side) that some of the other Wilson Jones binders have.  Yes, it only has the two standard pockets.On the bright side, it has the same nice reinforcement down the spine seams to stop tearing.  The rings sit flat on the back cover instead of the spine, if that matters to you.  The rings, though are a bit stiff and hard to open and close.  Hopefully that means that they will hold up well over time.  Also, be aware that this binder has the front and back cover outside pockets so you can label them with a slip of paper, which is nice.Yeah, I'd have to say this is a perfectly reasonable binder, even if I do miss the double pockets.  I also like the color (I got the red one) since you don't see that color very often in binders, and I'm starting to have trouble telling all of mine apart.  Anyway, this is a fine enough binder, so give it a try if you like!

I use binders all the time for my college classes, and I've ruined quite a few over the years by having them crack down the spines' seams.  So, the idea of a more durable binder is quite nice.  Enter the Wilson Jones Ultra Duty Binder with Extra Durable Hinge...This is a rather nice, all-around useful binder.  I can't say it's all that different from your average binder, except for a few details that make it nicer.  First off, I love the double pockets on each cover (that's four pockets total!  Four!).  It also has some nice reinforcement down the spine seams, so that'll help stop it from tearing there over time (a thing that happens to my binders).  It also has the one sided "easy open" thing for the rings (which are round, by the way).  The rings sit flat on the back cover instead of the spine, if that matters to you.  Also, be aware that these binders have the front and back cover outside pockets so you can label them with a slip of paper, which is nice.Yeah, I'd have to say this is a perfectly nice and serviceable binder.  It's a bit nicer than the standard cheap-y binders you can get at certain stores whose names end in -mart, so if you're looking for a more durable binder, go ahead and give this one a try!

Well, I was in the mood to replace my old flashlight when this thing popped up in Vine.  Hooray!  Oh, and my old flashlight is a nasty cheap thing from dollar tree, so obviously this is a big step up.  How good is it?  Let's find out!First off, size-wise it's quite small at only four inches long.  As for it being advertized as light weight, well it weighs 2.15 oz., so I'd say it's pretty light.  The build quality here feels fantastic.  The housing body is a sturdy metal, while the head and end are both plastic (nice plastic though).  I also love the metal clip part - that thing is never going to snap off!As for functionality...  First off, it can apparently take a variety of batteries, but I only had some AA batteries on hand, so I used one of those.  It was quite easy to screw off the button end and stick the battery in there.  Also, I feel stupid about this, but the flashlight arrived with no instructions, so it actually took me awhile to figure out that if you pull the head of it out, you can narrow the beam.  Just push it back in if you want a wider beam.  Speaking of which, I don't often run into tiny flashlights that have such wide beams, and I love it!  Of course, the ability to adjust it is even better!  Lastly, let's talk about the light itself.  The LED casts a more bright white light than yellow (don't know if that's important to you or not, but I like it).  As for brightness, mine's a 220 lumen version, and subjectively, I can say that it's pretty darn bright for its size.  It's certainly bright enough to look into the interior of a computer or behind the couch to see where you dropped your keys, but maybe not bright enough for a romantic nighttime beach walk.Overall, I'd say this is a great flashlight for its size, but just don't expect any miraculous, unfair levels of brightness out of it.  Also, the price as of the time of this writing was about ten bucks, so you really can't beat the price either.  If you need a tiny flashlight, you may as well get this one - it's nice!

I was really excited when I saw the brown version of this binder because it looks a lot like one of those really classy stitched-leather binders (I mean, if you squint a bit, from a distance...), and indeed, I got the brown one!  Once seen in person, it can sort of pass for leather (I mean, if you squint a bit, from a distance...).  Okay, in all seriousness, it's not going to fool anyone, but it still looks like a nice classy binder, and could be useful if you're going for that look.More important than aesthetics, though, is how well this binder functions.  In that regard, I'd say that it works as you'd expect (for the most part...).  The metal rings are good and hold paper well and if it matters to you, the rings are on the back cover and not on the binder's spine.  Some people prefer one way or the other, but I have no real preference there.  This binder has some pretty serious flaws, at least for me.  There is no back cover pocket, only a front one,  and it's one of those horrible half-pockets.  If you don't know what I mean, the right side of the pocket is totally open, allowing paper packets to fall out.  Not to mention, due to the stitching, any standard size 8.5”x11” paper you put in them stick out the top awkwardly by just a little bit (however, standard college-ruled notebook paper seems to fit fine; I guess it's slightly smaller).  That's a shame for such a nice looking binder, because anyone who'd drop money on this classy-looking item wouldn't want it to then look messy from papers sticking out the top.  The lack of functional pockets is what kills it for me in this item.Oh, and on a different note, the metal rings are removable.  According to the instructions, this is actually for recycling purposes.  I can't imagine that even people who recycle will remember this when the time comes to throw this binder out, but it's a nice thought on the manufacturer's part, I suppose.Well, I guess the last point of interest is price.  This binder was about eight dollars as of the time of writing this review, which is indeed more expensive than your average cheap three dollar white binder (we all know the type).  Of course, anyone buying this would be doing so specifically for it's appearance rather than just it's functionality as a binder, so the price might be worth it depending on one's perspective.  I'm just sad that the whole pocket thing keeps it from being a perfectly functioning binder.  I guess if you don't need that pocket or simply want to trade functionality for aesthetic appeal, then go for it!

I already have the Sauder Harbor View Computer Armoire (which I absolutely love) and the Sauder Vinegate Storage Tower (using it in the bedroom as a display cabinet since even though it isn't technically part of the Harbor View collection, the finish matches perfectly!).  After those two items, it seemed time to finish out my bedroom suite with the Sauder Harbor View 5 Drawer Chest.  My old dresser is actually another Sauder dresser, but in a finish that doesn't match.  I've had it for 8 years, and it has held up beautifully well (the only reason I replaced it was to get a matching color item).  What I'm trying to say is, I trust Sauder's quality.Sauder makes a lot of what I'd refer to as "high end particle board" furniture.  Unlike many brands that make particle board furniture (*cough* Prepac *cough*), Sauder actually makes rather nice quality for being particle board. Their pieces are nice and heavy and feel sturdy instead of weak.  However, this is only if assembled properly...That brings me to my next point that everyone seems to complain about: the assembly.  Yes, this will take you about 4 hours to put together (and I suggest having help to make things a bit easier).  Frankly, you shouldn't rush through this job.  I suggest reading through the instructions once fully before even starting so you have an idea of what pieces go together and what their ultimate articulation is going to be.  It helps a lot.  Then, lay out all your pieces and parts and go through the list, accounting for all of them and checking for damage (mine was completely undamaged).  Make sure your sort your screws and other parts into organized piles at this time.  Once you do start assembly, make sure you are slow, thorough and methodical to ensure accuracy (which is good advice for many projects in life).  I was able to assemble my dresser easily and it is sturdy, even, and beautiful.  Oh, and it's in the instructions, but as a heads up, you can adjust the individual heights of each dresser drawer so that they are all evenly spaced and perfect-looking.Unfortunately, though, when I made this dresser I thought I'd be clever and leave off the drawer Interlocking System (this prevents you from opening more than one drawer at a time) to save a tiny bit of time.  That was probably a poor decision, though, as I discovered after testing that the dresser will become unstable if you open just three drawers at once.  My old dresser didn't do that, but it was also a lot deeper (and much of that was empty space since the drawers were shallower by comparison).  So, this dresser sacrifices a bit of stability for a reduced size profile, which in my tiny apartment is much appreciated.  I then decided to retroactively put in the Interlock System, and did so successfully with minimal effort.Now that I've discussed all that, let's go through some pros and cons of this item.  First, the pros.  It's a very attractive item for being particle board.  Yes, it does have the "cardboard" back (but every piece of particle board furniture has this - there's no getting away from it).  It still looks good for what it is, and matching the other furniture from the Harbor View (and Vinegate) collection well.  As mentioned earlier, if assembled correctly, it is level, strong, and sturdy (for the most part, see my cons below).  On top of that, the drawers are rather spacious and make full use of the unit's size.Now, let's have some cons.  The finish will scratch if you aren't careful, but being an "antiqued" finish gives it the benefit of still looking acceptable if you touch up the scratches with a furniture marker.  Antique charm and all that.  The one big con I really think of is the drawer bottoms, which unlike every other nice thick sturdy piece on this dresser, is made of a very thin, flimsy material (some sort of press-board, I think).  This gave me some pause at first, but then I realized that my old dresser had the same sort of thin flimsy-feeling thing for it's drawer bottoms, and that lasted me 8 years of heavy use.  So, maybe it won't be such an issue after all.  I wouldn't use this dresser for a very young child's room, though, as they might manage to break the drawer bottoms, and besides, if they climbed up the dresser, it would surely tip over since it is front-heavy.Overall, I'm quite pleased with the dresser.  It's meeting my needs quite well, and is the Sauder brand quality I've come to expect (in fact, I'll be sticking to this brand as much as possible for future furniture needs).  Sauder's Harbor View collection (and honestly many of their other collections) are a great way to get a decent-looking furniture set without spending a fortune for real wood items (which will often run you $1000+ for a single item).  If you're on a budget but still want a nice look, I highly recommend the Sauder Harbor View 5-Drawer chest (and much of their other stuff too)!Oh, and for anyone who needs them, here are some relevant measurements.  The overall dresser dimensions are 49.5" high, 31" wide, and 17.625" deep.  The inner dimensions of the top dresser drawer is 25.625" wide across, 13.875" from front to back, and 3.75" deep (note that this is the smallest of the drawers). The next three drawers measure 24.5" wide across, 13.75" from front to back, and 6.375" deep.  The bottom drawer is only very slightly different from the other three, and is: 24.625" wide across, 13.875" from front to back, and 6.375" deep.  Well, hope these measurements were helpful to someone!Edit: Just an update.  The dresser is still working quite well for the most part, but I've encountered a minor issue with the drawer locking system.  The bottom two drawers stick sometimes.  What I mean is that they don't open sometimes even when the other drawers are shut, and strangely this problem is solved by opening a higher up drawer first, then closing it.  This was a kind of an annoying problem, so I removed the locking mechanisms from the bottom two drawers.  Problem solved!  Now it works fine and I have no further issues.  Just putting this out there in case someone's having similar problems and need a fix.

I'm long past the days of needing locker accessories, but I still thought this pencil cup looked interesting, either for a fridge door, or to sit on my desk like a normal pencil holder.  The color looks nice in person (a nice rich purple) and the construction seems solid.I tested it on the fridge and the magnets are quite strong, but I've decided to use it on my desk.  I like the idea of the divider in the middle so I can better organize my stuff.  Once closed up, the pencil cup still holds well and does not pop open accidentally (which is great).  However, there are some serious flaws in the design...First off, is a minor complaint:  it feels ever so slightly too tall for the average pen/mechanical pencil.  This is a rather personal subjective thing, but I wish it was just 1/2 of an inch lower.  I recognize that this negative point is a bit nitpicky, but there is a far worse issue I ran into.Those strong awesome magnets that let it hang on lockers and fridge doors are actually so strong that once it's closed (to use on a desk), anything that's got a bit of metal in it sticks the middle divider.  Yes, really.  My scissors stick to it, and even my mechanical pencils stick to it (by the top clip part, which is often made of metal in mechanical pencils).  I guess this could be good if you are using it in a locker and you want your mechanical pencils to be really secure because it's all magnetically stuck, but I found it irritating.  The magnets were so strong that every time I pulled my scissors out to use them, it would knock the cup askew just a bit.  It's just the sort of tiny irritation that would end up bugging me a lot over time...  And even if most high schoolers (the target audience for this product) wouldn't be stashing scissors in their locker, most of them will be using mechanical pencils, and they may find the tugging magnetism every time they tried to get one out annoying.  Or maybe it'll be a plus since the pencils will be so secure...Eh, my final verdict on this product is that while I had good expectations for it, I'm thinking it's not right for my particular needs.  I'm probably better off to just buy one of those simple organizer cups that you see everywhere.  Still, if you have a locker that needs a good, strong magnetic pencil cup, I think this might be just the thing for you...

I was rather intrigued when I saw this device – it's like a notebook and  binder combined!  Well, that's technically what it is – a hybrid between the two.  I use binders a lot for my college classes, and tend to avoid notebooks (don't like the fact that you can't replace or move paper).  Of course, the only downside to a binder is size since they can be a bit bulkier than needed depending on the size.  So, when I saw this item, I was willing to give it a try.First off, let me give you a quick run-down of what comes in this and exactly what it's all like.  The front cover has a clear plastic pocket so you can put any labeling page in there you want (such as “Accounting 101”).  The back cover is much the same, sans the clear pocket.  I really don't like these covers because they are floppy.  If only they had been stiff plastic instead!  The floppiness of them makes the whole thing feel unstable when you are lifting it in and out of a backpack, plus if you wanted to fold the front cover back and write on it in the field like a notebook, be prepared to have a really awkward thing on your hands.  Meh.Well, moving on from that, once you open the cover there are two pocket pages/tab dividers (apparently the theme of “hybrids” runs throughout).  Unfortunately, these pocket pages are nearly useless for anything more than 2-3 sheets of paper.  Why?  Well, the pocket's left edge isn't secured to anything.  Yes, it's just open and the pocket just sort of hangs there.  They added a flap to the top to help hold the papers in (they knew it was a terrible idea and tried to compensate).  If you put in something like a stapled packet of papers (the sort of thing your professor might hand out), it'd fall right out during normal use.  Sadly, compared to a binder with normal pockets (which a packet of papers WOULD fit into), this thing doesn't compare favorably.  Interestingly, on top of the open flap pocket, there's a smaller pocket that I don't really know what to do with.  I suppose a few notecards or something could fit in there, but of course, the number of notecards most people would use would be far too thick for it.  It might be fine to hold some pencils though.  Well, it seems that I'm not too impressed by these pocket pages (the tab label on the side works fine though!).Next up, we have some page protectors combined with tab dividers (see, hybrids again!).  Much like the pocket pages, they are open on the left side!  Completely unlike a real page protector!  These also feature a flap at the top to help hold the page in.  Unlike the pocket pages, though, being open on the left side doesn't hurt it too much since you'd only ever put two pages at most into a page protector.  The tab divider part functions well enough (and yes, they do include a few labels for them).  After those, we have a rather decent amount of lined paper, and a reasonable amount of grid-lined graph paper.  Those are rather nice freebies, but not really necessary.So, that is all that is included in this package, so let's talk about the construction of the main outer cover part.  As I already mentioned, the covers are floppy and I really dislike it (although this may be a personal preference – your mileage may vary).  The rings, interestingly, are rubberized plastic, and do not work on a spring mechanism like a traditional binder.  Instead, they pull apart and reveal a long plastic thing that fits into the hole to keep it secure.  They seem a bit weaker than a proper metal ring on a binder, but more importantly, they are on the outside of the whole notebook-thing.  This means that they are going to take the most abuse from rubbing around in a backpack and will be extremely easy to catch on something, which could be quite irritating.  If they were metal, then they might have been more suited to withstand that kind of wear and tear, but I suspect these plastic things won't last very long.  Other than that, there's a bit of fabric used to help hold the front and back covers together (and protect your pages) but who knows how long that'd last before ripping...  Size-wise, it says it can hold 200 sheets of paper, and I measured it expanded and it seems like it could be equivalent to about a 1 inch binder in size.Overall, I'd have to say that this hybrid notebook/binder idea was interesting in theory, but maybe not well-executed in practice.  Perhaps if they had replaced the rubber rings with metal ones and made the covers out of a proper stiff material instead of bendy stuff, it could've been good.  Not to mention making proper pocket pages and page protectors.  Supposing, though, that you are not like me and the bendy covers and rubber rings and open pockets don't bother you, there's still the issue of cost.  As of the time of writing this review, just one of these will cost you around sixteen dollars.  Compare that with your average 1 inch binder, which only costs about two-three dollars (or your standard notebook, which is also pretty cheap), and you have to seriously ask yourself how much you really like this item.  Imagine trying to buy one for each class!  I know you're thinking that you'd probably put all your classes in this one “notebinder” and not buy separate ones for each class, but remember that's it's only got about a 1 inch capacity.  I personally find that I need a separate binders for my classes, so I'd have to drop a lot of money if I wanted to switch to using only these things.  Sigh...  All things considered, I can't really recommend this item unless the things I mentioned in this review wouldn't bother you at all.  To me, it seems like a poor execution of a unique idea, or perhaps an idea that didn't need to exist at all...  Either way, I'm going to stick to my normal binders.

As a disclaimer before I start this review, let me describe my exact situation and interest in this product.  I am not actively on a diet/exercise program nor actively trying to lose weight.  I just happened to hear about these and read about their appetite suppressing abilities, and I was curious to see if they actually worked or not.  Since they came up in Vine for review, I figured I might as well give them a try since I really had nothing to lose.I followed the instructions on the label and took these well before the meal itself (the bottle says to take them 30-120 minutes before the meal).  I tested these pills for several days (about 2 weeks total).  I can honestly say that they had absolutely no effect on my appetite at all.  They didn't suppress it (nor increase it either, thankfully).  They didn't make me feel fuller sooner, nor as though I could go longer before eating again.  It was as though I might as well be taking nothing at all.  On the bright side, they didn't cause any horrifying side effects either (which is why I'm giving them 2 stars instead of 1).Overall, I'd have to conclude that these just didn't work with my body chemistry or that they don't work at all and all the happy people are just subject to placebo effect (which is entirely possible with something as subjective as “appetite”).  A third possibility is that this specific brand doesn't produce high quality pills and that another brand might be better.  Either way, I don't care enough to try out another brand.  If you're interested in trying these, I'd try to find a smaller bottle so that you spend a minimum amount of money first, so that if they don't work for you, you won't be out much.

I normally use clinical strength deodorant (Degree is my favorite brand) but they are expensive, so I'm always trying out other deodorants to see if I can get away with something cheaper.  That brings me to Speed Stick Gear, Cool Motion scent.  This is rather cheaply priced deodorant that makes the bold claim of being “48 hour protection.”  We'll see...Well, I normally put on my clinical strength deodorant at night after my shower, and then do not reapply until the next night.  Since the Speed Stick deodorant claims to be 48 hour, I decided to follow my normal application routine.  So, after trying it out for several days, I have made a few observations...Firstly, it is not quite as strong as clinical strength deodorant, but it's rather admirable for its price.  It does not last 48 hours though, as it seems that by the time night has hit, it's definitely time to shower and reapply.  It's pretty good at blocking smells but only average at stopping sweat (which is fair because even clinical strength doesn't seem to completely stop sweating for me, and I'm not even a heavy sweater).  Lastly, as for the smell, I rather like it.  I don't quite know how to describe what “Cool Motion” smells like, but it's pleasant (I guess if I had to describe it, I'd say it smells a lot like many brands of bar soap I've smelled over the years).So, in conclusion, I'd have to say that this seems like a decent deodorant option if you're on a budget.  In fact, I'm going to keep testing mine during the hot summer and see if I like it well enough to make a permanent switch to it, if only to save a bit of money.  If you're interested in getting away from expensive clinical deodorants, you might as well give this one a try – even if you don't like it, you're not out much money.

I normally stick to clinical strength deodorants, and my favorite is currently Degree Clinical Strength Motion Sense, so when I saw this “normal” version of Motion Sense, I decided to try it out.  I was mainly interested in trying it because it's a bit cheaper than the clinical strength stuff, and I have an issue with the holes in the clinical strength container getting clogged constantly with bits of fluff (and no, I don't really know where they come from – I didn't think my armpits were collecting that much lint!).  Anyway, let's see if this deodorant is any better for me...Interestingly, this deodorant is an invisible solid rather than a smooth solid (like the Clinical strength – which is sort of soft like a mixture between powder and gel).  Anyway, it went on easily enough, and didn't seem to leave cakey white marks on anything.  I rather like the smell, which is a strong berry-ish scent.  Some people might not like their deodorants so strong, but I enjoyed it.  The smell does, however, seem to lessen considerably in a couple hours.More important than the scent, though, is how well it guards against sweatiness and odor.  In this regard, since it says it offers 48 hour protection, I used it just like I did my clinical strength deodorant.  I put it on at night after a shower, and didn't reapply until the next night.  I did this for several days.  It does seem okay at protecting against sweat and odor, but not as good as my clinical strength deodorant.  I pretty much expected that since it is not a clinical strength product.  That being said, it's decent for what it is, and I can't really complain about it.So, this seems like a decent enough deodorant, but not a replacement for anyone on clinical strength.  If you need some average deodorant and like the idea of a berry scent, I'd give this a try.

I used to have an older Sandisk USB drive (it was a Cruzer Glide) in the same size capacity (128 GB) but it was an older model that didn't have USB 3.0 compatibility.  I used it to back up my personal files (which were about 88 GB at the time) and it literally took about 4 hours!  I eventually upgraded to a Corsair USB 3.0 Voyager flash drive that was much better, and only took about 1 hour and 45 minutes to back up that data.  This was all using USB 2.0 slots since my computer doesn't have any 3.0 slots, but more on that later...After my experience with the older Sandisk, I wasn't expecting much from the 'SanDisk 128GB Extreme Pro USB 3.0 Flash Drive.'  I figured I'd give it a fair chance anyway, though, by conducting a vaguely scientific timed test.  My personal files have changed a bit here and there over time, but they still have about 88 GB's worth of data.  Oh, and in case you're wondering what the files consist of, it's a fairly even mix of music, videos, text files, and pictures - pretty much the average sort of things that most computer users would have.  I decided to borrow another computer that has 3.0 ports to test this on so I could test both types of ports.  The files copied onto the drive in 16 minutes using a 3.0 port, and about 1 hour using a 2.0 port on the same computer.  That's pretty impressive!  On my own computer using old 2.0 slots, it took about 65 minutes to copy those files.  Still better than the Corsair!Well, now that we've established that this thing is really fast (which is honestly the most important feature) let's talk about some other things...  That software that came on it (the SecureAccess thing) allows you to password protect your files.  It only works on Windows and Mac, though, and my main computer is running Linux, so it's not of much use to me.  Besides, it's not really the sort of thing I need or find important, so I just deleted it off of there.Now, for those that find physical features important, let's discuss those.  The body of the flash drive is aluminum (all brushed texture and nice) with a strip of black plastic down the middle, and a loop for sticking a lanyard on there.  I guess I'd say it was an attractive-looking flash drive (although that sort of thing doesn't really matter much to me since I view this as more of a practical item).  Oh, and it does have a slide-out design if you prefer that over flash drives that use caps.  Size-wise, it measures about 3.875" long by 0.875" wide by about 1/2" thick.  It's not particularly huge or particularly small.  Do keep the measurements in mind, though, if you have some really crowded USB slots you need to use it with.Lastly, let's talk price.  This is indeed an item you're going to have to spend some money on (it was about 150 dollars as of the time of this review).  Clearly, you could save some money by going with a cheaper brand/model, but you'd probably be losing out on speed.  If speed is the most important factor for you, go ahead and get this flash drive - it won't disappoint!

I use a lot of sheet protectors, specifically for recipes in a kitchen cookbook.  The sheet protectors allow me to keep the printed recipes relatively protected from spills and splatters so that I can have a conveniently organized recipe book without having to constantly replace papers.  I always need a few more sheet protectors, though, as my recipe collection expands, plus over time some sheet protectors get so grimy (despite wiping) as to need replacement.  That's where this product comes in!These claim to be “heavy weight” and as far as I can tell after comparing them to my standard weight protectors, they are a bit thicker.  I'm not sure, however, that they are so much heavier as to justify their increased price from the standard ones (they are, however, competitive with other brands for their weight as far as I can tell).  Either way, they are decent page protectors, and work well.  I was even able to fit five pages in one comfortably (not sure why you'd want to, though).  Size-wise, they are the same size dimensions as every page protector I've ever bought before, so nothing new there.  The holes for the binder are made of a slightly heavier plastic than the main body, which can help prevent tearing, so that is much appreciated.Well, there's not much more to say.  These are decent page protectors if you really want heavy weight ones, but I'm not sure they are so much more protective than standard weight as to justify their cost.  They perform well though, so I can't really complain!

I use sticky notes constantly to remind myself of important to-do lists, and as such, have tried out quite a few different brands over the years.  I find myself returning to good old Post-it brand over and over again, though, since this seems to be the one brand that keeps a good, consistent quality.  These particular Post-it notes are no exception.After extensive testing, I can say I'm quite satisfied with these sticky notes.  The sticky notes are not too sticky (to where they damage wood veneer surfaces – yes I had that happen before with some Avery Brand sticky notes) and not so weak as to constantly come unstuck (once again, a problem with some Avery brand sticky notes).  Once I had stuck one to a surface, they stayed put very nicely, and didn't even lose their stickiness when removed and reapplied in a different location.  Neither did they curl up at the edges nor come loose over time.So, in conclusion, I am pleased.  There's not much else you could ask for from a sticky note, and it always sucks when you buy a whole pack only to realize that the sticky notes are terrible and you're stuck with them (pun totally intended), so I'm going to stick to Post-It brand from now on.

I have fairly regular allergies – pollen in the spring and summer, and also allergies to dust and mold (which often seems to hit in the winter).  So, I take a Zyrtec pill every day to take care of it, and it's reasonably (although imperfectly) controlled.  I'm fine most days and don't have massive sneezing and a runny nose most of the time, but I usually still have stuffed up sinuses.  Anyway, I decided to try out the Mucinex pills to see if they would help me any better than the Zyrtec does.Well, I've went ahead and tried all five pills, and honestly, I can't say it helps any better than the Zyrtec.  I'm not particularly impressed.  It didn't seem to stop the occasional runny nose I had (which was about the same as the Zyrtec's performance).  It seems it's about the same, performance-wise, but I seem to have had an extra side effect of nosebleeds.  I got two nosebleeds one two different days while taking these, and I very rarely get nosebleeds.  While I can't prove it was caused by the Mucinex, I can't help but correlate the two.I realize that everyone's system is different, and you might have better luck with these pills.  The only way to know is to try them yourself.  As for me, I'm thinking I'll just stick to my Zyrtec from now on – there's really no incentive for me to switch over.

I bought these to glue to the backs of cabochons and make my own earrings, as well as make earrings to sell.  I chose them specifically because the amazon title says they are made of surgical steel.  They are not, in fact.  I really should have looked closely at the photo, because it says right on it that it's made of brass (plated with silver).  Thankfully, I'm not allergic to metals, but I can't use these to make and sell earrings since I try to have my items as hypoallergenic as possible.  Of course, the packaging doesn't lie, so it's not really this product's fault that the amazon title is wrong (at the time of this writing, amazon may fix it in the future).Aside from the material, what is quality like?  Well, it's not too bad.  Most of the posts are fine and not bent or anything (I did have a couple that broke, though - the posts justs fell right off the pad!).  The earring nuts that come with them are fine enough, but they suffer from the issue of being a bit too loose.  Not ludicrously so (they do stay on reasonably well), but they are a bit looser than I'd prefer.Well, other than finding out they weren't surgical steel, I'd say these posts are alright.  Just be aware of what they are made of if you have metal allergies.

I'm not really a huge fan of Shark Week or anything (I mean, it's okay), so I actually bought this for the Mythbusters episode.  The other three episodes on here (Great White Shark Uncaged, Blood In The Water, Ultimate Air Jaws) are fine enough, but I primarily bought this set to get my hands on the Mythbusters Shark Week Special.I'm a huge Mythbusters fan and have been trying to get my hands on all their episodes, so this seemed like an economical way to get the "Shark Week Special" into my collection.  Unfortunately, and for anyone who's trying to do the same thing, you should be aware that the version of the Mythbuster's Shark Week Special on here is an edited version that 's only half as long as the normal one.  YES, it's only half the episode!  Imagine my shock to find out that half the special was missing!I've since done a bit more research and discovered that you can get the proper full episode on the "Shark Week: Great Bites Collection".  Aside from that, even if you're not specifically a Mythbusters fan and just want to watch shark-related shows, you'd get a better value for your money choosing some other Shark Week collection, such as the "20th Anniversary Collection" which has many more episodes on it than this.  Either way, whether you're a Mythbusters fan or a shark fan, I can't recommend this DVD at all - there's better options out there.

I already own several fake gauge earrings because I've really fallen in love with the look of them!  To round out my collection, I was interested in getting some that were made of tamarind wood.  That's when I discovered these.What I really love about these is how elegant they look.  Many other tamarind wood earrings that I've looked at in the past had a sort of "beach-goer/Bohemian" look to them, and while there's nothing wrong with that, I just really love the versatility of these.  The swirly patterned golden shell part lends these earrings an elegance such that they wouldn't be out of place when worn on a special occasion, yet the tamarind wood keeps them feeling casual enough to wear out and about everyday as well.  Speaking of the tamarind wood, mine looks much prettier than the picture.  Mine actually has nice black striations in the wood grain, and is therefore quite lovely.  Of course, this is a natural product, which varies, so there's no telling what sort of wood pattern you'll get if you bought one.  Oh well.Now, onto some useful information!  My earring measured about 1.75"x1.75", so keep that in mind if size is a consideration for you.  As for insertion, I found it pretty easy, but if you are new to fake gauges, you might need to practice a bit.  Just make sure you treat them gently so you don't bend the ear wire.  I find them to be very light weight when worn, and they hang very well (not crooked or awkward or anything).  I've pretty much come to expect this level of good quality from this seller, and I'm certainly not disappointed in these at all!So, overall I'm pleased with these.  If the idea of tamarind wood intrigues you, or you're just looking for some earrings that are unique without being too edgy, then give these a try!
Perfectly designed cable - the metal bump-out makes it so they work well with virtually any mobile device (even with a thick case!), and the build quality is bar-none. Highly recommended!

I was using another sleep mask for a few years that I liked, but I felt like it pinched my nostrils during the night - not painfully so, but it did seem to limit my air flow while breathing through my nose. One of the two head straps finally failed on it, so I decided to see what else was out there.I was a bit cautious about this one - seeing that it had a single head strap, which based on other products I'd tried, ended up hurting my ears. This one is well-designed and the head strap goes nicely on the back of the head at an angle that's natural and well-fitted. For me, it doesn't even go across my ears, but rather goes just above them. The eye cups are a nice addition and the overall fit is excellent with zero pain or pressure points. It's a great product at a great price!

The lens hood itself is fine - plastic, threads onto my 50mm f/1.8 STM lens just fine. The only bummer (and thus my 3 stars) is that when it's in place, I can no longer clip my lens cap onto my lens. Granted, it's only $5, but it's still annoying to have to be "either/or" with having a lens hood OR my lens cap. I might have to buy another one as I know this will become annoying over time.
It works perfectly - not much else to say other than that.
I have nothing negative to say: Good cable quality, works exactly like the Apple one at a fraction of the cost. The glossy finish is actually more durable than the one Apple supplies.

These boots run big (I wear a 12 in running shoes and a 10.5 in these boots), but they feel great and are comfortable to wear all day - which is saying something as I have a really high arch that typically hurts with most shoes. They have a great build, good tread, and look good as a rugged work boot or with some nice jeans. The squared toe is great for all-day wear, and also lets you wear them in more "dressy" settings without sticking out too much. Be a man; buy some already.
