This is my third Seidio Surface case with a kickstand. I continue to be impressed each time with this case maker and this product specifically. It fits perfect, adds almost no bulk to the phone, offers a kick stand, and great protection from drops and scuffs. I'll continue to buy these cases for each new smartphone I get - so far, that's been a winning game plan.

This case offers great protection, but the screen protector is open by the iPhone home button - which allows lint and dust to easily get trapped behind the screen protector. I wish that the case had stretchy rubber over the home button section to seal it off. Granted, that might interfere with the fingerprint reader on the iPhone - that's not a feature that my wife uses though. Overall very well made though and it is incredibly durable.

Good product; well made and offers good support. I wish it was a bit softer for my standing-desk application, but I do notice a difference standing on this all day vs. the hard floor. My "wish" for greater softness isn't a fault to the manufacturer though as different mats serve different purposes.

I had higher hopes for this device, based on the reviews. Granted, it is only $12 (currently). It tunes and works well, but the speaker placed in the device is sub-mediocre. I definitely didn't expect "booming" rich sound, but this actually falls closer to horribly bad. It does get fairly loud, but my smartphone (LG G3) has richer, better sound from a single speaker the size of a quarter. I wasn't expecting it to have great sound, but I did at least expect it to rival my smartphone for speaker quality.Again, it gets the job done - but don't expect much in the audio quality department by even the weakest of standards.

After installing a nice laminate floor in my work-from-home office, I wanted to protect it from my hard plastic caster wheels without using a plastic mat. I bought these guys and so far, they work great for the last month. I am quite pleased.
I had a leak from one of my bypass caps and this set fixed the problem just fine at a fraction of the cost my local parts store was asking. Good quality, worked great.

Works well (after figuring out the programming process with my old garage door opener). I do wish it had a dedicated "Enter" key instead us using the 0 key for that purpose - it makes it a bit confusing to explain the code to others. This is a very minor gripe though and I am overall pleased with the product.

For the price, you can't beat these shoes. I started elusively wearing ASICS about 5 years ago and I continue to be impressed with their support and durability. These are no exception, and at this price, you can't afford not to pick up a pair. These shoes "are nothing special" in that they're a basic runner - but they are great for all day wear or casual running. Unlike more serious running shoes, these have better lateral support - more like a cross trainer, but perhaps not quite as heavy. For a more serious runner, this lateral support is annoying, but I bought this for all-day wear in my active life - not for running. I have some other, more focused ASICS for running, making these the perfect daily shoe for my needs.

When I received my speaker set, I was a little skeptical. I’ve owned the original SHARKK boombox for some time now and love it, but I guess I didn’t really get how this system with two speakers would be better. In short, I was really wrong and love this thing!After having purchased a SHARKK boombox myself and getting a lot of great feedback on my review, SHARKK reached out and asked if I’d like to demo this new product. That’s not something I’ve done in the past but hey, why not, right? So they shipped me this product pair and I must admit that the new buddy system looks even nicer than the original – cleaner lines, better finishes, plus buttons that light up via a motion detector when you move your hand near the system. That’s a really nice (and helpful) touch!So the main question I had was, how does it sound? In word, awesome. I’ve always been impressed with the rich clarity of the original SHARKK boombox, so I found it hard to believe that this one would be any better than that. Well, it is. I don’t know how to describe it, but the audio from this thing is just crystal clear and so… defined. Not in a painful, tinny sort of way – but in a “hear everything beautifully” sort of way. The sound just isn’t muddy or riddled with overdrive or poor crossover. That’s a really good thing – so good, that it ended up replacing a desktop stereo system that I’ve used as studio monitors for years. Yes, really.Seriously, there’s just nothing else like this on the market that I’ve seen with two speakers (that can be used completely independently as separate, stereo speakers) that can be paired together with true, left+right stereo sound. As a test, I set these little puppies on my existing home theater Paradigm speakers in my living room, then started playing music through them – cranking up the volume. I did the ol’ wife test and called my wife into the room and asked her where the sound was coming from. To her utter amazement (and mine, to be honest) a monsoon of crystal clear, thunderous sound was coming from the buddy system speakers – not the Paradigm system. Can this get as loud as my home sound system? No, it can’t – but it was waaaay louder than I would want it to be, if I wasn’t testing it. Does the bass compare to my Paradigm speakers? Yes and no. On the normal, soundtrack type stuff, yes – it sounds very similar. For home theater stuff with explosions and really ultra-low bass, no it can’t match it. But really people, this thing is about 1/8th the size of my home stereo speakers. It’s ridiculous that it’s even worth discussing in the same paragraph.Feel free to ask any questions – I’ll try to answer them. This thing is just ridiculous; awesome when using the speakers separately, and then just insane when used as a pair with incredible stereo channel-separation. After several months of usage and testing, I still love this thing!

I bought this mouse (not a free sample) about 2 months ago as I was looking for a device to help with the joint and wrist pain I was experiencing in my work day. I work in IT management and as such, I use a mouse all day, every day – often for 12-16 hours a day, depending on how the day goes. Even as a 30 year old, by the middle of the day, even with my very expensive ergonomic mouse (Logitech Performance Mouse MX; love it for photo editing!), my wrist and knuckles would be on fire!So I bought this one on a whim to see if it would help my pain and hand cramps. Oh man! This thing has helped a ton! It does take a day or two to get used to it (you use your arm more and less of your wrist), but after about 6 hours of usage, I could already tell a huge difference in my hand/wrist.The build quality is great; the flat black finish does well at hiding finger prints while remaining easy to grip. I have larger (not huge) hands, and it fits me comfortably. I’ve never had any trouble with interference with other devices – even while having other USB wireless devices (Logitech) plugged in nearby on the same PC.This mouse isn’t the world’s most accurate mouse. It’s a fantastic general computing mouse, but if you do photo editing, video editing, or CAD drawings that require highly accurate mouse input, you might find this mouse to be lacking the accuracy you need. For those of you who don’t do those tasks, you do not have anything to worry about – this mouse is as accurate as any off-the-shelf mouse out there. For those with specialized roles though that typically purchase high-end, high-accuracy mice, this doesn’t possess that level of accuracy. For me though, I use this for my day-in, day-out work. If I need to photo edit for long periods (more than just 4-5 photos), I switch back to my Logitech Performance MX mouse for that. I hope this review was helpful. Ask if you have any questions!
Great product at an incredible price. I have nothing negative to say. I'm using this Cat6 on my Cat5 network without a problem.
This little guy is great - inexpensive option for expanding an outlet without using a power strip or similar solutions.
Well made, good price - I picked these up as I'd lost a few from a previous set and you really can't beat the price to quality ratio here.

First, this smells amazing. It's a great, masculine blend of cedar and citrus that's fresh, but not heavy or musky. It's great for the office - or for whatever. I really do love the scent.As other reviewers have stated though, the smell wears off very quickly and even with 4 sprays (quite a lot, if you ask me), it isn't noticeable after a two-three hours. I don't want to overwhelm anyone with a scent, but if you can't smell it at all, that's underwhelming at best - if not completely pointless.

What can I say? It works great and allowed me to keep my old panel, but still upgrade the electrical. This is only docked one star because one of the 2-pole breakers on the circuit breaker wouldn't reset when it first arrived, so I ended up doing some resistance testing and found that one side wasn't reset properly. Once I knew that, I then I worked it back and forth pretty hard to finally get it to grip the breaker and trip the one side that wasn't resetting. Since then, no problems - resets fine, went into the panel fine as well.

Excellent product; stays on my windshield without issue, easy to adjust into the perfect position, and the one-touch process makes it so easy to mount/dismount the device. I've been using it with my GPS and with my Motorola Moto X (with a Sedio Surface case) and it works perfectly.Pros:- So easy to use- Holds a wide variety of devices - even my Moto X, with a case- Very secure and stable; no vibration issues from roadsCons:- Not easy to remove once applied; the adhesive/suction method is very strong (this is also a good thing, however)

UPDATE OCTOBER 15TH, 2014:Jaime from Photive contacted me a few days ago to follow up on my poor experience with the bluetooth performance of the Soundscape 8 (see my original review below). He was very friendly and helpful and after asking some questions about the original device, he thought it sounded like mine might have been defective. Having no other unit to compare it to, I agreed to see if the replacement worked any better than the first one I'd received.I received the replacement device and instantly noticed better performance from the bluetooth - no more choppy sound or interference with other devices. The overall range of the bluetooth was better as well - very consistent in the 15-25ft range while indoors, which is good. This device does get a tad bit louder than the SHARKK I mentioned below - and the sound is a bit wider in its projection in the room. I can still hear a noticeable hiss (sounds like white noise) from the device speakers though while audio tracks are played more quietly, or when the softer part of a song is playing. I've tried turning my phone volume up and the speaker volume down, and vice-versa... and lots of other variations in between. Still same hiss. I don't know that it's a deal breaker, but it is noticeable while playing at mid- to low-volume, or during lower-volume tracks.I've given the device an extra star for a couple reason: One, because Photive was incredibly supportive and helpful. Really people, they have ridiculously good support. Second, because the bluetooth functionality does work well on my new, non-defective device. Why not five stars? The hiss is still quite noticeable - notably louder than other similar devices, and two, the bluetooth tech is still older. For instance, I love being able to control the volume of the speaker from my phone - or skip tracks from the actual speaker. Because this uses older Bluetooth 2.0 technology, controlling the tracks (play/pause/rewind/fast-forward) isn't possible from the speaker from what I understand. Likewise, I have to control the volume on the speaker and the phone - instead of being able to turn my phone/speaker up simultaneously. Both of these problems are isolated to the bluetooth technology; the hiss all but disappears when using an AUX cable. I look forward to seeing a new version with updated bluetooth in the future - Photive makes killer devices and I love the Photive Cyren!ORIGINAL REVIEW:I purchased this one alongside the SHARKK Bluetooth 4.0 BoomBox NFC 10 Watt Speaker to "duke it out." In short, the SHARKK won the battle: The Photive is louder, but I think that was a mistake on Photive's part - the sound becomes quite distorted and choppy at full blast. Additionally, the SOUNDSCAPE 8 had a very noticeable amount of hiss when playing music over Bluetooth - far more than any speaker I've ever used. That hiss essentially disappeared on an audio cable, but via Bluetooth, it's very noticeable.That, coupled with the fact that it kept causing Bluetooth interference with my wife's phone and that it used old, slow Bluetooth 2.0 made this one a loser in my book. I should also add that the Bluetooth 2.0 struggled with my higher bitrate sound files - making the audio bitrate fall off and sounding a bit "crunchy" when listening via Bluetooth. So to me, my thought was why would you buy a larger, less portable speaker with poor Bluetooth performance for the same price as the SHARKK? Apart from those glitches though, the specs are fairly similar.I not sure why you'd put Bluetooth 2.0 (old technology) into a brand-new device design. Sadly, this device could have been amazing - I wanted to love it - but it fell short due to distortion and did a face-plant when it comes to bluetooth performance and sound quality. There's a lot to love here, but the few glitches made it a no-go for me.I compared this device against many other Bluetooth speakers. If you'd like to read my full length, formal review, click my name above and see my reviews. Read the review titled, "Unbiased: You can't beat the volume, functionality, or quality-for-price of this device with anything I've tested sub-$200" for the SHARKK Bluetooth speaker, which is the one I ultimately setting on after buying this one first.

If a very small size and decent performance at a bargain price are at the top of your list, this is a winner. I really couldn't hear any difference between this device and the JAMBOX - which cost $100. It totally roasts the JAMBOX Mini - both in cost and performance.I bought this speaker along with a few others to compare side by side. If you'd like to read that full review with much greater detail that covers this speaker and many others, click my name above and see my reviews. Read the review titled "Unbiased: You can't beat the volume, functionality, or quality-for-price of this device with anything I've tested sub-$200."

First, I am not a paid or "free sample" reviewer for SHARKK; I bought this speaker dock all by-my-big-boy with my own money. Impressive, I know.So now for the review portion. I should start by stating that I am an audiophile... on a budget. I love accuracy. I love two-channel stereo. Yes, you heard me - I'm a purist and would rather have two quality speakers than 5, 6, or 7 speakers attempting to throw as much sound around the room as possible. I love big, warm, crisp sound. I want bass (*ahem*... that's "bass" not "base," by the way), but I don't want as much thump as possible just to have it - I want the bass to match the original audio, not to over-amplify it. If the recording thumps, so should the speakers. I want tight mid-tones - not the muddy, mushy stuff. I want crisp, clear highs, not the tinny pinch of some speakers. By my definition, the best speakers are the ones that can match the original audio without losing or distorting content.Next, I should state that this speaker sound great - but it won't beat out something two or three times its size, at least in most categories (it actually did in many of my tests, but more on that later). This won't rival your home theater sound system (or if it does, you need to upgrade). These statements all should be common knowledge, but judging by the reviews I read on this product and other portable speakers, it would seem that I am sadly mistaken.OK, now with the preliminary disclosures out of the way, let's begin...BUILD QUALITY:In a word: Excellent. Pick anything up off the shelf at Best Buy or anywhere, and I think you'll find that this is right up there in the top category. The metal is clean, nicely executed and classy. The plastics on the top and bottom are very sturdy and firm (why can't more American car interiors use plastic of this quality?). The buttons have great feedback and a nice tactile feel. Honestly, I have nothing negative to say about the build quality, it's just that good. I should also add that SHARKK added high quality rubber "feet" on the bottom of this speaker to keep it from sliding and vibrating around - they work very well and are better quality than most I've seen.SIZE/WEIGHT:The unit does have a bit of weight to it. No, I wouldn't call it heavy by any stretch, but it screams quality when you pick it up. I think the large battery, large speaker drivers and partially metal construction contribute to the weight - all of which I am thankful for and appreciate. As for the size, I consider this thing about perfect - no, it's not pocket-able (maybe in cargo pants?), but you can easily grip it in one hand. I have a phone that's pocket-able and it has a speaker built in. I don't need another one of those. So to me, the whole pocket-able market is a moot point. Portable yes, pocket-able, no.BATTERY LIFE:In short, really good. I charged it when I bought it and have been using it off and on for the last week and haven't charged it again yet. Granted, I usually turned it off when I wasn't using it, but that's awesome just the same. I feel comfortable saying that the 10 hour, 2500 mAh polymer Li-ion battery life advertised is 100% accurate, if not a bit modest.SOUND QUALITY:Here comes the meat and potatoes. Like I said before, I'm a bit of an audio nut, so when I buy speakers or headphones, I always use a frequency generator app on my phone to put it through its paces to see if it responds as well as advertised. Granted, this isn't the most scientific method because it still depends on the ability of my ears to hear it, but it's a whole lot more precise than someone saying "I listened to some music and this sounds really good!"The speaker has two, 5w 50mm speaker drivers - plus a passive "bass radiator" in the back. For the size of this device, that's awesome. Let me tell you, this thing gets loud. Uncomfortably loud. It won't replace a tornado siren on your block, but you could definitely hear it anywhere in an average home. For instance, I usually listen at 25% or 50% volume in our great room (shared space of kitchen, family room, dining room) and it fills the space with sound that is either light and ambient (25%) or clear but not obnoxious (50%). So in other words, at half-power, this is filling a space of about 800 sq. feet with clear sound. Saying a speaker is "loud" doesn't really mean much though; lots of people can sing loudly, but that doesn't mean I want to listen to them, so let's talk about sound quality.I used my frequency generator app and turned my phone up to full volume. I then started at 1Hz and gradually walked my way up until the speaker (also at full volume) began producing sound. At 18Hz, I could easily hear a very low rumble  - which by the way, is excellent. Granted, you'd have to be listening at full volume to produce this, but that's amazing for something this small. At 30Hz, the rumble was quite loud. By the time I reached 40Hz, the thing was really cranking. So in other words, for the size, this does actually produce a fair bit of passive bass. Will it "lay down bass?" Well, no. Something that fits in your hand isn't likely to shake the windows. Can you hear it though? Yes. Again, I think SHARKK's 60Hz information might even be a bit conservative - a fact I commend them for - but I can say this thing definitely has more warm "thump" than I would have ever expected from something of it's size.As for mids, I have nothing unusual to report. It passed with flying colors. The highs also passed with flying colors. I can only hear up to 17.5KHz (which is pretty good) - and that's faint - so I heard it all the way up to that point. As for 18KHz, sure... it probably reaches it. Good luck finding a set of ears that can hear that high though, apart from your cat or dog.Next, I cranked a classic rock song through it. It has a fair bit of bass, rich mids and an awesome high guitar part. This speaker killed it (in a good way). I was actually laughing out loud listening to it - in disbelief that this much quality sound was coming from something the size of a Chipotle burrito, sans guacamole. I called my wife out to the garage where I was testing and had her listen as well. She too was in disbelief. Granted, my wife is no audio nut, but the size-to-sound ratio is still remarkable.BLUETOOTH (AND NFC) PERFORMANCE:Again, excellent. I can listen to music streaming from within the advertised 30ft mark without a problem. I actually had it streaming at more like 40ft - with several walls in between. I wouldn't want to promise that, but it worked for me nonetheless. Bluetooth performance wains a bit outdoors, but that's common as there's often no walls to bounce or reflect the signal off of, it still worked well for me though. The speaker is very responsive (no lag) between commands issued from the speaker (e.g. - skip track) or commands issued from the phone. Additionally, the audio quality remained quite high. Of course you'll always get the best audio quality from a wired connection, but I found that while listening to music in the room, I couldn't tell a difference in quality. I could hear a very faint hiss when using Bluetooth if I held the speaker to my ear... but really though, that's what headphones are for, and I strongly discourage holding speakers to your ears. You look dumb, and you'll go deaf; bad combo.Next, NFC. Sorry iPhone/Apple folks, you can skip over this one because Apple doesn't think NFC is a cool technology. Others, stay tuned if your device has NFC. OK... so wow. I'm nerdy and can quickly pair with various Bluetooth devices, but I can't tell you how slick it is to walk up, touch my phone to the speaker, and have it immediately pair or disconnect (if already connected). I didn't think I'd use this feature, but I actually use it all the time. My wife also loves it - a person who is admittedly non-nerdy. I think she'd never use this thing if it required her to pair with it each time, or select it from a list in her Bluetooth menu. As it stands though, she can easily walk up and hold her phone on it and it pairs or disconnects. With the new (quieter) voice prompts, it's also incredibly intuitive at explaining the process without being annoying; you know when your device is connected or disconnected. Absolutely brilliant, SHARKK.CONCLUSION:I really like this speaker; I have a hard time believing that it was only $65 when I compare it with the items from Best Buy, and I have a hard time believing the sound coming out of it when I crank it up. It's no replacement for a home theater system, but it certainly has its place in the arsenal of portable listening. If you're considering any other speaker, give this one a try first.COMPARISONS:NOTE: Please don't take my prices as 100% certain; Prices change regularly and may have changed since this was originally written.I'll try to keep each review brief, but I wanted to offer a comparative review of the SHARKK speaker against many of the market options - both the Amazon devices and the more industry leader ones you'd find at Best Buy. Most of these devices I've just tested in store multiple times on multiple occasions, but a few I've owned personally.JBL Flip: Meh. Overpriced, about the same size as the SHARKK and much more tinny-sound. The volume level is nearly the same (SHARKK wins), but audio quality and price give SHARKK the clear win.JBL Charge: This one narrows the gap a bit, but I still think the win goes to SHARKK. The sound is still a bit richer with the SHARKK and the price $150 price tag just makes it a no-brainer.Sony SRSBTX300: In sound quality, the Sony probably wins. Granted, I find the sound a bit muddy and soft on the Sony, but it's hard not to like it's rich sound... if you want something that's the size of a shoe box and cost $100. Great speaker, but not what I was after personally.Sony SRSX5: This is my personal favorite; it's the upgrade of the device above but the audio quality is vastly improved. Granted, it is $200 and way outside my price range - and a bit big for my portable needs, but this thing really does sound awesome. If you have $200+ to spend, this is the device I'd recommend - or it's big brother, the SRSX7 ($300).HMDX Audio HX-P230 JAM: OK, seriously people. I shouldn't even have to say it, but I will. There's no comparison. The JAM may be small and funky, but it pales in every way compared to the SHARKK. Very portable, but poor audio quality.Ultimate Ears - BOOM: The only thing that goes "boom" about this speaker is the damage to your wallet; muddy sound, weird 360 degree sound projection (soft sound in all directions), over priced ($175 ish) and very little "umph" to carry your audio around the room.Jawbone - MINI JAMBOX: Personally, I think this device is a joke. It's quiet, way over priced, and hard to justify from any perspective. So from a price, audio quality and general functionality standpoint, the SHARKK kicks this thing's butt. If small size is on your high-priority list, get the Photive CYREN instead (see review below) and save yourself $110.Beats by Dr. Dre - Pill 2.0: This is louder than the MINI JAMBOX, but all the other notes apply here as well.Photive SOUNDSCAPE 8: I purchased this one alongside the SHARKK to "duke it out." In short, the SHARKK won the battle: The Photive is louder, but I think that was a mistake on Photive's part - the sound becomes quite distorted and choppy at full blast. Additionally, the Photive had a very noticeable amount of hiss when playing music over Bluetooth - far more than any speaker I've ever used. That, coupled with the fact that it kept causing Bluetooth interference with my wife's found and that it used old, slow Bluetooth 2.0 made this one a loser in my book. I should also add that the Bluetooth 2.0 struggled with my higher bitrate sound files - making the audio bitrate fall off and sounding a bit "crunchy" when listening via Bluetooth. So to me, my thought was why would you buy a larger, less portable speaker with poor Bluetooth performance for the same price as the SHARKK? Apart from those glitches though, the specs are fairly similar.Bose® - SoundLink® Mini: This thing sounds pretty good. I love to hate Bose, but I have to admit that they did a good job on this device. I think the SHARKK gets a bit louder though, and it's hard to deny that saving about $150 by purchasing the SHARKK is a winning choice.Beats By Dr. Dre - Beatbox: OK, this thing is $400. Of course it has bigger sound than the SHARKK. It's also the size of a beach ball and is about as obnoxious as a foot rash at a dance party. If you have $400, there are better options.Ultimate Ears - MINI BOOM: See notes for the "BOOM." This is just the rehash of the BOOM, but with slightly less BOOM on the wallet and even less BOOM in the room. SHARKK easily wins.Bose - SoundDock® Series III: This is $250 and barely portable. It does sound good, but I bet 5 SHARKK speakers would sound good too (how many you could purchase for $250, in case you missed the parallel).Beats by Dr. Dre - Pill XL: $300 for this? It sounds OK, not great, but OK. I really don't understand this item or the people who buy them; you could do so much better. For $300, you'd expect it to sound $250 better than the SHARKK, and it simply doesn't.Photive CYREN: I purchased this device to test out alongside the SHARKK. I will say that it is surprisingly small. At $40 though, the SHARKK absolutely kills the CYREN in terms of loudness, bass and flexibility. The CYREN is a fun device and would work well on an office desk, for instance, but not nearly the performance of the SHARKK. To be honest, this device sounded a lot like the JAMBOX to me - not very loud, decent sound, but not horrible either... it's just that the CYREN is about $110 cheaper.JBL Pulse: If owning a speaker that looks like a strobing lava lamp is your thing, then this is the device for you... at a $175 price tag. From what I could tell in my audio tests, this is a JBL Flip with strobe lights. Yippee.Jawbone - BIG JAMBOX: This does have richer sound than the SHARKK, but it's also $269, on sale. I will say that it's also bigger and the audio can be a bit over processed at times. Not bad though, just a bit pricey and big.Jawbone JAMBOX: The JAMBOX isn't a bad device, but I still think the audio is a bit muddy and sloppy for the sake of over-amplifying the bass... Which, oddly enough, isn't really that punchy even still. Note that the JAMBOX is nearly identical to the Photive CYREN ($40) in size and performance, but $110 more. The SHARKK is slightly larger than the JAMBOX, sounds far better and costs far less.

First, I should say that I'm a bit of an audiophile. Like, really. I have some great headphones and I have some not so great headphones. I have a pair for mowing the grass and a pair for running. I have a pair I use at work and a pair I use at home. For me, the thing that is most important is sound accuracy: How closely does the sound coming from the headphones mirror the sound coming from an excellent set of studio speakers. Or to say it another way, how closely do the headphones mirror what the microphone originally recorded in studio.Second, I should say that these headphones are currently $6 with free shipping using Amazon Prime. $6 dollars, people. 6. Count them: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. So yeah, if we really want to compare them, go look at the Wal-Mart.com $6 and less headphone rack. Depressed yet? Yeah, pretty sad.So when these arrived, I honestly expected to hate them. But get this, I don't. First, the tangle free cord works great. The build quality is actually really good. The fit works well - the ear clips keep them on my head if I'm running or working, but I found they stayed put during normal activity without the ear loops. They include three sets (small, medium, large) of rubber ear fittings and a little carrying bag.What about audio, you ask? In short, it's decent. Award winning? No, but it won't make your ears cry either. I will say that the call quality through the in-line microphone was excellent. I made a few calls and waited for people to say "huh" or "what" a few times and never got that, so after a while of talking, I asked my wife if she could hear me OK. She said I was almost too loud - in a good way. I was speaking naturally and she said I was coming in loud and clear and she actually turned down her phone volume a bit. If you've had any in-line headsets before, you know that's a rarity - most are quiet and unpredictable, but the SHARKK did quite well.I did some frequency tests on the headphones to see what they're actually producing. Granted, this is based on my ears - so it's not flawless, but a good frame of reference. The box states that the response range is 20Hz-20KHz. I was able to hear them at about 32Hz all the way up to about 16KHz. Not bad for (my less than perfect ears and) a 6$ pair of headphones with a tangle-free cord and a mic!Comparatively, I took my Sony MDREX10LP headphones ($9; Prime - no mic) and ran the same test. I could hear them at about 29Hz and all the way up to about 17KHz. That's a little better than the SHARKK headset, but not a huge difference.So that's the technical. Let me talk figuratively now. To me, the SHARKK headset has a nice, wide soundstage - meaning it gives a sense of depth and presence to the music that isn't often found in a headset of this price range... or much greater price ranges for that matter. The Sony's weren't able to provide this same "virtual depth" to the music; they sound like they're pumping music into your head instead of creating a theater sound system around you.The Sony headset sounds a bit fuller and definitely punchier on the bass end of the spectrum. The SHARKK headset is a bit more mellow, but still very enjoyable to listen to - vocals and guitars really shine on the SHARKK headset. Honestly, I felt like the Sony's force the low-end punch a bit and the SHARKK's probably could have forced it a bit more. Both headsets offer a nice listening experience, both are budget finds.So which is better? Personally, as an all-around headset, I think the SHARKK is better. With the ear loops, different ear fittings, tangle free cord, and the microphone... man, what can't this headset do? It could easily be your jogging, phone-talking, beat-listening, all-day-wearing, productivity accomplice. The Sony headset just can't do that. The Sony's sound good, maybe a bit forced, but they're simply not as versatile... and let's face it, if you're searching in the sub-$10 price range, you're looking for the best "all-arounder," not the best in class. Why? Because the best in class cost $278 more.... Ok, I just made that number up, but you get the point.As a technology reviewer, I requested a pair of these headphones directly from SHARKK. SHARKK provided these headphones as a free sample in exchange for my honest review... and there you have it folks. That's all I know. Are they "the best studio monitor headphones every created?" No. Don't be dumb, but they're pretty dog-gone good for six dollars. I'm still a bit baffled that headphones this well-made are selling for $6!

I won't take you on the incredibly lengthy journey I went on by searching for a "photo editor's monitor" at a budget price. My absolute max budget was $300, but I really wanted to be closer to $200 if I could do it. While I would love to own a 16 bit monitor, I was well aware that wasn't going to happen at the $2000+ price tag. At the same token though, I needed something that was color and print accurate so I could edit with confidence that my prints would look like what I was viewing on my screen.This monitor is fantastic - the contrast and viewing angles are great and the accuracy is really quite amazing at this price range. I recently edited about 50 photos for print from a recent shoot I did, picked up the prints and then compared them with the on-screen images. In sRGB mode, I felt like the colors were spot-on and the final prints mirrored what I saw on my screen. The screen is a bit too bright, compared to the prints - but not bad. In other words, the screen can give the illusion of a well-exposed image (because it's too bright) when in fact, I need to bump the exposure on the photo another 1/3 to 1/2 stop. So for future edits, I know that what looks pretty bright on screen is actually a bit dim in print - and I need to increase the exposure a bit more. That's an easy fix - either through calibration or through manually adjusting the photos.I should also note that I'm 6'5" and finding a monitor that adjusts well to my poster is hard - I often set books or get stands to elevate the monitor a bit. Not with this one! It has an incredible range of adjustments to practically an position you could want. All in all, I feel like this monitor was an absolute steal at this price! I can edit in confidence, knowing that the colors and contrast I see on screen mirror the printer's output... and for $200, that's not too shabby at all.If you're thinking about buying a monitor and want to keep it in the $200 range, stop thinking. Buy this one.

I should begin by saying that I have a high arch and narrow feet. In athletic shoes, I almost always wear a size 12 and ASICS tend to fit me best (typically high arch and run narrow). I bought the 11.5 and those were huge on me. I then got the 11's and those are still slightly too big in length. If I went for a 10.5 though, I think they'd be too small so I stuck with the 11.I found the insoles to be very uncomfortable. There's a heel gel square inserted into it, but I actually found this section to be bruising my heel over the course of the day. Additionally, the sides rubbed the under-side of my ankle bone. Couple those gripes with a lack of arch support and I wasn't too impressed... but I still liked the style, color and construction.I ended up removing the provided insole (pops right out, thankfully) and putting in the size 13 orthotic insert and it fit perfectly. Now they're pretty comfortable - but still a bit big. After a few days of break in and with the new insoles, they don't rub my ankles any more either. I may go back to Wal-Mart and get a flat foam insert to stick under the new insoles just to make them a bit more snug, but they're pretty comfortable now as is.Like I mentioned above, the styling really is great. Dressy enough to wear with a suit or dress slacks, but also non-showy enough to wear with some chinos or dressy jeans. That's what I was after appearance wise, so I'd say I nailed that objective. And thankfully, after some after market insoles, they're pretty comfortable now too. The construction seems to be good, although I've only had them a month, so I can't say for sure. Only time will tell.So in summary, it's a decent shoe. Can you do better? Maybe... probably. With Amazon's free returns (Prime), it's worth giving it a go though. Maybe you'll have better luck - it's pretty hard to find a shoe this well made and looks this good for this price.

I bought this case for my wife who, due to children and all that entails, is pretty hard on her phones. The case is a bit bulky, but with larger pockets, or wearing the belt clip, or (as my wife does) carrying it in a purse, it's not a problem at all. The kickstand works great and the built-in, reenforced screen protector is also a real plus.I certainly don't recommend abusing your devices or cases, but this one has been through a lot already; dropped, kicked, slobbered on, thrown, bounced and spilled upon - primarily by some toddlers who happen to live in my home - and it's handled it all without any signs of exterior damage to the case and certainly no damage to the phone itself.Seriously people, for this price... and really, regardless of the price, this case rocks. I can't think of a better option for people who need total protection. To quote my wife, "This case is a TANK! It can handle anything, and I love it that I can hand the phone to my toddler to play learning games on it and not worry if they're scratching the screen or going to drop it on the floor. It's awesome!"

Great umbrella - the materials are great, manufacturing seems to be sturdy and well-put together and the lighting effect it creates is predictable and lovely.Finding a decent umbrella with a removable cover at this price is difficult - especially with a the very desirable silver lining on the underside of the black liner. The light quality is great and the silver lining underneath the white does a great job of bouncing that last bit of light back out without making it harsh. In my mind, this is the perfect balance between the silver-lined umbrellas that can be a bit harsh in some circumstances and a non-lined umbrella that ends up absorbing some of your light.In short, it works great and seems to be built well. For $20, you can't go wrong... and I doubt you could do better.

This is something we occassionally (perhaps, annually) use preventatively in an unoccupied older home.  The instructions are easy to follow, and it seems to work well (no issues).  The smell does linger.

Small relief, big (stinky) smell.It smells (strongly) of tar, mixed with something else.  Very unpleasant, strong smell.  Which, might be worth it, if this were the miracle cure.  But, it's not.It does provide some healing and relief, but did not heal sores after a full thirty days of use.  (I will note that the packaging recommends a full 90 days to see results.  I am reviewing after 30 days, due to Amazon's vine time allotment.)  I tested this out on my mom, who has long term recurrent psoriasus abd eczema.  The smell nearly gave me an asthma attack, but it did provide some relief for her.  However, it didn't heal completely, and she had experienced better results with pure shea butter and herb extracts.I think it's worth trying, if you can stand the smell.  But, it's no holy grail.

First, it Is a strictly Cool Mist humidifier.I chose it because it looked nicer and more contemporary that my older one.  It also looked smaller.  It looks something like "Jeanie's bottle" which is cute.  In person, I discovered that, while it is a bit of a smaller footprint than my old one, it really is larger than I anticipated.In function, it works well.  The mist is fine.  It doesn't go up to a heavy mist (and there's no reason I want it to) but it needs to be turned past the minimum to mist noticably.  In states it will run for 6 hours, but I found that, in practice, (and with the lower settings I prefer) it will run longer.It assembles quickly and intuitively.My favorite feature is that the it the light will change color and it will turn itself off when it empties.  I feel much better sleeping with this on, because of that.  The light is, happily, not terribly bright.Why only four stars?  There is no way to fill this from the top.  The water resevoir must be flipped upside down, and a cap unscrewed in order to add water.  I found this a bit awkward (and give the conical shape is definitely requiring two hands).

I'm giving this a four star rating, because it's a good (not amazing) mattress whose pros far outweigh it's cons.  I feel it's correctly priced and should compete well at its price-point.  And, if you are furnishing a guest room, and you don't mind seriously annoying packaging, I would recommend you order it.  However, if you are looking for you OWN mattress that you are going to sleep on for the next 7-10 years, go to a local showroom, lay on a bunch of them, and pick the one you really, truly like and have them deliver it, set it up, and haul away the old one.Mattress preference is a very personal thing.  It's like the way you take your coffee (1 sugar, two creams) or the way you take your eggs (only in French Toast); you like it the way you like it.  Someone else's opinion can only take you so far.  (Fortunately here, I will interject that Amazon does have an excellent return policy, however returning something of this size would be at best slightly annoying in any scenerio.)  This mattress is a pretty good middle ground of a lot of likes and dislikes (which, granted, you might consider an excellent compromise or the equivalent of lukewarm coffee), which I will discuss below.  I do think it's quality on middle-groundness makes it well suited for a guest room (for guests you like) and may even make it a good match for you (depending on your preferences).Some people like the dense hug-your-body-ness of the memory foam, that solid squish.  Some (like me) prefer the springiness of a spring mattress (and can start to feel a little too-trapped-to-move in a memory foam only mattress).  This is a hybrid between the two.  Even as a lover-of-springs, I found I liked it.  The memory foam ensures you don't feel any springs and softens the effects of movement, but the springs presence allows for a quicker bounce and (to me) a more pleasant support.This mattress is, for me, a little on the firm side.  When you sit on the edge, it feels like it's going to be much softer than it is when you lie down.  Some would disagree with me, because it's not a real exxxtra-firm mattress.  (Some might even say it's not firm enough.)  But, personally, I want to sleep on a big fluffy cloud of cuddliness.The pillow top.  (Or, why it lost a star.)  The pillow top is a little wimpy.  And while the actual mattress itself hopped-to and totally ragained shape instantly, the pillow top took forever to smooth out and even retained a couple wrinkles.  And, it could be thicker.  I, personally, kind of want to add another pillow top to it.  But, then, I'm a junkie for softness.  The thickness of the pillow top is probably fine for most people; however, the pillow top's response to this packing method may be an issue.You will need deep pocked sheets for this, so make sure to add those to your order.And, do not forget to note that this is a mattress only.  No frame/box-spring/platform.  So factor that into your price comparisons (especially since most stores, in my area at least, advertise prices for sets).Finally, THE ANNOYING PACKAGING (or, the other reason we lost a star).  I haaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaate the way this ships.  My box, as others have noted, was completely trashed and half-opened.  Fortunately, the mattress is heavily wrapped in plastic, so it was still protected. I would say this weighs close to 100 pounds (defintely way more than my Golden Retriever---and I can't lift my Golden Retriever).  There are no handles or hold holes on the box of any kind.  Just getting it into my house, over the threshold, was a pain.  Then, awkwardly manuevering it into the bedroom, positioning it onto the bed, also a pain.  Once you get the plastic partially cut, it pretty much forces itself off from that point, like butterfly getting itself from a caccoon.  Pretty amusing that it pops up like a cartoon life raft.  Not so amusing that, with the way it's rollled, it unrolls automatically upside down.  So, just when you think you're done moving the heavy beast, you get to flip it over (the mattress does have side handles, but they aren't so useful when you are 5 foot tall).  Meanwhile, you have to handle disposal of the old mattress on your own (see your local charities about needed donations, they make pick up, and some cities have curbside pick up for large items on scheduled days).  I broke two nails and needed ibuprofen.  But, I did do it myself.  Hurrah for me.And, one more thing, ABOUT THE SIZING.  I can't comment on the ones other people recieved (go through the reviews and read their experiences) which may or may not have been like the one I have.  But, I did notice a couple comments that seemed to find their mattress to be of an irregular size.  So, I want to inject this here.  The compression seems to seriously (though, temporarily) contort the size.  Upon unboxing, I was convinced that there was no way it would fit on the platform of the bed I was placing it on.  I thought perhaps they had sent a different size than I ordered.  It looked that strange.  Happily, "upon inflation," I found that it was the correct size and it was perfectly regular, perfectly matching the platform size.  So, if you order this, and it looks oddly shaped when you try to roll it out, don't panic.  It re-inflates faster than an air mattress and gains it's real size as it does so.(PS: Instructions state that you should open box within 72 hours of reciept to gain full inflation, and that you should allow 24-72 hours to regain shape once open.  I opened the box instantly upon reciept and gave it 48 hours before testing out.)I love Amazon, I love online shopping.  Love it.  But there are some items that are more or less conducive to the online shopping experience.  And, I think personal mattress shopping is one of those things not well suited for online purchase.  It's a very personal choice and you should try it out and know how well it suits YOU.  The average person buys a mattress every 7-10 years, get one you really like.  However, as said in the beginning, I do completely recommend this for your guest room (assuming you weren't completely horrified by the packing and assembly).  It's completely more comfy than most guest beds or hotel beds I've been stuck in, and at a really fair price point.
Interesting and strangely amusing.  Strangely.

The author is pointing out real flaws in the system, and there are more observations than solutions.  The issues she raises aren't exclusive to black boys, but do often affect them disporportionately.  I found this book to be lacking in group solutions but still bold in it's addressing of issues and does give a few excellent pointers for advocating well for your child.

The primary reason that I am disliking this is the odor.  It has a weird, grandfatherly smell.  I can't decide if it's more Aqua-velva or shaving cream, but it's unpleasant and slightly stranger.  And very non-girly.  And not *attractively* masculine.  And it lingers.Constency wise, it feels completely different that the other dr brandt serum I've tried.  This is more of a light lotion, somewhat thick.  Disolves INSTANTLY into the face, yet doesn't seem to really moisturize.  Also, when followed with moisturizer, the combination felt a touch minty/tingly.I *don't* like it.  I don't like it at all.
Details abound, pop-culture, both modern(for the times) and antiquated.  Love the attention to detail.

Purely by happenstance, the author seems to have picked every character's name of my family tree (and specifically my maternal grandmother's family).  What are the odd?  So, my hightened sense of "something seems surreal here" is, no doubt, in relation to that.  That sense of sepia toned flashback is there (my advanced reading edition makes over-use of the imbedded letters and telegrams to communicate this, which I did not enjoy) for sure.  Overall, it's well written, but I still feel it remains to surface-level in its human experience and cannot, therefore, achieve greatness.

Three stars?  Four stars?  I couldn't quite decide.  Somewhere, there.  However, if I could send this overblown thing back to the editor to be pared down by about 20%, I would feel solid about the 4 stars.  Lengthy is fine, provided there's justification for the length....  Here, it wears...and not well.  It rambles.  It looses focus. Otherwise solid writing bevomes congested with worthless traffic of excess words.Edit, people.

I think this is a solid 4 star book.  It almost earned that ellusive fifth star because I found the premise and plot line to be both unique and fascinating. But, in the end, it was just a tad too slow to gain that fifth star.
This book reminds me of a bad perfume.  Annoying, cloying, sticky.  A few oversweet highnotes clashing with the other notes and something bitter never meant to fit with anything else.

This is one of those weigthy tomes that feels good in your hands, and then when you carry it to your heart, provides dividends to offset the time it asked of you.  The time relationships ask of you.  It weaves a world around you, lets that world of the gravity necessary for three dimensionality, and suddenly, you are a world away.Well written, tender, detailed treasure.

Interesting informal analysis of business acumen, creativity, and the efficacy of chutzpah.  Trying it out, finding through initial proactice, does it work? And then testing and retesting.  It's really an exporation of the hypothesis, not analyzed to death before tested, or overly romanticized in the creative realm.

How many sterotypes can you fight with one book and still be successful?  This book really kind of flirts with that limit and stumbles under the weight, yet, ironically, because of the weight speaks something about the weight of stereotyping in general.  Overall, the writing is both earnest and macabre in a way that recalls, for me, the writing of Flannery O'Connor (which is, very much, a compliment).  I would not mind seeing more from this author.
A truly unique piece of work, both in terms of subject matter and unique (and solid) writing.

I picked this up because I loved the title (and its allusions).  But, as it turns out, I didn't love the book.  It's perfectly okay, and perfectly forgettable.  It's an author that discovers how to create an interesting plot and some interesting characters, without learning to string words together in a remotely interesting or engaging way.  The dialogue is, in my opinion, particularly boring.The editor is probably at least partly to blame for this boring waste of paper, however, I do think this author should possibly rethink her career.

This book has some value in that it depicts something of the effect of WW2 on the "average" un-targeted civilian within German territories.  There is benefit to exploring that area of the war, which, in light of other far-more-extreme atrocities, becomes easy to ignore.  In spite of that, I could not help having a rather visceral reaction to aspects of the book.  Because it is the world-as-she-is-in-it, a world gone mad, the politicals powers of the day are referenced in very...regular ways.  Hitler, Rommel, the gestapo are all matter-of-fact background.  While I don't think a careful reading of this book supports them or their psychotic ideology, it's still...disturbing to read about that in such a casual way.  If you went into this book with no knowledge of WW2, you might miss a great deal.

This book makes me share her homesickness for Italy.  Aside from that, I think that anyone who's ever felt they had their feel in two different worlds and felt disoriented in both will find a bit of their own theme song here.

The cover makes a pretty fantastic claim, "A great new American epic...nothing less than Dostoyevskian."  Dostoyevskian, now that's aiming high.  I don't know a single American writer that I would lump with the greats of Russian or French literature.  But that cover claim is asking me to judge this along highly brilliant literary works (and I'm all for comparing and reviewing a work within and against it's genre).  So, it looses a star because it can live up to that, but, really, what can?It's good, though, it's really good.  It's appocolyptical, messy, all-over-the-map in terms of locations and people groups and classes...and yet, really, real.  It has dirt under it's nails.

A fragile, weightless world with a million (zillion) references to Western culture that are, for the most part, not organized into any linear parallels but do create a slight Looking Glassness to this world, though it is not a world of nonsense.  Well harkens to early, slightly earthy, bright-but-dark fairy tales.  Yet a solid tale told without the binding of all realities.

I do love that this system is designed for minimal handling.  Poisons...spook me.  However, rodents disgust me. I can't verify we killed anything with this, but we use it in an empty house and some outbuildings.  Preventitively, and it does seem to have helped avoid "critters."  I do have pets and I am unwilling to use any poison (however enclosed) in the house.

One of the saddest, most beautiful books that I've read in many days.  If you can make it through these pages without crying or remembering your own losses, I shall be surprised.  Incredible, and gut wrenching.  Well done.

This is an average to above average salycillic acid acne treatment.  It's a good product, but there's really nothing about it that truly distinguished it from other products.  In fact, I think I may slightly prefer Clearasil's rapid acting salycillic product.  Overal, it'sa good product, horribly packaged (more about that below).  With a name like Benzac, I was (happily) surprized to find this is not benzoyl peroxide based.  Salycillic acid is, based on both my knoowledge and experience, a slightly more gentle product, and it is well suited for those whose issues tend more toward black heads.  It's less likely than benzoyl peroxide to produce peeling, and I can happily report no peeling with its use (and my skin is rather prone to peel).  I also have rather sensitive skin and this was non-irritating.  Lots of things to like, and based on product alone, I would consider repurchasing.  However, since there are other similiar (and more readily available to me) products that I like at least as well, and I hate this packaging, it is unlikely that I will.As product performance is, overall, reasonable but not miraculous.The packaging is not reasonable.  It's annoying.  It desperately needs to be redesigned.  My first issue is more cosmetic, but is a function to a small degree.  The issue is a not-full tube.  The tube initialy feels half empty, which was odd.  However,  quickly noted that that was by design.  The tube is approximately the same size as a 1 oz tube of a competing product, but contains .5 oz.  So there's a perception of value that isn't there.  However, it also means that the product is packaged containing more air space, therefore more air, which, I suspect may affecs it's efficacy. It definately affects its use.  Which I will explain as I go onto the main issue. The opening to the tube is HUGE. Up to 3x larger than those of competing products.  No matter how careful I was, I was consistently squeezin out twice the product needed (this problem is compounded by the half empty tube, since you are squeezing product from the bottom).  It's a very liquid formula, so it needs a more petite opening.  It's designed for waste and mess.I did give the product the full four star rating of the formula, without deducting points for the packaging, however, do note that the package is one of the reason I don't expect to repurchase.

It's a frequently melancholy book, with an honest depiction of grief an its fallout, and the grief of change.  All through narrative.  Yet the "question of miracles" raises it to another place...also struggles with the acceptance factor of grief as it reaches for hope.  Really...read worthy.

A wonder of words.  Though prose, wonderfully sensory and poetic.  A gift to read, with a soft, sad beauty that stubbornly contrasts with the pugilistic plot line, the contrast results in a book that's very human.

If you like "Amish fiction."This is the sort of book I keep on my shelf t ensure my mother is entertained.  Personally, I wouldn't have picked it up for just myself, but that's because I don't even faintly understand the appeal the recurrent Amish background in fiction. However, presumably, if you are picking this up you LIKE that, and I am trying to judge it against its genre, hence the four stars.  My mother would give it five, I would give it three stars, hence, my total of 4.  I do think it distinguishe itself somewhat amoung the (too many) Amish fiction books out there.  The characters had a definite real and human (and less stock) quality to them.  The writing is condescending at times, but overall not bad.

There are lots of little sideplots sliding around here, and somehow they all tie together neatly and organically.  Quick moving plot.  Kind of shallow characterization, but enjoyable little read none-the-less.

Sweet, but reaching, and actually left me "bored to tears," if you'll pardon the cliche.  The author's roots are near my own, and  wanted to like it for that reason, but ultimately, even the Christmas motif couldn't drag it past the tree start mark for me.  (I kindly inserted the third star for the sake of the slight Christmas-y-ness.)

We are Natural Balance junkies.  It's my usual dog food for a reason.  My Golden loves it, and I love that her ears and skin stay healthy on this food.  I will say that of all the flavors, I am least likely to purchase this one.  (My  dog really likes the Venison and the Duck flavors best, and I've noticed that amoung ALL BRANDS, chicken always seems the most likely flavor recalled.  So, I lean to the other flavors, however, my dog loves this one, too.  She adores chicken.)This gets high marks on dog food analysis site (I can't post a link on Amazon, but you can google).  It's also readily available.

Do what you love.  And do it the way you love it.  And ask yourself some good questions to make sure what you love loves you in return.If you are falling in or out of love with your dream, this book should be a valuable asset as assess your business plan against prevailing wisdom.  Not getting lost amidst too many charts, not forgetting the thrill of base-jumping into your dream.

Cute, really cute.  I'll state that I'm not a frequent reader of graphic novels, however, on the few occassions I reach for them, I do tend to enjoy them.  This one was cute and action packed, full of humor (lots of puns) and I'm really glad it's a series (I think there is enough drama and relationships here to build on).The colored pages are complexly (not brightly, or primarily) and the background images are nice. There's a good variety of illustration focus points and frame sizes and a good sense of ation to cary you forward.Really adorable.

Because few things are what we expect them to be (and nothing is "exactly") it's nice to know you aren't alone when your had starts spinning with surprise.  A smidge of humor, a great deal of inspiration.

A surprisingly political book, and a bit dry (for which points were lost).  Still, it has something to offer in an interesting, if somewhat partisan, analsysis in the intersctions of faith, charity,...and government policy.  I confess I had expected a book that focused more on those first two elements, there is however, a heavy emphasis on the later.

The main reason I'm deducting one star is that the rules are...a little complicated, with a variety of versions.  With that said, this is still quirky and fun, and it's very unique in that it can be played "solitaire" with only one player.It's absurd (in a good way), quirky, slightly macabre, and FUN.  They really won me over with the curse cards, particularly the Duck of Doom.  Really?  How lovable is THAT.  Yes, it's a touch bloodthirsty, so you might want to round out your game cabinet with simpler board games as well, but personally...I thought it was a hoot.  I can't wait to play with my 10 year old nephew.Bonus: you actually do "construct" the castle (3D type puzzle pieces) which adds to the joy.

I was thrilled to get this as we are in the middle of redoing a very small hall bathroom, and all ingenius space uses are really helpful.  And this one actually looks nicer than anticipated.It's a brushed nickel look, but not too matte (I like the bit of shine).  It's sturdy, and I love the wall mounts.  The wall mounts are sleek and modern and have bit more size to them that makes them a decorative touch.Size wise, that curvature makes the small shower seem less clauserphobic---without stealing space from an already small footprint.  Also, these curved rods remove the issue of shower curtains that want to sway inward and cling to you (which is totally icky).Very happy with the sturdiness and quality of this item (also, it is well and protectively packaged).

Tough little case.  Somewhat streamlined (does) some bulk, as do most protective cases), with a sweet industrial look.  The clear portions are truly clear, which I like.  Smooth, but not so slick as to be ungrippable.  Also, does not fingerprint as horribly are feared.  Ports are accessible.I would repurchase from this brand.

We are fans.  Regu;ar Natural Balance customers.I really trust this brand.  The dog food is wonderful for my dogs health.  And the treats always smell fresh and real and not-chemically and fake.  My Golden's nose approves, it always brings a happy wiggle dance (if you have a Golden, you know their honey bee dance of approval).These are also pretty big (I tend to break them in half).  (I do tend to prefer tiny treats so I can offer them more often.  We're big Zuke's fans here, another good treat brand.)Recommend.

(I'm writing my Vine review before my item arrives because I am already a big fan of this brand---and a regular repeat customer.) Natural Balance and Blue Wilderness are my go-to dog food brands!  The Natural Balance brand tends to have a bit less protein than the Blue Wilderness, which is a plus for their kidneys (there is is still a really great amount of protein in this brand).I started feeding a limited ingredient diet several years ago.  I own a Golden, an AMAZING breed, which is also, sadly, prone to lots of health issues, including skin and ear infections.  We were experiencing multiple ear infections a year, and I was advised to adjust her diet.  Which has been amazing.  Her coat is also shinier, but most importantly, we have avoided so many vet visits.  Her ears are simply healthier.  She is also far less itchy.Huge fan.  She loves all the flavors, and I like to mix it up a bit in which I buy, but the Duck and the Venison are probably her favorites.(I would suggest finding a good storage container as these foods do smell rather meaty.)

By look and smell, these could easily be confused with human-food jerkies.  My dog voluntarily goes through her whole repetoire of tricks in an effort to bum them.  They are "barks" so they are a little easier to chew than some jerky treats.  At any rate, my soft toothed Golden makes short work of them.I always trust Natural Balance.  Excellent nutrition.
Good table for dollhouse. Not as good quality as others I have seen but the price was right.
Miniature stuff is hard to buy because the pictures are so much bigger than the actual item.  This is so small the detail gets lost.  It still works, just looks like a plain piece of wood.

I needed some of these pieces for my dollhouse and could not find them individually so I bought the set.  Some of the pieces are so fragile you have to be very careful with them.  Good for the price though.
Love this wallpaper.  I am using it in my dollhouse kitchen.  The proportions are perfect and it really looks like tile.
Great wallpaper for my Victorian dollhouse.  The scale and details are just right.
Very Victorian lock and key.  Just what I wanted for my dollhouse.  The key will not fit into the opening unless you drill out some of the wood behind it.
I am using this for my dollhouse bathroom.  I love the look.  I should have bought two sheets so I didn't have to patch but it was easy to cut on the tiles to patch.

Have never worked with this kind of glue/paste but it's working out well.  Enough time to reposition if you don't get it right the first time.  It is sticky so you need to have a wet cloth handy and wipe everything down before it dries.
Am building my first dollhouse and wanted some Victorian accents.  This will work in the parlor.  Very nice.
Saw this on The View and thought it would be great to have guilt free meals.  Not as good as I thought it would be.  Will try some of the recipes but many were not interesting enough to try.
Very funny.  A modern look at manners and what not to do. Love her sense of humor.

This set of dies is great.  Lots of individual leaves for lots of applications.  I like the small size because they work great for cards. You can position them to cut out multiples at one time.  I use the magnetic platform to keep them in place.
Great stamps for cards and scrapbooking.  Good assortment of shapes. Nice size.

This is the style I wanted but it has some issues.  The metal is thin and will bend with not much force.  I do not recommend hanging the second and third section with the clips....it's not stable enough.  We put screws in each section to make it secure on the door so it won't move when we open the door.  It is easy to install and the baskets go in fine.  I wish that there were more small baskets for spices.
Saw the ads but was still skeptical.  Then read the reviews and decided to get some.  Works great.  I saw the difference overnight.  Use it on my heels as well.
Great thermos.  Keeps liquids hot for a long time. You can burn yourself the first hour if your liquids are too hot going it. Easy to take apart and clean.  Love the color.
Love this cute flower pot.  I am currently using it to make invitations...just the pot, not the 3D part.  Will use the whole thing for table favors.  Easy to use.
Like this brand.  I have several pairs of their earrings.  Always get compliments on them.
Love long dangle earrings.  These fit the bill.  Good price. I got lots of compliments on them over the holidays.
Small but good for beading.  These only work on small beads but they look nice and give some bling to the beads.
Bought this for a friend who just turned 70.  It brings up some fun and interesting things to think about.  Light and easy to read.
Played this over the holidays.  It was ok but not the great fun I had expected....could have been the guests.
It's a light bulb and it works.  This is a specialty bulb that the home store don't carry so thank you Amazon.

Like the die but haven't used it yet.  Good size to go with the Sizzix sleigh die,  Will use it to make table decorations for next Christmas.  I am assuming that it will be as good as all the other Sizzix dies I have.
Fun beads.  Liked the stars foe the holidays.  Used them to make Christmas jewelry.
I thought I was going to find more useable things in here.  It's cute but not really my style.  Did make a couple of things but most of them are too funky.

I needed some circles with scallops that work with plain circles  so I got this.  It's okay but does not have the size variations that I was looking for.  Some of the scallops are too big for the plain circles.  Oh well, I'll keep looking.  Works ok for what it is.
Use this for all my card making.  Don't know what I did without my dispenser and refills.  Works great on anything that needs tape.

Great die for Christmas decorating.  Make this out of heavy cardboard, cut two and put a strip between then like a seat and it will make a darling centerpiece.  Add the reindeer from Sizzix and you're done.
Am using these for holiday jewelry pieces.  They look so cute on trees made from buttons.  Just the right size.

Great die from TH.  Wanted the pine branch more than the pinecone but surprisingly I have used the pinecone for decorations.  It's a little tricky the first time but after that they came together quickly. I use the branch for cards and scrapbooking.  Works great.  Looks beautiful in glitter paper.
Bought these for the holiday parties this year.  Had lots of comments and one friend wanted to borrow them.  Great value for the money.
My husband got this to warm up his bathroom.  Works great.  He likes the remote control.  He turns it on about 15 minutes before he takes a shower and the room is warmed up.
Wanted some very small bottles for configuration boxes.  These work great.  I will find other uses for them with my crafts.
Cute paper tapes.  I have been using them for making Christmas cards and tags.  You need to be careful putting them on because you cannot reposition them.  But they work.nice.
I had been buying this brand at WalMart but they are always out of stock so ordered from Amazon.  I like this brand because there is no fishy after taste. Big plus for me.
Saw this being used on one of Tim's tutorials.  Great stuff.  Sticks well.  Be sure to let dry completely.
Fun to use.  Great for hot flashes.  A little noisy. I have a big one that it a lot quieter. Good value for the money.
If you bake bread you will love this.  It has taken my bread to a whole new level.  The rising temp is now perfect and my dough loves it.  Worth the money.

This is actually a very pretty pin and I bought it because of the unusual colors.  Some of the reviews warned about the clasp not being well thought out....it closes on the top not the bottom where it should be.  My problem, however, is that it is very cheaply made and the top broke off as I was attempting to close the clasp.  No way to fix it.  I am very disappointed .
I took these off the rope to use separately for Halloween crafts.  Worked great but I wish they were jointed so they moved or at least bend a little.

Wanted small versions of bird and flower.  This fit the bill.  I layered several of the flower together for some dimension and a fuller poinsettia.  Just the right size for cards and crafting.  Very cute.
Great for cards and scrapbooking.  Nice vintage designs.
Nice Christmas paper.  I am using this for card making and it works very well.

This medallion flower is very cute but the die sucks.  You have to cut at least three strips, four if you want it to look like the picture.  Then you have to glue them all together and let that dry before you can make the medallion. The dies are thin so they don't come off the paper easily.  I used waxed paper to assist with that.  I do like the finished product, especially the backing that makes it look like a flower, but it's a lot of work.
Wanted some purple wire to play around with.  Great color.  Heavy gauge so it's not easy to bend in the shapes I want but works with a little bit of effort.
Good green wire to make jewelry.  Heavy gauge so it's not easy to manipulate.  Would work for other craft projects.
Good wire for jewelry making.  Heavy gauge so it's not easy to shape without tools.

Bought this for my mother when her old electric kettle gave up the ghost.  She likes that this is cordless and can take it off it's base to pour without having to unplug it.  The only issue she has is that it's very heavy when full.  She's 92 so that tells you something.  Other than that she likes it and is very happy with it.
Haven't used these yet but they are cute and will work for lots of Christmas crafting.  They are small....1 inch square.

If you’re a preacher, you’ve probably got a short list of individuals and authors you look to for encouragement and advice. For me, these includes a few personal friends and mentors, as well as a number of well-known individuals. There’s a great deal I’ve learned about preaching from the works of Charles Spurgeon and Martyn Lloyd-Jones, from listening to men like Daniel Akin and Matt Chandler.And then there’s Tim Keller. One of the things I appreciate about Keller is the fact that he holds his hearers’ attention without drawing too much attention to himself. He loves words and wordplay, but he’s not trying to entertain you (even though his humor is quite disarming)—he wants you to understand the Bible on its own terms, and to see Jesus in every jot and tittle. So when Keller set out to write a book on preaching itself, I was intrigued. Would he focus primarily on mechanics? Study habits? The C.S. Lewis saturation point in each sermon?In Preaching, Keller chooses to take a different approach than other authors writing on the subject by primarily looking at Word ministry philosophically, asking readers to consider how preaching serves the Word of God, reaches people, and is a demonstration of the Spirit and of power.The first section of the book addresses the best methods for preaching. Keller encourages making expository preaching your typical approach, as it best “expresses and unleashes our belief in the whole Bible as God’s authoritative, living, and active Word” (35).Topical preaching, on the other hand, can be helpful at times, and even necessary, but a steady diet of it doesn’t leave people appreciating the scope of God’s Word, nor grasping the Spirit’s power. Most importantly, it fails to show hearers how all of Scripture is about Jesus. He writes:"Try reading only one chapter out of a Charles Dickens or Victor Hugo novel without reading anything before or afterward in the book. Would you be able to understand and appreciate the chapter?  Certainly you would learn about the characters, and some relatively complete narrative action or subplot could take place within the portion of the book you have read. But much would be inexplicable, because you wouldn’t know what came before, and many things that the author was doing in the chapter would be invisible if you didn’t see how the story played out. That is what it is like to read and preach a text of the Bible and not show how it points to Christ. If you don’t see how the chapter fits into the whole story, you don’t understand the chapter." (59)Someone can give a great, inspirational message, but if Jesus isn’t there, if he isn’t made known, preaching hasn’t happened.The bulk of Preaching deals more with the issue of contextualization. Readers familiar Keller’s other works know that this is a hobbyhorse of his. Why? Because we don’t seem to understand what is meant by it.By contextualization, he does not mean conforming and compromising the truth in order to make it palatable for a 21st century audience—instead, he means communicating the truth in ways that they can actually comprehend. Though there are some who adamantly deny we should do this at all, we are wise to remember that “no one can present a culture-free formulation of biblical truth”:"The moment you open your mouth, many things—your cadence, accent, vocabulary, illustrations and ways of reasoning, and the way you express emotions—make you culturally more accessible to some people and force others to stretch and work harder to understand or even pay attention to you." (102)I was reminded of this reality a few months ago when speaking at a church in another community, and one illustration I made—referencing Calvin and Hobbes—just didn’t resonate. Because it was a very friendly and smaller group, there was a lot more freedom to adjust on the fly as I was preaching. So I asked, “How many of you know what I’m talking about right now?”One person. That was, on my part, poor contextualization (though, honestly, one that probably couldn’t be helped), in the same way it would be were I to use the word “sanctification” with the grade four and five kids in our children’s ministry without explaining what it means.But Keller goes one-step beyond simply reminding us that we need to remember where we are, but also reminds us of the need to correctly identify the spirit of the age. What Keller argues is that we are actually not in a post-modern age, but in a late-modern one. Citing Charles Taylor’s The Secular Age, he writes that, "…secular people are not more objective, but instead have embraced a new, constructed web of alternate beliefs about the nature of things that are not self-evident to all, are no more empirically provable than any other religious beliefs, require enormous leaps of faith, and are subject to their own array of serious problems and objections." (124-125)What makes late-modernity unique, though, Keller says, is, "nonsecular cultures are overt about their faith, and their members acknowledge the faith nature of their convictions. Many late modern secular people, however, don’t see or grant the leaps of faith they are taking."And that is what presents the great challenge to preaching in our day. This has been put before our eyes in the most graphic way possible by the Planned Parenthood video scandal. They’re edited. They can’t be trusted. Think about the services women wouldn’t have access to without Planned Parenthood? A fetus is human, but not a person… On and on the arguments go, all seemingly without anyone taking a moment to really think about what’s being said.That is the late-modern worldview at work. And that is what our preaching needs to combat. But even as we do, it’s wise to remember that, as Keller writes, “you are at odds with a system of belief far more than you are at war with a group of people. Contemporary people are the victims of the late-modern mind far more than they are its perpetrators. Seen in this light, the Christian gospel is more of a prison break than a battle.” (155-156)Preaching matters not simply because it’s something we’ve always done, but because of what it does in people—or more correctly, what the Spirit of God does through in people through faithful preaching. When the Bible is faithfully preached, some people are challenged in how they have been living and believing. Others are strengthened and given new hope. Others still find the message abhorrent and want nothing to do with it.
