I really like this. Though it actually two big for the lights I intended to use it for its so nice I am keeping it for future use. I set the gels in front of a light and they did get warm, but didn't melt at ll. For some reason the glow was not as consistent as I would like,  I could see a bright bulb(almost white spot) in the center instead of a glow of red, but that may be more to do with the type of bulb I am using. When I used the dimmer and changed some setting on my camera I did get the effect I wanted.The parts are metal and I think the honeycomb grill is really nice. The Gels are also set in metal frames and the thumb screws on the back are nice and big. This has a great build quality, even if these cost twice as much I think I would like them,.It's tough to tel whether the grill is metal or plastic, but if its plastic its good enough to fool me into thinking its metal. I will get another one of these.At 19.99 they are a fantastic deal!

I don't get the bad reviews. So many people saying the payments did not go through or its tough to find the payment link. That's a bunch of malarkey. I have made over 20 payments already in less than 6 months. It's a SUPER simple system and super easy to find the payment link. And once you set it up just put the link on your toolbar.,. You go to the link, enter name and password and pay, its not difficult at all!The payment credits to your account in less than 24 hours, so how he heck can anyone pay late?A++++++++++++++++++Don't believe the negative reviewers, if you are the type of person that pays your bills on time there is nothing to fear, the system works,\ and better than most credit and debit card that I have.The day you get your credit go online and set up an account and set up the bank info for paymnets, etc, Don't wait 30 days to try to do this, this is where 90% of the 1 star reviews come from. Waiting until the last minute and not realizing it takes a day or two to set up the payment account is a mistake. If the bank info is not set up until the day the first payment is do odds are  the the first payment will be late and a 35.00 charge will be incurred!go here: https://www.onlinecreditcenter6.com/consumergen2/login.do?accountType=plcc&clientId=amazon&langId=en&subActionId=1000Set up your online account AND the payment information, get it set up the FIRST day you get your account! Then buy something for like 20.00. Then after a day or two(or better yet 5 minutes after you make your first purchase with the new account)make a small payment, even if its 10.00, make sure the payment goes through. Once it does you are golden. If there are issues this gives you the entire month to get it set up right before that first payment comes due!I can only go by my experience and the experiences of 4 kids and wife that all have an Amazon account, None of us has ever had one issue getting a payment to go through!

I have a few references for my new Canon and more times than  not I grab this one. I ordered a couple more books that are new releases on the 70D and once I get those I will be able to compare. For now I am very happy with this and it helps me a lot. Although I have not checked out the manual since I purchased this I do think this is a companion to the manual and not a replacement, which is a good thing. Who wants a rehashed manual.

Bulbs found here: Julius Studio dot com - search JDDHere is the link, amazon may erase it:[...]Mine work great, I even bought more. I think some of the lower star reviews have more to do with peoples expectations. In my mind these are ACCENT lights! With two lights,stands and bulbs, plus the barn doors for 65.00(61.00 in my case) and  a dimmer they seem to me to be designed for accent lighting.As accent lighting these are 4 or 5 star. For lighting up your subject with nothing else, they are 2 star. For this price, configured the way they are with 150 watt low spectrum bulbs and with a dimmer it should be apparent to most these are for accent lighting only. And as accent lighting they are great for the price!The cords are not very long and of course the stands are not that great, I could see some buying these just for the top portion and setting the stands aside. All these type of lights get hot, even expensive lights get hot. The difference is the more expensive lights have better cords, insulation and parts to handle the heat. So be careful and simply turn them off as much as you can. In other words don't leave them on and go to lunch, that's probably good advice for any light anyhow. And I would not never leave these lights on without someone being present.If you need these as your main lighting source, pass on them. If you want some small accent lighting go for it!I believe the bulbs have an E14 thread:Search ebay for "120Volt JULIUS STUDIO Light Bulb E14 Base JDD150W Frost Bulb" or google "JULIUS STUDIO Light Bulb 120Volt E14 Base" and I think you will find them. Any link I give outside of amazon gets deleted.ebay seems to sell several variations, 150 watt to 250 watt both frosted and clear.Light bulbs included are:JDD Type120V 150WE14 Screw BaseI give these 5 stars because they do what I believe they are designed to do and the price makes them a good value. If they cost 65.00 for each set up instead of for two set ups I would give them 3.5 stars because of the fairly poor stand quality. I paid 61.00 including shipping for two set ups so I have to give them 5 stars. I will update in a month or so.NOTE AFTER many hours use: Okay after using these a bit I take that back about the stands. They may not be the best, but they are really good stands from a value standpoint. For value they are 5 stars for sure. Some pro stand cost 150.00 to 500.00 so compared to all stands they are 2.0 to 2.5 stars. Its tough to compare something like these to great lifetime quality stands that pro use on a pro set.  Still, 61.00 for two stands,barn doors and bulbs, value has to be considered so I am still at a 5 star rating as a set.  The bulbs are still going strong after 8 hours. I don't lug my stuff around so for people that do the stands are what they are and probably wont take tossing around very much. Then again wont these pay for themselves after one shoot? If they don't you are not charging enough!

It's wrinkled and thin but works so I give it 4 stars. the color seems nice, but my seamless paper is more white. I think I will buy a liner for behind it as well. This company does not include a "protector - back lining" so I am unsure why some reviewers are saying they it was not included. Of course not , the description does not say it is. I do think with a "protector" this would be 5 stars , even if they charged 10.00 more. Or if it were simply thicker.I do think a backer lining behind the muslin works better than a thicker single muslin drop. At least it seems to in my space. I am not sure why, maybe it has something to so with the way light bounces.

This part works perfectly. It looks nothing like the original part though. I guess this design is better.  I was told it was the fan itself and that if it were the resistor the fan would work on high, but I got nothing out of the fan switch at any setting. I didn't listen to the mechanic, swapped in this resistor and saved 200.00 for the fan and labor for the install!

I purchased the cowboy studio version, but it's the same exact thing except the 3 chains are each a different color, not all blue. Had I seen this one for 10.00 less I probably would have ordered this. I attached mine to my backdrop stand with U-bolts, not to a wall or ceiling and it works perfectly.

I returned the 53" roll and got this. Unlike the 53" roll the edges on this are perfect. For some reason it even seems more black than the first roll and I like that. I am very happy with this.Why do some people prefer vinyl? I don't like the shine on the vinyl and although vinyl may outlast this, for a hobbyist like me I bet this last years. I have the white too and will probably get more as time goes on. I have the rolls on the CowboyStudio Photography 3-Roller roller mount that I attached to a backdrop stand.
I didn't want to attach to a wall so I just used U clamps and attached to my  Ravelli ABSL backdrop and it works great!

Okay mine had minor wrinkles along the edge. Plus, I think it could be even more black. So 1/2 star off  for the wrinkle edges and 1/2 star off for my perception of true black.I guess this is the most black of any paper I could find so I sent  my 53" roll back and ordered the 107" roll. If the edges are bad then it will not matter much. The 53"  roll is just not wide enough anyhow, especially if the edges are bad like the roll I received.If you are going back and forth just go 107" if you have room. The 53" roll limited the pics of my kids quite a bit, even if the edges were perfect. I missed out on so many other poses I could have done. With only 3 of the 7 kids kids next to each other the 53" cut it so close. Even being very careful I had way to much post processing for cropping etc, I could not back up, they couldn't really pose or an elbow etc would run off the 53".I am changing everything over to 107". I am a beginner and if any beginner asked me now I would say go 107", it opens up so many more things.

Love these. I purchase two sets of 4 and will buy more soon. Mine have not ripped at all yet, I say yet because other have mentioned it has happened, but mine so far after 2 months are still like new.A great hint is to use the best quality freezer zip lock bags you can find and fill it with WHITE PLAY SAND to 9.5(10lbs max) and slip it in the pocket. You can slip the ziploc in the saddlebag pocket first, but I don't.  I like to weigh each bag to 9.5 lbs on my scale so they are balanced.Using the freezer bags instead of putting the sand directly in the saddlebags works great. They are so much simpler to fill(and unfill if the need ever arises). he biggest plus is if the saddlebag ever gets a hole sand will not leak out.The hint of the freezer bag was given to me by someone else doing a review and I highly suggest it!

This works and if you want an under monitor power strip this is about it, there are not many more on the market. The first thing I noticed is how incredibly light and cheap it feels. It does work though so I give it 4 stars. 1 star of for just feeling so cheap.

These are a neat little item. They stretch out my muslin nicely and I get away with a bit more wrinkle in the muslin than I normally could because of the way they stretch the muslin so tight(like a drum).

WOW these are HUGE. I have only had them on for about an hour, but so far so good. I don't use them much so I have no idea  how many actual hours they will last, but out of the box they are great. I will update as time goes by. For now I am extremely pleased, they were shipped and packaged very well.And 6500 K is so darn white(or even blue?) They work for me!

I love these batteries, I have a new Canon 70D and these batteries work perfectly. They don't last quite as long as a Canon, but for the money they are well worth it.Rotating these with the original  Canon battery I never go a day without power. I think these are cheaper only becasue each charge cycle one only last about 80% as long as on original Canon with a full charge and Wasabi doesn't do as good quality control.  This lets some of the batteries that are not good slip through to the consumers.If someone received batteries that don't have a good charge  I suggest returning them within the 30 days and try again.

A bit wobbly, but I am not using them with the bar they are designed for so possibly thats the issue. I like mine a lot, I only wish it was a bit longer and that the middle section was a bit wider to received a thicker bar. For my bar I had to remove one of the adjusters to allow it to fit.If it were just a bot larger in every dimension it would be 5 stars for me, its a lot smaller than I had envisioned it. Maybe if they introduced a heavy duty version I would give the 5  stars. Another 4.5 star item I am rounding down to 4 stars.

I grew up in Washington State, and learned our state history in the public schools I attended. Lip service was given to the role of the Indians, but it was mainly the white man's story; the story of the settlers. Messages from Frank's Landing is a readable account of Billy Frank, Jr., a Nisqually Indian who saw the devastating effects of the treaties his people were for forced to sign, and who decided to do something about improving the condition of his people, his river and most importantly, the salmon.This is an important book, and very accessible for the average reader. You will get a clearer picture of "the other side of the story," while getting some insight to an individual who played a key role in the controversial 1974 Boldt Fishing Rights Decision. This decision ended up becoming the template for similar treaties and decisions around the world.We've come a long way since the devastating days of logging and development of the post World War II era, but as more people move into this region, we have a long way to go. This book helps us to understand where we've been, and gives us some insight into the world view we need to move forward.

Although I haven't read the full version of this inspiring true story and biography, I didn't feel like I missed anything in this young adult (condensed) version of the book. It has all the drama of excitingly described boat races, as well as the pathos of a difficult childhood.I grew up about a mile from the Montlake Cut and the Husky Boathouse, where many of the events in this book took place (although my childhood was 20 years later). And I've been to, or near, many of the locations described here, and I found them to be true to the geography and history I know. I have a minor quibble with saying the boathouse is on Lake Washington, when locals would say it's on Union Bay (which is connected to Lake Washington). Also the area where Joe Rantz goes out in a canoe with is fiancée is Foster Slough, which is not named specifically.I will be recommending this book to the teachers of Washington State history at the school where I am the librarian, as so many aspects of our state history are brought up in this saga: a childhood in various locales around the state, farming, logging, mining, the creation and building of the Grand Coulee Dam, and of course the development of a competitive rowing crew that became the first entry from Washington State in the Olympics, not to mention that they won, much to excitement of our whole state back (and much of the nation) in 1936!

I am not from New Hampshire, but am married to someone who is. Rebecca Rule knows how to tell a story, particularly one with dry New Hampshire humor. I was enjoying this "glossary" with accompanying stories, but then began reading some entries aloud to my wife who began to split a gut with laughter. So, that's how I finished the book, reading aloud and laughing hysterically while learning some of the subtleties of New Hampshire speak.The "gazetteer" in back covers many NH place names with some hilarious tidbits about them, some very short and some longer. I only wish the book had a map to accompany the stories.

This is Willie Nelson talking to you about his life, his 4 marriages, his infidelities, his music, his drinking and eventual love affair with pot, his gambling, golf, music festivals (called "picnics"), Farm Aid, his causes including the legalization of marijuana, the environment and the family farm, and his relationships with various recording companies, fellow performers and songwriters, and the long hard road he took before he experienced success in the music industry. If you expected Willie to clean up his language or leave out some of the dirt, then don't read this book.But if you want to read about one of the most creative minds in the music industry, about a songwriter who is always, I mean always, thinking about the next song, and if you want to learn how many of those hit songs were written, then read on. If you want to read about a guy who recorded 24, yes 24, albums between the ages of 70 and 80, and who shows no signs of slowing down, then read on. If you want to read about a man who still acknowledges the faith of his youth, the one that he learned about in a little Methodist Church in a small west Texas town, even though he's adapted that faith over the years, then read on.Even though my lifestyle is quite different from that of Willie Nelson, and even though I currently don't have any of his recordings in my collection (having lost Willie when I abandoned vinyl nearly a decade ago), I found this book inspiring on many levels. I am a songwriter, and I always love reading and hearing about how songwriters get their ideas, and how they put songs together. Willie delivers in this intimate account of his life.

Many of the World War II stories I've read over the years (as well as WWII movies I've seen) were written while the war was still fresh, and the story is often propelled by a sense of patriotism. This one is thoroughly researched and written at the end of the life of the protagonist, Louis Zamperini, and provides a more holistic perspective.Zamperini lived a fascinating life prior to his enlistment in the Army Air Corps during WWII, growing up as the child of Italian immigrants in Torrance, California, where he, after living the life of a troubled youth, turned his life around to become a famous runner, and eventually Olympic athlete who competed in the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin, Germany. Zamperini intersected with history several times in his early years, which adds to the fascination of his story.He is trained as bomber and is sent to the Pacific Theater to fight Japan. After a successful bombing run during which his B-24 ("Super Man") barely made it back, being riddled with so many bullet holes. Then his crew is sent in a rescue mission in another B-24 ("The Green Hornet") that does not make it and he is one of three survivors of a crash landing at sea, where he spends 47 days adrift in his life raft, barely surviving thirst and starvation.His raft drifts into Japanese territory, and he and his one surviving companion, the pilot, are taken captive. He is moved from one POW camp to another, where the conditions become progressively worse."War is hell" is an often heard phrase, but in Zamperini's case (and in those of others who were imprisoned in Japanese POW camps) "hell" is almost an understatement. Descriptions of the prisoners treatment is vivid and horrible (and presented from various angles).The bulk of the latter part of the book describes life in the camps, the final days of war in Japan with American bombers fire-bombing the country, with the eventual use of Atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Zamperini is released, and eventually returns stateside. After the war he meets and marries his wife, even as his life is slipping into alcoholism as a way of dealing with the Post Traumatic Stress Disorder that pervades his life.As his life is about to fall apart, he experiences a spiritual change that brings healing and eventually leads him to "forgive" his captors.This is probably the most powerful World War II book I've ever read (actually listened to) and is one that I would highly recommend. It is sobering, but also redemptive.

The Memory of Old Jack is the tale of a Kentucky tobacco farmer looking back on his life near the end of it in 1952. He has made many mistakes, poor decisions, and while paying the consequences of those decisions had gradually learned from them. Old Jack is the last of his breed, before the new ways of farming with tractors took over during World War II. His was a life of horse and mule and doing things by hand. It was a life of hard work, connected to the land he loved.The story is slow, much like life behind a mule-drawn wagon would be slow. But it gives you time to mull over the events of the day while appreciating the beauty that surrounds you.This is the sixth book in the Port William series that I have read (actually listened to as an audiobook) this summer. Needless to say, I’m drawn to the writings of Wendell Berry, an author that had escaped my attention until recently. Berry has much to say in his fiction about the way things were, and the way they have changed, not necessarily for the better. There is a sad nostalgic undercurrent to his writing, but also a hope that we could return to the more honest values of the past. I feel like my life has changed, in ways I have yet to recognize, by my summer in Port William.Old Jack reminds me of a rancher I had the opportunity to work for in the summer of 1965. Yes, he drove a tractor, but his work ethic and the love of the land still harkened back to an earlier era. Guys like Old Jack lived all over the country, providing the country with the honest harvest we once enjoyed, and which we long for again.

I purchased the Panasonic SD-YD250 to replace my previous Panasonic bread machine that I owned and used frequently for about 30 years. I chose this machine because it's the "upgrade" of my first bread machine and works, more or less, the same way, with some enhancements. I like the additional selection of bread sizes, etc., the improved locking system for the paddle, and the quieter sound. I have had success transferring my favorite old recipes to the new machine. We make all of our breads "vegan," replacing milk with water and replacing butter and oil with apple sauce or canned pumpkin. It all continues to work perfectly.

Jaber Crow is the fifth novel in the Port William series by Wendell Berry that I have listened to this summer. Needless to say, I love this author and this series. I am drawn to his sense of place, the “membership” of the community, to a simpler time of small farms and a small town, where relationships and hard work were valued.But Jaber Crow, in my opinion, rises above all the others on many different levels. In addition to covering a larger chunk of time (basically from World War I to the late 1960s) and a slightly larger chunk of Kentucky geography, this novel provides an opportunity to engage in the thoughts of Wendell Berry on a number of topics, from changing farming practices, the Economy, war, life, death, love, philosophy and theology, as seen through the eyes of the Port William town barber and lifelong bachelor.I’m glad that I read several other Port William books before I got to Jaber Crow, but if you were to read only one book in the series, this would be the one I’d recommend.

This is the third Wendell Berry novel I've listened to as an audiobook this summer, based on the recommendations of a couple of people I respect dearly. I have not been disappointed. My favorite, to date, is Hannah Coulter, but I think perhaps the protagonist in this one is the "place" or at least the "membership" (as he calls it) of Port William. In this novel I felt like I got to know more about the various characters that appeared in Hannah Coulter, as well as Andy Catlett.I'm not really sure why this book is considered "Christian" fiction, other than that there is no profanity, sex, gratuitous violence, etc. The faith of some of these individuals is incidental to the story, and by today's standards we might question the practice of tobacco growing and smoking which pervades the pages of these novels. One of my favorite characters, Jaber Crow, is one who has walked away from the faith.But these Port William stories take place on the home front during World War II. One gets a glimpse of how the war provides the backdrop to those who are waiting, while working and farming, back home. And one sees the world as it is changing. Today we don't think too much about how WWII changed everything in our culture, but from this perspective one gets a glimpse of the "old ways" and the "new ways."I worked on a ranch in 1965, twenty years after the end of World War II, and the owner was from the generation that saw the transition from the old ways to the new ways. Listening to A Place on Earth, I felt like I knew some of these people, with their work ethic, their ingenuity, their sense of place on earth.
Be sure to add this to your order if you get the Medslant Wedge Pillow for Acid Reflux. I'm glad I did.

I thought I had finished this short volume a few years ago, but just picked it up and found my bookmark halfway through.It is a significant work, not just because it addresses the issue of same-sex attraction from the perspective of the Orthodox Christian faith, but because one could also infer the traditional Christian view of various other sexual sins (fornication, adultery, masturbation, pornography, etc.). What is refreshing is that Fr. Thomas Hopko clearly articulates the Orthodox view that sin is a disease, one that requires a cure, and that can be cured, within the context of the sacred hospital, the Church, and the medicine, the Holy Mysteries, that the Church prescribes.

I saw this film on PBS about ten years ago, and have thought about it many times. I mean, what little boy doesn't dream of building his own cabin out in the woods? And what man still wonders if he could, given the opportunity.Well, now I have a friend, in his late 20s, who just bought a piece of property and is planning to build his own cabin to live in, much as Richard Proenneke did in Alaska in 1968. My friend is inspired and influenced by this film and the accompanying book, and he gladly loaned it to me to watch.I was as inspired by this film the second time around, and now I'd like to read the book to find out "the rest of the story."There is much to appreciate here, but probably most inspiring to me is the way Proenneke gathers his materials, constructs his tools and builds his cabin. He is obviously a master carpenter putting together a lifetime of skills (while in his 50s) in the remote wilderness of Alaska. Even his self-filming techniques are interesting, especially in this day of people taking "selfless" all the time.I highly recommend this film to those who love the outdoors in general, Alaska in particular, or who can appreciate a man who pursues his dream to live a life of self-sufficiency.

I have have taught private guitar lessons since 1969, and I have led more Christmas sing-alongs than I can count over the years. As a result, I have collected a ton of songbooks, and in the early years have added the chords myself. This is the best collection I've found, to-date, that has all the best holiday songs, both sacred and secular, and for the most part, in guitar-friendly keys.The book is not without it's minor shortcomings. In some cases, not all the verses of well-known songs are included. In other cases, I would've selected different chords, chord progressions, or I would've named the chords differently. But this is now the book I go to to start with. I always compare against the best-known recordings of the songs, and make my changes accordingly. In some cases, I end up changing the key altogether.Most recently, my students wanted to learn "Last Christmas," but the version in this book is based on the Wham (George Michael) version from the 1980s. These young people wanted the Taylor Swift version, which is in a different key, but it's also easier to play.This is still a great book, and I would definitely recommend it.

In 2011, I read Prevent and Reverse Heart Disease: The Revolutionary, Scientifically Proven, Nutrition-Based Cure for health reasons, and made the switch to the whole foods plant-based diet. Although I had been a "part-time vegetarian," the first several weeks were tough, but it got easier, especially as I got healthier, lost weight, increased energy and got off several medications.Since that time I have become more and more convinced that this is the best lifestyle for me, and have been picking up more and more books to better equip me. I've become a fan of Lindsay Nixon (The Happy Herbivore) and we love her The Happy Herbivore Cookbook: Over 175 Delicious Fat-Free and Low-Fat Vegan Recipes, as well as her other titles. I've enjoyed books by Rip Essenstyn, including My Beef with Meat: The Healthiest Argument for Eating a Plant-Strong Diet--Plus 140 New Engine 2 Recipes.Lately I've read Whole: Rethinking the Science of Nutrition, by T. Colin Campbell, author of The China Study: The Most Comprehensive Study of Nutrition Ever Conducted And the Startling Implications for Diet, Weight Loss, And Long-term Health. And I recently decided to take a look at this volume by Dr. McDougall. While all of the above authors fall into the same food camp, McDougall stresses the importance of complex carbohydrates (starches) in our diet. He clearly points out the all around the world, healthy populations base their diets on starches (whether it's corn, wheat, potatoes, rice, taro root or other starches).In the diet he promotes here, he says you can eat as much as you want, until you feel full. And you will not only lose weight, but will get healthy in the process. I'm already convinced that it's true, because I've been following him on Facebook and have given this modification to my diet a try for several months. I feel more satisfied, and I have not gained back any of the weight I lost when I first began the diet.In these pages, Dr. McDougall tells the story of his personal journey in discovering this way of eating, and how he eventually started his own clinic in northern California. He addresses the poisons of meat, the healing power of the starch-based diet, the politics of food, and how, with our current American diet, we are eating our planet to death. He addresses questions about where you get your protein and calcium on a plant-based diet. And he discuses the problems of fish, as well as how you can be an unhealthy fat vegan (I know some, and what he says makes perfect sense).He also explains why it makes sense to get away from supplements, and he talks about the benefits (yes, benefits) of salt and sugar.The latter third of this volume is a cookbook by his wife, Mary McDougall. I have not tried any of these yet, but as I skim through the pages, they look delicious, easy to make, and completely in line with other plant-based cookbooks I've been using.While I can heartily recommend all the books mentioned above, I think this one by Dr. McDougall would be an excellent starting point. Give it a try. You have nothing to lose but your weight!

Frederica Mathewes-Green is uniquely qualified to explain the Jesus Prayer to our contemporary culture. Before becoming a successful author, blogger and podcaster on topics mainly explaining Eastern Christianity to our Western Culture, she lived the life of a hippie, feminist, and explorer of various religious and mystical traditions, before having a profound spiritual experience that eventually led her and her husband to seminary.Her husband became a priest in the Episcopal Church, where he served for many years, before departing and joining the Eastern Orthodox Church, where he is now a priest. It was at that point that Frederica began writing about their new spiritual home.Frederica did not begin writing this book about the Jesus Prayer until at least 15 years after she had been seeking a life of "unceasing prayer," with many of those years under the guidance of a spiritual father. She has also thoughtfully studied the classic texts on the subject from sources such as Mount Athos (Greece), Russia, as well as the Desert Fathers, and she makes many references to this literature, her spiritual father, as well as her own experience.Following the introduction, the book is divided into two parts. Part one covers history, Scripture, the meaning of mercy; terms, concepts and context; and heart, mind, and what she calls "the little radio" (or the nous). Part two covers numerous questions and answers she has received over the years on the Jesus Prayer, and provides many practical, as well as theological explanations.I have been saying the Jesus Prayer for many years, I have read several books and articles on the Jesus Prayer, and I have visited Orthodox monasteries, but I found that Frederica clarified many things I didn't know before. Frederica has the uncanny ability to take something as spiritually deep as "unceasing prayer" and translate it into something that most of us raised in the West can comprehend. This is especially helpful, since some of the literature available is awkwardly translated from other languages.This book is filled with memorable passages, and I will just quote a few from the introduction to whet your appetite:"...you should `warm up you heart' before beginning the Jesus Prayer..." (page xi)"The practice of saying the Jesus Prayer is accurately termed a spiritual discipline; it a disciplined learning process, like learning to play the cello." (page xii)"The prayer is not designed to generate fancy mystical experiences or soppy emotions." (page xiii)"The Prayer's goal is to help you keep always in touch with the presence of God." (page xiii)"The effect of the Prayer is to knock you down in your mind. Then you discover that it is safe to be knocked down, safe to be humble, because God's love is everywhere, filling the world with his light and life. The Prayer will make you into a child." (page xvi)If you are interested in deepening your prayer life, in learning how to live a life of "unceasing prayer, or if you are simply curious to know more about what the Jesus Prayer is, this is the book for you.

Disclosure: I have known the poet for many years.So, how does one review a collection of poems by a friend; an anthology spanning 21 years, from 1985 to 2006? To put it simply, it's like mining for gold.I found some of these poems hard work, in my case too much work, to fully digest and comprehend. I would've benefited with an introduction, a guide, to explain the subtleties of language and context, but such a guide was not available on these pages.But it was worth mining through these works to find the gold, those pieces that shimmer and shine and are worth every ounce of their weight.The author was one of my guides into the Orthodox Christian faith in the late 1990s. And many of these poems continue to elucidate the richness of this faith, this spirituality, this life that I continue to embrace, more fully, as he does himself.One poem, one that I posted by my desk for many years, is indicative of the spiritual depth found here:Setting OutPilgrim: What is it that you do here?Monk: We fall, and we get up again.In time, even the slowest pilgrim mightarticulate a turn. Given time enough,the slowest pilgrim--even he--mightregister some small measure of belatedprogress. The road was, more or less, lesscompelling than the hut, but as the benefitof time allowed the hut's distractions to attaina vaguely musty scent, and all the novelknickknacks to acquire a fine veneer of bone-white dust, the road became then somewhat moreattractive, and as the weather made a timelyif quite brief concession, the pilgrim took this allto be an open invitation to set out.--Scott CairnsNot all of these poems are about Scott's spiritual pilgrimage. Another poem ("A Prior Despair") that resonated particularly with me was about the loss of love, and his search for finding it again. I guess that's a journey of a different kind, but one that I could relate to.So, if you pick up this volume, be prepared to do some mining. You'll be rewarded for the effort!

Short Trip to the Edge reviewDisclosure: I have known the author since 1975, when he was a Baptist teen preparing for college.I purchased my autographed copy of this book at a poetry reading in downtown Seattle in 2008. For a variety of reasons I did not read it until 2013.When I finally opened it, I assumed it was going to be an autobiographical travelogue of Scott's first visit to Mount Athos, the Holy Mountain in Greece which is inhabited by Orthodox Christian monks in various monasteries. What I did not realize is that this volume covers three visits to Mount Athos, the final one with his then 14 year-old son, interspersed by one visit to Saint Anthony's Monastery in Arizona, all within the time frame of 9 months.I was correct in my assumption that this book is autobiographical, but it is much more. In these pages, Scott talks about his search for unceasing prayer, as well as his desire to find a spiritual father on Mount Athos. Scott weaves in pieces of his personal journey, including his childhood in a conservative Baptist church in Tacoma, Washington, and his sojourns in Presbyterian and Episcopal churches, before "coming home" to the Orthodox Church. And while Scott is weaving these pieces into the narrative, he also introduces the reader to some of the theology and practices of the Orthodox faith, as observed on the Holy Mountain, as well as from his life and readings back home. (There is a helpful glossary in the back of the book.)After reading the first chapter, I decided I needed to get out my pencil to underline memorable passages, and now looking back over the pages I see there are many. In one such passage he quotes Father Iakovos (one of the monks he visits several times) who tells his son, "Just as our lungs breathe air, so our souls breathe prayer. Our souls cannot develop, cannot survive without prayer."Who should read this book? I recommend it to Orthodox Christians, especially converts like me, who want to learn more about this faith, and especially about what it's like on Mount Athos. More specifically, I recommend it to women who are not allowed to visit Mount Athos; this is as close as they'll get. And I recommend it to anyone who enjoys a thoughtful spiritual autobiography (which I do).I think anyone who is not Orthodox, or who is not at least a bit familiar with the Orthodox faith, may (at times) go, "Huh?" It may even seem slow and dry to those readers, at least until they realize that the slowness and quietness of the book is part of the point.In these pages, Scott makes reference to The Way of the Pilgrim, one of the spiritual classics, along the lines of Pilgrim's Progress, for Orthodox Christians. I recommend checking that volume out, but also Father Arseny, 1893-1973: Priest, Prisoner, Spiritual Father : Being the Narratives Compiled by the Servant of God Alexander Concerning His Spiritual Father and Everyday Saints and Other Stories for very different perspectives on the Orthodox faith.

The beauty of Billy Collins' poetry is its profound simplicity. He takes seemingly mundane events like wearing hats (or not wearing hats), remembering his father, running over a snake in the road, or forgetting a poem he had written in his head, and turning them into something to look at, think about and even laugh at.His poems are not humorous poems in the traditional sense of the word, but many, if not most, have a humorus twist at the end.I read this volume over the course of several months, taking it with me while eating lunch outside, while waiting for a doctor's appointment, or getting a meal at a nearby restaurant, and each time I felt like I had taken a friend with me to chat about life while doing these things.After reading poems by Billy Collins, one looks at life just a little more differently.

I'm glad we added this cover for our Landmann fire pit. We live in a rainy region and the bottom of our pit is dry. Our neighbor, who has the very same fire pit, has one that is half-filled with mush (a mixture of rainwater and ashes).

I bought this book about ten years ago, while on a road trip, and it's been quietly calling me ever since. I finally heeded the call, picked it up, and enjoyed it, even though it is not at all what I thought it would be.I am a writer, not on the stature of someone like Dillard, but I keep a journal, I write songs (and sometimes poetry), I write reviews here on Amazon.com, I have published a journal off and for more than 30 years, and I write in the my line of work as a school librarian. Some people are driven to write, and I'm one of them. That's why I liked this book.Annie Dillard gives insight into how she works, rather struggles, as a writer. She seeks the quiet places, such as a cabin in the San Juan Islands, to get her work done. While she says she draws inspiration from reading literature, this little volume proves that she also gets inspiration from the non-writers she meets, such a local ferryman, and a stunt pilot (who also happens to be a geologist).Halfway through reading this volume, I decided to pick up a pen and underline some of the memorable quotes that she provides. I wish I had done it from the beginning.Here is one (from page 70):"A well-known writer got collared by a university student who asked, 'Do you think I could be a writer?''Well,' the writer said, 'I don't know.... Do you like sentences?'The writer could see the student's amazement. Sentences? Do I like sentences? I am twenty years old and do I like sentences? If he had liked sentences, of course, he could begin, like a joyful painter I knew. I asked him once how he came to be a painter. He said, 'I liked the smell of paint.'"Another quite I liked appears on pages 78-79:"One of the few things I know about writing is this: spend it all, shoot it, play it, lose it, right away, every time. Do not hoard what seems good for a later place in the book, or for another book; give it, give it all, give it now. The impulse to save something good for a better place later is the signal to spend it now. Something more will arise for later, something  better. These things fill from behind, from  beneath, like well water. Similarly, the impulse to keep to yourself what you have learned is not only shameful, it is destructive. Anything you do not give freely and abundantly becomes lost to you. You open your safe and find ashes."In closing I want to remark on the sense of place of this book. I'm from Washington State, where much of this book takes place. Not only that, I was in Bellingham in the mid-1970s, and I know that what she writes about is true to this locality. Mount Baker steaming, the stunt pilot flying from the Cascades to the San Juans, the glaciers in this region, the tides and currents of Puget Sound, the solitude on some of our remote islands, and some of the local characters she encounters.This book is filled with the raw emotion of a writer who both loves and hates writing. It's a struggle for her, which is an encouragement for people like me who write as an avocation, and sometimes wish we could do something else.

As a former pessimist, who was able to change his personal set point a few years ago with the help of of positive psychology, I was curious to see what Andrew Weil would have to say on the subject of happiness. I listened to the audiobook on my commute, and wish that I had a hard copy to take note of some of his helpful tips. Andrew Weil had a great reading voice, and it adds to the audio experience to hear the author read his own work.I give the book four stars because it starts at as a book on how to combat depression, not exactly what the title suggests, and as a result he spends a lot of time discussing various medications and nutritional supplements. I was about to give up on the book, when it got better.I believe Weil is at his best here when he gives suggestions on changes you can make in your life (apart from medications and supplements) to raise your personal set point. While he goes into detail in what he calls "secular spirituality," I found that most of what he says translates well into my own Christian spirituality.He has great advice in areas of gratitude, forgivenss, silence, nature, beauty, breathing, visualization and other things that resonate with where I'm at and the happiness I've experienced over the past several years. I was particularly pleased to see him recommend some of the practices of positive psychology. The "three good things" excercise was what turned my life around.In addition to my problems with all the medications and supplements, I would also quibble with some of his nutritional advice. I have been on a low-fat whole foods plant based diet for the past two years, and believe that if you are eating a well-rounded selection of fruits, vegetables and grains, you will need very few supplements. I think he's right on when he says you should reduce, and eliminate processed foods.So with a few reservations, I can recommend this book. Overall it really works, as I've already incorporated most of the advice he gives here. I just need to excercise a bit more, and I'm working on that.

This is the third book about food and nutrition I've read this summer. The others are Whole: Rethinking the Science of Nutrition and My Beef with Meat: The Healthiest Argument for Eating a Plant-Strong Diet--Plus 140 New Engine 2 Recipes, which I recommend along with this one by Michael Moss.The following quote by Moss (on page 337) pretty much summarizes what Salt Sugar Fat is all about:"It had taken me three and a half years of prying into the food industry's operations to come to terms with the full range of institutional forces that compel even the best companies to churn out foods that undermine a healthy diet. Most critical, of course, is the deep dependence the industry has on salt, sugar, and fat. Almost every one of the hundreds of people I interviewed in the course of writing this book--bench chemists, nutrition scientists, behavioral biologists, food technicians, marketing executives, packaging designers, chief executives, lobbyists--make the point that companies won't be giving these three up, in any real way, without a major fight. Salt, sugar, and fat are the foundations of processed food, and the overriding question the companies have in determining the formulations of their products is how much they need to achieve the maximum allure."Another quote that summarizes another minor, but notable, theme throughout the book (on page 341) is:"On a personal level, I found that many of the executives I talked to go out of their way to avoid their own products."Quite telling, don't you think?While I had been personally weaning myself from various processed foods for decades, it wasn't until I adopted the whole foods plant based diet two years ago (advocated in both other books mentioned above) that I went the route of "no exceptions" on processed and fast food. This book by Moss, simply confirms my decision and gives me more reasons to stay the course. Thank you, Michael Moss, for a well researched, well written book that should help many people become healthier, as they free themselves from their addictions to salt, sugar, and fat.

I listened to the audiobook version of this while on summer break from my job as a high school librarian."Heat" is a great story about a Cuban immigrant boy with an amazing pitching arm, trying to reach the Little League World Series with his team that practices and plays in the shadows of Yankee Stadium. There are all kinds of obstacles that arise that look like they will prevent him from reaching his dream: he is in the care of his under-age brother after his father dies; his brother gets in trouble with the law; they concoct a fabulous scheme to prevent offical people from separating them; Michael says something stupid to cause his first love interest to walk away; and worst of all, he is suspected of being "too old," and is removed from playing until his birth certificate can be located in Cuba.But all this has a happy ending. I love the way Lupica creates these obtacles, and makes you wait until the very end to see how they all resolve.I recommend this book to teens, mainly boys, who are looking for a good sports book.

Now that I'm married to a New Hampshire expatriate, and I've just returned from my fourth trip to the state in less than three years, I have finally realized that New Hampshire is a foreign country. Yes, they speak the same language...well, sort of. And yes, they drive on the right side of the road, however those roads are windy and never go in a straight line, but they always end up someplace.So, on this trip, I determined to purchase one book to help me understand this foreign place, and the people I've gotten to know over the past several years. While browsing around, this one jumped out at me. Why? Because it combines facts, with stories and humor. The only problem is, you don't know when the facts stop and the lies begin.But now that I've read it, and laughed, I think I know this state a bit better...well, sort of.This author reminds me a bit of Patrick McManus, who has written humorous bits about the state I live in. The book also reminds me of when I read "How Talk Minnesotan" many years ago.

I had never read a book (or anything else) by Mitch Albom until I picked up "Have a Little Faith" on a cross-country fight. Albom writes with a style that pulls you into his narrative from page one, and you immediately care about what he has to tell you.In this case, it's a journey of three people: Mitch's rabbi who has asked him to write his eulogy, even though he has only attended services at his synagogue once a year for most of his adult life; an African-American preacher and former drug addict and criminal, who has devoted his reborn life to helping the poor; and Mitch himself who is changed by his encounters, over the course of several years, with both of these men of faith.This is an inspiring account to encourage each of us to "have a little faith," to find meaning in the daily things of life, to forgive, to love, to care for those closest to us, to consider the afterlife, to be more faithful to the heart of our faith traditions, to laugh, to sing, to believe....I could go on, but I encourage you to read this book for yourself. It's a fairly quick read, but one that touches something deep inside.

I have been learning, and performing, songs by the Beatles since I was 14 years old (and that was in 1964). In those days I always tried to learn the pieces note perfect. In later years I began doing interpretations or arrangements of these songs, but when someone asks me to play a song by the Beatles, I usually grab "Norwegian Wood," or "You've Got to Hide Your Love Away," because I know people want to hear these songs like the originals.Recently, a group of high school students asked me if they could learn, and perform, the entire Abbey Road album. So I bought a copy of these scores to help me along.These scores were an invaluable tool, but I still had to do some extra work to communicate what was in them to these students.Here are a few things that come to mind:1. These songs are not in album order, and that includes the "medley" songs on Abbey Road. What a pain, especially when the transitions are not accurately notated.2. Sometimes the chord name is not accurate, so I had to tweak a few of these.3. I did not always agree with the notation or tab on the guitar solos. In one song, they attribute the solo to two guitars, when it is clearly one on the recording.4. The vocals are written an octave higher than the actual range. This is fine for people who can read treble clef, but I had to renotate some of the vocals so that the singers could see their parts more accurately.I'm not saying these things as a complaint, but as a way of saying this is an excellent guide to the work of the Beatles, but it's not perfect, and will still require your attention. The book has been an invaluable tool, and I plan to use it more in the future.

When it comes to science, I am one that normally glosses over. Not so with The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks. Here Rebecca Skloot has woven together a medical mystery with social history, biography, autobiography and a study of medical ethics into a fascinating account that makes me want to know more.I listened to the audiobook on my commute, which was excellently done by Cassandra Campbell with Bahni Turpin. And the audio version includes an interesting interview with the author at the end.I had never heard of HeLa cells, much less Henrietta Lacks, before listening to this book. But now this piece of history and science has come to life, causing me to ask questions about medical ethics that never occured to me before.I am a high school librarian, and have recommended this title to my colleagues, but especially those who deal with health, biology and medical ethics issues.

This is an excellent introduction to the low-fat plant-based whole foods lifestyle promoted by Rip Esselstyn, as well has his father, Dr. Caldwell Esselstyn.Rip visits two families that have decided to give the lifestyle a try. He starts in their pantries, clearing out items that are not allowed on the diet, and gives explanations why. Then he takes each couple shopping at Whole Foods and shows them what to buy. Then they return to each home and he prepares meals.Having been on this dient for nearly two years (as of this writing), I remember that initial overwhelmed feeling I had of what to eat, what not to eat, what to clear out of my kitchen, what to buy, etc. This video clealy shows the "deer in the headlights" look on the faces of these two families. But in the end they are eating delicious meals prepared by Rip.I agree with other reviewers that it would be nice to see how these families are faring six months or a year later, but for a hastily prepared video, this program explains a alot.I was alarmed to see Rip using his hands to spread out many of the ingredients, not spoons or spatulas. Some people might be disgusted with the excessive amount of fingers in the food. But Rip is a healthy, likeable guy, and this is easily forgiven.I hope that someday there is a sequel to see how these families did. This was worth watching two years after getting started to see how far we've come.

The former commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, a physician who says he had a problem with food addictions, presents a convincing argument that processed foods and fast foods are now created to make us addicted to eating more food.This is the young adult version of The End of Overeating, by the same author, but it works well as a book for anyone interested in this subject from middle school ages on up.I received my copy as part of a subscription service for my high school library. The subject matter caught my attention, because I've been a fat-free vegan for nearly two years. It was a quick read, and supports much of what I've read elsewhere in recent years. I already have several people waiting in line to read our copy.While the book is an indictment of the food industry, he does not demand that they change, but that we change the way we think about food. His final chapters give helpful tips on how to take control of our own eating habits.I will be recommending this book to our foods classes and to anyone concerned about diet. My friends who are not vegan will appreciate this book.Once you make the change to eating real food, you may want to look for cookbooks by The Happy Herbivore (Lindsay S. Nixon). Her first cookbook is The Happy Herbivore Cookbook: Over 175 Delicious Fat-Free and Low-Fat Vegan Recipes.

Frankly, I found this book (which I listened to as an audiobook) to be too well written to be taken as "proof" of anything. It has the feel of a very well-written novel..a short one, one that got my attention, but not one that provided proof of anything other than a testimony of the author's own supposed experience.I find it too convenient that the author has a website, selling other products, is connected with some other "New Age" foundation, and is a hot item on the speakers circuit (including Oprah).But even while I have my doubts about this book, it has opened the door for me to think about near death experiences (NDE) more and to perhaps examine some of the literature on the topic.In the mean time, I will return to the writings by and about Orthodox Christian monastics who confront their own mortality on a daily basis and who have very similar profound spiritual experiences.

"It would be a mistake to think of the sacrifices of Lent in purely negative terms--in terms of struggle and deprivation. We are to think of Lent as liberation. Lent calls us to sacrifice many of those things which, while they tend to occupy such a central position in our lives, are in reality things we can do without. Lent is thus a rediscovery of that which is most essential in our lives. In this rediscovery, we return to God and to the very meaning of life (Meditations for Great Lent, page 88)."This little book, with short chapters, gets at the heart of Great Lent, using quotes from the hymnody of the Orthodox Church, as well as quotes from Scripture. The author presents powerful meditations (or homilies) emphasizing humility, repentance, ascetic love, fasting from sin, not judging, the passions and virtues, joy, the cross and resurrection and the journey to Pascha.Since we are encouraged to do more spiritual reading during Great Lent, this is a great one to add to your annual list of readings. It is quick and easy, yet profound, and will do much to prepare your heart for the journey (even if you start this book late in Lent, it's never too late).For someone who wants a more in depth discussion of services of Great Lent in the Orthodox Church, I would also recommend Great Lent: Journey to Pascha.

Every once in a while a book is destined to become a spiritual classic, one that is appreciated not only by Orthodox Christians, but for people of all persuasions, whether they be Orthodox, Protestant, Catholic, I would even say atheist. This is such a book.It was recommended to me by my priest, but I quickly discovered that many people in my circle of friends and acquaintances were already reading it (or had just finished it) and all were enthused by what they read.Here we have a Russian Orthodox monk and priest, writing about the lives in and around his monastery; a monastery that not only survived, but also thrived, during the anti-Christian Communist Soviet reign of Russia. Each chapter is a story, a peak into someone's life, someone who is an "ordinary saint."This book fills me with hope and urges me to press on in my own fallible spiritual walk. Life is a journey, one that hopefully draws us closer to God, but one in which we all stumble and make mistakes.I will add this to my list of favorite spiritual classics. It's right up there with Father Arseny, 1893-1973: Priest, Prisoner, Spiritual Father : Being the Narratives Compiled by the Servant of God Alexander Concerning His Spiritual Father, The Mountain of Silence: A Search for Orthodox Spirituality and Wounded by Love: The Life and Wisdom of Elder Porphyrios.

80 pages of text, including many sidebars, plus several appendixes about the life and work of American Indian poet and author, Sherman Alexie, provide an excellent introduction for young adult readers.The book covers some of the same material that is found in Alexie's best-selling young adult novel, The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian, growing up on the Spokane Indian Reservation and transferring to nearby Reardan High School to further his education and play basketball. It was in a creative writing class at Washington State University that Alexie found his calling as a writer.This book would be excellent for students (or even adults) who want a brief overview of Sherman Alexie's life and career. I have heard him speak, and the humorous Alexie I experienced is clearly evident on these pages.Alexie describes himself as following in his grandmother's footsteps as a teller of tales when he says, "I was doing something old fashioned. I was a storyteller around a fire."

At times silly, a times profound.At times spiritual, at times an acid-trip.At times biographical, at times a fantasy.A bit of Liverpool, a bit of London, also Hamburg.A bit of India, California, Virgin Islands and Hawaii,Even New York.There are enough memorable quotes in this volume to plough through the stranger moments,And there is enough humor in the strange moments to keep you entertained,After all Eric Idle is here as well.At first I was ignoring the facsimiles of the handwritten lyrics,But then I was drawn to them to see how some of these songs evolved.I enjoyed the book. I think it's mainly for the die-hard Harrison fan, one who knows most of his songs. I connected better with his comments when I knew the song than the tunes I didn't know.I was a huge Beatles fan (saw them twice), but not as big a George fan in the post-Beatles days, other than his "hits." Also I became a follower of Jesus about the time he became a follower of Krishna, so much of his material was foreign to me. But like I said, if I knew the song, I enjoyed his comments about it more.As a songwriter, I enjoyed learning about George's songwriting process. I have similar scraps of paper laying around the house, with scratch marks through words, and new lyrics in the margins. It's nice to know George was not perfect. That he struggled with his songs, too.

I purchased this book for our high school library hoping to have at least one good introduction to Bob Marley for our students. While it will do the job, it's more of a photo-essay from the last two years of his life, accompanied by a biographical article that reads more like album liner notes.I was hoping for more description of the music, how it evolved, what it's about and how it was received. I was hoping for a more detailed chronology of his life, not just a recitation of names and events.Having said that, this book is better than nothing to get our readers interested in Marley. It'll do.

I recently acquired this book for our public high school library. Although this book has been favorably reviewed for high school students, I was wondering how her private life would be presented in this volume aimed at young adult readers. While it would receive a PG13 rating if it were a film, the main point of the book can be summarized in the following quote from the last chapter:"Fame had nurtured and encouraged Janis's wild, over-the-top behavior. People loved when she swaggered onto the stage with a bottle of Southern Comfort or waxed lyrical about getting high. And, along the way, she became as hooked on adulation as she was on drugs and alcohol. It was the attention she craved all her life, from her lonely high school days to her spirited college days to her crazy days in San Francisco, speeding around town in her psychedelic Porsche. To feed her voracious need for more love and praise, she became ever more outrageous. She took greater and greater personal risks until, finally, sheer carelessness caught up with her..." (Janis Joplin: Rise Up Singing, page 99).Janis was an awesome blues singer. I saw her shortly after she joined Big Brother and the Holding Company in 1966. But her life went out of control, resulting in her untimely death. This books celebrates the music, while providing a cautionary tale for readers that "sex, drugs and rock and roll" can lead down a dark path to addiction, and in this case, eventually death.For a young person wanting to better understand what Janis was all about, or to get a better understanding of the psychedelic music scene in the late Sixties, this volume does an amazing job of showing it as it was.

"Many revere Guevara for treating the sick and standing up for the poor. But few care to discuss the brutality he exhibited as a guerilla leader or his support of Fidel Castro, who imposed a harsh dictatorship on millions of Cuban people. In life Che Guevara was a political contradiction. In death he will always be young, brave, and defiant (Stuart A. Kallen, Che Guevara: You Win or You Die; page 75).While there is much to be learned about Che Guevara from this short volume (88 pages, including a timeline, glossary, and "who's who?"), it shies away from "the brutality he exhibited as a guerilla leader."I decided to read this title after it was sent to my high school library by one of my suppliers. One of my colleagues fled Castro's Cuba at age 10 and raised questions about a book that would treat Guevara as an "international icon." While her family had great hopes when he and Fidel toppled Batista's corrupt regime, in the end they felt betrayed and left the country after her family's assets were taken by the government.I give the book three stars because it does a good job of telling Che's story. I can't give it more, because it fails to tell the rest of the story.

I listened to the audiobook version of this book while commuting to and from work. That makes it difficult to pay attention to all the details.Having said that, this book helped me to think about my own approach to solving medical problems, and about why I sometimes follow doctor's orders and sometimes get another opinion, or search for more natural alternatives.I can see how my "medical mind" has changed a bit over the years, and this book has helped me to see why.It also has helped me to think about end-of-life decisions, and what I decide now might actually change later in life.I found this a helpful book, and will probably read other similar titles in the future. I also plan to recommend this to some medical professionals I know. I think they would appreciate it.

I just finished listening to the audiobook of Islam, by Karen Armstrong. As an audio experience, I found it difficult to attend to all the names of people and locations in the Middle East as they seemed to rattle by so  quickly.Having said that, I still found this book fascinating, especially since I know very little about Islam. While Armstrong claims that Islam is a peaceful religion, I was still struck by the amount of violence throughout the history of Islam.I found her chapter on "fundamentalism" to be fascinating, as she compares the fundamentalism of all the world's major monotheistic religions. This chapter is worth the price of admission (so to speak).I found myself interested in wanting to learn more about the Sufis, after listening to this book. I would love to compare Islamic mysticism with Christian mysticism and see what the similarities and differences are.When I finished the book, I turned on the news. Both Egypt and Syria were in the headlines and I felt like I never left the book.

I have read a fair amount of Holocaust literature over the decades, but for some strange reason had avoided "Night" until I recently picked up the audiobook from the library.Powerful is the most simple word to desribe it. Wiesel does an awesome job of pulling the reader into the terror, disbelief, agony, starvation, pain, and isolation of the Holocaust experience.I can see why this little volume is on so many "must read" lists. We need to be reminded that this should never happen again. And Wiesel also reminds us that neutrality is victory for the oppressor. We cannot stand innocently by if we see injustice happening.

I'm not sure how David Wilcox escaped my attention for so many years, but it wasn't until I heard "Language of the Heart," on Pandora that I stopped to take notice. "Language of the Heart" sang into my life as a relationship was breaking up and these lyrics said exactly what I was feeling at the time.I downloaded "The Very Best of David Wilcox," and put "Language of the Heart" on repeat until my tears were dry. Then I began listening to the rest of the album.Now a few years later, I own many more of David Wilcox's albums, and I'm grateful for my introduction to his work through this recording.One song that stands out now is "Break In the Cup," which also reflects a past relationship that went sour for me. How does David Wilcox know what I was feeling many years ago?Another one is "Strong Chemistry" which talks about the addictive nature of some relationships."Advertising Man" is a humorous tyrade against the tobacco industry specifically, but could also be interpreted to speak against any ads that promote a product that does not enhance a healthy lifestyle."Covert War" observes a mom and dad's relationship falling apart. I think he must've seen this firsthand."Daddy's Money" pokes fun at rich girls who have it all.And "Rusty Old American Dream" pays homage to the great gas guzzlers of the past...done in a 50s or 60s Chuck Berry rock and roll style.Every tune is great on this album, but some have worn out for me personally.Like I said, I have graduated to other David Wilcox albums, and each one contains more "best of" songs on them. This is a great place to start your exposure to the poetry, amazing guitar picking and observation of human behavior by David Wilcox, but if you're like me, you'll only want more. Also, be sure to check out his great videos on YouTube.

I read the first edition of The Diary of a Young Girl in my early teens back in the 1960s. It was a book that had a huge impact on my life, partly because I was born in Amsterdam (after the war) to parents who helped save Jews during the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands (1940-45).Anne Frank has stayed with me for nearly 50 years. Recently, as I was preparing to tell my parents' story to high school history classes, I decided to revisit the book, and checked out the audiobook verson of the "definitive edition." Wow!Not only is this edition about 30% larger, containing more of Anne's thoughts about her mother, living in close proximity to others, and her own sexual awakening as a young girl, it is probably the best audiobook I've ever heard. After completing the book, I learned that Selma Blair received a well-deserved Grammy award for this performance.What I noticed about the book this time around is how incredibly articulate Anne Frank is; at how perceptive she is of her surroundings, as well as herself as a growing young lady; and at how observant she is of her place in history.I have kept a journal most of my life, and I think it is the fact that I read this book as young teen that influenced me to do so. I highly recommend this book to all readers, but particularly teens who need to learn more about the Holocaust, or simply about growing up.

This is a fairly popular book in our high school library, so I thought I'd listen to the audiobook during my commute. In a nutshell, I couldn't wait for it to end.It felt a bit like a poorly designed amusement ride, with two characters in the car, waiting for each new obstacle or scary thing to happen to them. Each one lasts less than one of these short (two page) chapters. There is no character development and there are no sub-plots. And the scary stuff is simply boring. Who really cares what happens to Wit and Whisty? Not me.It is telling that there are more 1 star reviews here than 5 star. I'm giving it 2 just because the premise of the book is interesting. Too bad it falls short. Way short.

Fever, 1793 is an excellent piece of historical fiction written for young adults, one that adults would enjoy, as well. Laurie Halse Anderson obviously did her homework in preparing for this tale about a young teen who has to work in the coffee house run by her mother and grandfather during the time that Philadelphia is the temporary home of the new nation's capitol.With a mosquito buzzing around in the first paragraph, a hint to what is about to come, an epidemic of Yellow Fever breaks out, eventually killing thousands of people in town over the course of the summer of 1793. Mattie's world crumbles around her, with her mother disappearing, presumed dead, and her grandfather, after helping her survive the fever, dies at the hands of burglars.Anderson weaves together many historical elements, and characters, such as George Washington and Benjamin Rush, a famous Philadelphia physician, along with the daily lives, foods, shopping habits, jobs, medical practices, and travel into a believable work of fiction. There is a bit of love story sifted into the plot, but not enough to turn off boys, in my opinion. On the other hand, there is enough gruesome detail, and even some violence, to appeal to young male readers.I will be recommending this work to young people in my high school library who enjoy historical fiction.

Higher Ground is quirky. It jumps around a bit and makes one wonder what was left on the cutting room floor. There are several stories behind the story that don't quite get told, such as when this Evangelical group went from church to "house church" and then back to church, again. But since I lived through those times and saw many events like this in my own life, I found it easy to connect the dots.Higher Ground was disturbing for me as someone who saw a fair amount of abuse in the Evangelical scene, and as someone who finally escaped it. I know several people who are suffering emotional and spiritual scars from their times in that scene, and this film helped bring some of that stuff to the surface.Higher Ground is thought-provoking, just because of what I said above. I spent more time talking about this film afterwards than any other in recent times, probably just because I lived through similar things as the protagonist in this story. I came to the concusion that her "Higher Ground" was actually questioning what was going on around her.I wouldn't call this a "must see," as some other reviewers here. I'm glad I saw it, as it gave me a chance to reflect (once again) on some stuff in my own personal history with the Evangelical scene. I will continue on my journey of faith, and I will continue to seek "Higher Ground."

I normally don't read graphic novels (or graphic autobiographies, which this is), but when we added this to our high school library, I had someone question the appropriateness of this volume for our collection.Within minutes of starting this book, I was drawn into the dark and tragic childhood of David Small. The black and white and gray-toned water colors propel the story along. I finished the book in one sitting. While disturbed by the events of Small's childhood, his dysfunctional family (going back a few generations), and the events surrounding his own cancer, the positive spin is that he finds his "voice" through drawing and the therapist who recognizes his talent.While this book will have a limited audience in our high school library, it is worth having on the shelves. I'm sure for some students it will be just the right book to give them hope.

I mainly got hold of this volume to follow up on the Rabbit series. The other short stories help to underscore the impression I got of Updike reading the earlier Rabbit novels: he writes extensivevly about the effects of the sexual revolution on middle America.It's not a pretty sight, but as I look around me, I see that virtually everyone I know has been impacted by it, directly or indirectly. I think that's why I kept returning to the Rabbit series.In the final novella, we see Rabbit's son, his illegitimate daughter, his estranged daughter-in-law, and the son of one of his previous flings converge for an imperfect, but still hopeful, celebration on the eve of the new millenium. Rabbit's many imperfections are brought to the surface and to put it simply, he's described at one point as "selfish." He's one that leaves a lot of collateral damage behind after his selfish escapades.That pretty much sums up the mess that Rabbit has created and that the next generation has inherited. Like I said in a previous review: "Isn't he a bit like you and me."I'm done with Rabbit for now, but I'm glad I finally experienced this character, who is about as famous as Holden Caulfield from The Catcher in the Rye; another person you enjoy reading about but would never really want to know...or be.

Last summer I returned to my birthplace of Holland, which I had not seen since I was three years old in 1953. After checking out several travel guides, we decided to mainly use this one by Rick Steves. I suppose it helps that I live about 45 minutes from his headquarters and we stopped into his shop a couple of times to pick up travel gear.We spent two weeks in the Netherlands, staying overnight in four locations, three of which we got out of this book. The book did an accurate job of describing these bed and breakfasts and hotels, and we were not disappointed (although one hotel was a bit of a letdown after we got the best room in the previous hotel).We stayed near Arnhem, and in Amsterdam, Delft and Haarlem. Based on the book, we enjoyed museums, canal tours, restaurants, walks, bike rides, and we learned how to navigate the airport, the trains and the trams. There is no way you can do everything that is recommended in the book, but Steves and his companions make it very helpful to plan the trip, and to make adjustments in the itinerary once you're on the way.The one shortcoming is that not enough of the country is covered in the book. We spent a delightful day in Zutphen, looking up family history, and found it to be a town that any tourist would enjoy, but there is no mention of it on these pages. We also considered a side trip to Groningen, but again there was no mention of that region in this book.Holland may be small, but in our two weeks we discovered that there are distinctive characteristics to each region, and one could easily spend a long time in this country and just barely scratch the surface. Hopefully Steves will consider doing a longer book in the future, because he does such a good job at what he has already covered.

I have been listening to the Rabbit audiobooks from my library out of sequence, but it's been a fascinating ride. Rarely has a protagonist and series captured my attention the way Rabbit has.I'm still not sure why. Updike places Rabbit, his son Nelson, girlfriend Jill, "houseguest" Skeeter, wandering wife Janice, and a host of secondary characters solidly in the context of middle-class America in 1969. Updike's eye for detail from this period is impeccible.But it's Harry "Rabbit" Angstrom and his aimless hedonistic life, and his poor decisions that lead to disastrous results that propell the story along.As the book was wrapping up the lyrics of "Nowhere Man," by the Beatles  popped into my head. Perhaps this is why Rabbit's story appeals to me:He's a real nowhere man,Sitting in his nowhere land,Making all his nowhere plans for nobody.Doesn't have a point of view.Knows not where he's going to.Isn't he a bit like you and me?

I first encountered From I-ville to You-ville while dining with the monks in the trapeza (dining hall) of the Monastery of St. John of San Francisco back in 2007. It is the practice of the monks to read spiritually uplifting books during the meal, and this delightful children's book was selected after they finished a much heavier theological treatise. The monks, and the guests (including me) were delighted at the powerful message of embracing selflessness told so beautifully and simply.I bought a copy at the monastery bookstore, and brought it home and put it in my bookcase until tonight, more than four years later. Yesterday I finished another book that made reference to this one, so I pulled it out, and we decided to make it our read-aloud entertainment for New Year's Eve. There are no children in our household. Just two aging Christians seeking a deeper walk with God.We were delighted at this allegory about a boy from I-ville named Stubborn who meets a girl from You-ville named Serenity. She invites him to come visit, which he does. He finds it difficult to get there at first, but he reaches his destination where he undergoes a transformation. When he eventually returns home a year later, he has to face the reaction of those in You-ville to the changes in his life.Highly recommended for Christians of all persuasions. Children, too.
