I love taking pictures of myself in big hats, flashy sunglasses, bangle bracelets and various shades of nail polish..I just received this special nail color yesterday and while it's not as bright orange as the catalog page depicts, it's a lovely shade of orange. I wasted no time applying it to one hand. That was yesterday and I still haven't gotten around to doing the other hand. Shame on me, but I'm not going anywhere...It was easy to apply and looks stunning to me. Some say it looks better against darker skin, but I'm very fair. Since my neighbor is darker, we tried it on her and agreed that it looks equally great on both of us. Thus concluding that this color will look good on women of all nationalities.. On her, it reminds me of tropical fruit; on me, it reminds me of Easter eggs... (Does that make sense?)I also took time to remove this polish from one finger with polish remover and am happy to report it was easily removed. That's another plus, IMO.Anyway, with this sassy color, Essie has made a new customer of me.Highly recommended to everyone but the most conservative women.Reviewed by Betty Dravis, May 15, 2015Author of "The Search for Bobby McGee"

When I read the words "silk" and Geoffrey Beene in the same sentence, I just had to order this product. I didn't even need to see it to know it was quality because Beene is world-renowned for fine design and quality. All his designs are hot commodities around the world.Out of curiosity about the price and to learn the color of the piping on these classic, luxurious pajamas, I visited the Amazon catalog page and was not surprised at the expensive price tag... but as my mother always said, "You get what you pay for."Since this is a free gift for an honest review, for once I didn't have to be concerned about price, which makes these pajamas even sweeter.My son loves them, saying they are the softest, most comfortable that he has ever worn. Like most young people, he likes to wear the pants with various t-shirts... but not the top. That works for me because I like to wear the top half of men's pajamas. Always have! The loose fit makes them even more comfy... and cute, IMO. (Makes me feel like Suzanne Sommers in "Three's Company." )  :-)My son and I are both delighted with these elegant pajamas. Love you, Goeffrey Beene.Reviewed by Betty Dravis, May 14, 2015Author of "Six-Pack of Blood"

100% satisfied with this well-crafted and designed grab bar. I have had one in the master bath for about five years with no sign of weakening or corrosion, so am comfortable putting this one in the guest bathroom.The first one is installed in horizontal position because I always shower, rather than bathe. It works perfectly and I feel so secure at my advanced age.My son installed this new one in the guest bathroom in slanting position to allow for some guests bathing and some showering. That way it's comfortable and easy to grasp for anyone. In addition, we often have the grandkids overnight, and while we don't think of them as needing a grab bar, they certainly do. Kids tend to get excited and play around in tub, so it's an extra safe-guard in case they get rowdy and lose their balance.My son said it was easy to install and only took him about ten minutes. Wonderful!Needless to add, I love this product. It's another little way of making life comfortable and safer.Thanks to the trusted brand of Moen for supplying quality bath fixtures.Reviewed by Betty Dravis, May 14, 2015Author of "The Search for Bobby McGee"

I tired of the market flooded with vampire books, so had not read one in ages. But this one attracted me and quickly lured me into the lives of these likable, believable characters.I eagerly followed the complex Vampire-versus-Chasers plot, and quickly got involved in the blossoming romance between opposites who are sworn enemies. Maggie and Shane, their friends and siblings are so well-written they seemed like people I know. I cared what happens to them.Can't wait to read the next book in this twisting, turning story to learn what happens to all of them.Highly recommended for all ages.Reviewed by Betty Dravis, May 14, 2015Author of "Six-Pack of Fear"

I prefer tea over coffee and start each of my days with a hot cup. Always have liked it better than coffee because coffee seems too harsh to me.I've seldom tried loose-leaf teas because I'm always in a rush, but when I received the offer of this fine Asian tea in exchange for an honest review, I couldn't resist.I read the other reviews and after trying it, I agree that this is exceptional Asian tea. Not only is the flavor soothing and delicious, the aroma is wonderful.I delight in awakening with this soothing tea and often enjoy it with a dribbling of honey.Highly recommended to all who enjoy a real cup of tea produced by a culture that has a passion for its fine tea.Goodbye to Keurig pods! Hello to loose tea...Reviewed by Betty Dravis, May 13, 2015Author of "The Search for Bobby McGee".

This arrived today and I had to try it right away. My neck and shoulder have been aching due to heavy typing and craning my head to adjust to the monitor... not to mention old age. :-) After installing the batteries (which gratefully came with this product) and reading the very clear instructions, I placed the two pads an inch apart on my shoulder, then settled in with my Kindle reader while waiting through the fifteen-minute therapy session. (I can go as long as thirty minutes, but opted to start with fifteen). Thirty minutes three times daily is recommended, but I hope I don't need itt that often.Omron Electrotherapy Max Power Relief machine has three settings: patting, rubbing and kneading. After trying all three, I enjoyed the kneading, so stuck with that.I'm very pleased with the results. My aches and pains are all gone and it even seemed to loosen up my hip area. So that's the next place I will work on. My shoulder and neck feel much better and it's been over three hours since I tried this. I love it for giving me a bit more freedom.Since my friend has back pain, she is next in line... after I do my hip. :-)This is an amazing little product... and has various degrees of pulsation from which to use. You can test from moderate to severe and I chose #13 because it was the setting that felt best to me. It's great to have the choice.I realize this is temporary relief, but I'll take what I can get.Thanks, Omron, for developing this easy-to-use, helpful product.Highly recommended.Reviewed by Betty Dravis, May 12, 2015Author of "Six-Pack of Fear" (co-author Barbara Watkins)

This is a cool, creative product that my whole family is having a lot of fun with.I, myself, am gray now and realize gray is harder to color, but playing with it is like enjoying a second childhood. :-) But my simple pleasure is only part of the reason I like this. I love coloring the grandkids's hair when they come visit. They love it so much that I am going to get them sets for their birthdays. If it gets too messy for their mothers, it is easy to clean up.My daughter reported that the girls even talked their father into letting them paint his bushy brows purple and give him orange sideburns. They took a photo of him... It's so cute, they want to post it on Facebook but don't want to upset him.Outside the fun factor of this, it's rather attractive on the younger girls, making great photo opportunities. Even boys who like Mohawks and such are using this product, I hear. It certainly beats dyed hair that goes through shabby stages as it grows out.Hair Chalk simply washes out with no hassle. The only thing I don't like is that it's not quite as easy to use as claimed. It takes a number of hard swipes to make it hold, even with damp hair... which turns out to be the easiest way to use it.I have no complaints against the packing; it was nicely wrapped with a very attractive cover that includes all details for proper use of these clever chalks. And I love the wide array of bright colors.For fun and a change of looks, I highly recommend hair chalk. What will they think of next?I appreciate receiving this product in exchange for an honest review.Reviewed by Betty Dravis, May 11, 2015Author of "1106 Grand Boulevard"

Awesome locks.  They've made it through TSA multiple times without a ruckus.  I find them easy enough to set and lock/unlock.  While a set of bolt cutters would quickly gain access, it's more for keeping an honest guy honest than anything.  Worth the price, being that I shouldn't have to ever purchase new luggage locks ever again.  Most importantly, I can tell if TSA has accessed my luggage even before getting the their love note in my bag.

Very nice tie.  Colors are vibrant, lines are crisp, and it looks sharp in combination with the pocket square.  The pocket square is a strange false cut, which isn't noticeable as long as it's in the pocket.  The tie requires a lot of ironing to maintain it's smooth surface.  The length options are nice and accurate!  Good tie, little expensive.. but has the power to make you look incredible against a black suit.

The collar stays are great and functional.  The tie clips don't stay put on any of my ties due to minimal contact points.  They don't go quite far enough across the tie to grab the shirt causing it to slide down.  For the money they look decent.. however, only 3 of the 6 are nice enough that I'd consider using them.  The others have a cheap appearance, and in combination with them constantly coming un-clipped from the shirt it can make you look/feel like a noob.  For the price they are okay, but I've set them aside and lend them to coworkers if they ever forget theirs while on travel.

Caught this on sale and am happy with it for what I paid.  I use it for my dress shoes, running shoes, sneakers, and some folded undershirts.  It holds more weight than I'd expected it to.  It attaches with a very strong Velcro flap so you don't have to take the closet rod down.. which is awesome.  One of my only complaints is the zipper, sub par at best and it gets caught.  The opening flap doesn't open very easily making it a pain to get my shoes out some mornings.Being that it's strong, you can probably get away with severely overloading this closet organizer.  If you catch it on sale it's well worth it... if I had to pay full price id consider looking for some better options without the flap.

Excellent straws that should last longer than I will with care.  I use a small brush that I purchased on Amazon to keep them clean.  They're a heavy gauge that doesn't flex much and are long enough to use with my large Tervis mugs.  Wish they were a bit cheaper.. for a little more I could have purchased titanium milkshake straws.Be aware that they still have an incorrect photo up.  I ordered the flexible ones according to the photo, they are not flexible... solid.

I read other reviews about it being a disaster trying to set this alarm clock.  I figured, "What dummy can't figure out an alarm clock in 2015!"....SO.. it took this dummy about 30 minutes to get anywhere with this clock.  Even then, setting the alarm had me baffled.  I thought I was getting somewhere when it showed that the alarm was set, the correct time, and dimmed properly.  At this point I was excited about how awesomely the auto dimming feature worked.  Fast-forward....After a week of not being able to turn the alarm off, I've given up.  When it goes off, I hit multiple buttons that are placed poorly on the back that change settings and time while trying to make it shut up.  The alarm doesn't get very loud either.  I'm not THAT sound of a sleeper, but a short beeping at a 6/10 is about as loud as it gets.  Then lets discuss the awesome deal that includes the power cord.  Yes, you pay more for your clock to have a power cord... your electronic clock... power cord... pay more...what...the.......Anyway, this cord... that's about the length of my arm.  It forced me to resort to batteries (awesome battery life by the way) unless I wanted to keep my clock far away and at an angle.  Far away I can deal with.  However, if you are at virtually ANY angle and not staring head on... the screen appears solid white.Finally, the auto dimming feature.. yesss... let's compliment this piece of electronics.  This is something they nailed!  It dims to a comfortable setting based on surrounding light.  It's so nice, in fact, that I keep the clock on my night stand and use my phone as the alarm.  I've had it for months and not lost/gained time.. still running on the same batteries.. still functioning well as a clock.  For this reason it bumped from a 1 to a 2 star review.

This is a simple, genius invention.  I work in the field and use it at least 15 times per work day, often for 30 minutes or more.  I keep it on the passenger floorboard and pull it out each time I use it.  While it would be awesome if it somehow folded flat after each use, I have no complaints.  The hooks concerned me at first and I felt that they were flimsy.. but they have held up well.  Most of the time I am using my tablet but it holds my laptop just as well.  It's incredibly adjustable!I'd pay double the price for this if I had to.  While it isn't pretty or super high tech, it's functionality makes it a necessity in my line of work.

As far as compression goes, these shirts are great!  I can use them for running or mountain biking and stay cool/dry.  As far as the ever so common comparison to UA.. they aren't there in quality.  UA compression shirts are much more comfortable to me, lighter material, and dry a bit faster.  Then again, these are roughly 40% cheaper than the UA compression shirts I own.  I have a handful of white that I use as undershirts for work every day in the summer.  These Champion shirts seem to run short and I have a heck of a time keeping them tucked in.  The cut also seems awkward.. like it naturally rides up in the chest.  It's snug around the neck and bunches up constantly.Good shirts for the price, but they certainly aren't UA quality.  If you know what you're getting go for it... they serve the purpose and are fine for the price.

Perfection!  They are machined very well with flawless threads.  I ordered two sets and they are both consistently made.  Haven't had any problems with them backing out and the slot is perfect for a sturdy screwdriver.  They aren't over polished or tacky looking.  I don't know what else to say.. just get these and replace those ratty plastic eggbeater dust caps.

I'm that guy who is terrified of impulse purchases, for this exact reason.  I purchased it using my amazon app without bothering with reviews, solely because I saw it in the Verizon store and figured it'd be a quality product.PROS.  It seems to be shockproof, and the phone fits in the case like a glove.  I've dropped it multiple times while out in the warehouse and it has been flawless as far as protection goes..  I never performed a waterproof test, but I've used it in the rain and for mountain biking / hiking... solid in that department..  The built in screen protector is pretty awesome, and serves it's purpose.  The edge of the case around the front provides great screen protection on face down drops or while setting it down roughly..  The earphone jack extension cord is convenient, and also prevents any water or dust from entering the case while listening to tunes..  The buttons feel great.  They are firm and you can feel the 'click' of the buttons without having to mash them.CONS.  Can't hear squat.  I've tried everything, and it's a pain to hear anybody while not on speaker phone..  Others cannot hear squat.  I have to open the charging port door for anybody to hear me without yelling.. thus defeating the purpose of a sealed case..  The earphone jack plug seals well, but ripped off after a couple weeks of use. It needs to be a much stronger material..  The case is bulky, and it is fairly uncomfortable while in my pocket.. so i'm stuck lugging it around in my hand or on my hip..  The fingerprint reader is virtually useless.  Since I've had the case, it hasn't read a fingerprint once.. not even enough to set it up..  The rubber insulator piece inside the charging port door can easily fall off and be lost..  The significant lip around the front of the case can make it hard touching the edges of the screen..  As I should have expected, playing music and using speakerphone can be a disaster and sounds very muffled or tinny,.  Lack of grip while holding it.. especially when wet or damp.  It also slides around if you set it down while driving.  (don't judge my driving!)Overall, the case performs if you want to protect it in a work environment.  If you want to use all of your features, look elsewhere.  I wish i'd looked at the reviews before dumping such a large amount of money on a phone case... shame on me I suppose.  Also, if your case breaks like mine did good luck with customer service.  They want to make you jump through hoops until you give up all hope.

I packed these in my wife's backpack that stays in her car.  If you are going to spend hours driving in the Arizona heat each day, you'd better have a game plan in case of a break down.  They don't expire for a few years, but even if they did... expired water that taste like foil is better than no water in 115 degree heat with no shade in sight.  The packets don't take up much space and seem to be pretty easy to open.  It appears that some of the pre-cut edges were missed, so a knife might be required to get it started.  Good deal on a good product..

I had pretty high hopes for this, but was sadly let down when they frayed and shredded while trying to run them through the cassette.  They are also a bit overpriced for what they are, but I suppose people are used to paying for the name (that'll strike a chord with some i'm sure).  The one thing that these ARE great for is threading them through your rear derailleur gear and cleaning the springs or brake calipers.  They have a nice little shoe string end on each side making this process a piece of cake.  If you have a lot of grime or old grease in your cassette you will have to scrub it well with a brush first, otherwise the strings will be caked with grease and deemed useless after one pass.Ultimately you can create your own using a pack of microfiber cloths from the local auto parts store for a fraction of the cost.  It comes down to how often you clean your ride.  I spend a lot of time on messy trails and am pretty anal about cleaning/maintenance, so I'll tear through these pretty quick.  Not a bad product really, just not for me or those with filthy cassettes and chain rings.  In the product's defense, they may work much better on the road bikes with commuter grime.. which these may be geared more towards?

This is the best rim tape I've ever used.  Perfection on every level, from ease of installation to quality of the product.  I use this on my 26" XC wheels and it fixed the problems I had with the stock plastic-like crappy rim tape.  This is a perfect fit for just about any MTB wheels.. wide enough to cover spoke holes with plenty to spare in width.  The adhesive on the tape holds it in place flawlessly, but can be removed easily without leaving sticky slimy melted residue from riding in hot weather.The hole is sized for a presta valve.  If you are old school like myself and rock the schrader valves, simply cut a small X into the hole.. otherwise you'll have trouble forcing the larger valve through the opening in the tape.

The PVC is strong and sturdy, the color hasn't faded, and the lines/detail are crisp.  I took off the bead chain and put my key ring directly through the PVC loop.. no problems.  If it gets dirty over time (which it will), just hit it with an alcohol swab or sanitary wipe and it's back to lookin' like new.The only real issue I had with this key holder is how loose it fits an average house key.  I had to put the key in and super glue the rubber shut so it would stay in place.  Nothing worse than reaching for your house key and finding an empty Bart.  It's also pretty bulky, so if you keep your keys in your pocket and want your jeans to remain low profile you should keep looking.  Killer key holder, but don't trust it without sealing the seam shut around the bottom of the key!

Overall pretty good pump.  It's heavier and pumps slower than my Serfas TCPG Bicycle Floor Pump, but has an awesomely long hose that was the key selling point for me.  I'll keep this one in the shop and more than likely get another TCPG for in my truck.  The Joe Blow Race feels quite solid and has a nice wide base for those putting air in their tires after your cycling shoes are on.  The head mounts fine on both schrader and presta (can take a little fiddling sometimes) valves... and the pressure relief button is pretty cool feature.  Like I mentioned, the 4 foot hose was the key selling point for me and a sweet convenience.  The little yellow notch that helps to mark what PSI you're aiming for... it's flimsy and doesn't stay put.  Just one of those little things that irks me.Is it worth the money?  Sure, why not.  But if I could do it all over again I'd just replace the hose with a longer one on my Serfas pump and save a bunch of money.

One of the best investments you can make with your MTB.  The lock-out comes in handy for those who get into some XC riding with many climbs, and the remote poploc is nice.  While I have an appreciation for the poploc system, the plastic is really flimsy and can be broken easily.  If you ride a lot in the winter like I do, be careful with it in cold weather.  As far as the fork goes, I have about 700 miles on it and it has performed flawlessly.  It's forgiving for those that push the limits like me (bless that blowoff while locked), and can be fine tuned for anybody whether you be a clyde or weight weenie.  In this price range, you can't go wrong here..

This is a pretty solid investment.  My bathroom sink didn't have a drain cover and I almost lost my wedding band down the drain multiple times.  I should have probably went with the smaller option, but I figured that this would come in handy later in life if I ever needed a drain cover for a tub.  It fits well even in the bathroom sink, even though the edge is close to the back side of the sink... if that makes sense.  The water drains quickly and it works well.  My only gripe is that I wish the rubber ring was a little tackier so that it stayed in place better.

These are exactly as advertised.  They are heavier than a jersey cotton, but slightly thinner than standard sweatpants.  The material has a bit of a course/stiff feeling to it as well, which makes it feel sturdy and strong.  The gray color is nice and doesn't stand out, which many people may enjoy while working out.  The stripes are also a little more subtle than other brands that use tacky colors.  The drawstring will pull through, so make sure you tie them off asap.  They're nice for everything from long road trips to playing ball in the fall or spring.  They don't necessarily breathe very well, so make sure you pack some athletic shorts if you tend to overheat easily.They fit in the waist and rear exactly as I had anticipated.  However, they were forever long.  So I ran them through the wash and dried the heck out of them in the drier.  It successfully knocked the length down to where they belong.  Keep this in mind if you try them on and don't like the length.

These shorts are incredibly lightweight.  I could imagine they'd be very comfortable to play ball in during the hottest months.  Be aware that with the lightweight material comes a certain level of transparency.  What i'm saying is this... while they are made of a durable high quality material.. certain colors may possibly demonstrate your ball dribbling skills on and off the court.  Strap up and avoid the personal foul.  That said, they seem to run large.  I could have pulled mine half to my nips and they still would have been at my knees.  You might want to order a size down compared to other Adidas shorts.  Good quality item from Adidas, but this one wasn't for me.

This is a solid shoe bag, and serves it's intended purpose well.  I've used it to haul my gym shoes back and forth here and there without a problem.  My 10.5's fit in there snug width wise, but I have room to cram a pair of light shorts and tee-shirt on top.  I'm notorious for using items for everything but their intended purpose, so of course it's been everything from a carry-on bag for air travel to a storage sack mounted to my road bike for a quick ride to the store.  It does vent well with plenty of mesh, as long as you only have a pair of shoes in there allowing room to breathe.  The handle is VERY strong (I abuse my gear).  Best of all it cleans up well, so the possibilities are endless for this shoe bag.  The only downfall is that the zipper snags.  I had a heck of a time smoothly opening and closing the bag for the first several uses.. then it eased up.. and went back to being a pain in the butt.  While it hasn't gotten totally stuck yet, I predict that one day in the future it will jam and cause a brief moment of rage.

U.S. Polo should be embarrassed to have their name on this product.  I've used them for about 4 months and they are shot.  The seams pulled, the corners tore, the cotton feels like a cheap big box store tee-shirt, they are incredibly thin and see through, they're hot to lay on during warm nights, and they don't stay in place.  Quite frankly, the only thing I enjoy about this product is the color.  They haven't faded, though they look wore out even after only a few months of use.  Luckily I had purchased them on STP, so the price was half of that of Amazon..Look elsewhere if you want your sheets to last, and don't be fooled about these imported sheets just because they say Polo.

These were almost the greatest pair of suspenders I've ever used for hiking... ALMOST.  There is this one major flaw.  The straps seem to work their way to my armpit area and it feels like they're cutting me into pieces.  In the winter this is tolerable because I hike with multiple base layers below the straps, but in the summer when there is minimal to no padding it's miserable.  If Perry were to put a very basic connecting piece to keep the straps in a comfortable position these suspenders would be incredible.As far as performance goes they do just fine.  While hiking or doing bushcraft things, I keep a fairly heavy ESSE in a leather case on my belt along with a sidearm.  The suspenders keep everything in place whether I'm hiking, kneeling, trailblazing, or rock scrambling.  I also am impressed by the fact that the plastic clips are TSA approved and don't slide off the belt while getting in and out of vehicles.  In fact, they seem to always stay in place.Great product if they'd fix the one major flaw.  Other than that, I love these things and i'll continue to use them for winter hikes...

I broke the rules like a true hardcore rebel and still have no major complaint about this shelf.  Not for use as a television stand?  Pshh.. BAM!  36" TV up top.  Second shelf has my computer tower sitting sideways with a speaker on each side... and a PS3 on top of it.  Next two shelves have PS3 games and my not so extensive Stephen King collection.  Bottom shelf gives me a place for random items and a bin with electronics cables / adapters.I exceed the weight limit for this stand on the top two shelves alone, but it doesn't phase it.  The glass used in the shelf shows no sign of stress and is rather excellent quality.  In fact, everything about this tower is high quality!  I have two minor inconveniences and neither are very significant.  First, the studs that screw into the side beams and hold the shelf up.. they are smooth and can be a bear to get a grip on during assembly.  Secondly, the shelves aren't adjustable.  I assume they are assigned certain positions to maintain the structural strength of the tower overall, sooo deal with it.Yeah yeah, I know i'm not using it for it's intended purpose.  Over all, this is a classy looking piece that serves it's purpose well.  High quality with a killer price tag... you can't go wrong!

For starters, don't pay more than three to four dollars for these trash bags like this sucker did.  If they are still gouging look elsewhere.  These aren't all that durable, are incredibly thin and see through, and do not fit 4 gallon trash cans.  Look for 5 gallon bags or larger if you own a 4 gallon trash can, as you need extra to fold over the top of the can.  Then consider that you lose some capacity when you try to tie it closed.These are perfect for in the bathroom, where I have a 2.5 gallon can that these fit well.  The bags can handle empty toilet rolls and q-tips, but I wouldn't trust them any more than an old wally world bag.

The finish is actually quite attractive for being such an inexpensive particle board table.  It's painfully easy to put together... four bolts that come with the washers already on each one (allen wrench included).. and four screws for the bottom shelf.Three of the four bolts which hold the legs on went in smoothly, but one split the wooden brace that the leg screws into.  Not that big of a deal, and it seemed to hold up well even though the leg was only snugged down with one turn.  Onto the bottom shelf.. which is an absolutely ridiculous design.  You must pull the legs inward as you screw directly into the bottom of the shelf.  While you pull in, you must hold the shelf up and push against yourself.  In my case the shelf slipped from my hand while holding it up and screwing, and two of the four corners are now busted off.  With that rage ensued, the screws went flying, and I went after some wood glue.  I magic markered the exposed broken particle board so it would blend in and glued the shelf into place instead of screwing it in.. then let it set to dry.Long story short, the design of the bottom shelf is pathetic.  Had it mounted from the top it would have had better structural integrity and been a cinch to install while being worthy of a 4/5 star review.  Lesson learned..

I've used the Cuban Crafters Stainless Perfecto Cutter for years, and decided to grab this as a spare for in the truck.  This cutter is solid and serves the purpose well, but I tend to smoke a variety of cigars.. including the occasional torpedo,  This means that the cutter will take two or three swipes and leave a bit of a mess.  The CC cuter has a hole in the backing that allows a torpedo to slide through a bit, then holds the clipping until I get out of the truck later.  The blades on this COHIBA are quite sharp, make a nice clean cut, and are high quality surgical stainless.  This cutter only cuts up to a 50 ring, but the CC cuts up to a 54... luckily I rarely enjoy large ring smokes.  The blades are set at a nice depth from the backing and it does provide a perfect cut most of the time.Over all this is a great cutter.  After all, how can you go wrong for only ten bucks or so.  In my personal opinion the Cuban Crafters is a much better option, but i'm satisfied with the Cohiba.  If you don't bother with torpedos and stick to 50 or smaller ring gauge.. this a solid selection!

These could be my all time favorite jeans!  To be honest, I struggled to find anything negative about them... minus the fact that they run ever so slightly large in the waist.  That in combination with the 'comfort waist'.. you might want to consider going a size smaller.  The color doesn't seem to fade over time, they don't really shrink much at all in the wash, and the thread quality is right on point.  They look like brand new after a month of wear and tear, which is promising.  Hopefully these last as long as the other jeans I own which cost nearly double that of these.  The most important feature is that they stay in place while allowing room to flex and kneel often.Solid jeans, and if the next pair I order is just as awesome they will be my new go-to pair of pants.

I'm a HUGE fan of the classic Irish Spring Body Wash, so I figured i'd give this a go.  The scent isn't as strong or long lasting as the classic, it doesn't wash off as easily, and it only lathers up about half as well.  I didn't notice a significant difference in it clearing up my skin, even with the 2% salicylic acid that's in it.  The price is far from realistic at nearly nine bucks for a 15 ounce bottle.  It isn't the worst body wash I've ever used, but i'm far from impressed and will not be purchasing it again.

Nautica jeans have always been made of a more comfortable material than others in my opinion, and these don't disappoint.  The color is exactly as displayed in the photo and they haven't faded after several times through the wash... nor have they lost any level of comfort.  They do run large, so be ready for that.  I'll order another pair eventually and go at least 2 sizes smaller in the waist.  The legs are a bit baggy and long, but they're big and tall relaxed fit so this should be expected.  If you are tall this is the way to go. While they are a bit pricey, I feel that these will last a long time just as all the other Nautica pants I've owned have.

These glasses are excellent quality for the price point.  The logos are all nice and haven't faded after many uses/washes.  They are true 16oz beer glasses that have a decent amount of weight to them.  There are heavier options floating around, but I prefer a somewhat light glass with a solid heavy base... and this fits the bill.  I tipped one over the other day while it was empty and it survived... soooo.. I'd say they're fairly sturdy.If only they came with three drinking buddies...

I used the good ole boiled water method to dye a couple of hats, one cotton, the other canvas.  Look around online and you will find plenty of demonstrations using Rit dye on different materials.  Mine came out a little darker than expected, but I suppose that is because I left it in the water a while longer than I originally intended to.  In fact, I remember someone mentioned that the Brown dye looked Purple, and I believe them.  My hat is such a dark deep brown that in dim light it appears to have a purple tint to it.. but it is clearly brown in the sun.  Is should fade and wear over time being that I use it for hiking, so I am satisfied.  One bottle seems to go a long way!!  Good dye..

The first couple cans I tried were so-so, and I was incredibly disappointed.  The next week I took them to work where I kept them on ice, and they were delicious!  So I experimented here and there and came to the conclusion that if they are in the fridge for a day and VERY cold, they are great.  If they are anything but ice cold, they have an odd taste and you may dislike them.I also find them to be rather expensive, but I suppose they are a 'specialty' item and this is to be expected.  I won't be buying them again until I catch a sale..

I have a lot of Bluecell battery cases and use them for everything (backpacking, hunting, hiking, BOB, EDC, drawer organization).  The quality is right on point... sturdy plastic, strong snap closure, ect.  My beef is that the ridges cannot come up enough to hold CR123A batteries securely, otherwise it would intrude into the space needed for the 18650 batteries to fit comfortably.  They should market these as 18650 cases, and market a modified model to hold CR123A batteries tighter... but I suppose with that the cost would go up.  The colors are convenient so that you can easily tell which ones are used and new without confusion, or tell which ones you need at a quick glance.Don't get me wrong, these WILL hold CR123A batteries, four of them per box.  If you want to store them in a drawer or somewhere where they will lay undisturbed, these cases will be fine.  I wanted to throw them in my EDC for my flashlight, but they are just sloppy enough of a fit to bounce around and bang against each other in the case.HOWEVER, i've found a way to make them work.  The Bluecell hook and loop strap that comes with the battery case to hold it shut or keep them together can be folded and closed inside with the batteries (I uploaded a terrible photo).  This holds them perfectly in place!  I've never had an issue with any of my Bluecell cases popping open, even after repeated abuse.. so I had the straps just laying around anyway.

This is another awesome Artgame bookmark!  The image itself is very intense, and the detail is spectacular.  The 3D is crisp and easy on the eyes, unlike some that are hard to make out and cause your eyes to strain.  Good quality here..

This little pipe tool grew on me over time.  The color isn't as vibrant as the photo makes it seem, but looks good enough for the price.  The pick is designed well but the reamer is rather large and can be difficult to get into a smaller bowl.  Same goes with the tamper.. bulky and a tight fit with smaller pipes.Overall quality is pretty good.  I can't see why it wouldn't last a lifetime if taken care of, and it certainly serves the purpose.

The material quality is fantastic, and it feels as though they would last with proper care.  The Velcro is sturdy and seems like it will hold up well over time, but I'll never know for myself being that I only got one use out of them.This glove runs incredibly small in areas.  I suppose this glove would be perfect for someone with narrow hands and long slender fingers.  Normally OR is right on with size, so I'm thinking its possible that mine are defective.  The Velcro was maxed out and could hardly make solid contact around my wrists.  The fingers are all too long, some by nearly an inch.  The body of the hand actually felt nice, and the fingers were perfectly snug.. which is how they are designed to fit.  They feel great and did an excellent job of blocking the 18 degree 40mph wind gusts.. but I couldn't get over the clumsy long fingers.The list price is a but high for what they are, but if you catch them on sale and don't end up with an odd fitting pair you will be just fine.

At first I found this a bit overwhelming for me.  I worked through about half of the container and found myself becoming quite fond of it.  It is very much like the old Red Hots that you used to get for Valentines Day as a kid (or was that just me?).. and if you steep it just right it can be pretty delicious.  I found that if you drink it straight, it goes down like fire and you can feel it travel all the way to your gut.  If you want it to be a bit more mild, just splash in a little skim milk and it will is right on point!This is one of those teas I have to be in the mood for, but I like having it around.  When I finish this tin I will probably grab another one..

The coconut flavor of this tea is delicious!  It isn't overpowering, and doesn't taste like that sweet fake coconut flavoring... more like real fresh coconut.  When you open the pouch and take a whiff, it practically takes you to an immediate state of euphoria.  However, it isn't near as strong as it smells.  The coconut flavor is there, not quite as strong as I'd like, and the tea itself is rather weak.If you aren't into strong teas and prefer a mild coconut flavor, this certainly is for you.  I'll move on to another when I finish this and see if I can find something a bit stronger.

The zipper on this pouch needs to lead further down the sides.  It is a bit of a pain getting in there and reaching items in the bottom of the pouch because it only pulls open slightly.  There is a surprising amount of room in the pouch, and if you organize it well you can fit an impressive amount of stuff without significantly expanding it's profile.  The MOLLE loops would be better if the two on the edges were full width, that way it could be secured to the pack at wider points (Maxpedition Tac Ties will not fit the two outter loops).  This would make it less floppy and hold a tighter profile to the pack.Here is the major issue with this pouch.  The zipper has a material flap to protect it and keep dust/dirt out.  This flap snags EVERY time, and becomes incredibly frustrating.  I've seen where others took a knife and cut the flaps away, but this pouch if far to expensive to butcher right off the bat.  Hopefully it softens up over time, as most Maxpedition products do, and it won't be that bad.  I have quite a few Maxpedition items, and this is the first I've seen this zipper design.  Hopefully it is the last..

I love this little light, but have never used it on a key chain.  It hangs from a loop inside my EDC backpack, so I can just twist it quickly and have light inside.  It twists very easily, and though it hasn't happened yet, I fear that I will accidentally twist it the wrong direction and it will come apart.  Not the end of the world, but I wish there were some sort of safety to prevent twisting to the point of battery removal.  Then again, you have to twist pretty far before it gets to that point.  The key chain clip seems pretty secure, so I'm sure it would handle the every day abuse of being on a keyring.  I'd say it is WELL worth the price.. good little light!

My Acer desktop stopped working after a power outage/surge.  I suspected the power supply was damaged so I looked online for something affordable and maybe slightly more powerful as a replacement.  I ended up ordering this and was a little worried about replacing it as I have never had done this before.  It was super easy.  The power supply fit perfectly in the old space.  The cables are nicely protected and long enough for even the longest distances.  The screws in the back of my case didn't match the power supply, but I managed to get one in tight enough to hold the power supply in place.  I read that some people said this power supply is loud.  Maybe my old original power supply was extraordinarily loud, but this new one is quieter than the one I had.  I hear no noise coming from it at all.  It is nearly silent and a big improvement from the original.  I can't comment on longevity as I have only owned this a few weeks.  I hope it will last a while...

My daughter loves this little boat.  We got her the red one.  She especially likes the little life ring which she holds just about the whole time she is in the bath.  The boat is well made and doesn't get moldy like some of the floating ducks which have a little breathing hole.  The little gray rubber line around the boat also keep it from scratching the tub or other items if it is slammed against something.  Highly recommended.

I wasn't sure if this was the right choice when I bought it.  I assumed the color display was one of those fancy gimmicks and the weather station wouldn't be very good as a whole.  But it was on sale and I gave it a shot.  I have had it for about a month now and I am really impressed.Readability is excellent.  Much better than the black and white LCD displays from prior stations.  You can see the temperature in and out across the whole room.  You can have the display on low or high brightness, or you can have it adjust itself.  I use this function and it basically turns to low brightness at night and back to high during the day.  Works quite well most of e time.I entered the pressure manually via the local airport pressure online, and it it has matched it ever since.  It finished learning and the forecast seems pretty accurate so far.My absolute favorite function is the fact that you can calibrate the in/out temperature and humidity individually.  I have never owned a weather station which can do this.  The in and outside temperature were off by a degree so I matched them to what my thermostat and other thermometers displayed which were all in the ballpark.  If you do this, allow the base station to be turned on for an hour or so, it seems it warms up once it is plugged in (I assume the electronics or display inside get a little warm) so allow it to settle before you calibrate it.  Originally I didn't bother using batteries but sure enough, the second night I had the station the power went out for a moment and it lost all calibration changes and the air pressure I entered.  I brought the sensor back inside for the day and re calibrated it all and then I added some batteries for back up.  No issues after that.I do wish the time display was bigger, and really, the only function I wish it had would be the ability to receive the atomic clock signal.  Then this weather station would be absolutely perfect.At this point I'm giving this five stars.  If it goes on sale again I will buy another for my father.

This may be the worse smelling cleaner I have ever purchased.  It smells like a mixture of our diaper genie and cat litter.  It also isn't any better than your average orange cleaner.  I threw mine in the trash after the first use, couldn't handle the smell.  Definitely not recommended.

I purchased this dish brush somewhere else.  Have had it for a few weeks.  I have to say, this is the worse dish brush I have ever come across.First, the few self dispensing brushes I have used always applied the soap to its own bristles so that the brush itself stayed soapy - makes sense.  This brush just squirts the stuff straight out onto whatever dish you may just be holding it over, or into the sink or the water, depending how you are aiming it.  I guess it works, but I prefer it the other way.  Also, even if you apply the same pressure in one push, sometimes you get a huge amount of soap, sometimes hardly any.Second, I'm not sure who designed this thing.  Sure, it works well for plates and silverware, but try washing a cup or glass with it.  Or a smaller pot.  There are no bristles at the front, so you don't really get the base of a cup or glass.  Same with a smaller pot.  On top of that, if you have a nice Teflon pot, you scratch it with the plastic border at the front of the brush.  The fact that this brush gets very thick quickly due to the reservoir also prohibits you from cleaning thinner glasses and cups.I'm going back to the cheaper regular dish brushes.

I bought this for my Galaxy S3 for which I have a Laza extended battery which has a capacity of 4200mah.  I charged the charger all the way and then attached it to my phone which was down to 9% of battery power.  The charger filled my phone up to 86% in about three hours and then stopped and was completely empty - even the flashlight didn't work at that point.Unscientifically, this means it charged my phone around 77%.  That roughly means it charged my phone with 3200mah.  Seeing this is the first time I ever used the charger, I hope that performance will increase a little bit as the charger gets cycled a few more times.  For now I will give it four stars, as it is short 1200mah of what was quoted.  If this number goes up a bit over time, I will update my review and increase the number of stars.I'm actually ok with what this charger delivers.  This will extend my phone by a whole day with medium use.  I don't need much more and am willing to accept that it can't charge my battery all the way seeing that it is very light and compact as a trade off.  Anyone with a regular phone battery should see this charger top their phone off all the way with no problems at all.The light switch is very easy to operate and I can see this being a problem when in a bag or suitcase.  My solution is to take a penny and scotch tape it over the switch.  That will keep it from being turned on accidentally.Edit:A month later I did a identical test.  I waited until my phone was at 9% again.  Then charged it with this charger which I had topped off the day before.  It charged it to 88% this time in just under three hours.  No significant change there.  I guess 3200mah is what this charger will deliver.  It's still ok with me.  That's more than a day of power for me with the S3.

I am on the road and plane a lot.  This battery is amazing.  With very low usage at home the battery will last four to five days.  With very heavy use it will last at least one and a half days.  The case fits very well too.  Of course the SIII is thicker and heavier now but I actually like that, it is easier to hold. I would highly recommend this.I have had a Laza extended battery for a HTC phone before, and it lasted two years with hardly any loss in capacity.  I'm pretty confident that this one will last for the life of my phone too.

I bought this food because of the high ratings.  We have two cats.  They both liked it.  However I noticed that one of the cats threw up all of the food about an hour after eating it.  In the beginning I didn't put two and two together.  After a few feedings I gave them some other food again.  The cat was fine within a day.  Later, I tried it one more time just to see if it was a coincidence but the same thing happened again.  Spot's Stew and my money went right into the trash.  The other cat was fine, so I won't give a one star rating because I have to assume that our cat must be allergic to something in this food.  However, this has never happened with any other food we ever fed the cats, so I can't give it a high rating.

Yikes, all these Amazon Vine reviews...I purchased this on a whim at my local grocery store.  I was really surprised how good this coffee is.  Actually, I think it is the best Keurig coffee I have had so far.  I usually get the San Francisco Bay coffee's.  They taste very good and are quite cheap making them a great every day coffee.  The Melitta coffee is too expensive for every day use, but if you want to treat yourself every now and then, it's a great choice.As for the taste, I like a stronger fuller coffee.  Most Keurig coffee pods are very weak, with very little body.  The San Francisco Bay cups have much more body and flavor than the average Keurig cups.  The Melitta is even better, with a lot of flavor.  I wish they sold them in larger amounts to bring the price down.

This is obviously a personal opinion, since everyone is different.  But I like the smell a lot, and so does my wife.  I discovered the Kilo line by accident when I bought the Kilo body spray on clearance at Target to try it out.  Liked it so much that I ordered more here and tried the shower gel too.  As to the shower gel itself, it cleans as well as most other shower gels I have used, so it does what it is supposed to do.

These gloves work well.  They do the job as expected.  Fit is good, except the fingers are a tad long, you have to pull them back a little bit.  I'm assuming this is because they want them to match all different sizes of hands.  No big deal.  The finger openings have a couple of threads sticking out, but they can be easily trimmed.  All in all, for the price, they are recommended.  Will buy them again if I need to.

I have been thinking about an adapter like this for years but was always turned off by many negative reviews.  Finally decided to try one and I'm glad I did.  Main reason really is that I am tired of paying the horrendous prices for CF cards when cards of similar capacity cost a fraction in the SD and MicroSD format.I use this with a Canon 5D Mark II and sometimes a 7D.  I have tried several SD and SDHC cards of different capacities with it.  Works great with all of them.  Recently I got a great deal on a 32GB MicroSD card.  So I gave that a shot, put the MicroSD card in a SD adapter and plugged all that into this adapter.  Works like a charm.  I do have to add that I am not a high speed shooter, so I can't vouch for how well all these setups work when shooting high speed consecutively.I also have two different older 4GB Eye-Fi cards.  This adapter works with both of them.  I get about 8 feet distance with them before they stop uploading to my iPad 2.  I did not take the metal sides off like some suggest.  May try that someday.  But I didn't have to update any firmware either to get them to work.  My older Eye-Fi cards won't transmit RAW files, so to fix that, I shoot RAW plus small JPG, then the JPG gets sent to the iPad for immediate evaluation, and the RAW is stored on the card.  Have not really had enough time to use this setup for longer shoots, I will update if I run into heat or other problems.I uploaded a few pictures of the card in my 5DII and with the MicoSD card.

I bought this to lubricate the wheels of a stroller which were not rolling smoothly.  Now the wheels spin like they have ball bearings.  Amazing.  I had to clean the gutters today, so I got my collapsible Werner ladder out.  I noticed that the locks on the ladder were really hard to pull out.  I remembered I had this stuff, applied it to the locks, and wow, they just slide right out.  Another example is my old garden hose spray nozzle.  I had already bought a new one because the old one had become stiff.  You had to press really hard to get it going, and sort of had to pull on the trigger lever to shut it off again.  I applied some of this stuff, exercised it a little, and now it works like new again.It's not going to come as a surprise that I tell you I recommend this grease.  It does a great job of greasing stuff up.  Seems to work on anything, but really does well when you have plastic meeting metal.

I was a little worried, seeing all the reviews from the other manufacturer of the same looking box.  But figured I'd give it a try.I'm glad I did.  It works perfectly.  Plugged it in, red light comes on, paired it with the phone and password "1234" and the Torque app on my Android phone started communicating with it immediately.  It blinks a lot of lights when it's communicating.  Although, I don't really see them as in my car the adapter is turned with the lights toward the door when it's closed.  No big deal, it's probably better that way, no crazy blinking lights at night.  The adapter does become a little warm after use, but not hot.I have not decided yet if I should leave it plugged in when I don't drive.  The adapter stays on with one red light lit (obviously the OBDII port is active when the car is turned off for fault analysis etc...) but I'm not sure how much power the adapter is pulling when idle and I don't want to have a dead battery when I get in the car one morning.  If anyone has any insight to that, please do leave a comment.I also have a HP Touchpad with Android on it, and Torque is even more fun when using that since it's a much bigger display and you can have more gauges on one screen.  So if you have a Android tablet, give it a try.I was kind of disappointed that my 2012 Honda only displays about half the data which this adapter is able to show, but hey, it's still fun, and the one item I really wanted to see was MPG, and I got that.I also used it on another car which had the check engine light on.  It read the codes out perfectly, and I like the feature in Torque that if you have internet access you can get more detailed info on the codes.For the price of under $30 including the app, you really can't beat this combo, I highly recommend it.  Much cheaper than ScanGauge or similar items.I added a few pictures of the Scan Tool in my car with the Touchpad and Torque.Edit:I couldn't resist, I had to add a on/off switch to this adapter.  See the pictures I uploaded for details.  Doesn't take very long if you know how to solder.  Works like a charm now and I don't have to worry about it draining my battery.

Received these a few days ago.  Very happy with them.  I was deciding between these and the Weathertech version.  Decided to save some money and went with the Husky's.  I'm glad I did.  These fit absolutely perfect, didn't have to cut or squeeze or push anything.  They have absolutely no odor which was a pleasant surprise.  The color isn't a perfect match to the interior tan color of the Accord, but it's close enough, it doesn't bother me one bit.  I thought the plastic would be more slippery, but my shoes really don't slide around much on them.  I'm sure the carpet has more friction, but you can't have everything I guess.  I have two friends who have Weathertech's in their cars.  They were both curious and inspected these closely and both said that they seem equal in quality to theirs.Of course the true test will be this winter.  I will update this review in the spring.  Hopefully they are as durable as they look.  I also added a few photos to the product images, maybe that will help someone picture how they look in their cars.Update:I have had these for a few years now.  They have held up nicely.  I take them out every spring and clean them thoroughly.  Yes, they are starting to look a little used.  There are some scratches on them, and some dark marks from shoes.  But the carpet has stayed dry and when you pull these out it looks like new.  I am glad I bought them and still highly recommend them.  Originally I thought I would remove them during the summer and put the original mats back in, but I decided to keep them in the car all year round now.  We also had a baby and so the rear ones are making even more sense.

I bought this because we ran out of room with our surround tub, too many shampoos, conditioners, you name it.  This shower caddy is great.  Lots of room to put extra bottles.  The soap bars also fit on the bottom part, no more soggy soap bars falling into the shower/tub.  You can hang razors on it and a loofah.  Our surround tub is smooth plastic, so it's the ideal surface for it to stick on.  We have had it several months now, and it's still sticking even though it is crammed full of stuff.  It also looks pretty nice, not like a cheap add-on.  I definitely recommend it.

I like supporting "green" stuff.  But after trying this dishwashing soap, I was a little disappointed.  It has noticeably less degreasing / foaming / cleaning power than whatever random non-green soap I used to buy.  Since cleaning dishes efficiently is my priority, and this soap can't do that, I have to give it three stars.  I definitely commend Clorox for making green products, but I don't think I will buy this again.

I started with a cheapo Chinese door bell for a few bucks.  It lasted about three weeks and stopped working.  Mostly this was due to temperature fluctuations.So I gave this one a try.  I live in Ohio, and have had it from December through June now.  We have gone from an outside temperature of 15F to 95F.  The doorbell keeps on working.  There really isn't much more I can say about it, you can't ask more from a door bell than to reliably work for a long period.  This one has done just that so far.I like that it plugs in, one less battery I have to worry about.  The base unit is hidden behind some shelves, and it's still loud enough to be heard throughout the house and send the cats running for cover.

I received this the other day.  I desperately needed some more USB ports for all the gadgets which are accumulating around my computer these days.This mini hub seemed to fit the bill, cheap, good reviews, I gave it a shot.  In general I have to say it works quite well.  Windows 7 64bit recognized it right away.  Basic items such as jump drives which were plugged into the hub also worked as soon as the driver was installed.  So no problems there.Then I ran into a small glitch.  I play flight simulator and have a throttle and joystick attached to my computer.  Both are plugged directly into the computer USB ports, not into the hub.  But when the mini hub is plugged in, the throttle jumps around and is pretty much useless.  Not sure what the interaction is on the USB bus ports from a plugged in hub to a device plugged directly into the computer, but apparently it creates issues.  When I unplug it, it's fine.  I'm going to look into this issue, maybe there is some combination I can come up with which resolves this problem.One other minor complaint, the orange LED light which lights up when the mini hub is plugged in is really bright.  In a dark room, it is like a night light.  Probably wasn't necessary to make it that bright.All in all, it functions well, I'm hoping to fix this problem with my joystick, otherwise I will have to find another USB hub which I can leave permanently attached.  For now four stars...Update:Couldn't get rid of the problem.  So I'm not using it much.  It's a shame, but for most people this probably won't be an issue.  For my use, I will have to downgrade it to three stars.

I have a few metal European four color pens which are nice, but not perfect.  So I decided to try this one.  I was pleasantly surprised, the mechanism for sliding the different colors in and out works very smooth.  I hardly ever used the green color of my older pens, so I won't miss it in this one.One thing I was surprised over was that this pen is pretty thick.  Thicker than the four color pens I have.  That doesn't make a lot of sense and I do wish it was a little thinner.  However, it still fits in my shirt pocket, so it's ok.This pen writes very nice.  Much better than the four color pens I have.  It writes thin and the ink runs smooth and bold, no typical lighter areas which you get on cheap ball point pens.The one thing which irks me the most is that I didn't receive the white version.  I really wanted the pocket clip to be transparent so that the pen would be less visible.  I'm not going to subtract that from the pen, because it's the sellers fault to have the wrong picture on the product page.  If you are looking for the white version, be sure to ask the seller or verify the model numbers I suppose.  I did post a picture of the black pen I received.Edit: Seems like they finally put the correct product picture on the items page.

I am surprised that nobody has mentioned this.  My situation is that I am away from home randomly for a few days at a time.  So I wanted a feeder that I could turn on when I leave, and off when I am back.  I prefer feeding the cats myself when I am home, more accurate portion sizing and also wet food at times.  Either way, once you turn the unit off, it loses all information.  Time, feeding times and portion size.  I am by no means a newbie to technology and can program even a radio scanner from Radio Shack (that means something if you know what I am talking about), but this feeder is pretty tough to program.  So this is my point - every time I turn this feeder back on, I have to reprogram the time, the feeding schedule and the portion size.  I guess if I do this often enough, I will learn the programming steps, but it's a huge hassle.  I realize that I can program it to run for only so many days, but I sometimes don't make it home on the day I hope to, but the next day etc...I guess if you use this feeder 24/7, it does the job, but for someone who is in and out and wants to turn the unit off frequently, it's really not the perfect machine.Also, when I received it, one of the flaps on the bottom which are spring activated didn't seem to want to move.  I discovered it had some extra plastic from the manufacturing process and was sticking.  Had to use a knife to trim it down to the correct size.  Now it works fine.Update:I have had this feeder for about 4 months now.  I just changed the rating from 3 stars to 4 stars.  I have to say, it really is a reliable feeder.  The batteries are still going strong, they are the original ones.  It has never failed to dispense food and even though I have never measured it scientifically, it seems to dispense more or less the same amount every time.  I do have to say that I usually keep it fairly full though.  I still hate the fact that I can't turn it off without reprogramming, if they were to fix that issue, this would be a wonderful machine.My concoction for feeding two cats is still holding up too, I did post a picture on this page of what that looks like.  I used two pieces of rain gutter downspout and a pedestal I made.  Both cats have lost some weight thanks to not having a never ending supply of dry food while I'm gone.Update:I made myself a little cheat sheet for the programming process, printed it out and stuck it on the fridge.  Maybe it will help someone.  I use two feeding times.  Also I use the default "smallest" feeding portion, so I don't have to change that:1) Turn feeder on.2) Within 90 seconds, set time:3) Press "Clock" to set hour / press "Timer" to set minute4) Press "Set" to confirm.5) Press "Clock" to toggle between 12/24 hours.6) Press "Start" to confirm clock settings.7) Display now shows "1 07" (first feeding at 0700)8) Press "Set" for two seconds until display flashes.9) Press "Timer" to set desired feeding time.10) Press "Set" to program second feeding time.11) Press "Timer" to set desired feeding time.12) Press "Start" to save and exit.[To change portion size:]14) Push VOL key to display portion size.15) Press and hold the SET key until the digit blinks.16) Press the VOL key to set the portion size. [ 1 = 1/4 cup, 2 = 1/2 cup etc... ]17) Press the START key to confirm.Another update:Had the feeder for 15 months now.  Still works perfectly.  I've gotten used to its few quirks and am very happy with it.  Yeah, still could use a better user interface, but hey...  The four D cell batteries are finally getting low.  They have been in the feeder for 15 months now and it has been on every day.  Not shabby.One more Update:Had the unit for nearly exactly two years now. Still working perfectly twice a day without a break.  Still on the second set of D cell batteries. I'm changing the rating to five stars.  I really can't complain.  Yeah, I still would love to be able to turn it off and not lose all the settings.  I also wish that you could control the dispensing amount a little more accurately, but that wouldn't be easy seeing the way this machine is built.  But for the money, you do get a good value.  Still recommended, a little more highly now.  We just took our two cats to the vet, our "bigger" cat went from 18 pounds to 12 pounds. The vet praised us telling us that most people don't manage to bring their cats back down to a healthy weight. We told her that the feeder did it...  Now we have to make a little extra manual feeding when we are home so they don't lose more weight. This is where a smaller incremental increase in portion size would come in handy. Going from 1/4 cup to 1/2 cup is just too much.

I have been looking for the perfect walk around lens for a long time.  I have gone through most of the kit lenses, from the original 18-55 which had horrible optics, the next generation which was slightly better, and then the 18-55 kit lens with IS which really is quite good.  I did buy a Canon 17-40L and was not impressed with the image quality and range on the crop cameras, so I returned it.  I rented the Canon 17-55 2.8 IS which was a good lens.  The 2.8 was nice, but the range wasn't that great and I didn't think the image quality on it was that amazing either.So I gave this lens a try, and it's certainly a keeper.  The range is great, 15mm really satisfies your wide angle needs.  85mm also does a decent job of zooming in when needed.  Image quality is nothing short of amazing.  I'm impressed every time I upload my images to the computer how good a lens with this zoom range can be.  Tack sharp, even in the corners.  Colors are nice.  Only thing I don't like about it is the vignetting.  The 7D does a decent job of correcting it in-camera, but it's still visible under certain conditions.  Nothing you can't fix post processing, but it would be nice if you didn't have to worry about it.Image stabilization works well, I can't attest to whether it does the 4 stops, but I can certainly hand hold some shots that I could normally not.Build quality is nice.  The lens is very well balanced, hefty enough to make it stable, light enough not to be a brick on your camera.  It does creep a little in the mid zoom range if you hold it up or down.  Doesn't bother me that much.I would highly recommend this lens, yes, it's a little on the expensive side, but hey, it's still worth the images you end up with in the end.

These are nice bags, no doubt about it.  Well made and nice and plain.  Actually a tad small for shopping.  I'm giving it four stars because local stores are now selling very similar eco bags (granted, with their logos on them) for as little as one dollar per bag (Sears) which is a whole lot less than these.If you don't want a brand logo on your bags, these will do the job.  If you can deal with a logo, look around your local stores, you're likely to find cheaper solutions.

I bought this book on a whim.  Oddly enough, I had just read Ender's Game online because it's supposed to be a great classic.  I have to admit it was.  It is very apparent that the author had also read Ender's game, as this seems to be a modern version of it.  The book is well written and the storyline is very captivating.  When I read a good book like that, I always expect a big ending, but this book didn't offer a big ending unfortunately.  It just sort of fizzled out.  I still recommend this to anyone who is interested though, it's a very entertaining and thought inspiring story.

I bought this unit while it was on sale.  I had a Jeep which had the check engine light on.  It took me just a minute to follow the instructions, plug it in, read the codes and erase them.  That's all I bought this unit for, and it did that perfectly.  Highly recommended if all you want to do is to read the codes so you know what's wrong and then erase them.

My fiance gets frequent migraines.  I bought this mask for her just to see if it would work.  She fell in love with it.  She swears it's the best thing ever to help her soothe the pain.  I just ordered a second one so that she gets more useful time out of it.  If you put it in the freezer, it does get completely hard and does not fit well on the face.  However, as soon as it warms up a little it starts fitting itself to the face.  You can just put it in the fridge and it's also nice and cool, but frozen it definitely works longer.I would definitely recommend it.

Don't have too much to say about it.  This iron is well thought out and works just right.  It glides over clothes like no other iron I have owned.  The water refill nozzle is big enough in order to easily add water and it closes so that water doesn't spill everywhere when you move it around.  The cable also retracts without having to fight with it.  It's the best iron I have had so far...

This was my first R/C plane.  My first flight actually went without a major crash.  Just a couple of hard landings in the grass which didn't break anything major.  Later on as I became better, I performed more daring stunts and it received some damage, but nothing that rendered it un-flyable. I find that repairing the Cub is kind of fun also, and as you take it apart and modify it you learn a lot about the plane itself.The replacement parts are also very affordable, so if you do actually destroy something, it can be replaced without too much financial pain.  Depending on how much you push the motor, you get to fly it about 10-15 minutes on one battery charge.I bought a Muvi Veho camera for it, and you can tell that the Cub struggles a little bit with the extra weight, but it still easily goes to altitude and takes fun airborne footage.I adjusted the elevator servo one notch so that it has more up travel than down.  This REALLY helps landing the Cub as you have more up elevator as you come in and during the rollout.I used the ACT crash protection once, and it stopped my prop on take off and the plane crashed, I never turned it on again...I think I have learned how to fly the Cub quite well now, being able to fly it inverted and buzz through the goal posts of the local (empty) soccer field.  I now want something that has more power for better climb performance and ailerons.  I'm looking at the T-28 Trojan form the same company.If you are thinking about getting into R/C airplanes, you really can't beat this Cub.  It takes a lot of abuse, is easy to fly and very affordable.

I bought this about a year ago.  The unit has a lot of potential, but plenty of issues.First issue is that the remote control needs to be aimed DIRECTLY at the unit, or it will not work.  This can be very frustrating.The second most annoying feature is that you can not record something and watch something else at the same time.  That means that if my girlfriend has programmed the unit to record a certain show, I am forced to watch whatever she programmed in order to not interrupt her recording.This has some minor sub-issues.  If I am time shifting a live TV show, and a program is about to record, it will just start recording and stops the time shift without warning.  This drives me up the wall every time it happens.Another issue is that if the power fails, even for a second, the unit will lose the time setting and all timer programs disappear.  If you have let's say 10 shows programmed to record, it's really annoying to have to re-program them again every time there is bad weather.Changing channels also takes several seconds, which can be annoying.I never record anything on DVD, so I can't report on this feature.Besides these issues, the unit is great.  I use it with a roof antenna, and all the channels come in fantastic quality in HD.  When it does record shows, it works wonderful.I do wish there was more choice of DVR's out there.  I don't understand why there isn't.  For now, I don't see any better options out there than this unit

I bought the Squeezebox on a bit of a whim because I was thoroughly tired of the local radio stations.  I also lived abroad for a long time, so the temptation to listen to my old "home" stations was big.  I was contemplating a HD radio, but that really would have just brought the local junk stations in clearer...All in all I am extremely happy with the Squeezebox.  I read some reviews here before I bought it, so I already opened a account with Logitech.  Start-up was easy, plug it in, find your wireless network, enter the password.  It did do a firmware update and then I was ready to play.The choices of stations are really overwhelming.  I didn't know what to listen to at first.  And this was only the "Internet Radio" option.I then added Pandora which was very simple.  Highly recommended.  Even more music choices and no commercials.I know there are even more things you can do with it, but right now I'm happy with the thousands of stations already available to me.I hooked the Squeezebox into my big stereo via a 3.5mm-RCA cable from the headphone jack in the Squeezebox to the AUX input in my stereo.  The sound from the Squeezebox alone is very nice, through the stereo it's amazing.I never tried the Alarm Clock functions of the Squeezebox, so I can't comment on those.The Squeezebox looks very nice.  No complaints there.  I also like the fact that the display dims and gets really dark when the room is dark, which I really like.  Most alarm clocks still light up the room at night, the Squeezebox does not.Reception around the house is great.  In my living room which is about 40 feet and two walls from the router, it reports full signal strength, better than my laptops.  Never had any reception problems.  Of course, it does take a little hit on the available internet bandwidth, but not enough to really notice or be bothersome.My biggest issue is that the Squeezebox only has 6 actual station memory buttons.  With the ability to have so many choices, they should have really tried to add some more buttons for simplicity.  It's not a deal killer though.  Also the whole search process (entering the letters via the wheel controller) can be tedious.  But again, I enjoy the new radio experience enough to overlook all that.If there was a Squeezebox II, I would like to see maybe a small pull out keyboard or a remote with a little keyboard.  That would be fantastic.But as for now, if you are contemplating getting a internet radio, you should really give this one a shot.  I am having way more fun with it than I thought I would.

I bought this flashlight on sale at a local store.  I am really impressed with it.  Despite the fact that it is smaller than my 2 AA LED Maglite, it is brighter.  It is nearly as bright as my 2 AA Inova Bolt flashlight.  Quite a performance.  The light it throws has a very strong center and then falls off quickly in contrast to the others which light up the area around it much more.It is odd that the description states that this light uses 3 AAA batteries.  There are other places on the internet which do the same.  Life Gear does have a 3 AAA light, but it looks different with a larger reflector and has the push button on the side, compared to this 1 AA one which has the switch on the back.If you need a compact but bright flashlight which doesn't cost a fortune, then this should fit the bill.  Highly recommended.

Bought the Orange Box for PS3 because it was so cheap and everyone ranted and raved about it.  I didn't really expect that much.  A few months later I couldn't believe I had finished all the episodes and am hoping for more.  Half Life is incredible.  The story line is wonderful, the graphics are stunning, you really get immersed into this game.  The game isn't easy, but it's never so hard that you want to give up or get bored.  It's really the perfect mix.  I think, overall, this may be the best game I have ever played.  Now I am eagerly awaiting Episode 3...

It's true, this book is a little gruesome at times. However, I remember my parents reading it to me when I was a kid.  And I didn't see it as gruesome, it was just outrageously exciting.  It's one of the few books which really stand out from my childhood - in a positive way.  I would definitely read this to my kids, or let them read it.  And to this day I still enjoy reading it myself.  I highly recommend it.

I am a complete novice when it comes to underwater photography - not above water though...  So I had the G10 and was going to Belize on vacation for sun and fun and snorcheling.  I decided to buy this case as it actually seemed quite reasonable for what it offers. Let's get to it.I will list the cons first.* The plastic of the case is rather soft, so even though I only went on three snorcheling trips with it, I ended up with a ton of scratches on it, and I WAS trying to be very careful.* The plastic of the case - and across the display - is very glossy.  So when you are snorcheling close to the surface and the sun is shining, you can barely see anything on the display, it is just reflecting the brightness of the sea surface above you.  I assume this would not be as much of a problem if you are scuba diving and further down in the water.* Being spoiled from the ability to change just about any setting on this camera while it is in its case, it is a shame you can't manipulate the ring control in the back which changes aperture or shutter speed depending on which mode you are in.Neutral:* The flash works surprisingly well under water, however just for very short distances.  It is also very close to the lens so that if the water is not perfectly clear, it will light up every dirt molecule and render the picture worthless.* The case is surprisingly large.  Originally I thought this might be a nice combo for the beach or in general maybe in the rain - but the case is about the size of a Canon XTi with a 18-55mm lens on it and really too large to casually carry with you to the beach etc...  Also, at a beach in the sand I would be very worried again about scratching the plastic.* You should know your camera well because the labels on the buttons are just stamped into the clear plastic and you really can't decipher them under water.Positives:* Just about everything else.  The case is easy to use and all the buttons are accessible (except the ring as I mentioned).  The case is completely waterproof, I didn't have one hint of water inside it.  I did take it down to about 25 feet a few times.I really enjoyed taking my G10 under water.
