Even the upstart cost-cutting mini grocers sell No. 4 cone coffee filters at boutique prices.Rockline is the second-biggest American producer of Melitta-type cone filters and the No. 1 producer of private label brands, so I know they can be trusted. Maybe my taste buds are pedestrian but I can't detect a difference in flavor when I brew 100% Colombian coffee with these filters or with unbleached filters.  Similarly, the "flavor pores" and rippled texture of the leading brand don't seem to make much difference.  Where I really feel it is in my wallet.  When I get down to the last bag, I bundle these into an order that's eligible for free shipping.As to sturdiness, I've never have one blow apart.  Just remember to fold and crease the crimped seam before placing the filter in the basket, and when the coffee's brewed, grab the filter by the folded seam to lift it out.

When I lost my job in June of 2011, I lost my health coverage and prescription plan as well.  After the amlodipine ran out, I sought out a supplement alternative and found Michael's Blood Pressure Factors.  I had always viewed supplements as "can't hurt, might help".Today I gave blood at the Red Cross Bloodmobile in our church's parking lot.  When the technician said my blood pressure was 120 over 84 without any comments like "That's a little high" or "Are you taking anything for your blood pressure?", I had to ask "Is that good?"She replied "It's fine."  And this was a few hours after having a 20-ounce mug of coffee with breakfast.Now that I'm working again, I'll soon be eligible for health coverage.  I'll see what the doctor says after a thorough examination and report back.  Stay tuned!

Just because you're in tech support, it doesn't mean you can't wear a working man's polo shirt.  These Dickies shirts, especially in black, fit the need.  The extra long cut means no "plumber's crack" when you need to dive under a desk to hook up a printer or plug in a network cable.  And if you should get some printer or copier toner on your hands, just wipe 'em off on your shirt and remember to use COLD water on laundry day.The wicking properties mop up a lot of perspiration with minimal salt trails, i.e.: no more wisecracks like "Is that a map of Antarctica on your back?"Order up enough for a week's wear and you'll be set.

My less-geeky-than-me wife is happy to have my hand-me-down MacBook Pro when hers no longer runs the current version of Mac OS.  When it's time to do the dance, this cable comes into play, providing a fast, easy transfer, first of my data from my MacBook Pro to a new (well, refurbished) one, then from hers to my old one.  At FireWire speed, the whole process is done in barely an hour per machine.It'll be a while before we do it all over again because both MacBooks run Mountain Lion, but it's nice to be ready.

A 10:00am cup of coffee that was brewed at 7:00 in the morning is usually lukewarm enough to be used as a mouth rinse.  Not so with this Thermos Nissan bottle.  I preheat it for 10 minutes with water boiled in an electric kettle, empty it and pour in the Joe.  Hours later, it's still steaming, and the flavor has been preserved in a sort of suspended animation.  When the coffee's gone, a minute's shake with a little hot tap water and a few drops of dishwashing liquid, a couple rinses and it's ready for a night in the dish rack before going back to work in the morning.It might not be as pretty as an air pot or carafe, but it does the job and it's easier to clean.

Amazon.com is littered with cheap iPod, iPad and iPhone chargers that all share a common flaw: they don't charge certain iPods, iPads and iPhones.  As many disgruntled shoppers have discovered, it's a crap shoot.  What works with a friend's identical iPhone doesn't work with theirs.Some are potentially dangerous counterfeits of Apple's charging cube labeled "Designed Abble in California" instead of "Designed by Apple in California". If they're faking the shape and the Abble, uh, Apple name, you think the UL stamp is legit, too?  If you need an extra or a replacement charger, consider this one from Monoprice.  It's not the cheapest but you can't put a price on safety.  It meets Apple's OEM specs, so you won't get the dreaded "Charging is not supported with this accessory" warning.  Since the cord is permanently attached, you're less likely to lose it.

Cathy replaced our old worn Chinese stoneware dishes with two of these sets so we'd have enough for company. Amazingly, the eight place settings stack in a fraction of the space the old stuff occupied, and the bowls nest so well there's no danger of them toppling when you lift them to reach for a dinner plate or a bread 'n' butter plate. They've become our everyday dishes.  The entire stack is barely half the height of our glazed terra cotta dishes.The plates and bowls shrug off knife marks, spoon trails and fork scratches as if you were eating with plastic utensils. A trip through the dishwasher and they sparkle like new. The old stuff was so scarred, half a can of Bar Keeper's Friend couldn't rub out the damage.Call me sentimental but every time I set the table or grab a plate for a quick bite, I just have to turn it over and see the phrase MADE IN USA.And, yes, I know the mugs now come from places like China and Thailand. If only World Kitchen would bring back American-made white Pyrex (anyone remember it?) or even Corning Pyroceram from France as the base material for the mugs. Ah, well. . .

When we lent (and never got back) the clips that came with our Behringer C-2 mics, a pair of these clips were the perfect replacements.  The jaws are lined with a grippy foam that hugs the lipstick-sized C-2s but also caresses the tapering ice cream cone body of, say, a Shure SM58 or a Samson R21.  They're compact enough to fit the case that comes with the Behringer mics and priced for the musician on a budget.

I make four pounds of meatball mix at a time and freeze one-pound portions in FoodSaver bags.  When I have the time, I defrost a bag overnight in the refrigerator, but if it's early enough in the day and we decide on spaghetti and meatballs for dinner, this reversible griddle becomes the perfect defroster.I put the unopened bag on the smooth side and park it in a cold oven to avoid drafts.  Two hours later, the meatball mix has thawed enough to work with.  The interior is a little firm but not rock-hard frozen, and any temperature difference will equalize during the shaping and roasting.If you never use it as a griddle or grill, the convenience of safe, fast defrosting is worth the price.

Seems Culligan has heard our pleas and read the reviews here and at Consumer Reports.  CR rated Culligan's faucet filter at the top of the pack but gave it only a fair rating for water flow.  Our most recent replacements were made in 2012 and filter the water at a faster rate.  Instead of an anemic dribble, the filtered water comes out in a solid stream that fills a gallon pitcher in a minute and 6 seconds.  I don't even mind waiting to fill a stockpot with filtered water for cooking pasta.

When ants follow trails, you can usually track them to the point of entry and use a spray. But when you're dealing with ants that wander aimlessly and avoid bait traps, this is what to reach for.We previously had infestations of such ants in our bathrooms, which was odd given the lack of food. We set off the fumigators right before heading out for the evening, making sure to stay out of the house for the required 3 hours. The fumigators didn't just kill the ants, it chased them away. There were no li'l corpses to sweep up and no re-infestation over a year later.Most recently, our kitchen was invaded by another army of wanderers, some of whom traveled inside our gas range. One fumigator and 3 hours later, they had bugged out (intentional bad pun) and haven't been back. Since it's a smoke, it doesn't leave any aerosol residue behind.

When ants follow trails, you can usually track them to the point of entry and use a spray.  But when you're dealing with ants that wander aimlessly and avoid bait traps, this is what to reach for.We previously had infestations of such ants in our bathrooms, which was odd given the lack of food.  We set off the fumigators right before heading out for the evening, making sure to stay out of the house for the required 3 hours.  The fumigators didn't just kill the ants, it chased them away.  There were no li'l corpses to sweep up and no re-infestation over a year later.Most recently, our kitchen was invaded by another army of wanderers, some of whom traveled inside our gas range.  One fumigator and 3 hours later, they had bugged out (intentional bad pun) and haven't been back.  Since it's a smoke, it doesn't leave any aerosol residue behind.

Buy a pressure cooker if you think you'll use it at least once a week.Buy this Fagor Splendid pressure cooker set and you'll use it a lot more often. At home on ANY kind of range (smooth-top or coil electric, gas, induction), the two pots and their interchangeable lids add versatility to speed, and that equals more bang for your cookware buck (pardon the bad pun). The glass lid turns the 8-quart pot into a handy stockpot or pasta boiler. Put the lid on the 4-quart pan and, voila, it becomes that extra saucepan you never seem to have when you really, really need one. When dinner's ready but you're not (pressure cookers are rocket-fast, you know), replace the pressure lid with the glass lid to keep it warm without overcooking or drying out.The stainless steel basket isn't big enough to hold a pound of long dry pasta, despite the photo, but it's the vessel of choice for shorter cuts like penne and rotelle, and for blanching filled pastas like ravioli and pirogies. Set it atop the trivet and it becomes the perfect steamer, whether you use the glass or pressure lid. And if it happens to fit a pot you already own, consider it a bonus.Fagor pressure cookers are among the easiest to use and care for. Instead of a wobbling weight or a ringed post pressure indicator, Fagor uses a spring-loaded pressure regulator. Heat the cooker on high heat until steam begins to flow from the regulator, start your timer and then back off the heat to maintain a steady gentle hiss. Once you've found your stove's sweet spot, you're not chained to the cooktop. As long as you can see steam or hear the hiss, you can go about your other cooking tasks. Wobbling weight regulators can be thrown off if the pot is jostled, and sealed-system pressure cookers require a constant eye on the number of visible rings. The regulator is also the pressure release valve, engineered so that the steam dissipates and cools quickly. At six inches from the vent, the steam is warm but not hot enough to burn your skin. Remember, this is steam that's 250 degrees Fahrenheit when it's under pressure!To keep the cook safe, Fagor pressure cookers have three locking mechanisms. The manual latch engages a pressure-activated locking pin that rises as pressure builds, keeping the cooker locked as long as pressure is present. The pressure itself pushes the flanges on the lid and pot together, creating a natural locking action. You'd have to be built like Mister Universe to force open a pressurized cooker. A small cutout in the lid exposes a portion of the gasket. If the pressure has no other way out, the gasket will stretch or snap, but will stay in place while the pressure escapes through the rim of the lid, not into the cook's face.Odds are, whatever you pressure cook in one pot will be served with something you can prepare in the other as well. We use the 4-quart pot to pressure cook spaghetti sauce with quarter-pound meatballs in just 10 minutes under pressure, while the 8-quart pot and glass lid take care of the spaghetti. Every piece in the set, except the pressure lid and gasket, can go in the dishwasher. Your humble author uses Bar Keeper's Friend to take care of any really tough discoloration. Keeping the gasket clean is easy because it's so easy to remove and replace. With weekly use and proper care, a gasket lasts about 12 to 18 months. The money you save on energy will more than pay for a new gasket.If you've never heard of Fagor or you're wondering if it's a brand a pro would use, just note how many are used in a typical episode of Iron Chef America.  Can you think of a better endorsement?

Why do internet service providers provide such wimpy phone line cords with their DSL modems and gateways?  It's almost as if they don't want you to get the speed you're paying for.  If the phone line is static-free but hammered by external interference from CFL bulbs, cordless phones and even the Wi-Fi signal from the router or gateway, your ISP compensates by momentarily disconnecting the line and reconnecting at the next lower speed.  Even worse, it's a one-way street.  Once the speed has dropped, it won't go back up unless you cold-boot the modem or gateway.  Log into the modem's setup screen and check its connection speed (don't log into the router's setup screen and don't use a site like speedtest.net for this).  Ideally, it should be at least 80% of the promised speed.  If it's not, this cable might be what you need.The shielding reduces external interference so the wire can deliver every megabit to your modem with fewer re-sends and dropped packets.  Get it along with a heavy-duty noise filtering surge suppressor like the Furman SS-6B Steel Power Strip and Amazon pays for the shipping.  Combined, they could make all the difference between getting all the speed you can instead of settling for what you get.

I use this opener on every can, including those with pull-off lids.  When you yank the lid off or open a regular can with a conventional can opener, two sharp edges are waiting to wreak havoc: the lid itself and a sharp rim that juts a few millimeters into the can's opening.  It chews up rubber and silicone spatulas and, given half a chance, will slit your finger as you go after that last bit of carrot from a can of ready-to-serve chunky chicken noodle soup.  If you like to store your coffee in a canister or some other resealable container, that rim thwarts your efforts to empty the can.With this opener, every can from a 6-ouncer containing tomato paste to that aforementioned coffee can opens safely, neatly and with nothing in the way of the contents.

Shred a credit card statement, the DSL drops.  The cordless phone rings, the DSL drops.  Turn on a lamp (with CFL bulbs), the DSL drops.After trying all the usual fixes (plug the DSL gateway into a separate circuit with its own surge suppressor power strip, move it farther away from the cordless phone, coil up the slack in the DSL modem cable) it became clear we needed something even stronger.  If this Furman power strip can filter out power line noise for DJs and musicians, could it do the same for computer gear?Yes.  I even thrash-tested it by rapidly flipping the reverse switch on the document shredder to bombard the room with EMI mini-bursts, calling my home phone from my iPhone and flickering the lights on and off.  The line stayed up, and has done so since I replaced the wimpy power strip with this one.  The faster your DSL line, the more you need this kind of power protection.  It won't fix problems on the DSL line itself, but it will deliver clean noise-free power to your DSL modem or gateway, and many times, that's all you need.

Things sure have changed since I gave my mother a Presto Harvest Gold pressure cooker back in the last century. Fagor replaces the wobbling weight with a captive spring-loaded pressure regulator. Instead of a rubber plug that blasts out of the lid in the event of excess pressure, the Fagor's emergency release is a cutout portion of the lid that exposes part of the gasket. The gasket stretches but if it should snap, it would stay in place and the steam would escape out the side, not into the cook's face. To earn the Underwriters' Laboratories seal, Fagor pressure cookers feature a pressure-activated safety lock in addition to the manual latch. You'd have to be built like Mister Universe to force open a pressurized cooker.In operation, the Fagor behaves a little differently than a weight-regulated pressure cooker. On the latter, you have to determine if the weight is wobbling at just the right rhythm. The weight should waggle but not bang against the vent stem. With the Fagor, all you have to see or hear is a gentle constant flow of steam. The regulator knob is also the release valve, should you wish to depressurize the cooker immediately instead of allowing the pressure to drop naturally. The steam is routed through a fan-shaped outlet, allowing it to disperse and cool quickly. At six inches from the outlet, the steam is warm but not burning hot.So far, the cooker has performed as promised. Lentil soup with diced smoked sausage cooked up thick and flavorful in just 10 minutes under pressure. Ditto for spaghetti sauce and whole links of Italian sausage. The sauce had intense flavors of garlic and herbs, and the sausage came out juicy with a hint of snap in the casing. Three pounds of diced red potatoes and the peeled cloves from a whole bulb of garlic were ready to mash in 6 minutes.The amazingly short cooking times omit the time required for the cooker to come up to pressure which can take about 10 minutes. Still, you save a lot of time overall.Keeping the all-important gasket clean is a cinch because it's so easy to remove and replace. The lid and pot are made of gleaming 18/10 stainless steel with an encapsulated aluminum base that cooks over any gas or electric heat source as well as the latest induction cooktops. When it's time to clean up, you can use cleaners like Bar Keeper's Friend on the inside and out, but if the discoloration is from cooking lentils, split peas, potatoes or beans, it's iron and other minerals that are good for you. Just wash and dry the pot and put it away until you're ready to prepare spaghetti sauce or some other high acidity recipe. You'll get back a little nutrition and you won't have to scour your pressure cooker.

With nearly the same footprint and dimensions as the printer it replaced in our house, the Brother HL-2270DW begs the question: "Where did they hide the duplexer?"  If you're an IT support tech, the mention of the word "duplexer" usually causes you to cringe because you tend to hear it as "Oh, Joe!  The printer in Human Resources won't print!  It says 'DUPLEXER ERROR'!"  In office printers, the duplexer is a big complicated Rube Goldberg contraption prone to jamming, usually around page 71 of a 75-page print job.  Its job is intercepting each sheet of paper after the first side has been printed, flipping and orienting it correctly and sending it back through the printer's imaging engine.  When all goes well (about as often as planetary grand alignments), each sheet emerges printed on both sides, saving paper (thus, trees).In this Brother SoHo printer, the duplexer is so well integrated and so far, so reliable, you're almost tempted to attribute its performance to pixies.  Contrary to others' experiences, every Mac in the house found this printer on the first try after I added it to our WiFi network using the USB cable method.  Setting it up in Windows 7 running under Boot Camp required manually configuring a TCP/IP port.There's not much to say about the print quality except, if you can't see the difference, why pay the difference for a more expensive printer?  If at least half of what you print is black and white text, and you want to save paper doing it, look no further.

An online small appliance parts store wants twenty bucks plus tax and shipping for a replacement carafe for our DeLonghi coffeemaker.  We've been cleaning the tank regularly with vinegar, so we might just get a decade's use out of it.  When the original carafe developed a dribble near the spout I went shopping for a replacement here on Amazon.com and read more about this one on Medelco's website [medelcoinc(dot)com].At about half the price and with FREE Super Saver Shipping, this one wins the prize.  As recommended on the "Product Fits List" at Medelco's website, I removed the pause-n-pour mechanism since we never steal a cup before the coffee's ready.  With the flatter of the two supplied lids, the carafe slips in and out smoothly and just looks sleeker and more modern than the cylindrical original.  Best of all, we no longer have to lean over the kitchen sink when we pour.

"Holy frickin' moly!" comes close.  "Miracle"?  Perhaps a little too powerful.I plugged a pair of Sylvania Silverstar Ultra headlights into my 1996 Subaru Legacy sedan and . . . bleah.  Where's that intense white near-HID light I paid for?!A non-abrasive headlight restoration kit yielded negligible results.  The Manny-Moe-Jack chain wanted at least half a C-note as did my trusted shadetree mechanic.  When I asked him about the 3M kit, he admitted, "It's what we use."  Next stop: Amazon.com.I read the reviews, watched the video and gambled the price at the local O'Reilly (I was impatient) where the counter guy continued the litany of praise.  Armed with my Ryobi 18 volt drill and the rest of the required tools, I plunged right in and restored the headlight with the worst corrosion, including a snowy white oxidized silhouette of a mountain range along the bottom.  I was skeptical, believing nothing would remove the oxidation.  Amazingly, it sanded right out.  Upon completion, I stepped back and reveled for a few moments in the difference.  After a battery recharge (yes, it takes the power of 2 battery packs per headlight), I finished the task and topped it off with a quick trip to an automated car wash to remove the restoration residue.  A bottle of 3M's lens cleaner and protectant is on its way from Amazon.comAnd, yes, I've posted a before-and-after photo.

Fresh & Easy, like many cost-cutting grocers, packs their old-fashioned rolled oats in a plastic bag.  Reusing the cardboard canister from another brand runs the risk of rancidity, since the cardboard absorbs a small amount of the natural oils in the oats.What's good for cold cereal is also good for hot so I grabbed one of these on a trip to Fresh & Easy.  Like all Klip It products, this cereal keeper is built to last, with real hinges for the blue locking clips and the pour spout.  No part is engineered to fail. Between fillings, you can take it completely apart, put the parts in the dishwasher (I've loaded the bin in the bottom rack without warping from the drying cycle) and know it'll come out cleaner than you can wash it by hand.

Seems when Sennheiser discontinues a headphone, like my wife's HD 435, they discontinue critical replacement parts as well.  They sell replacement ear cushions but if you break the cable, they expect you to buy a new headphone.We needed to replace the cable and the inline volume control wasn't really an issue.  A straight 3.5mm male-to-male would be fine.  Problem is, most have big chunky ends that won't seat into the headphone's left earcup.  Another online seller was extorting, er, uh, asking almost $60 for the cable with the inline volume control.  Sorry, nope, not gonna pay it.A quick search of Amazon.com turned up this one so she decided to gamble the price.  Jackpot!  It's a perfect fit and either end serves either purpose (plugging into the headphone or plugging into the headphone jack).

When you chuck a can of coffee into the freezer, the plastic lid can stiffen to the point that it splits and cracks when you try to pull it off.  I found this container at Fresh & Easy so I put it in my cart with a large can of coffee.  Unlike many plastic containers, no part is engineered to fail.  It's big enough to handle the entire contents of the can and the lid snaps on nice and tight.  Since you don't have to flex the lid to take it off, it's less likely to crack.  The blue sealing liner and the hinged locking clips seal out air and keep the coffee fresh until, well, the last drop.

If you've reinstalled Windows just once in your life, you've learned enough to tackle a full virgin installation of Windows 7 from a system builder DVD. Microsoft has finally created an operating system with so much built-in support and maintenance technology it practically does all the work for you, so if your current Windows XP machine is labeled "Windows Vista Capable" or "Windows 7 Capable," this is the way to go. Just to be sure, install and run Microsoft's Upgrade Advisor.  If it passes the 64-bit system requirements, order up!You can't upgrade from XP to 7; you have to wipe the drive or partition and perform a clean install, but even an upgrade from Vista to 7 is fraught with peril, so you might as well do the same if you're running Vista. Just back up your data and find all your application installation software before you begin. Once you activate Windows 7, it's married to the PC's system board. You can't reuse the product key on another machine unless you can convince Microsoft that the previous PC is out of commission. You're also not eligible for free phone and chat support from Microsoft, but there's a big enough expert user base that you should be able to solve most problems by joining a few Windows 7 users' forums. If you're not building an exotic tricked-out übergamingmaschine with overclocked handmade graphics cards, you shouldn't have much trouble that will require outside help. Your humble author installed Windows 7 64-bit on a MacBook Pro using Boot Camp.  It found our Brother WiFi laser printer and installed the latest drivers and Brother's printer control center.The biggest advantage: you'll skip all the "enhanced experience" software the likes of Dell, HP and Lenovo cram onto their otherwise zippy machines. After the latest updates install, head off to microsoft dot com slash securityessentials and you'll get all the virus and malware protection you'll need absolutely FREE. Pay a visit to your PC maker's website, let 'em scan your system and grab all the latest hardware drivers.With a system builder DVD, you don't get both the 32-bit and 64-bit versions.  If you should find that 64-bit isn't right for your machine, don't fret.  Just Google the phrase "legal windows 7 download" and the first match will show you how to create a 32-bit installation DVD that you can activate on the same PC using the product key from the 64-bit DVD.  The new installation wipes out the old one and that keeps everything legal.

If you've reinstalled Windows just once in your life, you've learned enough to tackle a full virgin installation of Windows 7 from an OEM copy. Microsoft has finally created an operating system with so much built-in support and maintenance technology it practically does all the work for you, so if your current Windows XP machine is labeled "Windows Vista Capable" or "Windows 7 Capable," this is the way to go.  Just to be sure, install and run Microsoft's Upgrade Advisor.You can't upgrade from XP to 7; you have to wipe the drive or partition and perform a clean install, but even an upgrade from Vista to 7 is fraught with peril, so you might as well do the same if you're running Vista. Just back up your data and find all your application installation software before you begin. Once you activate this OEM version, it's married to the PC's system board. You can't reuse the product key on another machine unless you can convince Microsoft that the previous PC is out of commission. You're also not eligible for free phone and chat support from Microsoft, but there's a big enough expert user base that you should be able to solve most problems by joining a few Windows 7 users' forums. If you're not building an exotic tricked-out übergamingmaschine with overclocked handmade graphics cards, you shouldn't have much trouble that will require outside help. Your humble author installed Windows 7 32-bit on a late-2006 Apple iMac using Boot Camp.  Windows Update found a better driver for the ATI Radeon X1600 display adapter than Apple provides.The biggest advantage: you'll skip all the "enhanced experience" software the likes of Dell, HP and Lenovo cram onto their otherwise zippy machines. After the latest updates install, head off to microsoft dot com slash securityessentials and you'll get all the virus and malware protection you'll need absolutely FREE. Pay a visit to your PC maker's website, let 'em scan your system and grab all the latest hardware drivers.With the OEM version, you don't get both the 32-bit and 64-bit versions. For most users bringing along their XP-generation software and most peripherals, 32-bit is the best choice, especially on PCs with a maximum capacity of 4GB of RAM. If your PC has one of the latest Intel Core i-series processors, you'll reap the benefits of Hyper-threading, giving you the performance of 4 32-bit cores. Opt for the 64-bit version if you have a PC with a Core 2 Duo processor or better and have boosted the RAM beyond 4GB.So, if you're ready for Windows 7 and don't have a pile of cash to burn for the full retail version, order up and have a ball!

Before we replaced our hardware store house brand garbage disposer with a new Waste King (which liquefies food waste instead of turning it into sewer pesto), kitchen sink drain clogs were at least a twice-a-year event.  A SoCal plumber advertises on the radio that he'll clear almost any clog for "just $99", so I'm already a few hundred bucks ahead.Most recently, I used the Drain King to blast a clog out of a slow shower drain at my mother's house.  A plumber had ballparked an estimate of around $2,500 for a worst-case scenario after repeated uses of chemical drain cleaners and plungers had failed.  With nothing to lose, I called in the Drain King and His Majesty did not disappoint.  A nearby garden hose was long enough to reach to the shower drain, so I shoved the Drain King in as far as it would go and held it in place while my mother turned on the water.  The Drain King sang its distinctive song.  I knew it was working because if the water had backed up with nowhere to go, the pulsating sound would have slowed to a stop.  Instead, I let it work for a full five minutes, followed by a 10-minute hot water flush.Clean drain, happy mother, and another $99 saved.  Long live the King!

The feed tube on our Black & Decker food processor's work bowl went to pieces while I was washing it, so it was off to Consumer Reports' web site in March of 2011 for advice on buying a replacement.  I wanted the highest rated Recommended or Best Buy model I could afford.  Seeing this KitchenAid 7-cupper among the likes of Cuisinart at half the price and a single point lower in score than the top-rated model was the clincher.  Next stop: right here.I just finished putting it through its paces preparing the onions and bell peppers for my pressure cooker marinara sauce.  The first thing one notices is its quiet purposeful drone, not an ear-splitting whine reminiscent of a circular saw.  With the slicing disk in place, it sliced the onions and peppers into perfect strings, ready to release their flavors into the sauce.  Next, I switched to the blade and pureed the tomato paste with half of the beef broth in my recipe.  I rinsed the San Marzano plum tomato cans with the remaining broth and poured it into the bowl to rinse out the rest of the tomato paste mixture.Cleanup is easy because every removable part is dishwasher-safe and KitchenAid includes a handy spatula that fits into the various nooks and crannies.  You can wrap a dishtowel around it to dry the rim in the work bowl lid.As to ruggedness, I'm a "take care of your tools and they'll take care of you" kind of guy, so I expect it to outlast the B&D.  Updates as they happen.

One of the previous owners of our house installed a hardware chain store's house brand 1/3 horsepower food waste disposer but left the IN-SINK-ERATOR drain flange in place.  We had been doing the dishes with the help of an impostor, and not a very good one.  When it came time to replace it, we ordered up this one and my building inspector brother-in-law was happy to put it in, insisting that we install the new WASTE KING drain flange so the world would know we made a good choice.True to everyone else's experience, removing the old 3-bolt mount unit took more time and effort than installing the Waste King.  Once it was in, we treated it to its first meal: chicken bones from Popeyes.  Though it lacks the sound shielding of its costlier siblings, the Waste King L-1001 purrs quietly enough to let you carry on a conversation and the grinding noise is just loud enough to tell you it's doing the job.  You can also hear the higher RPMs (2,600 versus 1,800 or so).If you buy a Waste King, don't be alarmed by the loud CLANK! when you switch it on (If you're an ancient IT pro, it'll remind you of the loud startup click emitted by certain early hard disk drives).  According to the documentation, it's the anti-jam swivel impellers swinging into place.  If it sounds like it's laboring, it's really raising the torque to handle tougher food waste.  Our maiden voyage confirmed that.  It plowed through the bones, a few at a time, in a couple minutes and then resumed its quiet throaty drone when the job was done.

Even if you never venture out to antique malls and estate sales, The Complete Guide to Corning Ware & Visions Cookware is a stroll through the department and discount stores that line Memory Lane.  After a quick and concise history of the laboratory accident and marketing blunder* that launched one of the most successful cookware empires of the 20th Century, it's off to the hunt!  Wherever possible, photos make it easy to identify specific patterns.  Coroneos includes some of the true rarities like exclusive promotional and corporate designs as well as licensed accessories (anyone remember GEMCO Ware?).Because of its shorter original lifespan and smaller selection, fewer pages are devoted to Visions, the see-through amber cousin of Corning Ware Pyroceram.  The book's release was obviously timed to come as close to the 50th anniversary of the Corning Ware brand as possible, but had the author waited he would have been able to expand the book to include the re-launch of CorningWare Pyroceram and the expansion of the Visions line in 2008.  Responding to consumer demand, World Kitchen Inc. didn't want to observe the golden anniversary with only the stoneware bearing the "CorningWare" name.  But as it is, the book still gets 5 stars for the author's depth of research and the pages of nostalgic eye candy.*Did you know that market research indicated American consumers preferred a wheat motif over the original Blue Cornflower design? Corning was impatient to get the product to market and went with the second but ultimately iconic choice.

Far too often, snazzy jazzy styling is wrapped around mediocre hardware. Not so with these headphones. To anyone who complains of too much bass, too much treble, an unnatural soundfield, and so on and so on: check your gear. Flatten your EQ. Switch off SRS and other sound enhancement. Disable genre presets like Rock, Vocal, Jazz, etc. The frequency response on these phones is so nearly perfect they deliver the good (the original source material) with the bad (misapplied sonic embellishment). If you must equalize, use a light touch and you'll achieve listening Nirvana.When I stripped my entire iTunes library of EQ and volume presets, the sound came alive with the kind of all-around-you presence that had me looking over my shoulder more than once. As to fit and comfort, they're a tad weighty when you first put them on, but like a pair of eyeglasses, you eventually forget that they're there. As an eyeglass wearer, I tried them with and without my glasses. I couldn't detect a difference in bass response and overall sound quality. The cushions effectively seal off the outside world, even with eyeglasses. I have yet to wear them over my glasses and the headband microphone I wear when singing in the choir and running the sound mixer at church, but they seem up to the task of letting me sing and monitor the mix at the same time.

Yeah, I know, you think someone's been inhaling industrial adhesives down at the local Home Depot, but, hey, nearly everyone on Food Network from Alton Brown to Ina Garten says the hardware store is the best place for many kitchen tools.Somehow, I lost the clamp that came with my pasta machine.  I didn't want a big chunky C-clamp that might damage the countertop or get in the way of the crank.  A quick trip to the aforementioned yielded a pair of these little gems.  They grip the baseplate of the pasta machine and the overhang of the countertop securely, and the cushioned jaws pamper both surfaces (see picture).The ratchet triggers don't impede the crank, and when the pasta's finally rolled out and cut into spaghetti or fettuccine, the clamps release with a touch.

Yeah, I know, it's just a knob off the dryer but it beats leaving a pair of pliers out so you can turn the shaft.  It's at least as sturdy as the knob it replaced and Virginia Service Supply gets 5 stars for having it in stock at a reasonable price with a fair shipping charge (think of how many Amazon merchants charge $15.00 to ship a $6.00 item).Next time I need a knob, I know where to look first and which Amazon Marketplace merchant to buy it from.

My collection of hard-anodized nonstick and glass-ceramic cookware keeps growing along with the need for the right kitchen tools.  This OXO Good Grips set delivers the goods.  The heat-resistant nylon pampers Circulon and prevents metal marks on CorningWare and Visions cookware.  The big bulgy handles reduce fatigue and every tool in the set cleans up with minimal effort.As a starter set for a new homemaker, replacements for worn out utensils, or as a gift for a foodie friend, you can't go wrong for the price.  Order the OXO Good Grips Nylon Ladle at the same time and you'll get everything with FREE Super Saver Shipping.

The facilities engineer at work was about to throw out this clock because it couldn't find the signal from radio station WWVB in our office building.  Since we already own one La Crosse Technology clock, I took it off his hands and saved it from the dumpster.Our first radio-controlled clock is hanging on the inside of an exterior wall that runs north/south, so the antenna is oriented for optimal reception.  When that clock was delivered, it set itself to the correct time within seconds of inserting the battery and hanging it on the wall while the sun was still up.  Most radio-controlled clocks won't sync until the wee hours of the A.M.This clock is in a more precarious location on an interior wall that runs east/west.  It's also hanging directly above our TV set.  With the TV and DISH Network satellite TV receiver turned off, I slipped in the battery, pressed the PT (Pacific Time zone) button and hung the clock on the wall at about 6:00pm local time.  True to form, the hands paused for about a minute or two before spinning wildly until all three hands were in sync with the first clock.  A phone call to NIST's time service (303 499 7111) confirmed the accuracy.  Days later, the second hands on both clocks still advance with the ticks on the phone.  The performance appears to be unaffected by IF emissions from the TV and DISH receiver.

We had two plastic colanders.  One melted and warped as I was trying to drain some cooked bacon bits for a baked bacon cheeseburger mac.  The other has such large holes that I tended to lose a strand or two of spaghetti through the bottom.  This one's just right for both tasks.  I can drain and toss the spaghetti to my heart's content without worrying about the random escapee.  It certainly seems up to the task of draining cooked bacon and browned ground beef, plus it cleans like a dream.  It handled turkey bones and the cooked-limp vegetables from a batch of turkey stock admirably without letting the undesirable stuff into the final product.I'll keep the plastic colander for washing veggies and stuff, but when it's time to handle the hot stuff, this is the one I'm reaching for.

Western Digital makes great high-capacity hard drives.  Western Digital makes lousy external enclosures for them.  When my WD My Book Home external hard drive started flaking out and wouldn't back up my iMac and MacBook Pro with Time Machine, I thought all the saved data was lost.  I took it apart to see what might be done to rescue the data and found a fatal design flaw.  The USB/FireWire interface unit is attached to the 500Gb Caviar drive, absorbing much of the heat generated by the drive.  Over time, the heat fried the electronics.I perused Amazon's selection of drive enclosures and chose this one for its built-in cooling fan.  A few Free Super Saver Shipping Days later, the enclosure arrived and the installation went without a hitch, requiring only a Phillips screwdriver.  The StarTech enclosure comes with a full-size USB cable, not a mini-USB as on the My Book.  I wouldn't be surprised if shoving all that data through a mini-USB interface is another factor in generating excess heat.When I first fired up the drive, it still wouldn't connect to Time Machine, but after a couple repair runs in Disk Utility, it's purring along nicely and hasn't missed a single scheduled backup.The enclosure's fan emits a quiet drone that's no more objectionable than the sound of the drive in the original My Book's plastic enclosure, which relied on convection alone for cooling and provided no sound insulation.  The aluminum exterior is barely warm to the touch and never gets as hot as the My Book's enclosure.  If plastic is hot, that's a bad thing because plastic is an insulator, not a heat conductor.

Step 1: Insert AA alkaline battery into battery holder and press the button corresponding to your Time Zone in the USA.Step 2: Hang clock on wall.That's it.We did that around 6:00pm on the day the clock arrived and within seconds, the hands were spinning to the correct time.  After a couple weeks in operation, the second hand still syncs perfectly to the ticks of the atomic clock at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (which you can verify by calling the audio feed of radio station WWV at 303-499-7111).This is the first radio-controlled clock we've owned that set itself to the correct time while the sun was still up, not in the wee hours of the morning.  It's hanging on the inside of an exterior wall that runs north/south so the built-in antenna is in the optimal position to receive the signal.  We recently acquired another La Crosse Technology clock that's hanging on an interior wall that runs east/west.  It, too, had no trouble picking up the signal.

Since my MacBook Pro is with me every Saturday and two Sundays a month to project hymn lyrics on our twin LCD projectors at church, it only made sense to record the choir on the MacBook as well.  Our Behringer XENYX mixer came with the UCA200 USB interface and since it's the church's property, I needed a USB interface of my own.  The UCA202 is a perfect step up.By hooking the signal from the mixer's 1-2 subgroup to the UCA202, I get a clean recording that I can further tweak with Audacity (available from audacity . sourceforge . net). The main mix with a little cathedral reverb from the mixer goes off to the church's sound system.  The UCA202 does the heavy lifting, freeing up precious CPU cycles.  Audacity never misses a note and Microsoft PowerPoint never freezes or stutters.At home, we use the UCA202 to transfer vinyl into the digital realm.  And if we're feeling patient, we can isolate and eliminate clicks and pops.Oh, the things we can do with modern technology.  Simply audacious!

You can get this skillet and its 12-inch companion for even less when you buy them as a set.Rule of thumb: search Amazon for the entire Infinite Circulon line before you buy. You might just strike black gold, but not the liquid kind.

You can get this skillet and its 10-inch companion for even less when you buy them as a set.Rule of thumb: search Amazon for the entire Infinite Circulon line before you buy.  You might just strike black gold, but not the liquid kind.

Having written the most rated review for a flip-over Belgian waffle maker, I found myself craving the classic "American"-style waffle after ordering one at the local Spires restaurant. We found this Cuisinart iron at Macy's so I whipped out my debit card.It takes only 1/3 cup of my own waffle batter recipe to fill the grids (and then some, given the tiny overflow rim) but the stainless steel exterior shrugs off overflows after the iron cools. Three minutes' baking time on the number 3 setting does the job nicely. Despite the small size, the lid has enough heft to press down on the batter and force it upward into the top grid. After the third batch of waffles, the grids became so well seasoned that they no longer need a shot of cooking spray.As with my review of the Belgian waffle maker, updates will be posted as they happen. Stay tuned!

I ordered this stud finder along with a pot rack because I wanted to hang it properly.  The Zircon i520 showed me that there wasn't a stud for the pot rack's upper center support.  It also showed some sort of metal cladding on one of the studs.  Armed with that knowledge, my wife Cathy bought a precut piece of plywood and painted it to match the wall.  I pre-drilled starter holes in the left stud to get past the metal, and then secured the plywood to the studs.  I was then able to secure all three support points on the pot rack to the plywood.  The result, as you can see from the picture I've posted, is stable and sturdy.Moral of the story: spend less than fifty bucks now and save hundreds you would have spent fixing the wall later.UPDATE: When I replaced the switch for the food waste disposer, the Zircon MultiScanner verified that all the power was off in the duplex switch box by the kitchen sink.  Saved a call to an electrician and, quite possibly, saved my life.

There are two reasons to have a pot rack.  It keeps the pots and pans you use most often within easy reach.  And it lets you flaunt your trophy cookware, like my Infinite Circulon collection.  What were once stacked and hidden away in a cabinet with dishcloths as cushions are now proudly displayed in your humble author's kitchen, safely separated to protect the nonstick surfaces.Our kitchen presented an installation challenge.  As in most American suburban homes, the studs behind the drywall are 16 inches apart while the mounting points on the pot rack are horizontally spaced 8 inches apart.  Securing the side supports to studs leaves the top center support weak and prone to pulling free from the drywall. Conversely, anchoring only the top center support to a stud puts too much strain on the side supports, causing them to dig into the drywall over time.Our solution: Cathy bought a precut 23 by 23 inch sheet of plywood and painted it to match the wall.  I secured the plywood to the left and right studs and then attached the pot rack to the plywood. The result, as you can see in the photo I posted, is sturdy and stable yet pleasing to the eye. Rightly, some have pointed out that the anchor screws are difficult to get to but I was still able to maneuver a Ryobi power drill into position and drive home the screws.

UPDATE 05-21-2012: Amazon hears and answers our packaging prayers.  Our last shipment was packed box-within-box with a double layer of bubble wrap around the inner box.  A few cans were slightly deformed from normal handling but not seriously dented and all 24 were perfectly usable.We've replaced canned tomato sauce in all of our favorite recipes with these ravishing red beauties from Italy and we're never going back.  Aside from being peeled and then pasteurized in the can, these San Marzano plum tomatoes are just about as fresh as when they were plucked off the vine in the Campania region of Italy.  That means they aren't cooked until you cook them, and what a difference THAT makes, especially with sauces simmered all day in a slow cooker or thrown together on the spur of the moment in a pressure cooker.Amazon.com's Free Super Saver shipping makes them a bargain compared to ordinary canned tomatoes and a steal versus the price of San Marzano tomatoes from the store.

The age of the 2-cent coffee filter is over.  The Target near me no longer stocks a pack of 200 coffee filters for $3.99.  Ditto for Walgreen's where I nearly dislocated a shoulder reaching way to the back of the shelf for the last $1.99 package of 100 filters.  The best price I could find locally was 100 filters for about five bucks.  Sorry, no deal, not gonna pay it.As I was reaching for a can of the San Marzano plum tomatoes I had ordered by the case from Amazon.com, I wondered: Do they have a similar deal on coffee filters?Boy, do they!  So what if they're a cent and a half more?  They're still a better buy than any supermarket or drug store package.  All of the packaging is recyclable, including the shipping box.  And having them come right to the door is as good as a flavor shot.  When I get down to the last box, I just order up another case.I couldn't really taste any difference in the coffee but I can feel the difference in my wallet.

There's nothing namby-pamby about a nice smelling bathroom, but heavy perfume isn't the answer.  I tried Glade Scented Oil and discovered that the fragrance doesn't eliminate bathroom odors.  It mixes with them, creating an unpleasant olfactory cocktail.When I picked up one of these at the market, I was impressed by its heft.  The large surface area gets more of the product into the air where it sends odors packing.  Instead of a heavy cloud of phony florals, a wisp of orange zest lets you know it's working.Of course, you'll also know it's working when you no longer hear shouts of "Shut that door!" as you emerge from the, uh, reading room.

Printer sharing was a great idea but its days are numbered. You already know how it goes: You're in the family room with a laptop and you need to print something on the printer attached to the desktop in the bedroom that's become the home office. You click the Print icon and then make the pilgrimage to wake up the desktop or call out and hope someone's near enough to wake it up.This printer fit right into our Mac household which includes a MacBook that occasionally runs Windows XP and Ubuntu Linux. The WiFi setup was delightfully boring using the network cable method. And, hey, who DOESN'T have an extra network cable around the house? You follow the step-by-step instructions without compromising your WiFi security. When you're finished, you unplug the network cable and you're printing wirelessly (is that a real word?) from anywhere in the house.Setting up the printer in Windows via Boot Camp was like adding any other network printer. I needed only to pick the IP address of the printer itself (not the wireless print server's IP address) and in seconds a Windows XP Printer Test Page floated into the output tray. Ubuntu found the printer all by itself and installed its own CUPS (Common UNIX Printing Solution) driver.Brother has even tucked a mini web server inside, giving you web browser access to important information about the printer. Just open your favorite web browser and type in the printer's IP address. A wealth of information appears and tells you more than any front-panel display while saving the paper and toner you'd waste on configuration, status and maintenance reports.If at least half of what you print is black and white text and you already have a wireless router, you NEED this printer. Inkjet ink is just too expensive for that, and printer sharing is SO last century.

These key chains are the cutest things ever!! The details of these little shoes are just like a real sized shoe right down to the laces that you can tie and untie. These are great goodie bag items or even a stocking stuffers. I am part of the PTC at my kids' school and  these were little prizes to the kids that won one of the games at the sham bam. Converse have seem to have made a come back and these are those style.  I love the colors because they neutral.I did receive these at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I had to race my kids to get this from the ups driver because they like to open the deliveries and I would me mortified if they got this. I was pleasantly surprised that the box is plain whine with the word bombex and very little detail otherwise on the box. This is a well-made polo shirt from Oxford NY. The material is soft and comfortable. The thickness is exactly what I look for in pull-over shirts. There are a couple of minor issues that I think are important enough to point out. First the sizing tends to be on the small size. The shirt fits close to the body and in the sleeves. If it were a half-size larger, it would be perfect, but since that's not available, I would order a full size larger for myself. The second issue is that it is rather short by a few inches and it doesn't fit well when tucked into the waistband of your pants. The shirt is made to be worn outside your waistband, but even so, it isn't long enough to suit my preference. There is no shirt pocket and the collar lies flat. The discounted  price is excellent for the quality, so I may consider getting more shirts, but at the next larger size.

This Oxford NY crew neck t-shirt is much nicer than I expected. The quality of the stitching and the material is excellent. It is medium weight material and is neither too thin or too heavy for year-round wear. The length is the same as my Polo shirts and longer than my Jockey shirts.Pro: It has actual soft labels stitched into the neck. This is a huge plus for me. One thing I dislike about the majority of t-shirts being made today is that they leave off the label, which makes it difficult to tell which direction the shirt is facing when getting dressed.Con: The shirt is just a bit tight across the shoulders and back, so if I raise up one or both arms over your head, the shirt tail will pull up. This doesn't happen in my Polo shirts which are cut to be more relaxed across the back and in the sleeves. Maybe I just have bigger than average shoulders. While I still prefer the Polo fit as my "gold standard", the Oxford NY shirt is almost as good and the price is better than what I have paid for the Polo shirts in the past. So this  "con" is not a deal breaker and I would definitely buy the Oxford again and I do recommend it. If I were wearing it when being very active with a lot of arm movement, I would get one size larger, but for average wear, I would stick with my exact size.

Finally a freezer bag that lives up to the task! The last box I bought from "Brand X" was terrible and literally fell apart in my hands when I opened and closed them. These Hefty gallon-size freezer storage bags have the best zip-closure I've seen. Once closed, I could not force the bag to open until I unzipped it with the slider. The interlocking closure has a rounded edge to it that helps to protect the seal and keep something else from rubbing open the bag by accident. The closure has a very slight click sound when it is fully closed, which is a nice idea. The bag itself is thick and has a white rectangle on it for writing down the date and/or the contents. Definitely a quality bag to store and protect your expensive foods.

I've owned 2 Remington MB200 models, which I liked, but the only problem was that the battery didn't last long. This Remington MB4045 model has all of the positive features of the older MB200, plus it has a powerful Lithium-Ion battery which is expected to last longer. The MB4045 also provides 3 length-adjustable heads to let you trim long, medium, and very short (stubble) beards. The MB200 only had a single adjustable head. The MB4045 also has a pop-up trimmer in the back for sharp edge trimming of sideburns and around mustaches and van dyke style beards. This is quicker/easier than having to break out a razor and shaving cream for those areas.The kit includes a pair of scissors and a hairbrush as accessories. The scissors are much too small for me to put my fingers in the handle holes. My hands are probably medium in size. So the scissors are useless to me. The bristles on the hairbrush are short and very stiff. The overall brush length is also very small and I can't easily hold it by the handle. Both of the accessory items are made more for the hands of a small woman or man. I would have preferred getting a small comb and a groomer cleaning brush as the MB200 kit provides. I took off one star for the disappointing accessories, but the groomer itself is excellent.

I'm disappointed in the Swiffer 360 product. It's OK, but I probably wouldn't buy it again. Fortunately I have a box of the original blue Swiffers on hand, which work great. The original Swiffers have less material and are more open in construction, so they capture and hold more dust than this version in my opinion. This 360 version is so tightly packed with fibers that there is no room for the dust to go, so whatever dust that doesn't stick on the outermost surface just falls on the floor or goes up into the air. I think it was a good idea to take a regular Swiffer and make it a 360 version, but they should have stopped there instead of also making the product denser and changing the way it picks up dust.

The dispenser box doesn't work very well. The bottom flap is too small to pull out a single packet of oil. When you pull out one, a couple more come out with it. I think a top opening flap would be better.The oil itself does smell like raw coconut, but I didn't find the taste of it to be all that strong. I made popcorn with it and the kitchen smelled like toasted coconut. The flavor of coconut was enhanced by the cooking, and it tasted pretty good on popcorn. I found it to be less heavy than regular cooking oils, which added to the pleasant taste. I also found that it works really well when added to fruit salads.As a skin lotion, it seems effective as a lubricant and not sticky. The coconut fragrance is pleasant on the skin.It does seem to be a bit expensive, but you are paying in part for the convenience of having small travel packets. The packets are coated paper and have an easy to tear opening.

These Hefty cups are acceptable for adults, but understand that they are very thin and flimsy compared to other plastic cups you can buy. Children with their small hands will squeeze the cup and cause the sides to collapse. So it is not a cup I would recommend for kids. Adults don't have that dexterity problem managing a flimsy cup, but even so, the sides of the cup collapse when held, so you might want to warn your guests when serving drinks. The embossed diamond pattern is there to reduce slipping, but this is an example where something has been engineered to the point that it becomes almost unusable in an effort to reduce cost and reduce waste. I think this design actually increases cost and waste since the cup is only usable once, while more sturdy plastic cups from other companies are washable and reusable many times. I can make plastic cups from other companies last through several uses, but this I would never use more than one time. The only way I can see to get around the problem with this design is to double stack the cups, which is really wasteful.

These seem to be really good quality cables. Much better than the one that came with the phone power supply and also better than others I purchased in the past. Getting a 6 pack is the best way to go if you have multiple devices or need to have cables in multiple locations (home, office, car, travel bag, etc).

Excellent quality graphics card. I'm using it to drive 4 monitors for a Flightgear simulator. I immediately upgraded the drivers when I installed the card and software. Monitor setup was frustrating and difficult, which I think may be more of an issue with Flightgear and/or Windows 7 and not the card itself. Specifically, the monitor numbering/order kept randomly switching each time I rebooted. Only after considerable trial and error over the course of 2 days and then adding the monitors one at a time was I able to use the ordering of the ports to correctly match the ordering needed by Flightgear. After acheiving success in the layout order, I've been able to successfully reboot to the same configuration each time. So if you run into a similar problem, just take good notes and systematically try different configurations adding the 3rd and 4th monitors individually and you will resolve the problem.

This is a good product for the price. However, you need to be in a darkened room and also have your eyes dark-adapted to best appreciate the lighting effect. The barettes themselves are quite bright and have a multicolor LED that flashes at different rates and colors. There is only an off-on switch and no selection of constant light or a constant color. The ends of the fibers also are bright, even though the fibers are very thin and hair-like. However, the fibers themselves don't leak that much light from the side. So you need to see them in the dark for best effect as shown in the photo.I actually bought these as a source of optical fibers for another hobby project and this turned out to be a very good deal to get 12 batteries, 6 multicolor flashing LEDs, and a large quantity of fibers. Two of the barettes had strands that were somewhat bent becease they were kinked during packaging and one barette turned on sometime during the shipping and was not as bright as the others by the time I received it. These were minor issues though.

Charmin is my favorite brand and Ultra Soft Mega rolls are the type I usually buy at the big-box store. However I decided to give the Ultra Strong Mega Roll version a try. I really can't tell any difference between the 2 versions in actual use. They both seem soft to me. I used a micrometer to compare the roll thickness to the Ultra Strong to the Ultra Soft. If I measure from the inside tube to the outer surface, the overall roll thickness averages 4.4 +/- 0.2 cm for the Ultra Soft Mega Roll (using compression by the thumb-roller on the micrometer),  while the Ultra Strong Mega rolls are slightly thinner (about 3.8 +/- 0.2 cm). So I think the difference is that the content of each sheet of the Ultra Soft is fluffed up more and that makes it more absorbent, while the Ultra Strong sheets have the fibers woven in a manner to be less resistant to tearing and are not as fluffed up. I don't have a way to measure the relative weights of each roll, but the physical length and width of each sheet is the same and the number of plys and sheets are the same for both brands. So the difference is that the Ultra Strong sheets must be very slightly less thick than the Ultra Soft because of the way the fibers are arranged.In any case, they are both excellent products I recommend, and whether you get the Ultra Strong or the Ultra Soft, you are going to get the same number of sheets and plys.

Charmin is my favorite brand and Ultra Soft Mega rolls are the type I usually buy at the big-box store. For this review I used a micrometer to compare the roll thickness to the ones I bought several months ago and there is no difference in sheet size, number, or thickness. If I measure from the inside tube to the outer surface, the overall roll thickness averages 4.4 +/- 0.2 cm for both the old and new rolls (using compression by the thumb-roller on the micrometer). So I see no measurable reduction in absorbent fiber content from what I purchased in the past. I also have the Ultra Strong version and those rolls are slightly thinner (about 3.8 +/- 0.2 cm) because of less absorbent material compared to the Ultra Soft, but the number of sheets are the same and the ply count is 2 for both types.I don't notice any difference between the two types in actual use, and they are both soft to the touch. I do believe there is more absorbency in the Ultra Soft version however, because there is an actual measurable difference in thickness.,

This is an OK printer. There are less expensive all-in-one models out there that have the same or even better specs, but lack the "2-year" supply of ink that this one comes with up front. So the price will likely even out or maybe even favor this Epson in the long run. However, you do have a higher up front cost in buying this Epson and you are gambling that it will last long enough to pay for itself. The "2-year" supply of ink is of course and estimate and depends entirely on your own usage.I think the strongest selling point for this Epson printer is the promise of having a single package that combnes printing, copying, faxing, and scanning and comes with pre-purchased ink reserves. This was a selling point for me since I have a 2 year contract coming up where I need to set up a remote office and this package gives me nearly everything I need from the start in a small package without the concern for buying extra ink for some time. I would have preferred a full duplex printer, which Epson does offer in a more expensive model. If saving paper is a major concern for you, look for that model instead. I do like the fact this is wireless and makes the installation location more flexible without the need to run cables.While this is a good package, there are some things that are lacking. First the printing quality is just average for color graphics. I wouldn't bother doing finished color photos with the printer since it doesn't have the kinds of inks needed for color photography. You need to buy a true photography style printer for that (Epson does sell those and I have one). But for business charts and graphs and draft photos on ordinary office paper, the color reproduction is OK. Second, I think it is just kind of slow all around. If you want faster printing, you might want to look at the printing speed of color laser printers. There are also some much faster business scanners. Third, the printer consumes your color inks even when just doing black-only printing. There is no need for this, since b/w printers do a perfectly good job of printing only with black ink. I fnd this a common and very frustrating aspect of today's color business printers since it not only wastes ink, but prevents the ability to print only in one color when that is all you need. This basically forces the customer to buy a separate b/w printer in order to have truly cost effective printing if that is the primary need in the office.So overall, I think this is an OK combo printer for color business graphics in a small office, but I think if you have the room, and you want the best equipment available, you might be better off separately purchasing a very fast b/w duplex laser printer, a color inkjet printer that is photography-capable, and a duplex scanner that can scan both sides of a document at once.

The Corsair RM750i is a high performance, high quality, low noise power supply for use in new custom computer systems or as a replacement for an existing system that needs to be upgraded or repaired. I won't go through all of the specs for this power supply. They are readily available here in the product listing and provided by some of the other reviewers. Here are some questions and answers that maybe some shoppers are thinking about:Q. Why would I need this?A. If your current power supply has failed and you need to replace it, or if you are upgrading an existing system with more power-hungry peripherals, you will need a power supply such as this one. At 750W, it gives you the power supply of a workstation. You can power multiple SATA cards, one or more multi-monitor graphcs cards, and other power-hungry peripherals. For me, this upgrade was needed in order to power a new Geforce graphics card for a research lab flight simulator using 4 monitors. Although I had an existing 750W power supply, I didn't have all of the connectors I needed to power the new card, plus the old power supply was often noisey under load. Anyone wanting to build their own custom system from scratch will need a reliable power supply, and this is an excellent choice for long-term use, particularly for a gaming system where intense graphcal rendering requirements are expected.Q. Is it easy to install as a replacement?A. Yes. Just remove the old power supply and replace it with this one. You will need to use a screwdriver and be somewhat mechanically inclined, but it is not a difficult replacement. All of the cabling uses connectors that are keyed so you can't accidentally plug a device into the wrong sized peripheral connector. Follow all of the common-sense rules when working with electrical devices. Also read the instructions before starting.Q. Is it highly rated?A. Yes, it has a gold-level 80-plus rating, which simply means it has above-average reliability for delivering consistent power output. The warranty period is for 7 years, which is probably longer than the average age of a system when it gets replaced with something newer. The RM750i also uses  high quality Japanese capacitors.  Having had smoked capacitors in a couple of NT-era workstations, it is a frustrating experience, particularly when the product is out of warranty. Here the capacitors are the best available, and the 7-year warranty will have you covered in the event that something does happen.Q. Does it have all of the connectors I need?A. It should have everything you need and then some, including cabling for all modern peripheral devices. You should need any other adaptors, unless you have some very unique server system that maybe has a large number of disk drives to power. I think for 99% of users, the included power cables will cover all of your needs. If you have any doubts, check the spec sheets before ordering and compare it to your peripheral devices and boards. All of the power cables are black, and personally I wish cables were in different colors to make them easier to identify inside of a computer case, but that is just me. I think most people don't care or they prefer the black cables. The power cord is of typical length and neither too long or too short.Q. Is it loud? Can I use this and not have it disturb others in the room, such as in a bedroom or a quiet office?A. The RM750i is very quiet! It is the quietest power supply I have ever owned. It uses no fan at all when drawing under 300W and above that the fan speed will ramp up. At the typical ambient temperature of a full 750W output, it has only 20 dB of sound coming out, which is equivalent to a whisper in an empty auditorium.Q. Is Corsair a good quality company that stands behind their products?A. I have been using Corsair products for many years and have never had a problem with any product they made. I've never had to use their warranty service, but I believe they stand behind their products and would not hesitate to recommend them.Q. Does the RM750i provide access to power monitoring?A. The i-system means that it interfaces with the Corsair Link digital monitoring and control system. This provides the power user with the ability to monitor temperatures and adjust fans speeds and coolant regulated heatsinks through a software interface. The Corsair Link product system  is described at their website.

This worked just as it should. I tested it using an InFocus VGA projector at 720p (the limit of the projector) and using a 6 foot VGA cable. The HDMI signal passed through to the VGA port without degrading, and I had no video problems while watching a movie from a DVD player. The Belkin adaptor was connected directly to the DVD player when I tested it.I noticed that the audio signal was slightly attenuated when passing through the HDMI adaptor as compared to a separate direct audio connection of the speakers to the DVD player, but this was not a significant reduction in volume. In fact, it was only noticable when I purposely changed the cabling to compare volume. I also can't say that the Belkin adapter was the cause, because the source of the attenuation could have occured within the HdDMI circuitry of the player itself.I did all of my testing with a USB power adaptor attached to the adaptor. When disconnected the power, the video and audio signal did not degrade in any noticable way. Use of a longer VGA cable or an HDMI cable might require the added power to always be used as described in the installation sheet.I think this is a great item, and it allows me to now use the video projector with DVD players or other HDMI enabled devices. Previously I could only use the projector with a VGA-ported computer, but the adaptor gives me more options for using this older equipment.

I received this product at no cost so I could examine it thoroughly and post my review on Amazon. The review expresses my personal opinion.Completeness of the model kit: 5/5Overall durability of the parts: 5/5Play/Fun potential: 5/5*Imagination potential; 5/5*Teaching potential: 5/5**Potential will vary with the interest and skills of each child. I am referring here to children who enjoy building or taking aprt things, and who have the mechanical skills to build simple models. If the child prefers music, reading, or sports to building things, this is maybe not the right toy for them.Potential downside: the product uses many small parts that can easily be lost. You can use this to teach children to build models in a place where parts won't get lost, and to put the parts away in plastic bags or in boxes when stored. Also if the child likes to put things in their mouth, they aren't old enough for this toy.Synopsis:This is a very nice erector set model of an excavation shovel. It is similar to the erector set models I made over 50 years ago, but the parts are a bit safer these days with rounded corners on the piece of metal. I have no concerns with letting my grandkids play with this model.There are a total of 193 pieces, which includes all of the screws and nuts. In addition to the metal parts, this model also includes several colorful plastic pieces that can be bolted on which have more complex shapes, such as the steering wheel and the seat. The rubber tracks are nicely molded with almost no flash (flash being the extra bits that squeze out of the mold). The rubber is not overly stiff, but also not overly soft, so I think the treads will last quite a while provided the child doesn't purposely break them. Usually the rubber pieces are the first to go bad by getting brittle or decomposing into goo, but I think this is about the best quality you can expect for a model of this type. I couldn't find the wrench at first and then found it inside the bag of metal parts after I opened it. The kit also includes a small phillips screwdriver, which I think is quite nice. The child can then learn also about putting their tools away in a safe place for the future. .The instructions are perfectly clear and are plenty big enough to read. There are 9 panel views of different stages of the assembly. Eacch view is about 3x 3 inches, so 9 square inches per panel, which makes for 81 square inches of assemby instruction diagrams. If you have ever built a model or assembled Ikea-like furniture, the instructions are no problem. Every part is shown in exploded view and the number of parts used are listed in each panel. For a child who has never built anything, a parent or older child can help them understand how to copy what they see in the pictures, and after 5 minutes of help, the child will have it figured out.The model is listed for 6+ years of age. Some younger children will be able to put this together easily if they are mechanically inclined. If they play with other bulding block toys without sticking the pieces in their mouth, they are probably old enough to move to the stage of putting things together with screws and nuts. This is a very good way to help kids understand how things are made out of parts and which way to turn screws to make them tight or loose. The parts can be used to make all kinds of models - not just the one that is pictured. Models like this can really stimulate your children's imagination. Of course, they will want more of these to build, and that is a good thing. This is not a toy to be played with for a few minutes, but a child with good mechanical skills will keep reusing the pieces over and over for many years to build all kinds of clever machines.Summary: I would love having this if I were a kid. The giant erector set I got one Christmas was one of my favorite toys and I played with for many years. These days the erector set toys tend to be packaged in smaller sets like this, but this makes it easier to manage the cost of adding to the erector set over time, and also keeping it novel and interesting for the child.

This is a speedy 3.0 USB flashdrive with a moderately large 32 Gb capacity. In reality the capacity is just under 30 Gb because of the installed encryption software. I tried to install a file that was exactly 30Gb and it wouldn't fit. Whether or not you want to keep the encryption software on the drive or move it to your primary drive is up to you. I can recommend this drive for a one-time backup or for occasional use, but you might want to compare this to other flashdrives before deciding which one to buy.The reason I recommend it only for one-time or occasional use is because the USB connector is made entirely out of very thin plastic that I don't believe will hold up to continuous use from inserting and removal from a USB port. So if you are looking for a flashdrive that will hold up to many insertions a day, you should look at the higher end Lexar drives with metal connectors. But if you only want to use the drive once a week or less, and if you are careful inserting and taking it out of the port, this drive will be good enough.As mentioned, the drive comes with pre-installed encryption software, so I think this should actually be marketed as a long term backup storage device that is used perhaps once to store backups of important files (like family photos, financial records, or lists of account numbers and passwords) and then put away in a safe location. The encryption software is entry level, but it is perfectly fine for the average user and is easy to use with your own password. If you want more heavy duty encryption, you can purchase an upgrade online and then you can select a higher grade of encryption.In summary I'm taking off a star since the connector can easily break, but it does perform well as a storage device and the encryption software you get is a nice added bonus. The drive comes with a small lanyard, but I doubt that most people will even attach it.

This is a  remarkable lens for the affordable price! I'm currently using it for astrophotography and the results are much better than I expected. There is a slight amount of coma in the far corners when used below f/3.5, but even when used at f/2, I think the coma is acceptable, particularly if you wind up cropping your images anyway. Using this lens at f/2 and 20 second exposures lets me get test images of the sky to check for the quality of haze before I make the decision to set up y polar tracking platform. Even the 20 sec untracked exposures are useful for stacking.  There is also a small amount of luminance drop-off in the corners, but not enough to be noticeable unless you measure it with Photoshop or a similar product. So far I haven't found the need to implement a luminance correction. There is also very little barrel distortion. I was expecting much more, but it really isn't noticable unless you specifcally try to emphasize the distortion.The version I have is the Nikon mount, and I'm using it on a D7100.
