I use it mainly in the manual setting mode (M), but I've done ordinary photography with all camera settings including auto and the everything works as it should. The AE chip in the lens correctly sets exposure in the camera and it does it well. The in-camera focus guide correctly assesses manual focus. Since I'm using this primarily for astrophotograpy, I set the focus based on the ring markings. I did a night of testing just the focus for different f-stops and.there were no unexpected surprises. The ring markings on my lens are accurate for infinity, and the focus hasn't slipped even when moving the camera around to different parts of the sky.

My Sony Vaio reported the battery as defective and unable to be charged as soon as I turned on the laptop. I tried several times to reinstall the battery, and also tried installing on another Vaio laptop with the same battery style, but it could not be charged. I returned it for a full refund. I believe this one simply has a bad cell, but since only one was listed as available, I couldn't reorder.

This is a very easy to install faucet. As long as you have standard 9/16ths inch water shutoff connectors already plumbed in place and the predrilled faucet hole in the countertop is 1-3/8th inches, the installation is easy and straightforward.  Once the hot and cold water supplies are turned off and the old faucet and supply lines are removed, attach the provided hot and cold flexible supply lines to the base of the Kraus faucet. Only hand tightening is required. The seal is made by dual o-rings on each line. These flexible supply lines are reinforced with stainless steel braided covers for extra burst protection. Each supply line also has an integrated wire mesh filter to help prevent particulate matter in the water line (eg sand) from ever reaching the faucet.  Next, pass the supply lines through the hole in the top of the counter and then attach the large washers and the nut from under the counter. You may need someone to hold the faucet upright and in the correct orientation since it is tall and a bit top-heavy. When in the right position and the main nut is tightened, tighten two philips-head screws to keep the main nut from coming loose. Then attach the supply lines to the water turnoff connections and turn the water back on. I would recommend using plumber's teflon tape for these turnoff connections. You may also want to add silicone sealant around the countertop hole before installing the faucet, but be careful to not get any on the nice bronze finish.Be aware that the spigot on the faucet does not rotate to different positions from side to side. It is fixed to one orientation - directly forward. The faucet is designed for raised basins on a flat counter and look best in that application. This faucet is really too high for sinks that are depressed  within the countertop. There is no lever for operating a drain in the basin. The lever at the top is for water control. The bottom lip of the faucet spigot is 9.68" from the counter top, which is an important measurement because you need this to plan for the basin height. The center of the spigot to the center of the faucet pipe is 4.72".The fit and finish and overall quality of the faucet are superb. The rubbed bronze finish is flawless. The top lever is made of porcelain. Metal parts are brass for corrsion resistance. The faucet comes in a cloth bag for protection and a cloth wipe is included for keeping the finish clean and free from scratches during use. All of the parts are well packed with thick foam padding on all sides.

The monitor is rather basic in that it only has 1 HDMI port and 1 VGA port. It lacks a DVI port and there are no USB ports. It has internal speakers, but if you want acceptable audo for games and videos, you will be happier with external speakers. However the onboard speakers do get the job done for a  basic computer setup.The native setting for color leans toward the warm side. If you are older and have naturally yellowing lenses in your eyes you will want to tweak the color toward the blue to compensate. However, I could never find a satisfactory setting when attached to my nvidia graphics boards. If I tried pushing it to the blue suing the rgb channels, it immediately became too blue. If I adjusted the brightness and contrast, it didn't help. If I adjusted the gamma or the color temperature, it also didn't help. My guess is that this is somehow related to the blue filtering circuit in the monitor which seems to always be on. Even though I have the blue filter supposedly turned off, there is still a bit too much yellow in the whites and grays. I suppose if I had younger eyes, it wouldn't bother me as much. I have Sony, Asus, and LG monitors without this problem, so I feel the warm tone is just an inherent characteristic of this monitor. When viewing movies and photographs, it doesn't bother me, but webpage backgrounds and Windows applications just look too warm to me.The crispness of the monitor in native resolution (1920x1080) is sharp, but not quite as sharp as my other monitors which are all IPS LED. When viewing on this monitor alone, the lack of crispness is not apparent, but when set side-by-side with my other monitors, the slight lack of crispness is there no matter what the contrast and brightness settings are. I have the feeling that the lack of crispness is related to the blue filtering circuitry.The response time is slower than my 1 ms monitors, but for general computing use it is perfectly fine. I do no gaming, but I do rendering to animate 3D graphs, so this is not an ideal monitor for that purpose.I do recommend the monitor for general computer use and for watching videos and viewing photos. I'm going to use this as a dedicated monitor for recording teaching videos and for reviewing photos in real time from my DSLR. It should perform very well in those applications.

This is a nice medium-duty vise for a drill press, or it can also be bolted to a workbench. It is fairly large. The clamping surface is 4 inches across and approximately 1.5 inches high. The clamp opens to a length of 3 and 7/8 inches. The overall open length is almost 18 inches. The bottom of the vise is completely open so you can drill through materials completely. The frame is made of heavy aluminum, with steel rails and a steel lead screw. The handle is smooth and made of a synthetic material and it has good gripability (i.e., not slippery). It might be slippery though if you have grease or oil on your hands. However, the handle can flip to 90 degrees for increased leverage by pulling out on the spring-loaded handle and flipping it to the side. The tie-down bolt slots are 1/2 inches wide and 4.5 inches long. The frame is 7/16 inches high at the tie-down slots. The side rails are large enough for using quick release clamps on your drillpress base to hold down this vise. The vise has a quick release button on top for rapid positioning of the clamping lead screw. The top of the button is plastic, which might be easily damaged, but the locking mechanism beneath is metal.There are no major problems with the vise and I believe I would buy it again. I do recommend it. However there are a few deficiencies that you should be aware of:1) There is no flat surfaces at the bottom of the clamping cavity to rest material on. The material rests directly on the round steel rails, and for some uses, this is just not good enough. I much prefer drill press vices that use machined flat side rails. However those vises are more expensive.2) The clamping surfaces are steel, but only 3/16 inches thick. This means that the vertical and horizontal grooves for holding round materials are very shallow and essentially useless for this purpose. The grooves appear to be about 1 mm deep. On my favorite vice, the clamps are 3/4 in thich and the grooves are about 1/4 in deep, which is much better for holding round stock. Also the grooves on both plates didn't align correctly, but this can be corrected by loosening the screws and adjusting the positions of the 2 plates. I actually took the plates and reversed them to have perfectly flat clamping surfaces. You can also remove the steel plates and install your own nylon, rubber, or wood plates instead. The steel plates are attached by 2 flat-head screws on each plate.3) The lead screw uses a quick-release button to rapidly position the clamping surfaces. This works really well. It does make the screw a little hard to turn for long distances, but since you would initially adjust by using the quick release, the issue is very minor. I only mention it to let you know it is normal and not something to be concerned about - it is not defective. The lead screw works very well when tightening.Overall, I think this is a very nice clamp for general workshop use. It isn't intended for use on a milling machine, so it lacks some of the nice features found on heavy-duty clamps for precise positioning, but this will handle 90% of my workshop applications.

These golf shows exceeded my expectations. It is a high quality shoe for a reasonable cost. The overall quality is superb with absolutely no defects found in the upper leather, stitching, outer soles, or interior components. The arch support is close to perfect for me, and I am always somewhat critical about this because of an old tendon injury. The shoes are surprisingly light in weight and almost have a slipper-like comfort to them. Normally I wear a 10.5 wide, but the size 11 medium fit comfortably. The width was barely snug, but not uncomfortable even after hours of walking and even before they have been fully broken in. They gave excellent stability with no unexpected or abnormal ankle roll when walking or driving a club. The low-profile rubber-cleated soles gave good traction even in wet grass and pathways. The shoes came with two colors of shoe laces: white and a dark navy blue color.

These are very nice 100% cotton dish towels. I like the design with a smiling chef preparing spaghetti and meatballs. One side has the design and the other is blank. The photo shows the background to have a greenish-yellow color, but what I have is the same design with a gold-yellow color. These are exactly what I wanted.

This is another excellent Avery label product. The package is listed as Internet Shipping labels,which sounded odd to me. The name refers to additional Avery software that can be downloaded to print out a specific style of shipping label. The label is designed for internet businesses that ship products. However, these are blank labels, so the user can design the label to be anything they want. They don't have to use a template only for shipping. If the user wants to use special software that computes postage and/or fills in the addresses automatically, the package provides the internet linksto the USPS, ebay, and pbSmart web sites. There is also the internet link shown for the Avery site for Design & Print software or the MS Word template.The labels are stacked 2 to a sheet and each is 5.5" x 8.5". The label is somewhat lighter in weight compared to other Avery shipping labels I have used in the past. I believe the lighter weight and the minimum amount of waste (just the backing material) allows Avery to list this as a more environmentally favorable product when compared to other products of a similar size. The label corners are rounded, and the labels are easily removed from the backing sheet. It works well in both laser and inkjet printers, with no smudging.

This is a full-function, full-size iron. It is not ligtweight, but I wouldn't say it was overly heavy. For casual ironing at home, the weight is OK. It has all of the features you expect to find on an iron such as 3 steam settings, steam burst, water spray, fully adjustable temperature range settings, and auto-off. It has a light to indicate it is operating. The cord is sufficiently long to not be an issue for most users. The ironing surface is wrapped with stainless steel. Some people prefer a non-stick surface, while others prefer the stainless steel, so keep this in mind when choosing your iron.The top point on my plate was slightly rough around the top where it wrapped around the point, but it didn't catch on the fabric I've used it on. The water tank has a flip-down cap. It is a bit hard to fill, but this is true for most irons. The manufacturer includes a plastic cup to help fill the iron. The only obvious flaw I found was that one side was not correctly in place when the bottom base part was screwed on. This doesn't seem to affect the use of the iron, but there is now an uncovered plastic tab hanging out on the side that could potentially catch on fabric someday. Normally I could fix this in less than a minute, but because the screws in the base are non-removable, I can't loosen the base to put the piece back in the proper place. I really don't like appliances that can't be repaired (e.g., the cord can never be replaced in the future), so I took off a star for the defect and the inability for the user to service or repair the iron.

I've never seen these in the stores in my area. These are a basic tortilla that's been pre-shaped into an elongated flat-bottom bowl. The photo makes them look a little deeper than they really are. But I think the way they come is the perfect size. The taste and texture is very good. As with all tortillas, they are greatly improved by warming them up in the oven. They come in a pack of 8 in a sealed plastic package.

The version I got is different from the product description, so I will mainly review the function. The product uses plastic tiles that have artwork attached. There are also some versions that have a picture frame or a drawing board instead of the pre-made artwork.The tiles attach to the wall using the Commander velcro strips. These are easy to apply and remove from the wall, but you must clean the wall with some alcohol first to make sure the glue on the back of the Commander Velcro strip grips the wall firmly. This is especially true in places like kitchens and bathrooms. The tiles have a built-in bubble level to make it easier to align. Once the large tile is attached to the velcro, the artwork is then put onto the face of the tile and it is held there by a magnet.My version came with an optional stand-off piece to make one of the tiles "float" further from the wall. This adds visual interest by allowing the art to occuply a different plane away from the wall. The standoff uses the same magnet method as used by the artwork to attach it to the large tile. If you like the way the standoff works, you can buy more of them separately.The entire system works fairly well and I like the fact that it has built-in bubble levels. If you have a modern decor and live in an apartment or college dorm, it might appeal to you because you can hang art without damaging the wall. Also if you change your wall art often, this might be a good choice for you This is not something I would use in my home since I don't care for any of the art work shown in the brochure, but I'm sure the art will appeal to someone. I think it is well-made, but it really doesn't look all that great. I think if they had team logos or nature photos, it would be a more interesting product. They are rather expensive at the time of this review, and while this is an innovative method, the cost is going to turn off many potential buyers..

This is a difficult review to write because this is not a typical history book. It is unlike anything I've read before. It is history in the sense that it is a compilation of recollections of men who served in 3 battles (Bunker Hill, Gettysburg, and Iwo Jima). However, this work lacks all of the key elements that places these recollections into some sort of historical perspective. We aren't given any detailed information about who was involved, where they came from, what they thought before, during, or after the battle (or war), how and why they were motivated to take up arms (or not), and for the most part, whatever became of them. There are many names associated with these recollections, and in fact, the book is remarkable for the many references it provides. But they are just names to the reader and there is no information about who these men were. Also, because much of this book appears to be based on recollections by individuals (as opposed to official Army reports, for example), there is a tendency to wonder if these recollections have been eroded or embellished by time. It is not that I doubt anything stated in the book, but I just have the feeling that so much is missing. Likewise, the juxtaposition of so many stories in such a concentrated format can give the reader a wrong impression or it can numb the reader emotionally.Likewise, we aren't given any political, economic, or sociological information to understand the motives of men and country. Nor are we given any detailed background information about the tactics or strategies or equipment and methods used by these armies. These are important elements, because it may be difficult for some younger readers raised predominantly in the 21st century to fully understand the lives of men from the 18th or 19th century. Those of us who lived in the mid-20th century are still able to understand the lives of warfighters in WW II, but even now the cultural knowledge of young people is vastly different from what it was a scant 80 years ago.  So I really wonder if a younger reader can truly appreciate the content of this book. One can argue that the historical context can be found elsewhere, but because there was nothing here to place the recollections of the soldiers into perspective, I found it surprisingly difficult to become interested in this book. While reading this book, I kept referring to my own memories of other history books I've read and studied of those 3 eras. Without that background of knowledge, I think this book can be unsatisfying.Surprisingly, nothing in this book is particularly memorable to me. I finished it and nothing in particular stands out in my mind. That's a strange outcome for reading a significant amount of material. However, the emotional feelings I had while reading the book are more memorable to me than the words I read.  It is indeed a book that can trigger visceral negative emotions, including anger, disgust, sadness, hatred, sympathy, and more. It can also trigger flashbacks to horrific events in our past that some might not wish to dredge up. I found it difficult to wade through the blood and guts descriptions, which makes up a large percentage of the book, or maybe it just seems that way. I would almost call this war pornography, because the main purpose seems to be to evoke an emotional knee-jerk response from the reader. Perhaps there is something educational here, but as I said, the reader has to have some prior historical knowledge to take this book and appreciate what it delivers. I found that I approached this book by imagining myself listening to the worst of the war stories from veterans of these battles. The book gives you little in terms of stories of the days spent in training or what soldiers and Marines did to relieve the boredom and loneliness. There are no funny stories or letters from home. There are no memorable officers or non-coms, no mention of friends, troublemakers, or lost loves. You instead get the stories that are the hardest to tell and also the hardest to read. And these stories seemed to become  worse as we developed better ways to kill. So the book is certainly not balanced in describing the lives of warfighters, but neither is it sanitized or self-censored in the descriptions of the battle itself. You read in great detail about bodies being blown apart by mortar shells, cut in half by machine gun fire, decapitated heads strewn about, the stench of burning bodies, the mountains of limbs and guts, of being covered in feces and parasites, of bodies being torn apart by explosive compression, of brains being traumatized by concussions, and the madness of losing psychological control. You read the stories and take them for what they are and you put them into whatever context you wish because the stories are related in a matter of fact way. These stories have been reported elsewhere because they were familiar to me from other books, but this is the first book I've read where the stories have been presented as a collection.. The text goes into highly explicit detail that I think was intended primarily to shock and disturb the reader, so I don't recommend this book for young people or people with sensitive emotions.While the purpose of using 3 American wars is to show commonality and differences in what  warfighters have experienced, the author doesn't go into a true comparative analysis. Nevertheless, the research is cited in depth, so for the interested reader, this could be an excellent resource to pursue their own analysis from the cited materials. The book is quite different from other historical works of the American Revolution, the American Civil War, and the Battle of Iwo Jima. It is not for everyone and it is frankly a very depressing book to read, but that is the nature of war. Most history books I can read in 1 or 2 nights, but this took me over 3 weeks to finish because it lacked any of the humanity that men seek in wartime and only presented the inhumanity. In a way, it is suprising that battles from Vietnam and Iraq were not included in the book to bring the entire American warfighter experience up to date, however the author does touch briefly on his reasons for not doing this.

I've used Scott's Outdoor Cleaner with good results on large surfaces (a patio deck and a double garage door). This is the pre-mixed version in a spray bottle for smaller jobs. No mixing or diluting required! This does a great job on removing mildew from the outside of large planter containers (the spray is garden plant safe!), cleaning up outdoor furniture (including picnic tables at the park), cleaning entry doors and windows, and getting the grime and mildew off of garden statues and other outdoor decor items. You can refill this spray bottle using the large bottle of Scott's cleaner.
This is a wonderful grinder. I bought this one to use at the office. I have another one at home exactly like this that I've used to grind coffee beans every morning for over 9 years.

This is a great surge protector. Hardly takes up any space and fits all kinds of wall wart power supplies and regular 4 prong and 2 prong power cords. I would prefer it come in a beige color, but dark gray is OK.
It has lasted a couple of years now and still performs like new. Very pleased with the quality and performance. Reacts fast to power surges and outages.

Very good product, but pricey. However, you get what you pay for. Since it is an OEM replacement, it fits and works perfectly. It looks like I will get all of the sheets out that was estimated. Some of the refilled secondary toner cartridges will deliver less than half the number of pages expected, and are not always a good deal.

Most deerblock mesh I've tried goes bad after a year, but this mesh has really stood up well here in the sunny south. No problem at all with it falling apart due to UV and exposure to the elements. I created a totally enclosed area that is 20' x 32' by 8' high for growing vegetables during all 4 seasons. The mesh is still like new after more than a year in place, and no animals have broken through it. It has even stood up to small limbs falling on it.

Very nice propane camping stove. Nice and stable. Good fuel flow adjustment. I use it for camping to heat a dutch oven, fry foods, or to boil water. The main reason I have it is as a backup for emergency applications where power is lost. Propane is safe and easy to store and reliable as an emergency fuel source.

I wound up buying 6 of these. They have lasted for over a year of daily use and are still like new. There is no discernable difference in the appearance of the images in all monitors. The resolution and contrast are excellent. These are often used for viewing medical images where accurate color reproduction is required. The adjustable stand if well worth the added cost.

These are great! Many t-shirts are not long enough. These are the perfect size. The weight is ideal - neither too thin or too thick. The do not  stretch and stand up to many repeated washings. The color (black) does not fade. They hold up so well, that I haven't needed to replace them.
Very good quality. They last through many washings, don't stretch or shrink, and the black did not fade.
Exact replacement as the original. Same shape, length, weight, and thickness. I used this on a 42 in mower deck on my LA125 mower.

I'm very impressed with this 40 volt Lithium-Ion battery-powered Dewalt blower. It is nearly as powerful as my 2 stroke gas engine blower. I think the main difference is that the gas blower has a constrictor tip on the end to concentrate the force of the air, while the Dewalt blower has no such tip. Even so, the Dewalt is more than strong enough to do the job of the gas-powered blower.It easly clears off leaves and pine needles and pine cones up to 4 inches in diameter. It will also blow away fallen tree branches that are an inch thick and 3 feet long. I even used it to blow down a couple of wet clay fire ant mounds with no problem. On a full charge and blowing at full blast the entire time, I can clean off the pad for a 2 car garage, a separate 2 car parking pad, 200 feet of driveway (up and back), 100 feet of sidewalk (up and back), and 70 feet of front porch. I can probably also clean the dust out of the garage as well, once I get used to conserving power. Note that when the charge gets low enough, the blower stops in order to protect the battery charge from getting too low.I like that the 40 volt power pack has a built in charge indicator. Just press the button on the battery pack and green leds light up to help you to estimate the remaining charge. I also like that the charging station itself can be set on a workbench or it can be mounted on the wall to save space. The mounting bracket is a slip cleat style so you can slip the station off the wall completely and take it elsewhere. The charging station has a very large, easy to see red light on it that tells you when charging is in progress or finished.The weight of the unit is nearly the same as my gas blower (maybe a few ounces less), so It feels very comfortable to carry and familiar to use. It is much quieter than a gas engine and releasing the switch turns off the motor completely. I can use this comfortable, while the gas engine blower is so loud that it helps to wear hearing protection. You won't need hearing protection with the Dewalt. You can also partially squeeze the control and get less blowing force. It even has a "cruise control" speed controller so you can set the trigger to any speed and you can then take your finger off the trigger entirely. The blower seems huge compared to my gas engine blower, but it is still comfortable to hold and doesn't seem that bulky when it is actually in use. It does take up a bit more storage space, but that's not a major concern. The fan is lightweight, so you aren't fighting any inertia from a gyroscopic effect of the fan turning.Overall, I think this is an excellent blower for a homeowner who has a lot of property to cover, but wants to greatly reduce the noise while cleaning up. It comes with a 3 year limited warranty and a 90 day no-questions-asked money back guarantee. It also comes with a 1 year free service maintenance policy.

Jasmine green tea is very hard to come by in my area. I used to get it all the time, but the last couple of years it has disappeared from store shelves and can only be found through online sellers or my local tea shop in bulk. I like the idea of having a sealed package on hand at home that will keep indefinitely and will be there when I want to brew it. I don't have a K-cup machine, so I prepared this using my loose tea brewing cup with a stainless steel strainer. The jasmine flower flavor is definitely present and delicious. The green tea component is not bitter and does not overpower the jasmine. I would say they got the name correct in that they put the jasmine before the green tea. Overall this is a mellow, flavorful blend of tea that I would recommend to anyone. I would very likely purchase this Numi tea again if the price was right.

I tested this on a small section of my back yard lawn 4 days ago, and it is already greening up in that section. I plan to finish the rest of the bag in the back yard where I have been getting some invasive crabgrass. This size bag covers 5,000 square feet, which is perfect for my backyard. This is also sold in a larger bag.I couldn't find the fertilizer ratio listed on the Amazon site, but the back of the bag says it is 30-0-4. I'm unsure what herbicide is specifically aimed at the crabgrass. Later on in the spring I'll report back on how well the crabgrass problem is under control.I really like the Scotts lawn and garden products and use them. I've used Scotts Bonus S Southern Lawn Weed and Feed for the front yard for the last 10 years. It greens up the lawn in under a week (after being watered in) and knocks down the dollar weed until the following winter. My lawn looks as good as the lawns in the neighborhood that are professionally maintained, and even better than some. I just pour a bag of Scotts in my tractor spreader and I'm finished in no time. Scotts fertilizers can also be broadcast in small lawns with hand spreaders and in medium-sized lawns with walk-behind spreaders.UPDATE: After 3 weeks I'm now seeing a significant die-off of the weeds.

This Head & Shoulders Instant Relief Dandruff shampoo from Proctor and Gamble is unique because it has tea tree oil and peppermint oil in the formulation. It says on the container that is provides instant relief  and cools on contact. Additionally it lists attributes that are common to all of the Head & Shoulders shampoos, namely relief from dry, flaky scalp. I don't have dandruff, but perhaps that is because I currently use the Head & Shoulders 2 in 1 shampoo for men. However, I can compare the mint version to the version formulated for men and report on that.First, there is a slight mint fragrance to the shampoo, but it is not overwhelming. Maybe that is just me and someone else with a better sense of smell can distinguish the mint frangrance better than I can. It is not for example the same as opening a bottle of mint mouthwash, which to me has a strong mint fragrance. In fact the fragrance of this shampoo to me would be indistinguishable as mint without reading the label. However, I want to emphasize that the shampoo has a pleasant fragrance and it is definitely a different fragrance from the H&S shampoo for men. It is just hard to distinquish or describe how it is different. I think it  doesn't have a medicinal kind of smell to it, so that is probably important to many people. It is just pleasant and mild.As far as cooling, I didn't notice that at all. I take very hot showers, so any sense of cooling would probably be lost. The product does contain both alcohol and menthol, so these should create a tingling or cooling sensation, but I just couldn't distinguish this myself. On the other hand, if you washed your hair in a sink, you might notice a cooling sensation.  After washing and rinsing, I didn't get any significant cooling sensation that lingered.. To me the sensation was no different than using any other version of Head & Shoulders shampoo. I suspect that if you do have dandruff and flaky skin, that you very likely would notice a tingling or cooling sensation though. Having a healthy scalp probably makes a big difference in terms of the sensation. I put some on the back of my hand after showering and I didn't notice any cooling effect either. Oh well.Overall, I think this is a very good shampoo that I would buy, use, and recommend it to friends. While I didn't a notice siginificant difference to another Head & Shoulders product I use, I still think it deserves 5 stars. I also believe that people with active dandruff and a sensitive scalp would definitely feel the tingling and cooling sensation.

This cover is made specifically for built-in outdoor BBQ cookers. If you have a stand-alone or portable BBQ, Classic Accessories also has a wide variety of cover styles and there will be one to fit your particular application.Outdoor cooker covers have to withstand the elements, and unfortunately this reviewer doesn't have a crystal ball to see how well the cover will stand up to mother nature over the course of a few years. Furthermore, how well the cover stands up depends a great deal on where you live and whether your cooker is completely exposed to the weather or somehwat sheltered from the wind, sun, and rain. Movement in subfreezing weather and excessive exposure to the UV in sunlight tend to cause an early end to any cover. My general impression is that this cover should last at least 3 years here in the Gulf South where humidity is high and the sun and heat are very intense in the summer. That is my best guess, but it is based on a lot of experience of how quickly I've seen similar materials break down.The cover is constructed of panels sewn together. There is a large central panel that wraps over the BBQ cooker, and then smaller panels on the right and left sides that create a boxy form to the cover. The stiching between panels is double stiching, but there are places where single stiching is used, such as along the edges where the outer material wraps around to the inside. The edge wrapping is a good inch or more and this gives a lot of rub protection to the edges. The outer surface of the material appears to be a coated canvas-like weave of polyester material. It looks very strong and sheds rain water. The inner surface of the material is a fully waterproof vinyl. At initial insepction, it appears as if there are two materials that make up the cover, but it is actually just one layer of material that is treated differently on the outside and the inside. It is quite thick, but is flexible. It kind of reminds me of a canvas work coat, but stiffer due to the vinyl coating on the inside.Around the lower part of the back and sides is a stretchable internal cord (like a bungee cord) that is wrapped and sewn into the material, which grips onto the back and sides of the cooker. The tension on this cord is not adjustable, so you need to measure the dimensions of your cooker and buy the correct sized cover to assure that it will slip over and still grip the cooker tightly. The outer part of the cover also has an extra woven panel sewn onto it which is narrow and darker in color. This band of material goes around the entire cover. The purpose seems to be to give the cover some extra strength and rigidity where the user might pulll up or down on the cover.  It is also decorative since the color is darker than the rest of the cover. There are also two handles that are sewn onto the cover at the top of the two side panels. The handles are flexible, but strong and are well-stitched at the ends onto the cover. However, the vinyl wrapping on the handles themselves is only single-stitched. Inside of the cover are two belts with plastic connectors that allow the cover to be securely clamped and tightened to the cooker handles. These belts are about a foot long and once clamped, the excess slack can be pulled out like you would on a seat belt. These belts along with the wrap-around elastic cord do a great job of keeping the cover securely in place on the cooker. I also want to note that the end panels of the cover are perforated to allow wind to pass through from inside, which also helps to keep the cover in place. Although the end panels are perforated, there are additional panels on the outside that keeps rain from blowing in through the perforations.There is a metal plate with the name Hickory Series on it that is riveted to the cover. To help keep the inside part of the rivets from rubbing against your cooker, there is an extra internal panel of material that runs the horizontal length of the cover that covers up the inside part of the rivets. Also this panel helps to prevent the knobs, handles, or front edges of the cooker from rubbing directly on the waterproof interior of the cover, so it gives an extra layer of protection to the front where it will be rubbed often when taking the cover on and offMy overall opinion is that this is a well-made and well-designed cover that should satisfy the majority of users. I would not expect it to stand up to hurricane winds, but it will do fine during normal use. My biggest concern is the material holding up to UV light and subfreezing temperatures that could cause cracking. Covers that are completely exposed to sunlight are naturally going to have a shorter lifetime than covers that are used in areas with some shade, particularly in the middle of the day. If you have sub-zero temperatures, it is important to be sure the cover is fitted correctly so it doesn't move around and crack from bending in the cold. If you consider that the cover needs to be replaced after 3 years, but is 100% effective in protecting the cooker during that time, then it is doing its job.  If you get more than 3 years of use out of the cover, you are coming out ahead. If you get less than 3 years of use, then you probably have extreme weather that is causing the cover to fail prematurely, and it is hard to find any cover that holds up to extreme winters or summers.

I love to garden, but I'm always looking for ways to make the results better with less effort on my part. I have three hose sprayers for liquid fertilizer, and those use pre-measured packages for fertilizer. However, this product is NOT hose sprayer fertilizer. The Scotts Super Bloom Water Soluble Plant Food is is made for watering cans or jugs.You take a specified amount for a given volume of water. If the plants are in pots, the recommended concentration is 2 TEASPOONS to one gallon of water. If the plants are in outdoor beds, large containers, or planters, the recommended concentration is 1 TABLESPOON to one gallon of water. I happen to use a 1.5 gallon watering can that I use with small containers and hanging plants that are too small for the liquid sprayer. So it is easy to mix the Scotts plant food as 3 tsps to my 1.5 gal can.I think very highly of Scotts lawn and garden products and use them all the time. This Super Bloom food will help me to supplement the time-release fertilizer I put in at the beginning of the planting season. I will be using this on plants that were put in last fall (mostly pansies and petunias), and the new plants I'll add soon (impatiens, mums, violas, etc). This is a 12-55-6 food, which is rather potent, so follow instructions carefully when mixing the concentrate with the water. Don't use it at a higher concentration and don't just throw it dry around the plant and try to water it in. You can use it once every week to every 2 weeks to keep the blooming continuous.

This is one of the most useful divider sets offered by Avery. It has 5 major sections, which can be used for organizing by workdays during the week, or by annual quarters plus a complete year summary. Or you can just use it for organizing any project with 5 or less major divisions. To make this even more useful, each of the 5 major sections also has 3 subsections marked as A through C. Included with the set is a Table of Contents page where you can print the detailed information including in the 5 major sections. Each section has a unique color (gold, light orange, orange, red, and purple) for easy identification. The section and subsection tabs are colored with white labels on each. The dividers are heavy paper with reinforced holes punched for a standard 3 ring binder. All of the divider tabs are clear coated to stand up to a gret deal of handling.

This is a clever method of creating professional-looking printed tabs for a binder. What you get in this set are 16 dividers that are punched for 3-hole binders. Each divider has a unique a tab. You also get a sheet of adhesive labels that you can print on with your printer. Once you print the adhesive labels, you can then place the labels on the dividers in sets of 8. They are self-adhesive. You are given 10 groups of 8 (80 tab labels total), so you have plenty of extras in case you mess up (you only need 16 out of the 80). To further help, you get a practice sheet with marking that replicate the adhesive labels and you can use this to test your printer output. You can make a copy of this if you think you need another practice sheet. The set works with either laserjet or inkjet printers. The tabs are about 1-inch wide and about 3/8ths of an inch high, so you should pick a font size that gives a good fit in this small of a space.To assure a good result, use the Avery Microsoft Word template for this set: 13150. You can get this template from the Avery website if you dont already have it loaded in MSWord. You can also get the Avery Wizard or Avery Online Designer.

If you are looking to buy a first stapler for school or a general-purpose office stapler, this is a good one to buy. It is palm-sized and can fit in any desk drawer. It is very stable and has a full-length rubbery-like surface on the base to keep it from sliding around during use. The top has small depressions where you press down so it wont slip from your hand.The stapler uses a flat-clinch bend instead of a curved clinch bend of the staple. I much prefer this flat type because it is easier to open up and remove the staple without tearing the paper. The stapler does NOT open up flat for stapling into other materials. It is only made to bind together thin materials that fit within the jaws. There is no adjustable paper guide, but it does have markings (indentations) on the base to use as a placement guide. It is very easy to load staples, and the inner metal surfaces have all been nidely polished to remove sharp edges on the stamped metal pieces. I'm glad to see this because some staplers have very sharp metal edges and can unexpectedly cut a finger. You should be safe with this one.The only thing I found to be an issue is that the stapler opens up a little too easily. There isn't a definite catch or latch to keep the top in place. So sometimes when I pick this stapler up by the top, the stapler opens up and the staples can fall out. As long as you know to pick the stapler up by the base, it won't open unexpectedly. I don't feel this is big enough of an issue to take away a star.The stapler uses 24/6 mm or 26/6 mm flat-clinch staples and if you forget, this is listed on the underside of the base.

This laminator heats up very fast! Within 2 minutes you are ready to feed your first sheet. The Fellowes M5-95 has bright red and green LEDs on the top that are easy to see. You can tell from across the room whether the machine is ready to go. It is whisper quiet in feeding the sheet through. Heating is uniform across the sheet and I didn't have to feed any sheets through a second time. Even with a thick sheet of paper (about a 40# sheet), the sealing is complete right up to the edge of the paper (no air gaps or bubbles). I really like the fact that it has an auto-off feature. This makes it perfect for the absent-minded professor types. I think the auto-off feature makes this one an easy choice.

I've been using this Pioneer for over a year and have so far burned over forty 25GB Blu-Ray discs, backing up data from my computer, including much video footage.  So far I've never had a coaster.  Every backup has been flawless.I use exclusively Verbatim disks (non-LTH).  I've been backing up data on PC's since PC's first became available in the early 1980s.  I learned long ago the importance of using only high quality media for my backups.  It's a waste of time and money to have to throw away a disc because a burn has failed.  It's even worse for the burn to look like it succeeded but then to try retrieve the data a few years after the backup and find that that the data has been corrupted.  I now only use the best media, and in my experience, Verbatim makes the best consumer-grade discs, though I've also had good experiences burning TDK DVD's.If you use lower quality discs, be sure to install Pioneer's firmware update.  It's available on the Pioneer website.  From what I understand, it helps with burning lower quality media.I've been using the free version of Cyperlink's Power2Go software for burning Blu-Rays.  It came bundled with the Pioneer.  It's worked well for me, but I'm currently trying ImgBurn as an alternative.  Power2Go is a better choice for most people.  It's simple to use and reliable. The free version has worked well for burning Blu-Ray data backups.  If you like more control over your software and aren't intimidated by many pages of settings options, ImgBurn is a great alternative.  It's Open Source and free.

This is much a higher quality than I expected. There is also a mystery - two unidentified extra parts included with it.The build quality is excellent and everything about the light feels solid.  It's not a light you'd want to use for an entire scene, but for a podcast or similar situation in which you have a single subject and fairly tight quarters, it's excellent.  I used it as a back light located 3-4 feet above the subject's head.  It's bright enough that I had to use it at low light settings. I'm really happy that Bower includes two filters. I used the amber for the back light and it worked perfectly.I intend to buy two more of these to use as key and fill lights for future shoots.However I do have a complaint: there's no calibration on the adjusting knob, so you have to readjust the brightness every time you use it.  In my case, I had it set in the same place for four shoots on different days.  I wish that either there was a separate on-off switch so I could leave the adjusting knob at the right adjustment, or calibrations on the knob so I could quickly dial it back to where I want it after turning it back on.  However for the relatively low price, I'm not complaining too loudly.  It's just a small detail that Bower could have solved easily with some numbers on the adjusting knob.Now for the mystery - mine came with two extra parts that aren't mentioned either in the instruction sheet that comes with it or on the Amazon or Bower web pages. They both appear to be AC adapters.  They plug directly into the battery slot on the light, and have a receptacle for a cord from a power brick, as well as a slot on top that might be for another battery (but the Bower battery doesn't fit).  There's no identification on it at all.  And there are two of them!The box appeared unopened, so I don't think a customer returned it with extra parts.I highly recommend this little light for situations where you need relatively close-in lighting, such as for podcasts.  It's an excellent light.

These are going to be very useful to me.  One of my needs is for leveling a video camera in the field, and several of these levels will work great for that.  The pocket level is particularly useful.  It clips onto a shirt pocket and comes with philips and flat tips.  The tip's fit is just snug enough for light screwing, but isn't super tight and the tip could fall out if you're carrying it in your pocket.  However the there's enough room inside the level to hold both tips, so it's not a problem.I compared them against a good quality professional carpenter's level.  All but two were spot-on.  The pocket level wasn't quite accurate, but it was only off slightly, not enough to be noticeable.  The bulls-eye level was the least accurate, but sill reasonably accurate.  The bubble was just touching inner circle of the bulls eye, so for most purposes it would probably be acceptable.These levels are definitely basic.  No one will mistake them for expensive tools.  They're just basic levels in basic, red plastic.  However they appear solid and for how I will use them, I expect them to last years.I hesitated for a long time about buying them, but I'm glad I finally overcame my skepticism.

This is a rewrite of a review I previously wrote about both the Logitech C920 and Microsoft Lifecam Studio 1080p HD. I've raised my rating from three to four stars for both webcams. They are both very good units, but both have significant flaws that make it impossible to give either of them five stars.I bought these webcams for a video project, so all of my testing has been for video capture and editing.  I haven't tested still images or Skype.At the end of the review, I also will give some information about four software packages that are available - one of them free - for recording video with these webcams: Active Webcam, Arcsoft's Webcam Companion, CyberLink's Youcam, and Virtual Dub.I'm rewritten this review after using the Logitech for a month and the Microsoft for three weeks. I ordered the Logitech first. I've been buying Logitech products since the 1990s and until now was never disappointed. This time I was so dissatisfied with it that I ordered the Microsoft, only to be even more disappointed.It's not that they are terrible. They are both excellent in many ways. However I expect more from a 1080p unit than from an ordinary webcam, especially considering the glowing reviews they receive.One thing I love about both webcams is the tripod mount.  For my video project, I needed to mount the webcam on a tripod, so this was a requirement.  It will also be useful in future shooting.  Both webcams will work with any standard tripod.  I used a Sony VCT-R100 tripod for my project.Microsoft's most obvious flaw is advertising this as a 1080p webcam without mentioning that it only does 1080p still images, not recorded video. If you use some non-Microsoft software (Virtual Dub and Cyberlink's You Cam), it will record at 1080p, but the quality is poor if there's any movement in the scene.On the other hand, the Logitech doesn't come off well either. Its most obvious flaw is in its video compression, which results in major video artifacts under certain conditions.  If you don't know what a video artifact is, it basically makes the scene look like something out of science fiction.  The strange thing is that the recorded video plays with no problem in a video player, such as Windows Media Player, but when I try to edit it, the artifacts appear.  I've read reports by other owners who say it also happens with Skype.  I haven't tried these webcams with Skype, so I have no experience with this.I did find a way around the problem with Premiere Pro, but the easiest way to avoid the problem in recorded video is simply to use non-Logitech software for recording video.  I tried Virtual Dub, Arcsoft's Web Companion, and Cyberlink's You Cam.  All of them recorded video from the Logitech with no artifacts.One other recording issue is video format.  If you are buying the webcam for recorded video on a Mac or Linux, or if you want to edit the video, you may find the Logitech the better choice. The .wmv format is a Windows format, so anyone on a different system will probably have to convert it to a different format to use it, and even on Windows, editing it can be a problem, but the Microsoft records only in .wmv. The Logitech records 1080p and 720p as .mp4 and 480p and 360p video as .wmvThe Logitech's other problem is color balance, which is disappointing. The Microsoft's color balance is generally much better. I gave up completely on using the Logitech's automatic color and set it manually every time.The Microsoft is much more demanding of your CPU. Unless you have a fast computer, you probably won't get z good HD recording with it. I have a quad core 3.0GHZ i7 with 24GB of RAM, but the Microsoft could record only 13.1fps at 720p and 6.4fps at 1080p, using Virtual Dub. The Logitech did much better, averaging exactly 30.0fps at both 720p and 1080p. Using the Windows 7 Performance Monitor, I found that the CPU usage while recording ranged from about 40% to 60% for the Microsoft but only about 15% to 35% for the Logitech.I also tried it on my 1.6GHz Samsung netbook.  The Logitech recorded better than I expected, though it you wouldn't want to use it on any scene with movement in it.  The Microsoft's greater demands on the CPU made it completely unacceptable for recording 720p video on the netbook.To my eyes the Microsoft delivers a much sharper image (a purely subjective measurement) than the Logitech.If you transport your webcam a lot, then the recessed lens on the Microsoft offers much more protection than the Logitech lens, which has no protection at all. The Microsoft comes with a rubber lens cap, but it's so loose that it's completely useless. The recessed lens is an excellent design feature, however. The Microsoft is also much smaller, which could be useful if you move it around a lot.The Microsoft software won't let you change the microphone on the Microsoft, but the Logitech software does allow it. The Microsoft microphone is located on the top rear of the webcam, which I expected would be a terrible location, but in practice it's better than I expected. The Logitech microphone is in front, where it should be, and does produce better audio (I was sitting about two feet from the webcams for the tests).  The Logitech is stereo and the Microsoft is mono. If you use other software for recording, such as Virtual Dub, Arcsoft's Web Companion, and Cyberlink's You Cam, you can specify different audio inputs.The autofocus isn't great on either unit, but Logitech's is better than Microsoft's.Logitech's software allows you to specify a folder for storing videos and photos, but Microsoft's does not. On Windows 7, it stores everything in My Pictures. Microsoft creates .wmv video files and Logitech creates .mp4 files. Logitech offers three levels of video and three levels of audio quality. Microsoft doesn't give a choice. Logitech allows recording at four video resolutions: 360p, 480p, 720p, and 1080p. Microsoft allows recording at seven video resolutions (eight for photographs): 160x120, 320x240, 424x240, 640x360, 800x448, 960x544, and 1280x720.Zoom controls on both tend to be erratic in how they operate and often don't work at all.Microsoft tilts and pans, rotating a full 360 degrees.  The Logitech can only tilt up and down.  If you want to pan, you need a tripod.The sad thing is that I actually prefer both the color balance and the zoom & pan controls on my old Kodak S101 640x480 webcam, though the Microsoft and Logitech both are superior in image quality, even at low resolutions equivalent to the Kodak's.The Microsoft developed some intermittent problems towards the end.  The previously excellent automatic exposure sometimes didn't work properly, and my computer occasionally gave me a warning that it didn't recognize it as a USB device.My bottom line:==============I only needed one webcam for my project.  I originally disliked the Logitech so much that I ordered the Microsoft and intended returning the Logitech, only to be even more disappointed by the Microsoft.  I ended up using the Logitech for my project and I am returning the Microsoft.  It was frustrating, because in many ways I prefer the Microsoft, but recording only 720p video and having higher CPU requirements made it less useful for me.  I returned it because of the intermittent problems I experienced, but would have returned it anyway because of the other issues.Now for the software.  If you buy the Logitech and you plan to do 720p or 1080p video recording, then you'll definitely want to look into alternative software because the Logitech's produces video with unacceptable artifacts that you don't see while watching them, but become very apparent if you edit the video, at least with Adobe Premiere Pro.Virtual Dub (free)=================At first this one turned me off, but after I played with it for a few weeks and watched a YouTube video on configuring it, I fell in love with it.  If you are serious about video, this is the one to get.  It's loaded with options, but it's not the most user-friendly software available.  However after you get used to it, the others are frustratingly limited in comparison.  However it's definitely not for casual users.Cyberlink You Cam ($35)======================If you're going to edit your video or if you're on a Mac or Linux machine, this is the one you want to get because records .avi files.  It's a great choice for nontechnical people who don't want to deal with Virtual Dub's nonintuitive user interfaceArcsoft Webcam Companion 4 ($35)==============================This is a nice package with just one problem: it only records .wmv files.  This is a Windows format, so you'll need to convert it to use on a Mac or Linux machine, and you may have problems editing it.Active WebCam ($29)=================Initially this is the one I thought I'd like, but I was never actually able to test it because it was constantly freezing up.  If you are using multiple webcams for surveillance, you should look into it.  It does get good reviews.  However the user interface leaves a lot to be desired, but because of the freezing up I never had the opportunity to give it a real test.
